[Bears]: Now, how we,

[Bears]: address those problems, how we build processes, how we improve systems, how we address systemic challenges is by putting forward solutions.

[Bears]: this council, when it comes to the budget and the funding of our schools, when it comes to the resources that we need, when it comes to the resources that we need in this moment, when we know, hey, there was violence at Medford High School when I was there.

[Bears]: There was violence at Medford High School 30 years ago.

[Bears]: And we can talk about certain numbers.

[Bears]: The one number that hasn't been talked about any of this is actually looking at the trends and data on this issue.

[Bears]: But the one thing we do know is whether it's Medford or a neighboring community or every community in Massachusetts or every community in this country is that student supports are deeply needed.

[Bears]: That mental health is a serious issue.

[Bears]: That conflict resolution and addressing problems in a peaceful manner is a huge problem.

[Bears]: And that quite frankly, before these things got worse, it was a problem.

[Bears]: It's an even worse problem now.

[Bears]: Students are walking out because they recognize it.

[Bears]: Students are crying out because they know that they need help or they know someone who needs help.

[Bears]: It's a question of resources.

[Bears]: The first thing I thought about when I ran for office was the funding for our schools three years ago, that was before the pandemic.

[Bears]: It was my first concern in June when we were talking about the fiscal 23 budget and the $2.8 million that got cut from our schools at the last minute.

[Bears]: And two weeks ago, it was again, where I was focusing my energy and efforts in a resolution that passed this council

[Bears]: about funding and asking what are the supports?

[Bears]: What are the funding that's needed?

[Bears]: Another thing that needs resources and funding.

[Bears]: We were just talking about it for municipal vulnerability plan.

[Bears]: We were just talking about it.

[Bears]: When we talk about this whole city, schools and city side, communications and engagement, the city doesn't invest its budgetary resources in that issue.

[Bears]: So we have, you know, people scrambling to put something together to get it out when there's an emergency situation.

[Bears]: We have in a million other situations insufficient resources for communication and engagement.

[Bears]: So all of these things, no one is happy here.

[Bears]: We've all identified problems that we want to solve.

[Bears]: We're starting to talk about solutions.

[Bears]: The big elephant in the room solution that we don't want to zone in on is that we don't have the resources to address the scope of the problems that we have.

[Bears]: And until we are willing to admit that,

[Bears]: and engage in a good faith discussion about what is the true scope of resources that we need to invest in our schools and in our community to address the sheer scale of the problems that we have.

[Bears]: We're not going to unify or come together or solve these issues.

[Bears]: And they are of a scope and scale we could not have imagined four years ago.

[Bears]: So that's the crux of this whole question.

[Bears]: We come together in government

[Bears]: to pool our resources to address our collective problems.

[Bears]: That is what we do more than anything else.

[Bears]: And we've clearly identified a collective problem that needs resources and the resources, we are literally unable to put those resources on the table.

[Bears]: Now, I think there are things that we can do and should do.

[Bears]: and try to do in the short-term, medium, and long-term with what we have to better target what we have and do the best that we can do with what we have, but that's not going to be enough.

[Bears]: The other two things I want to talk about here are that we are once again not going to get unified and be on the same page and be able to move forward collectively unless we are moving on a single set of facts.

[Bears]: about who has the authority to do what, who has the power to do what, and who sets the rules about what.

[Bears]: The state and the Department of Elementary and Secondary Education set a number of rules about a lot of the things that we're talking about tonight, or have talked about in previous meetings.

[Bears]: The state defines the scope of the authority of the school committee and the city council.

[Bears]: The one place where we truly do have authority

[Bears]: is on this fundamental core question of funding and the budget.

[Bears]: That is where we can partner.

[Bears]: And I know that there's a resolution from Councilor Scarpelli on that question and a resolution from Councilor Collins and I on that question, because that is where we can most and best engage in this discussion.

[Bears]: And I don't say that to limit that there may be other things, but that is where our authority and power lies.

[Bears]: And the last thing I'm going to say, people aren't going to be happy about it, you know,

[Bears]: I'm not happy about everything that everyone else has said, so I'm just going to go ahead and say it.

[Bears]: I don't know what veiled accusations about national organizations are going to get us anywhere.

[Bears]: When we have information that is not correct out there about why people are making decisions that they're making or what decisions have been made or the policies and rules that actually exist and are actually being followed or should be being followed,

[Bears]: we're never going to get on the same enough page to move forward in a collective way and really talk about having the community and collaborative conversations that we need to have.

[Bears]: So, you know, I know that that's, that's the nicest way that I can think of to say what I really want to say here.

[Bears]: But when we talk about unity, we can't then have the next sentence be something that divides.

[Bears]: And I think, again,

[Bears]: The thing that we can unify around here, maybe it's not the most heartwarming thing to unify around here is that nobody is happy.

[Bears]: There are problems and we need to identify and move forward on solutions to those problems.

[Bears]: And I think if we can do that and accept a single set of facts about what is truly going on, then we are laying the foundation

[Bears]: to have the substantive conversations and make the real actions that we need so that kids in our schools feel safe.

[Bears]: I know what it was like to not feel safe.

[Bears]: I stayed home for a whole week from school because I didn't want to get on the bus because I was attacked when I was in middle school, okay?

[Bears]: And I'm not even equating that to what happened on Monday or what happened to other people, right?

[Bears]: I experienced that in my family.

[Bears]: So we can say that there's a monopoly on the feelings here,

[Bears]: but we know what we know and we know that what we have to put forward is not sufficient at this moment to address the scope of the challenge that we face.

[Bears]: And I think the best thing that we can do is to look at the resolutions before us that are solutions focused and ask the people most affected, the students and teachers on the ground to work with

[Bears]: the school committee and the mayor and the school administration and the city council to figure out what we can do in the short term to address funding and what we can do in the long term to make a systemic solution and a systemic approach to make sure that we're addressing this issue in two weeks, in two months, in two years, and in two decades, because we heard last night that there were people who felt that 30 years ago to today, things hadn't been fixed.

[Bears]: That's all I wanna say on this.

[Bears]: Beyond that, I'm not gonna speak to this paper anymore.

[Bears]: I'll speak to the solutions focused resolutions that we have next, and I'll leave it at that.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I'll be short.

[Bears]: The game is rigged.

[Bears]: We can try to change our game plan as much as we want, but when we're talking about city departments and city budgets that in real inflation adjusted dollar terms have less money now than they did in 1980, the game is rigged.

[Bears]: So that's the first thing.

[Bears]: I'm not disputing that there are things we could do immediately to bring people together and try to find solutions.

[Bears]: There are things we could do with short money that could make a big impact and make people feel safer.

[Bears]: But I think the idea that we can fix this whole problem or that the notion of putting more resources, this is just throwing money at the problem, that we can address a problem that has been persistent, that is growing in scale, that is not just unique to Medford, even though we could do what we can in Medford to find unique solutions with what we have through reallocation and additional resources, it's promising something that's unachievable.

[Bears]: So I agree, let's do what we can now with short money or no money at all to make people feel safer in the schools.

[Bears]: a budget ordinance which can better assess, show the public this is exactly what our budget process is, these are the steps to be involved, work on making that process more transparent, accessible, and bringing the community in so that we can have the values like this question about how we're gonna address the aging in our community and what resources we can bring to bear to that question in our budget.

[Bears]: And that's why DCR has been cut by 35%, and the T's in massive trouble, and public higher education.

[Bears]: I grew up when my parents could buy a starter house here, and I can't.

[Bears]: And I grew up at a time when people who grew up here could stay here, and now all my friends are gone.

[Bears]: Medford City Council Committee of the whole April 23rd 2024 is called the order.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Present

[Bears]: 6 present, 1 absent.

[Bears]: The meeting is called to order.

[Bears]: There will be a meeting in the Medford City Council, Committee of the Whole, 6 p.m.

[Bears]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George B. Hassett Drive, Medford, MA, and via Zoom.

[Bears]: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss paper 24-045, the annual budget process for fiscal 25.

[Bears]: This is a preliminary budget meeting.

[Bears]: And tonight this is the second preliminary budget meeting of the FY 25 budget process.

[Bears]: The mayor has communicated the following presentations will occur in the following departments will be present.

[Bears]: We will have a presentation by director finance director Bob Dickinson on the budget.

[Bears]: as it stands now, kind of the top lines of the budget, and we will also hear from the legislative department, which is the city council, the city clerk, and the finance department.

[Bears]: So we are all here and we are all present.

[Bears]: Given that, I will turn it over to the chief of staff and the finance director, Nina Nazarian and Bob Dickinson, to give us the first look at our fiscal 25 budget, as well as a financial update.

[Bears]: we're not talking about water store enterprise and then we're not talking about anything else special revenue funds or other fee fee or grant funded essentially things that are outside of the general fund budget council

[Bears]: Yeah, the way that the state works, so and I worked on a bunch of education legislation, which is the only reason I'm chiming in here, but.

[Bears]: There is a charter school reimbursement formula.

[Bears]: So when a student moves from the public school system to the charter school system, there's a three-year step-down reimbursement.

[Bears]: In their first year, I think it's 100%, second year, 80%, third year, 60%, and the year after that, 0%.

[Bears]: So we send out over 8 million, I think, or around 8 million a year.

[Bears]: to charter schools we only get back somewhere in the one to two million dollar range maybe 1.6 I'd have to look at the cherry sheet but it's um it's does not fully reimburse the cost of charter sending and charter sending is our by far the biggest assessment that is placed on the city by the state so that so this is just sorry this is just the quick summary of what revenue we we receive from the state on the bottom

[Bears]: And then I know just from some preliminary conversations that you're still working out the final amount.

[Bears]: There's still some hundreds of thousands of dollars to bring the expense number down to equal the revenue number, which of course we have to do because we are required to have a balanced budget every year.

[Bears]: Having those additional numbers will be helpful for us to understand, you know, what was requested that the departments need what we aren't able to do this year because of the fiscal restraint and restrictions put on us by what we're allowed to do as a community when it comes to raising revenue.

[Bears]: And then we can certainly work.

[Bears]: to explain and educate the public on why we couldn't do certain things this year, work together to understand what was prioritized and what wasn't prioritized based on trying to save staff positions and make sure our departments can continue to provide the service level that they currently provide to the community.

[Bears]: 24-366, request for appropriation, Community Preservation Committee.

[Bears]: May 23rd, 2024, to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, Medford City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts 02155, regarding Community Preservation Committee appropriation request.

[Bears]: On behalf of the Community Preservation Committee, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable body approve the following recommendation of the Community Preservation Committee.

[Bears]: requesting the appropriation of $5,000 from the CPA General Reserve to Trees Medford and the Department of Public Works Forestry Division to conduct an inventory of trees in city parks.

[Bears]: The project will be tracked in the Community Preservation Fund.

[Bears]: The CPC recommendation letter is attached and incorporated.

[Bears]: CPC Chairperson, CPA Manager, Teresa DuPont and a member of Trees Medford will be in attendance to answer questions.

[Bears]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: Amanda, if you could raise your hand on Zoom.

[Bears]: Please, if you're gonna keep talking, thank you.

[Bears]: There's people talking in the back.

[Bears]: I'm not seeing Amanda.

[Bears]: And I'm happy to read the funding recommendation letter if you'd like.

[Bears]: Funding recommendation decision, May 14, 2024.

[Bears]: Applicant name, City of Medford Forestry Division.

[Bears]: Co-applicant name, Trees Medford.

[Bears]: Public tree park inventory on May 14th, 2024.

[Bears]: The City of Medford Community Preservation Committee, CPC, voted six to zero to zero to recommend to the City Council that Trees Medford and Medford's Forestry Division be awarded $5,000 to conduct a citywide inventory of all public trees in city-owned parks.

[Bears]: In reaching the decision, the CPC found that the project meets the CPA objective of preserving and restoring city-owned recreation spaces.

[Bears]: 24-367 Zoning Update Project Proposed Amendments to the Medford Zoning Ordinance Package 1.

[Bears]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we refer the following recommendations for amendments to the Medford Zoning Ordinance to the Community Development Board as reported out of the Planning and Permitting Committee.

[Bears]: 1.

[Bears]: Amending the format of the table of use and parking regulations to replace the parking and loading code columns with specific parking and loading requirements.

[Bears]: 2.

[Bears]: Amending Section 94-12 definitions to add new defined terms and revise existing definitions.

[Bears]: 3.

[Bears]: Adopt a new GIS-based digital zoning map.

[Bears]: Adoption of the new map format is not intended to result in any material changes to the zoning of any parcels within the City, but is intended to be applicable to the City regarding the existing zoning designation for all properties in the City.

[Bears]: 4.

[Bears]: Exempt municipal uses from certain requirements of the Table of Use and Parking Regulations and the Table of Dimensional Requirements.

[Bears]: The recommended changes are attached and can be referred to informally as Package 1 of recommendations from the City Council and Office of Planning, Development and Sustainability's Zoning Update Projects with Innes Associates, Council Paper 24-033.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: On the motion of Vice President Collins to refer to the Community Development Board, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: 21-057, committee of the whole report, February 21st, 2024.

[Bears]: This was a meeting on the leaf blower ordinance, which was reported out of committee and is on the agenda tonight.

[Bears]: 22-494 was an administration and finance committee report on the budget ordinance, which was reported out of committee and is on the agenda tonight.

[Bears]: 24-056 was on the CPA applications, which we approved at our last regular meeting.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: 24 to 055 establishing a stabilization fund dear President Bears and members of the City Council.

[Bears]: I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body establishes a general stabilization fund as authorized by Chapter 40 section five B of the general laws.

[Bears]: Once free cash has been certified, I plan to return with a request for this honorable body to fund the stabilization fund.

[Bears]: As you probably know, the vast majority of cities and towns in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts have a general stabilization fund.

[Bears]: In order to provide for emergencies and unforeseen expenses, a two-thirds majority of the city council is required to establish a stabilization fund.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: So we have a stabilization fund proposal from the mayor.

[Bears]: I will recognize Councilor Collins and then I will recognize member of the administration, Councilor Collins.

[Bears]: During those nine months, we can't use that money for any purpose and it can't be appropriated.

[Bears]: By establishing a stabilization fund, which is all that's happening right now, and if money were to be put in it in the future, during those nine months when free cash is not certified, the reserves would still be able to be appropriated for an emergency fund.

[Bears]: Currently when free cash is not certified, our reserves are not available for those purposes.

[Bears]: 23-369, 96-104 Winchester Street, Planned Development District 1, Planned Development Special Permit and Site Plan Review.

[Bears]: The subject property known as 100 Winchester Street is comprised of an assemblage of parcels located at 96-104 Winchester Street on the Medford-Somerville Line near the Ball Square MBTA Green Line Station.

[Bears]: The site contains commercial light industrial buildings along with historically significant structure.

[Bears]: The applicant has proposed to redevelop the site in accordance with plan development.

[Bears]: Winchester Street Plan Development District 1, approved by the City Council August 15, 2023, for mixed-use development consisting of two structures.

[Bears]: After considering the submitted materials, presentations from the applicant team, recommendations from city staff, and public comment received at and in advance of the public hearing, the board found that, as conditioned, the proposal met the required criteria and voted five to zero to recommend approval of the site plan and plan development special permit.

[Bears]: 24-041 offered by Councilor Leming and Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: whereas the city of medford requires approval from the commonwealth of massachusetts to impose a real estate transfer fee and whereas 18 other communities in massachusetts have submitted home rule petitions to impose local real estate transfer fees and whereas real estate transfer fees create a sustainable funding stream for needed housing production and affordable housing production in medford by levying a small fee on certain real estate transactions now therefore

[Bears]: be it resolved that the Committee on Planning and Permitting meet to develop a Home Rule petition, quote, an act authorizing the City of Medford to impose a real estate transfer fee.

[Bears]: Dear members of the Medford City Council, unfortunately I'm away and cannot be present at tonight's city council meeting.

[Bears]: However, I'm submitting this letter in support of item 24-041, a resolution to develop a real estate transfer fee home rule petition.

[Bears]: I'm a homeowner in Medford and I've watched as my home has gained value over the past 30 plus years.

[Bears]: It is now worth about five times more than it was when it purchased in 1991.

[Bears]: skyrocketing real estate costs may have benefited those of us who own homes, but it has been devastating for renters and those seeking to buy a home, a real estate transfer fee could begin to correct this imbalance, a home rule would allow men for to work out the details of an RTF in a way that is best for assuring that Medford has the housing resources it needs to continue to be a welcoming community.

[Bears]: I believe that the RETF should apply to all properties and not be limited to those selling for over $1 million.

[Bears]: As others have pointed out, a 1-2% transfer fee for affordable housing is not going to break the bank for those of us who have pocketed years of property value increases, nor will realtors who take a commission of 5-7% be put out of business by this additional 1-2%.

[Bears]: The fact that our homes are worth more now than when we bought them is not to any effort on our part, but as a windfall.

[Bears]: Sharing a small percentage of our good fortune through the RTETF is a small price to pay,

[Bears]: For increasing affordable housing and making a home rented or purchased a reality for more people sincerely Jennifer Yanko 16 Monument Street Medford ma 02155.

[Bears]: And I have one more.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears I'm sorry that I will not be able to participate in the city council meeting on Tuesday but I would like to express my support for paper to four dash zero for one to submit a home real petition for a real estate transfer fee.

[Bears]: Our ETF, I recognize that the details are to be worked out later but I would like to add that I oppose the exclusions that have been discussed exclusions from sales of properties under 1 million and sales by seniors would leave out about 94% of residential transactions and cut the amount of funds generated for affordable housing to merely 260,000 a year or so.

[Bears]: A drop in the bucket when when we need is a waterfall.

[Bears]: Many low income seniors like myself have owned our own properties for decades and benefited greatly from the speculative bubble that real estate has become my hundred and $6,000 home is now worth over $600,000.

[Bears]: Is it too much to ask that I pay 6000 or 12,000 of my 500,000 profit upon its sale.

[Bears]: gain not due to my hard work, but merely to living here while it appreciated in value so that others might have a chance of buying or renting a home.

[Bears]: I would like to note that the loudest voices in opposition to an RETF are those of realtors.

[Bears]: In my opinion, it is highly offensive for these people who pocket a whopping five to 7% per transaction to sound alarm bells about how a one to 2% fee would harm home buyers and sellers.

[Bears]: I hope I'm not the only person to call attention to this hypocrisy.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Barry Ingber, 9 Draper Street.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I mean, we did have good turnout.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: And with that, I'll.

[Bears]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Committee of the Whole, March 20, 2024 at 6 p.m.

[Bears]: in the City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, MA via Zoom.

[Bears]: To submit written comments, please email ahertobeast at medford-ma.gov.

[Bears]: Action and discussion items 20-020 offered by former Councilor Knight on the food truck ordinance.

[Bears]: The motion was being resolved that the Metro City Council move forward on the food truck ordinance, and we've had several meetings.

[Bears]: Our most recent meeting was in November of 2023, where we requested a redraft of the food truck ordinance to this point, where the City Council is requesting that we establish

[Bears]: the board of health as the board that would provide food truck licenses for one day events and special events so that they don't have to come before the city council and meet on the city council schedule and board of health or health department.

[Bears]: So we do have a draft back and I will go to vice president Collins and then vice president Collins, you can guide us along the way.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I don't know why I'm.

[Bears]: I'd like to go next.

[Bears]: I think, you know, and I appreciate the work that went into this, but I really think that what the council's intent is to make the granting of food truck licenses for one day licenses and special event licenses an administrative task that does not require

[Bears]: The to be brought to a council meeting does not require a public hearing and likely doesn't even require necessarily a public meeting.

[Bears]: That's what we did for outdoor dining.

[Bears]: The building commissioner has the authority.

[Bears]: I think we would like.

[Bears]: a staff member of the city to administratively have the authority to grant food truck licenses without all of this procedural rigmarole that we are, the issue that, the reason this is coming up is the issue is people were getting applications for food trucks in too late to us and we couldn't approve them in time for events.

[Bears]: And I think the intent here is to make this an administrative task of a staff member and not a request requiring the approval of a public body in a public meeting.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: I think Councilor Callahan asked what is always a good question, which is what do our neighbours do?

[Bears]: And just from a quick search, I think that it looks like Somerville

[Bears]: We shut down Riverside Ave.

[Bears]: There's a ton of food trucks.

[Bears]: We've never ordered any of that.

[Bears]: So that's another thing that I'm just, you know, DPW has control of the public way to organize that event.

[Bears]: There's just been a lot of past practice where for things like that, I don't think we want to make and create an onerous and rigorous process for having, you know, fried dough at Clipper Ship Day.

[Bears]: So any other questions?

[Bears]: comments from members of the council, go to Attorney Stein.

[Bears]: Could you walk me through where in the ordinance there's a differentiation?

[Bears]: I may just be missing it.

[Bears]: Attorney Stein.

[Bears]: But I think we're conflating two issues.

[Bears]: Because this second point, are we conflating two so so but

[Bears]: If there were to be a food truck to be hosted on school property, what you're saying is that under this draft, it would need the Board of Health to say, yes, you can have a food truck license.

[Bears]: And then you'd also need to have whoever's under the custodian of the property to say, we will host the food truck here.

[Bears]: So that's why I think we're conflating two different things.

[Bears]: It seems like the sticking point here is that essentially we are saying, as a council, that second piece of the process we have not had anything to do with, to your point, because it is not relevant to our ordinances, right?

[Bears]: All we are doing is approving a food truck license.

[Bears]: I guess, and I think we're just getting into the weeds here of who has custody and care and control of different city properties in a way that maybe we don't need to be getting into.

[Bears]: I think all that we're saying is that we would like to no longer, the city council to not be responsible for the issuance of food truck licenses and for the health department to be responsible for the issuance of food truck licenses.

[Bears]: And what I'm trying to get at is it seems like you're saying, Councilor, that there's a sticking point there because if we wanted to delegate all that control, technically, we still have control of the public way.

[Bears]: So if it's a food truck on the public way, it would still need to come back to us.

[Bears]: Okay, I'm going to go to Councilor Kiley in just a second.

[Bears]: I think what the, from the previous meetings, what we're asking for is that the food truck license process, that the health department be able to issue one time and special event food truck licenses.

[Bears]: Those are the only licenses for food trucks that we want to allow at this time.

[Bears]: If they need permission from the custodian of public property, they would ask whoever the custodian of a specific property is to make sure that the food truck is allowed.

[Bears]: And that when it comes to the public way, we do not want them to have to come to us for a food truck in the public way.

[Bears]: They could go to the DPW, essentially.

[Bears]: I guess, and this is where it's breaking down for me.

[Bears]: Are you saying that under the existing regime that whoever is the custodian of another public property could issue unlimited food truck licenses on their own without the approval of the council or without an ordinance establishing those licenses as part of the city code?

[Bears]: I'm sorry.

[Bears]: The zoning code regulates what the Medford public schools could do on school property?

[Bears]: Right, they wouldn't need to ask us.

[Bears]: Yeah, sure, and then I'm gonna go to Councilor Callahan and Councilor Collins, but yeah, Councilor Schripper.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan?

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: I guess I'll try, maybe, unless you're ready.

[Bears]: I guess, Attorney Stein, my question is, it seems like the intent of the council is to, whether it's public or private property,

[Bears]: whoever is the custodian or has care and control of the property, our intent ideally would be to, through whatever ordinance or zoning amendment, to say that a designee, right now we're calling it the health department, would issue a food truck license, only limited to a one day license or a special event license,

[Bears]: regardless of what property it's on, whether it's public property, private property or the public way, is what you're saying is that we legally can't do that.

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: I mean, I guess I have two questions here.

[Bears]: Our existing process is that basically anytime anyone on any type of property wants to use a food truck, the council approves a food truck license.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: Is that not the process?

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: Let me see if I can pull up the most recent example of this in the records.

[Bears]: Mr. President, just a second, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: I just want to see if we can find this here.

[Bears]: So we got a dear, dear President Morello and members of the city council.

[Bears]: This is September 21st, 2023.

[Bears]: The council records for our meeting of October 3rd, 2023.

[Bears]: On behalf of the below entity, I respectfully submit to the city council the following request for a food truck permit of the city of Medford.

[Bears]: In addition to city council approval, vendors are.

[Bears]: It was coming to you.

[Bears]: Just a second Councilor.

[Bears]: I'd like to answer my question first.

[Bears]: I'm going to go to Councilor Stroud, probably then Councilor Collins and Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: There's a motion of Councilor Scarpelli to table.

[Bears]: It was undebatable.

[Bears]: Is there a second?

[Bears]: Hearing no second, I'll go to Council Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I just want to, I think we can actually get to the crux of, I'm starting to wrap my head around it a little bit, I think.

[Bears]: And I think where my sticking point was, was that our past practice does not seem to be grounded in any sort of legal authority that anyone can find.

[Bears]: So essentially, we've been granting pointless permits with no authority for some period of time, at the request of the, you know, under multiple mayoral administrations to multiple councils, mayors have been requesting that the council approve things.

[Bears]: that need need to be requested nor needed to be approved, which actually means that we have no regulation on this other than on the public ways, which is the council has to control things in the public ways, which I don't think is a status quo that any of us wants to maintain as a status quo.

[Bears]: Um, so attorney sign if if I may.

[Bears]: And please, when I'm, it seems to me there's three things here, that the council could create a use of the food truck under the Zoning Act to regulate where and which districts food trucks can be used on private property, and we could make them by right or by special permit by some authority of a board.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: Right, and that would be creating a use and then what district the uses would be in and what authority, you know, we could say that a special permit of the council is required in every district for the use of a food truck and that would regulate all private property in the city that falls under the zoning ordinance.

[Bears]: Okay and then on the public way the council controls the public way so we we could right now under the existing ordinance potentially with some modification to address the very specific concern about the sale of fruit um we could

[Bears]: pass an ordinance to say you have to get a license or permit of some kind from the council or its designee on the public way.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: And then there seems to be this third, I think I get it on both ends of that.

[Bears]: There's a third kind of middle area, and I'll throw in what you just said about exempt uses.

[Bears]: So basically, like the Dover uses might also fall into this weird middle ground where public property that is not under the care and control of the council, the council does not have the authority to say that basically, right, like,

[Bears]: I get where it would work on a public way, I get where it would work on a private property that is not exempt from zoning.

[Bears]: I think what we were trying to thread the needle on was that on those other properties,

[Bears]: we still only want to allow one day and special event licenses for food trucks.

[Bears]: And it seems like what you're saying is that by your analysis of the law, that the sanitary code can't do that.

[Bears]: All that the health department can say is, oh, this is a safe, this is a healthy food truck.

[Bears]: They can serve food.

[Bears]: And then it would be up to the exempt property owner, for example, Tufts University, or the public property owner, custodian that is not the city council, for example,

[Bears]: the school committee for Medford Public Schools property that they could determine that they could have food trucks at times other than one day or special events.

[Bears]: And okay, so that's exempt use private property that may be exempt from the zoning route.

[Bears]: For the properties that are not under the control of the city council, but are city owned,

[Bears]: or state owned, for example, and then we can go down another avenue to state owned but city controlled because we have some of those.

[Bears]: Is there a legal authority that we can find to say that we only want one day and special event food trucks to be licensed?

[Bears]: And then where we would run into some issues on the zoning side of things, we can't designate the board of health as a special permit granting authority, right?

[Bears]: I think where we were potentially not entirely accurate was that we had assumed that we had the authority blanket, similar to how we do for other licenses to grant a food truck license, and that that would apply on all property in the city, regardless of its status of ownership or control.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: For me to give to you probably the easiest way to find this information, and we could maybe go deeper, but if you go to our MuniCode site and you just type in food truck and you go to the documents, you should be able to see records going back 10 plus years.

[Bears]: Some of them will have records of the meetings where we've been having a conversation about this, but a lot of them are requesting that the city council approve food trucks

[Bears]: you know, there's one for 2018 here, 2017.

[Bears]: So if you go through the documents tab, so there's codes, ordinances and documents, there should be documents that should have like 68.

[Bears]: uh, results next to it.

[Bears]: I can happily send you the link too, but.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: And then that searches all of the records council records.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: So we have, um, yeah.

[Bears]: There's a bunch of things in here that may be of value.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: And I'm not aware of prior legal opinions, but I'm sure you probably know better than I that if there were any, that Janice Spencer in the law department would probably be able to find them.

[Bears]: But I'm not aware, and Councilor Schaer probably has dropped off, so I don't know if he has specific... Yeah.

[Bears]: Okay, was that a motion, Councilor Collins?

[Bears]: And I appreciate everyone's indulgence.

[Bears]: I just wanted to kind of put the legal authority into boxes so that we don't have to have this discussion again as best as possible.

[Bears]: I think we could just collaborate with Attorney Stein.

[Bears]: No, we were just saying that maybe we could sit down outside of a public meeting.

[Bears]: Sure.

[Bears]: Council Vice President and I and you and just kind of see in structure here that meets the now relatively, I think shared as best as possible understanding of the fact that we're coming at this, addressing this food truck problem requires different legal authority for different settings.

[Bears]: Seconded by Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: All those in favor?

[Bears]: Opposed?

[Bears]: Motion passes.

[Bears]: Any further discussion or motions?

[Bears]: Councilor Collins, Vice President Collins?

[Bears]: He's not.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And I just want to also say that I was kind of thick headed on this last meeting and I appreciate Attorney Stein's diligence and getting through my thick head about what this actually means.

[Bears]: I was just like, why can't we just do what we've been doing?

[Bears]: And it's because what we've been doing has no basis in reality.

[Bears]: City Council committee of the whole May 14 2024 Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Present.

[Bears]: 7 present, none absent, this meeting is called to order.

[Bears]: There will be a meeting of the Medford City Council Committee of the Whole today at 6 p.m.

[Bears]: in the Medford City Council Chamber, second floor, Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford MA and via Zoom.

[Bears]: The purpose of this meeting is to discuss the annual budget process.

[Bears]: This is preliminary budget meeting number five.

[Bears]: The mayor has communicated that the following departments will be present, the library and the police.

[Bears]: So without further ado, we'll go in alphabetical order.

[Bears]: We'll take the library, we have Director Kerr, and this is a little bit different from previous years.

[Bears]: We are meeting with you before.

[Bears]: the budget is fully presented.

[Bears]: This is, as I said, our fifth meeting, and we're excited to have you.

[Bears]: We do have copies of your budgets in front of us, and I've basically been asking four questions of the department.

[Bears]: One, what was your budget request?

[Bears]: Two, are there any programs or other additions that you didn't request this year that you would be looking at in the future?

[Bears]: and then asking you to share kind of the narrative of your budget for your department.

[Bears]: And at the end of the presentation, I will just note that if we see a big change from today to when the budget is presented to us, we may invite you back in June for another round.

[Bears]: So very quickly, I will just read off here the library budget.

[Bears]: For fiscal 24, the budget was $2,012,177.

[Bears]: The budget this year is proposed at $2,245,111.90.

[Bears]: And the main changes there are in our fixed cost growth category with 104,000 involved in staff increases and moving the office manager from 30 hours to 35 hours.

[Bears]: 44,000 also in the staff to ensure that there's a pay increase for the hourly part time and a $90,000 increase in data processing because the cost of tech in our new library is much bigger.

[Bears]: than our old library.

[Bears]: And with that, I'll turn it over to you.

[Bears]: Great, and feel free, if you wanna walk through this infographic or share your budget narrative, we'd love to hear what you've been doing this past year and what you're going to be up to next year.

[Bears]: I have some extras here too.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Thank you, Director Kerr.

[Bears]: Any questions from members of the Council?

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Any further questions for our library director, Director Kerr?

[Bears]: Council Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Great, thank you.

[Bears]: Any other questions by members of the council for the library director?

[Bears]: Seeing none, I have a few.

[Bears]: One, I just want to confirm, there's no headcount increase in the budget as far as I could tell.

[Bears]: The only real major change is the 30 to 35 hours for the business manager?

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: A follow-up on the part-time hourly salaries.

[Bears]: You said that the last time that had gone up was 2019.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: And I just want to put it out there.

[Bears]: The reason that they were making less than the minimum wage is that technically cities and towns are exempt from the minimum wage law in the Commonwealth.

[Bears]: So it was not illegally.

[Bears]: Sadly, the laws of the Commonwealth allow that.

[Bears]: So I'm glad to see that that's changing.

[Bears]: My last question is kind of a three-parter.

[Bears]: You mentioned around new staff and programs that you'd be looking for in the future, the program librarian.

[Bears]: Could you talk a little bit more about that, what that job does?

[Bears]: Has that job existed in the past?

[Bears]: And also, are there any other programs or staff that you would like to see maybe in future budgets?

[Bears]: I know this is a tough year.

[Bears]: And my last question, you mentioned that some of this is bringing onto the budget items that have been funded temporarily by the Metro Public Library Foundation, part of the new building.

[Bears]: Is there anything else that needs to be brought over from that?

[Bears]: And also, is there anything that was being funded at the library by ARPA that is being brought onto the general fund?

[Bears]: No ARPA, okay.

[Bears]: Great, that's great to hear.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Any further questions by members of the council?

[Bears]: Seeing none, is there anyone in the public who would like to comment on the library budget?

[Bears]: Any members of the boards of trustees?

[Bears]: Feeling good.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: Well, thank you then.

[Bears]: Thank you very much.

[Bears]: We will certainly invite you back if anything changes.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: We have Chief Buckley and I will

[Bears]: say once again, kind of the framing here.

[Bears]: We have the Manford Police Department budget.

[Bears]: We had for fiscal 24, $14,566,880 budgeted.

[Bears]: For fiscal 25, the proposed budget is $14,785,259.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: The meeting is called to order.

[Bears]: Please rise to salute the flag.

[Bears]: 24405 offered by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Congratulations to Mr. and Mrs. Alexander and Lucy Lemme.

[Bears]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council congratulate Mr. and Mrs. Alexander and Lucy Lemme on their 70th wedding anniversary.

[Bears]: They were married on June 13th, 1954.

[Bears]: Mr. Lemme was born in South Medford and has lived in Medford all his life and attended and graduated from Medford High School.

[Bears]: He served in the Korean War and then returned to Medford and married his beautiful wife, Lucy, where they raised their family, Alexander, Josie, Janet, and Paul Lemme.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by Council Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes, 7 in the affirmative.

[Bears]: None in the negative.

[Bears]: The motion passes.

[Bears]: 24-409 offered by Council President Bears.

[Bears]: Be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we congratulate the Medford High School Class of 2024 on their graduation and send them our best wishes as they begin their next adventure.

[Bears]: I wanna send my congratulations as well.

[Bears]: Very impressive group of students, regardless of what they may be doing after.

[Bears]: I just hope that they will contribute some of their great success to our community.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Tseng, seconded by Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes, 7 in the affirmative, zero in the negative. Motion passes to 24-411 congratulations to the organizers of Medford porchfest 2024, it was all by the Medford City Council that we congratulate the volunteer organizers hosts and attendees at Medford fortress 2024 on an incredible day of music and community building.

[Bears]: We had Medford Porch Fest recently.

[Bears]: It was an incredible success.

[Bears]: We saw, I think, over a hundred locations hosting music.

[Bears]: I managed to get to three of them, and it was just a really wonderful day for our city to see so many people coming together and out in the streets and just making a great show of Medford's arts, culture, and community.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: petition for a grant of location, National Grid Inc.

[Bears]: of North Andover, Massachusetts, Medford, Massachusetts City Clerk's Office.

[Bears]: You are hereby notified that by order of the Medford City Council, a public hearing will be held in the Howard F. Alderman Memorial Chambers and by Zoom at 7 p.m.

[Bears]: on Tuesday, June 11th, 2024, on a petition filed by the Massachusetts Electric Company, DBA, National Grid, and Verizon New England, Incorporated, to add one additional joint owned pole located at 171 Park Street, Medford, MA 02155, and permission to locate the wires

[Bears]: including the necessary sustaining and protecting fixtures along and across Park Street.

[Bears]: National Grid is petitioning to install a new 40-foot Class 3 wood pole at 171 Park Street in order to install a new 50 kilovolt amp transformer to offload existing overloaded transformers on Park Street.

[Bears]: A new Zoom link for this meeting will be provided not later than Friday, June 7, 2024.

[Bears]: The petition has been filed in accordance with the plan marked National Grid Plan Number WR30955.

[Bears]: 090 Park Street, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, March 28, 2024.

[Bears]: Wherefore, I praise that after due notice and hearing as provided by law, it be granted a location for and permission to erect and maintain poles and wires together with such sustaining and protecting fixtures as it may find necessary.

[Bears]: Said poles to be erected substantially in accordance with the plan filed here with Mark Park Street, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: Also for permission to lay and maintain underground laterals, cables, and wires in the above or intersecting public ways for the purpose of making connections with such poles and buildings.

[Bears]: as each of said petitioners may desire for distributing purposes.

[Bears]: Approved by the superintendent of wires approved chief engineer with the following conditions.

[Bears]: The grant of location is limited to one additional joint owned utility pole located within the sidewalk between 179 and 171 park street labeled P three nine zero nine one dash one two.

[Bears]: Before starting work, the contractor shall notify dig safe and obtain all applicable right of way permits from the engineering division.

[Bears]: The project must obtain a public right of way occupancy PRO permit pursuant to section 74

[Bears]: dash one for one of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Bears]: Three, no other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, pipes, or any other appurtenances are adversely impacted.

[Bears]: National Grid shall ensure that all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to any excavation.

[Bears]: Four, placement of the joint owned utility pole must provide at least 36 inch clearance of accessible travel path around the structure in accordance with ADA regulations and city standards.

[Bears]: Five, the cement concrete sidewalk restoration shall be done at the time of installation and in consultation with the engineering division per the requirements of an approved PRO permit.

[Bears]: Any concrete sidewalk damage during this work must be replaced in kind and cleanly cut at the control joints.

[Bears]: Temporary patching using bituminous concrete pavement will not be permitted.

[Bears]: The sidewalk restoration of the temporary patch located at utility risers on P3092 must also be restored during this time in accordance with old petitions that were granted by the city.

[Bears]: The project site must be swept after installation or daily and shall be kept free of debris for the duration of the installation.

[Bears]: Park Street is a very narrow, heavily traveled roadway and requires a mandatory police detail to perform this work.

[Bears]: The engineering division recommends that the applicant consult with the Medford Police Department traffic sergeants prior to scheduling this work since work hours may be restricted to outside normal operations.

[Bears]: Nine, at least 72 hours prior to the start of the project, National Grid must coordinate a better communications with the director of communications and submit any required information

[Bears]: that may be requested to effectively inform the public, signed Adam L. Hurtubise.

[Bears]: Do we have a representative of National Grid in person or on Zoom?

[Bears]: Thank you for being here.

[Bears]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Bears]: And if you could just describe the project and give us any information, and then we can open the public hearing.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: 24367 public hearing proposed amendments the Medford zoning ordinance chapter 94 public hearing notices Medford City Council June 11 2024.

[Bears]: The

[Bears]: Medford City Council, a subsequent public hearing.

[Bears]: The Medford City Council shall conduct a public hearing on June 11, 2024 at 7 p.m.

[Bears]: in the Medford City Council Chamber on the second floor of Medford City Hall.

[Bears]: 85 George P. Hassett Drive and via Zoom, a link to the public hearing will be presented no later than June 7th, 2024 on the following proposed amendments to the City of Medford zoning ordinance.

[Bears]: One, amending the format of the table of use and parking regulations to replace the parking and loading code columns with specific parking and loading requirements.

[Bears]: Two, amending section 94-12 definitions to add new defined terms and revise existing definitions.

[Bears]: 3.

[Bears]: Adopt a new GIS-based digital zoning map.

[Bears]: Adoption of the new map format is not intended to result in any material changes to zoning of any parcels within the City, but is intended to confirm the best information available to the City regarding the existing zoning designation for all properties in the City.

[Bears]: Amending sections 94-1.4

[Bears]: 94-6.4.3 subsection 2, 94-11.7.2 subsection 4 and 94-12 to exempt municipal uses from certain use parking and directional dimensional requirements.

[Bears]: The full materials for the amendment can be viewed in the office of the city clerk, city hall room 103, or on the city's website at www.medfordma.org, slash department, slash planning, dash development, dash sustainability, by clicking on current CD board filings.

[Bears]: If you need reasonable accommodation to attend, participate in either meeting, please contact Francis Nwaje, telephone 781-393-2439, or email fnwaje at medford-ma.gov, per order, Adam Hurtubise, city clerk.

[Bears]: would recognize vice president Collins, the chair of the planning and permitting committee.

[Bears]: 24410, dear President Bears and members of the city council, in addition to a $76 million general fund appropriation for the school department,

[Bears]: which I have submitted within the fiscal 25 budget, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body appropriate an additional $1,007,500.00 in American Rescue Plan Act funds for the fiscal 25 budget to stabilize the school department budget.

[Bears]: These two appropriations, if approved, provide the school department

[Bears]: with $77,750,000 to operate the Medford Public Schools in fiscal 25.

[Bears]: Further resources could be directed to the school department in fiscal 25 and beyond if the city council votes to place an override question on the November biennial state election ballot and voters approve such a measure.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: 24-413 proposition two and a half debt exclusion order and ballot question for fire headquarters.

[Bears]: Ordered that the city pursuant to general law chapter 59 section 21 C subsection K shall seek voter approval at the biennial state election to be held on November 5th, 2024 to assess taxes in excess of the amount allowed pursuant to general law chapter 59 section 21 C.

[Bears]: for the payment of principal and interest on bonds, notes, or certificates of indebtedness issued by the city to pay the cost of designing the project, equipping and furnishing the project, site improvements, and all other costs for a new fire station headquarters, and that toward that end, the elections department is hereby directed to notify the Secretary of the Commonwealth

[Bears]: of the within vote of the city council to place the following question on the ballot for use by the city at the November 5 2024 biennial state election the question would read as follows shall the city of Medford be allowed to exempt from the provisions of proposition two and one half so-called the amounts required to pay for the bonds issued in order to pay the cost of constructing a new fire station headquarters to be located at 120 main street in Medford Massachusetts

[Bears]: including the payment of all costs related to designing the project, equipping and furnishing the project, site improvements, and all other costs incidental and related thereto, yes or no.

[Bears]: 24-414, proposition two and one half override order and ballot question for schools and DPW, order that the city pursuant to general law chapter 59, section 21C, subsection G, shall seek voter approval at the biennial state election to be held on November 5th, 2024,

[Bears]: to assess taxes in excess of the amount allowed pursuant to general law section 21c for the general operation of Medford public schools and department of public works and toward that end that the elections department is hereby directed to notify the secretary of the commonwealth of the within vote

[Bears]: of the city council to place the following on the ballot for use by the city at the November 5th, 2024 biennial state election.

[Bears]: Shall the city of Medford be allowed to assess an additional $3,500,000 in real estate personal property taxes for the fiscal 2025 general operations of Medford Public Schools, $3 million, including but not limited to funding costs of teachers, literacy coaches, behavior specialists, administrative assistants, and nurse physicians, and for regular facilities maintenance.

[Bears]: and for FY 2025 general operations of the Department of Public Works, 500,000, including but not limited to additional staff for road and sidewalk infrastructure repair for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2024, yes or no?

[Bears]: The final paper is 24-415, proposition two and a half override order and ballot question to invest in future of Medford public schools, ordered that the city pursuant to general law chapter 5921C, subsection G, shall seek voter approval at the biennial state election to be held on November 5th, 2024, to assess taxes in excess of the amount allowed pursuant

[Bears]: to General Law Chapter 5921C for the general operation of the Medford Public Schools, and that toward that end, the Elections Department is hereby directed to notify the Secretary of the Commonwealth

[Bears]: of the within vote of the City Council to place the following question on the ballot for use by the City at the November 5, 2024 biennial state election.

[Bears]: Shall the City of Medford be allowed to assess an additional $4 million in real estate and personal property taxes for fiscal year 2025 general operations of the Medford Public Schools to create a high school schedule that increases access to arts

[Bears]: and vocational programming, expands classroom instructional opportunities, and for classroom teacher and paraprofessional compensation for the fiscal year beginning July 1, 2024.

[Bears]: to address the fiscal crisis that we're in in our schools.

[Bears]: if this package does move forward, that we can have further discussions, hopefully with a city solicitor hired at this new rate about potentially restoring that position in the future.

[Bears]: If we have a student here, someone who needs to get home, it is a school night, so we'll make a school night exception.

[Bears]: But it'll be three minutes for each speaker for the first two hours, followed by one more minute.

[Bears]: After two hours, we'll go to one minute.

[Bears]: So please keep your comments as brief as you can.

[Bears]: The city does have the maximum tax exemption for seniors, veterans, and the blind that is allowed by state law.

[Bears]: That's not legally allowed under state law.

[Bears]: Um, Jessica Taddeo, 50 fells.

[Bears]: You have mentored.

[Bears]: I may to the members of the city council, the mayor and the public.

[Bears]: I write to you today to express my support for proposition two and a half override and use of a free cash reserves to fund our schools, fix our infrastructure and provide mentor for the permanent support structure.

[Bears]: I do not believe it as a generalization to claim,

[Bears]: and a majority of residents were shocked and appalled to see potential outline cuts to various programs.

[Bears]: And as one of those residents, I believe wholeheartedly that this is the only solution to these problems we face.

[Bears]: I ask that you use the city's free cash as a short-term solution so a budget that funds all necessary programs can be passed by this council.

[Bears]: The free cash is meant for emergencies and this is without a doubt an emergency.

[Bears]: I believe the use of these reserves are a necessary step prior to a vote taken by the public regarding a debt exclusion and override.

[Bears]: I've spent a lot of time talking to voters over the last four months, and many of them are quick to voice their concerns over funding for the schools and the state of our infrastructure.

[Bears]: These are the two biggest issues for residents in my eyes.

[Bears]: This seems like a perfect fix.

[Bears]: I believe that with a coordinated effort, strong message, and open dialogue,

[Bears]: Many residents would be in support of any measure taken that promises a strong school system.

[Bears]: I am a product of Medford Public Schools, and I am endlessly grateful for the education and support I received.

[Bears]: It is important to me that future generations of students receive the same support, programs, and opportunities my classmates and I enjoyed, specifically fostering a performing arts program.

[Bears]: Research shows that those involved in art, performance, music, and dance are smarter, better analytical thinkers, and bring a necessary perspective to more, quote, conventional disciplines.

[Bears]: Additionally, these spaces are refuge for many children seeking communities and way to express themselves.

[Bears]: The proposed cuts are daunting and I believe that 7.5 million as a minimum for an override would set up younger generations for a future of success, knowledge and creativity.

[Bears]: Opponents of this will claim that supporters are squeezing money from working families, unfairly taxing residents, and that the city will not use the money responsibly.

[Bears]: These opponents are the same people with the loudest voices expressing concerns about our schools, roads, potholes, and lack of services for residents.

[Bears]: To opponents, I say, no matter your politics or views on the city finances, a strong foundation for future generations is paramount to any political or financial concerns in the present.

[Bears]: To opponents, I say these resolutions are proof that your elected officials are listening and helping.

[Bears]: I implore you to consider a budget that allows our schools to flourish for decades to come.

[Bears]: The time is now to fix this longstanding issue.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And I have from Ken Kraus, 50 Mystic Street.

[Bears]: Dear Medford City Council members, I am part of a demographic that might be expected to oppose tax overrides such as the ones being proposed for the November ballot, a senior citizen with no children or grandchildren in the Metro Public Schools on a fixed income and with new and increasing medical bills and other expenses.

[Bears]: But in fact, I am 100% in favor of this measure being approved to appear on the November ballot, where I'll be eager to vote for it.

[Bears]: Simply put, the city of Medford, the cost of business continues to go up,

[Bears]: just like my plumber does when costs increase, it is reasonable to ask the paying customer to pay more for services.

[Bears]: It has never been more clear than during the current budget process, especially regarding the schools, that we don't have enough revenue to cover the basic costs of running a high-functioning city, let alone major capital improvements such as a new fire headquarters or high school.

[Bears]: It is appropriate for the city to examine how to increase revenue from each leg

[Bears]: of the multi-leg stool of sources, including property taxes.

[Bears]: True, in my 24 years as a Medford homeowner, our taxes have been low compared to neighboring communities, one of the many things that make Medford such an appealing place to live.

[Bears]: Sure, everyone wants their taxes to be as low as possible, but a small increase in this segment by way of an override is a reasonable proposition and a good investment in helping the city bring its annual budget closer to where it needs to be to cover essential needs.

[Bears]: residents should know that the city is working hard to increase revenue from the other legs of that stool as well.

[Bears]: After a major decline in life sciences, sidelined several promising large projects, major commercial development projects have reemerged, including a $20 million makeover of former Century Bank building at 400 Mystic Avenue and large residential projects at 970 Felsway and 280 Mystic Avenue.

[Bears]: These and others to follow will be providing substantial commercial tax and other revenue to the city.

[Bears]: The Mass Gaming Commission recently approved the city's current request of $1.04 million from its Community Mitigation Fund for 10 projects across the city, including $300,000 for improvements to Chevalier Theatre, the primary economic engine for Medford Square that has created tens of thousands of dollars in meal and hotel tax revenue for the city alone, not to mention jobs and steady purchases from a multitude of other Medford businesses.

[Bears]: Those are just two examples I cite in response to people say the city is overburdening the residential taxpayer.

[Bears]: Finally, I noted above, we're talking about the city covering essential needs such as robust education, that doesn't short-range departments such as the arts, and not that many things in the city could truly use help to make it thrive.

[Bears]: Our city's departments are hardly bloated.

[Bears]: For example, Somerville, albeit a bit larger city, has 10 staff members for its arts council.

[Bears]: The Medford Arts Council has zero staff members, and the council's volunteer members do not even receive a stipend for serving.

[Bears]: just think how much stronger this important community asset both in terms of quality of life and its significant economic benefit to the city could be with just one staff member rather than the city relying almost completely on volunteers such as those with cache west medford open studios medford porch fest etc to put on more than 1 000 events you'd see 1 000 events a year almost totally on their own

[Bears]: Last, the city must be able to offer competitive wages in order to attract top quality employees.

[Bears]: Many city hiring managers will tell you about strong candidates who are lost to other municipalities, not to mention the private sector due to higher salary offers.

[Bears]: The city needs more revenue to provide residents with the best possible staff and best possible services.

[Bears]: I strongly urge the city council to vote in favor of putting three proposed tax overrides on the November ballot.

[Bears]: And thank you for all your hard work in bringing forward these vitally important measures.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Ken Kraus, 50 Mystic Street, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: I have a motion passes.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins, I'm gonna ask you to take the chair.

[Bears]: 24-412.

[Bears]: resolution to recognize and discuss the Stop the Sigma campaign in relation to our neighbors with substance use disorder, whereas substance use disorder is a recognized disease by the medical community, and whereas in 2023,

[Bears]: Medford was home to 403 individuals with active prescriptions for buprenorphine and medications as a treatment for opioid recovery.

[Bears]: And whereas buprenorphine and methadone are lifesaving medications to treat substance use disorder and are effective at treating opioid dependence.

[Bears]: And whereas between July, 2022 and June, 2023, Medford was home to 22 individuals who died for reasons related to substance use disorder.

[Bears]: And whereas in 2018, 16% of individuals with a substance use disorder did not seek treatment because they were worried it would have a negative impact on their employment and approximately 15%

[Bears]: 15% felt it would impact their community's view of them.

[Bears]: And whereas a disease is not a moral failing now, therefore be it hereby resolved that the Medford City Council recognize that all Medford residents are deserving of care and respect, regardless of their medical disability or disability status, be it further resolved that when we speak of the services we can offer our residents, we do so while offering the utmost dignity to all people at all times.

[Bears]: Council Luzardo.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I just want to thank my fellow Councilor for putting this item on the agenda, bringing up some very important issues.

[Bears]: And I think we all know how much the opioid crisis has impacted our community.

[Bears]: Such a serious, serious issue.

[Bears]: And, you know, whether it's meant for overcoming addiction or our prevention and outreach office or just the sheer amount of work that so many people in this community have done to do harm reduction and also try to just save lives.

[Bears]: I think it's important that we acknowledge that, you know, yes, it's a difficult issue.

[Bears]: Yes, it's tough.

[Bears]: But that

[Bears]: There are people and families in our community who have been so deeply affected by substance use disorders and people in our community.

[Bears]: I mean, I have been to funerals of people I went to school with in Medford, at Medford High School, who maybe if our society thought about these a little bit differently or spoke about these issues a little bit differently,

[Bears]: would have gotten the help that they needed and they'd be alive.

[Bears]: So for every statement that is made that I can understand fear and concern, but I think that humanizing these human beings in our community and these human beings in our, whether they're just in Medford or they're around the region, it's important for us to do that.

[Bears]: And I see that as the intent of this resolution.

[Bears]: So I thank you for putting it forward.

[Bears]: I just wanted to note one thing.

[Bears]: I misspoke on the dates of the meetings.

[Bears]: It's not the 25th and the 26th.

[Bears]: It is June 26th, Community Development Board, June 27th, Zoning Board of Appeals.

[Bears]: My apologies.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Madam Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Announcements, accolades, remembrances, reports, and records.

[Bears]: 24429 offered by President Bears.

[Bears]: Resolution celebrating Tom Lincoln's service as Brooks Estate President.

[Bears]: Whereas Tom Lincoln has served as President of the Medford Brooks Estate Land Trust and Belt since its founding and

[Bears]: Whereas Tom Lincoln led the efforts for the permanent preservation and conservation of the Medford Brooks estate, including both the historic buildings and open space.

[Bears]: And whereas Tom Lincoln has volunteered tens of thousands of hours to Medford over the past 30 years, helping to draft legislation to establish M-BELT, run hundreds of meetings and events, recruit volunteers, raise funds, write grants, and be the public face of M-BELT to the Medford and regional community.

[Bears]: And whereas after decades of service, Tom Lincoln recently stepped down as M-BELT president and has returned to the ranks of volunteers and citizen advocates,

[Bears]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we congratulate Tom Lincoln on his storied career, preserving and restoring this essential city-owned property for future generations.

[Bears]: Be it further resolved that we invite Mr. Lincoln to attend a future city council meeting to present him with a citation for his achievement.

[Bears]: Be it further resolved that we invite the entire Medford community to attend the annual Brooks Estate picnic on Saturday, July 13th, 2024 from 12 p.m.

[Bears]: to 3 p.m.

[Bears]: at the Shepherd Brooks Manor to enjoy food,

[Bears]: community and to celebrate Tom Lincoln's work to preserve and conserve the Medford Brooks estate for all time.

[Bears]: Any comments by members of the council?

[Bears]: Councilor Lemme.

[Bears]: Any further comment?

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: And I have been lucky to serve now for five years as the City Council's representative on the MBELT board and work with Tom.

[Bears]: And Tom's tenacity, his experiences, frustration with the pace of change are all something that I've come

[Bears]: to know very well, and I am excited to thank him and congratulate him.

[Bears]: He is going to keep working with the Brooks Estate and on the Brooks Estate, which I think is fantastic.

[Bears]: We also have a new president, Carly Nesson, a Medford resident who stepped up to take on the role, and we're really excited to see what the next 30 years at the Brooks Estate looks like as we hope to finalize the master plan that was started 10 years ago.

[Bears]: Much of it has been done in terms of the restoration of the building, and now it is time to build the access drive, finish the restoration, and make sure that everyone in every part of Medford can access the wonderful open space that is the Brooks Estate.

[Bears]: So thank you all for your comments.

[Bears]: I'm sure Tom appreciates them, and is there a motion?

[Bears]: On the motion approved by Councilor Tseng, seconded by Councilor Collins.

[Bears]: Madam Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes, seven from the affirmative and the negative, the motion passes.

[Bears]: 24-430, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we congratulate Sylvia de Placido on her retirement as assistant city clerk and thank her for her decades of public service to the city of Medford.

[Bears]: Before I go to councilors, I do have a statement from the city clerk who could not be here tonight.

[Bears]: He didn't know when he made plans that Sylvia would be retiring, so he's traveling, but he did want to say something.

[Bears]: He said, inside room 103, I am the city clerk, but Sylvia is the boss.

[Bears]: Capitalized.

[Bears]: Even though I am a Springsteen fan of more than four decades, Sylvia is still the boss.

[Bears]: She gave this city 32 years of selfless, dedicated service.

[Bears]: If we count Dorothy Donahue's tenure as acting city clerk, and we should, then Sylvia has worked with four different city clerks, beginning with Joe McGonigal.

[Bears]: She knows everything there is to know about the city clerk's office.

[Bears]: She's our living encyclopedia for literally everything our office touches.

[Bears]: Sylvia leads by example.

[Bears]: Behind her seemingly gruff exterior is one of the kindest, funniest people we will ever know.

[Bears]: Sylvia's patience and humor have pulled our entire team through some particularly challenging times.

[Bears]: She has been an incredible teacher and mentor.

[Bears]: She is completely unafraid to tell me what I need to know, when and how I need to know it, in words that are unequivocal and easy to comprehend.

[Bears]: She is constitutionally incapable of sugarcoating anything.

[Bears]: These are virtues.

[Bears]: I will miss Sylvia's daily presence, but she's about to find out that she's only a phone call away.

[Bears]: I'm thrilled for her as she embarks on her hard-earned, well-deserved retirement.

[Bears]: My hope for her is nothing but happiness and more priceless time on the lake with Peter, Michael, Peter, Mark, and her beloved grandchildren.

[Bears]: Well done, boss.

[Bears]: Well done, and thank you.

[Bears]: It bears repeating.

[Bears]: Vice president Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you and just I want to say congratulations and your service has been so appreciated.

[Bears]: I mean, it is the basics of civic life that run through our clerk's office, nevermind council agendas, which may not be the basics, but there's something.

[Bears]: since I've been vice president, now president, especially this past couple of years, I've spent a lot of time in the clerk's office and I've appreciated your humor, your welcoming me and pointing out that I may be sitting at the desk too much and shouldn't be an honorary member of the clerk's team as often, but always made me feel welcome and always tried to feed me candy and cookies, which,

[Bears]: I appreciate and my doctor regrets.

[Bears]: So it's been a real joy to spend time with you, Sylvia, and to get to know you and to see the end of many years of service, just the last tail end.

[Bears]: Now I'm gonna read from the clerk about Janice.

[Bears]: She has been a go-to resource for businesses, dog owners, restaurants, retail establishments, and anybody who needs information related to city government.

[Bears]: Speaking of go-to resources, she's been a go-to resource for everybody at City Hall.

[Bears]: She arrived at the clerk's office with a large network of teachers and former students, all of whom she remembers by name, when they arrive in Room 103 for copies of their birth certificates, to file their marriage intentions, and to renew their dog licenses.

[Bears]: and all of whom remember her by name with kind words as well.

[Bears]: Janice nails our customer service mission every single day, leading with kindness.

[Bears]: She has passion for her job, combined with skills that can't be taught in any training session, along with a cosmetology license for anybody who might need a quick cut or trim.

[Bears]: She enjoys our customers and her colleagues, and they enjoy her.

[Bears]: She leaves City Hall with many years of service to our city and our residents.

[Bears]: She has made our city a better place in which to live and work.
