[Bears]: 24426, be it ordered that the city council enact a temporary moratorium on the issuance of licenses and permits for the purpose of operating a methadone clinic distribution facility in the city of Medford, and be it resolved, this moratorium remain in effect until a recommendation is received from the mayor's office proposing amendments to the zoning use chart to establish safe access to said facilities in the city of Medford, and be it further resolved, all meetings related to this topic be held in the hybrid fashion, accessible to both citizens, both in person and virtually.

[Bears]: We do have an update.

[Bears]: We received a letter from Habit Opco LLC today, June 25th, 2024.

[Bears]: I'll read it now.

[Bears]: Re Habit Opco LLC application for a special permit for Treatment Center 360 Salem Street, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: Dear city councilors, we're writing on behalf of Habit Opco in connection with tonight's city council meeting.

[Bears]: As you know, on April 16th, Habit Opco applied for a special permit.

[Bears]: for a comprehensive treatment center, quote, CTC proposed for 360 Salem Street.

[Bears]: Yesterday, we learned of a proposed resolution, 24-426, placed on the meeting agenda.

[Bears]: The resolution urges the city council to impose a citywide moratorium on opioid treatment programs.

[Bears]: We thought you should know that Habit Opco is withdrawing its special permit application for 360 Salem Street.

[Bears]: It intends to search for a different location within Medford,

[Bears]: We made this decision carefully after meeting with officials, reviewing public comments, and weighing relevant considerations.

[Bears]: As you know, after filing its application, HABIT OPCO reached out to city staff and officials, including city councilors, to discuss any concerns.

[Bears]: It is an open-door policy to discussing issues and considering feedback, and we intended to approach the special permit hearing with the same openness.

[Bears]: We still feel we could address neighborhood concerns, but we recognize that there are times when a certain amount of adversity can undermine a cause.

[Bears]: We take as genuine the comments of many Medford residents that they are not averse to the use

[Bears]: or blind to the need, but have concerns with the proposed location.

[Bears]: Habit Opco is committed to ensuring that victims of the opioid crises have access to life-saving medical care.

[Bears]: Medication-assisted treatment is the best tool we have to combat that crisis that has claimed thousands of lives in Commonwealth.

[Bears]: There's an urgent need for treatment facilities, yet locations are not easy to find.

[Bears]: We look forward to working with the city to find an appropriate location for a CTC, and we thank all of those who have provided helpful insights over the last two months.

[Bears]: Please feel free to reach out if you have any questions.

[Bears]: Douglas Troyer, attorney for Habit OpCo LLC.

[Bears]: We also have Planning Director Hunt and legal representation here.

[Bears]: And with that, I will turn over to Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: I will just remind everyone again, the application has been withdrawn.

[Bears]: The council is not the special permit granting authority for this type of use.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: I think we have noted here that all of the parties involved, whether it's the city council and city councilors or planning office or residents and community members who are engaged and even the petitioner, as they noted in their letter, they did want to hear the feedback of the community.

[Bears]: They did want to engage in good faith.

[Bears]: They did want to do this the right way.

[Bears]: So that is where we are.

[Bears]: We have an intent and an approach, I think, to work together to find a site, if they want to continue looking in Medford, that meets community needs.

[Bears]: And I think that is what we ask of everyone who petitions for a special permit of any kind.

[Bears]: I also want to note that the zoning we have now does need to be updated.

[Bears]: We're working through that process.

[Bears]: This was a special permit process, so there still would have been a process to require.

[Bears]: They couldn't just come in and do it in a residential area, which I think is an important point to note.

[Bears]: We do have the planning director and council present.

[Bears]: I do want to invite Director Hunt up.

[Bears]: to speak, and then I'm hoping we can refer this to the committee to come up with something.

[Bears]: I know that we got some legal advice around the specific structure of something like this, how it would need to be structured.

[Bears]: People with substance use disorders are a protected class, so we have to be very careful in the legal construction of anything around this.

[Bears]: Right now, if we were to institute something with the current zoning, we would ban any medical office from opening in the city of Medford whatsoever.

[Bears]: So we really need to go through the diligent process to get this right and follow the law.

[Bears]: So that's what we will do.

[Bears]: And with that, I will go to the Director of Planning, Development and Sustainability, Alicia Hunt.

[Bears]: I just wanted to confirm what you just said for simplicity's sake.

[Bears]: The application has been withdrawn.

[Bears]: There's currently no application to consider this from this company anywhere in the city.

[Bears]: It will be withdrawn at tomorrow night's City Community Development Board meeting, Thursday's Zoning Board of Appeals meeting.

[Bears]: And as discussed in the letter and as discussed by Councilor Scarpelli, the intent of all parties is to have more discussions about as a city developing

[Bears]: and looking at this in the zoning context and from the applicant working in good faith with the city and community members to find a site if they want to continue in Medford, that is not in a residential area.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: 24418, recommendation for Medford Affordable Housing Trust Fund Board of Trustees.

[Bears]: June 10th, 2024 by electronic delivery regarding recommendation for the Medford Affordable Housing Trust Fund Board of Trustees.

[Bears]: I respect the request and recommend the honorable body approve the following candidates to serve on the Board of Trustees for the Medford Affordable Housing Trust Fund.

[Bears]: Yes, we just moved through the item and it has been disposed of.

[Bears]: I'm happy to take it up under public participation or public participation item from Charles Rodriguez.

[Bears]: I'm gonna keep reading.

[Bears]: In accordance with the MedFed Affordable Housing Trust Fund Ordinance, the Board of Trustees shall be appointed by the Mayor.

[Bears]: Upon approval from the City Council, the Board must consist of seven members, including the Mayor or their designee.

[Bears]: The Ordinance stipulates that the initial appointment of Trustees must be staggered, with three members serving a one-year term and the remaining four serving a two-year term.

[Bears]: Subsequent appointments and reappointments except for the Mayor's seat will be for two-year periods.

[Bears]: Below are the six recommended candidates with their initial staggered terms.

[Bears]: One, Kayla Lesson, two-year term.

[Bears]: Two, Roberta Cameron, two-year term.

[Bears]: Three, Lisa Ann Davidson, two-year term.

[Bears]: Four, Carrie Weaver, one-year term.

[Bears]: Five, Penelope Taylor, one-year term.

[Bears]: Six, Lisa Son, one-year term.

[Bears]: Furthermore, information on each candidate is enclosed to support the candidate recommendation submission.

[Bears]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: I would invite the Office of Planning, Development, and Sustainability Director or the Chief of Staff to present the nominees.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: The Office of Plenary Development and Sustainability has received and reviewed applications for the Board of Trustees and has met applicants to understand their backgrounds and interests in affordable housing.

[Bears]: The Affordable Housing Trust Fund will convene once a month on Wednesday with its first meeting to be scheduled in July 2024.

[Bears]: The specific date for monthly meetings will be determined after consultation with the trustees.

[Bears]: The trust may establish a subcommittee or a working group that will meet more frequently to develop an action plan for the trust.

[Bears]: Below are the six recommended candidates with their initial staggered terms.

[Bears]: Kayla Lesson, two year term.

[Bears]: Kayla Lesson is a resident of South Medford and works as an asset manager with legal background.

[Bears]: Kayla has 13 years of experience working for a real estate company that owns mixed income apartment buildings in the greater Boston area.

[Bears]: Kayla has worked with Mass Housing, HUD,

[Bears]: and HUD regulators to manage regulatory compliance.

[Bears]: She is well-versed in affordable housing policies and programs initiated by Mass Housing, the Executive Offices of Housing and Livable Communities, and Mass Development.

[Bears]: Roberta Cameron is the Community Preservation Act Manager with the City of Somerville and serves as Chairperson on the Medford Community Preservation Committee.

[Bears]: As a former planning consultant, Roberta has 25 years experience working with Massachusetts cities and towns.

[Bears]: Her areas of expertise include affordable housing,

[Bears]: economic development, land use, public facilities, and impact assessment.

[Bears]: She's also established and advised affordable housing trusts and community preservation committees across the region.

[Bears]: Lisa Ann Davidson is a resident and deputy housing director with the city of Somerville.

[Bears]: In the past, Lisa has served as a trustee on the Somerville Affordable Housing Trust Fund and as a director of the Somerville Homeless Coalition.

[Bears]: She's created five permanent support housing programs and has worked with the unhoused population for nearly 20 years.

[Bears]: Carrie Weaver resides in Glenwood and works as a child care professional.

[Bears]: She is passionate about affordable housing and currently lives in an affordable home.

[Bears]: Carrie is eager to share her lived experience in affordable homes.

[Bears]: She has also assisted the Medford Housing Authority in administering the family self-sufficiency program for voucher holders.

[Bears]: Lisa's son works as an architectural designer specializing in sustainability and affordable housing.

[Bears]: She holds a dual master's degree in architecture and urban planning with a focus on ecological design.

[Bears]: Lisa has worked with local housing authorities to retrofit affordable housing in order to achieve net zero carbon emissions by 2050.

[Bears]: She also has experience reviewing development projects and has volunteered at Homeless Outreach and Habitat for Humanity.

[Bears]: Penelope Taylor works at the City of Somerville's Office of Housing Stability as a Program Development Policy and Outreach Coordinator.

[Bears]: She advocates for low-income clients with housing needs and assesses the effectiveness of housing programs.

[Bears]: She serves on the Somerville Residential Anti-Displacement Task Force, researching housing policy suggestions for the city, and also served on the Union Square Neighborhood Council Board for three terms, focusing on affordable housing, and all six of the appointees are Medford residents.

[Bears]: With that, I'll go to Aditi.

[Bears]: If there's anything else you'd like to present, and then we can go to members of the council for any questions before we vote on the appointments.

[Bears]: So the council voted on the paper that had been proposed, and we'll be looking at the zoning element of this, which is within our purview, and what the state law allows us to do, what the legal cases allow us to do.

[Bears]: In terms of, in general, prevention, health, addressing substance use disorder, and the opioid crisis, we do have the Office of Prevention and Outreach, which has done some really great work on that in this city.

[Bears]: and they convened the Preserving Mental and Behavioral Health Commission, which we established three or so years ago.

[Bears]: In terms of the rights of providers, right, I get the four R's, and I think it's important for the city to engage in looking at that, but the provider themselves as a corporate entity, non-profit or for-profit,

[Bears]: they do have a right to petition for zoning or to want to open a business or something like that.

[Bears]: So the city can't control them from coming and asking.

[Bears]: And then we have to follow the laws of the public process as laid out.

[Bears]: So I think that's why you found, you know, that there's all this, you know, there was a special permit of the zoning board for this use in this district.

[Bears]: So that's the process that outlines there, what has to happen there, engaging those other bodies, you know, in a more holistic look at mental health and behavioral health.

[Bears]: That is the work of the Office of Prevention and Outreach, but they don't actually have approval or denial authority over special permits.

[Bears]: So that's why there's some mismatch there and why certain groups are engaged in certain elements of the process.

[Bears]: And the result was that the applicant said, we heard this isn't gonna work here.

[Bears]: and we're withdrawing.

[Bears]: So the result is it's not coming, the application is not applied, and now we wanna come and work with all parties involved to put this in a place where people feel comfortable that it should be here.

[Bears]: So that was what happened, that was the result, and I think that's being lost a little bit in this discussion.

[Bears]: 24-421, Ordinance Creating a South Street Historic District.

[Bears]: I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body adopt the enclosed ordinance proposed by the Medford Historic District Commission in accordance with the Massachusetts General Law, Chapter 40C, Section 3, Creating a South Street Historic District.

[Bears]: A map of the South Street Historic District dated November 9, 2023 is also enclosed.

[Bears]: In accordance with the requirements of establishing a historic district,

[Bears]: One, an investigation and report was made by the Medford Historic District Commission with the support of a consultant, Skelly Preservation Services, and transmitted to the Community Development Board and the Massachusetts Historical Commission for their respective consideration and recommendations.

[Bears]: Both entities have considered and recommend

[Bears]: approval of the proposed South Street Historic District, encloses a copy of the Community Development Board recommendation to approve the creation of the South Street Local Historic District, and the Massachusetts Historical Commission discussed the proposed district at their September 13, 2023 meeting, for which they ultimately concluded and incorporated into their minutes that the quote, Massachusetts Historical Commission encourages the City of Medford to establish the South Street Local Historic District.

[Bears]: The Medford Historic District Commission held a public hearing on February 8th, 2024, and notices were mailed in accordance to the statute to ordiners as they appear on the real estate tax list.

[Bears]: And a final report dated February 20th, 2024, with recommendations by the Medford Historic District Commission is also enclosed.

[Bears]: The above ordinance has been reviewed by Attorney Robin Stein at KP Law PC, and the recommended changes have been incorporated.

[Bears]: Further, the sufficiency of the vote required by the council would be a two-thirds majority.

[Bears]: Medford Historic District Commission Chairperson Christopher Bader will be in attendance to present this proposed ordinance to the council and answer any questions from the council.

[Bears]: Thank you for your consideration.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Brandon Lingo, current mayor.

[Bears]: 24427, appropriation for Medford High School MSBA feasibility study.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the City Council, I respect the request and recommend that your Honorable Body vote as reviewed, the following as reviewed by the Massachusetts School Business Authority, I think I should say School Building Authority, and we may need to correct that.

[Bears]: that the City of Medford appropriates the amount of $3 million, $3 million, for the purpose of paying costs for the feasibility study for Medford High School, currently located at 489 Winthrop Street, Medford, Massachusetts, including the payment of all costs, incidental or related thereto, and for which the City of Medford may be eligible for a grant from the Massachusetts School Building Authority, MSBA, and the set amount to be expended under the direction of the Medford Comprehensive High School Building Committee.

[Bears]: To meet this appropriation, the Mayor, with the approval of the City Council, proposes the use of $3 million in free cash.

[Bears]: The City of Medford acknowledges that the MSBA's grant program is a non-entitlement discretionary program based on need, as determined by the MSBA, and any costs the City of Medford incurs in excess of the grant approved by and received from the MSBA shall be the sole responsibility of the City of Medford, and that the amount authorized pursuant to this vote shall be reduced by any grant amount set forth in the feasibility study agreement that may be executed between the City of Medford and the MSBA.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention in this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: And I will go to the Chief of Staff,

[Bears]: I will go to Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you, whereas chapter 43, section 22 applies to ordinances and their multiple readings, and none of the papers require multiple readings.

[Bears]: We're gonna keep moving on this.

[Bears]: I have a question to the chair.

[Bears]: Do you have a written legal opinion I can review?

[Bears]: Is there a written legal opinion for review by the chair?

[Bears]: Yeah, Chapter 43, Section 22 applies to ordinances for multiple readings.

[Bears]: General law.

[Bears]: I'm reading it right now.

[Bears]: Yes, it reads.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli, do you have a written legal opinion for the chair on this matter?

[Bears]: I will get you that tomorrow.

[Bears]: I limit choice of the discretion of the chairs that I read.

[Bears]: I'll read chapter 43, section 22.

[Bears]: Any ordinance order or resolution may be passed through all its stages of legislation at one session, provided that no member of the council objects thereto.

[Bears]: But if any member of the council objects, the measure shall be postponed for that meeting.

[Bears]: Ordinances have multiple stages of legislation, a first reading, a second reading, and a third reading, whereas none of the paper, at least the paper before us, and if your intent is to apply it to 24428, 24432,

[Bears]: 24433 and 24434.

[Bears]: Well, I'd have to read 24434.

[Bears]: That may be an ordinance amendment, but at least the first four are not ordinances.

[Bears]: They don't require multiple stages.

[Bears]: And therefore the objection doesn't apply and the rule, the law doesn't apply.

[Bears]: The law does because if the council would like to provide a legal opinion to the chair, we've done that.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: We'll go to the next.

[Bears]: Said no.

[Bears]: No negative emotion fails the ruling of the chairs that chapter 43 section 22 does not apply to this I would appreciate if you could provide it tonight without legal fighting for transparency and open government

[Bears]: Well, you know, again, there's been no evidence presented.

[Bears]: We're gonna maintain business and we're gonna move forward on this item.

[Bears]: Oh, so many people are so, so many accusations of shame.

[Bears]: So many accusations.

[Bears]: Let's move ahead.

[Bears]: I would like to continue on this item.

[Bears]: Are these questions related to the item before us?

[Bears]: I'll go to Councilor Lazzaro, Councilor Leming and Vice President Collins and then Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: Forum is for, required.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And yes.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And just before we continue, I just want to explain the free cash process.

[Bears]: As Councilor Lazzaro was noting, the previous free cash certification was for July 1 of 2022.

[Bears]: That was in the amount of $25 million and change.

[Bears]: Last week, the Department of the Division of Local Services, I believe,

[Bears]: issued a free cash certification for the city as of July 1, 2023.

[Bears]: While the free cash amount was not certified, and that amount was $34 million, while that amount had not been certified when the financial task force was having its discussions, we were very aware

[Bears]: that the reason for free cash balance amounts and the certification of amounts was due to essentially three factors.

[Bears]: One was the use of ARPA funds provided by the federal government instead of free cash in many situations over the past three fiscal years.

[Bears]: The second was the conservative estimation of local receipts as part of revenues.

[Bears]: I see Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Was the conservative estimation of local receipts.

[Bears]: As part of the local revenues, as we heard from our finance director this year, the amount estimated for local receipts for the fiscal 25 budget is at the upper bounds of comfort of what we have submitted, and I'm seeing a smirk and smile.

[Bears]: Mr. Dickinson, and it's a fingers crossed.

[Bears]: And the third was turned back to open positions, most of which have been filled, there was no expectation whatsoever by anyone familiar with the finances of the city that we will continue to see free cash balance increases of five to $10 million a year.

[Bears]: Those are not reliable revenue sources, they're not stable revenue sources, and they are not responsible revenue sources to base our budgets on or to suggest that we have enough funding for Medford Public Schools or for DPW or for a new Medford Fire Headquarters.

[Bears]: So those are the facts of free cash.

[Bears]: Those are the financial statistics of our community.

[Bears]: That is why even though there is a free cash balance certified

[Bears]: as of July 1, 2023 for fiscal 24, $34 million that we need the stable recurring revenues as proposed by the mayor and approved by the council for the override votes in November.

[Bears]: This is not, free cash is not a solution to those problems.

[Bears]: It never has been and it never will be.

[Bears]: We also have this amount, which is good, basically thanks to the federal ARPA program.

[Bears]: There is a documentation in here outlining the draft free cash plan of the administration, which we can discuss tonight and consider further as a council.

[Bears]: It brings us back down very, very quickly with our capital needs to the 10 to $15 million range of free cash reserves recommended by all of the state financial agencies for

[Bears]: communities to have I think it's between five and 7% of their annual budget in a reserve and that's where this will bring us so.

[Bears]: The federal ARPA program did give us some spending in recent years that we otherwise wouldn't have had.

[Bears]: It gave us a little boost to address capital needs.

[Bears]: Those capital needs, even if we spent all 34 million on them tomorrow, would not address the massive capital deficit we have for our city facilities, school facilities, roads, sidewalks, water and sewer system, which as we've discussed at numerous meetings of this council, is in the hundreds of millions, if not billions of dollars.

[Bears]: With that, I will go to Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: I'll second Vice President Collins' motion.

[Bears]: Any further discussion on the MSBA feasibility study, or is there a motion on the floor?

[Bears]: Is there a motion on the floor to approve by Councilor Lazzaro, by Councilor Collins?

[Bears]: Vice President Collins, seconded by Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: On the motion to approve this appropriation of $3 million for the MSBA, and is there an amendment to the paper to change business to building?

[Bears]: On the motion to approve as amended by Vice President Collins, as seconded by Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: Discussion members of the public?

[Bears]: Can I have an address for the record, please?

[Bears]: You have three minutes.

[Bears]: Yes, the free cash balance that we have has come from unfilled positions, underestimated revenues, mainly in local receipts.

[Bears]: So not really from the property tax and from the use of federal funds.

[Bears]: So we're now proposing to use those balances on these one-time expenditures like the feasibility study and the other things outlined in the plan.

[Bears]: Your income was more than your expenses, our expenses that we budgeted for we were not able to spend because of things like, for example, 10 police officer positions were unfilled many things.

[Bears]: So, and there were many positions unfilled correct so any money that wasn't used then to pay for overtime was turned back.

[Bears]: But we still need to budget that money going forward otherwise we'd have to cut 10 police officers or cut those firefighters so for that wasn't that there was an overtaxing, it was that the budget was not able to be spent exactly how was expected in June of the prior year so we, but we still need to spend that money, we took in more money than we expended.

[Bears]: Yes, that's what we're trying to do.

[Bears]: I'm going to go to Mr. Castagnetti on Zoom.

[Bears]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Bears]: This is being appropriated from the city's free cash reserve for the one time expense of the school building authority feasibility study.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Seeing none in the chamber and no hands on Zoom, on the motion of Vice President Collins, as seconded by Councilor Leming, Madam Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: As amended.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: from Mayor Bernalino Kern to fund General Stabilization Establish and Fund Capital Stabilization Funds.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that Your Honorable Body vote to appropriate free cash in the amount of $6 million into the General Stabilization Fund established earlier this year by Your Honorable Body.

[Bears]: As you know, the vast majority of cities and towns in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts have a General Stabilization Fund.

[Bears]: In order to provide for emergencies and unforeseen expenses,

[Bears]: a simple majority of the City Council is required to appropriate funds into a stabilization fund.

[Bears]: Further, in accordance with Chapter 40, Section 5b of the General Laws, I respect the request and recommend that Your Honorable Body take the following actions, each requiring a two-thirds majority vote of the City Council for establishment.

[Bears]: One, establish a capital stabilization fund and vote to approve $5 million of free cash to this fund.

[Bears]: Two, establish a water and sewer capital stabilization fund

[Bears]: and vote to appropriate $2 million of retained earnings to this fund.

[Bears]: As you are aware, free cash and retained earnings are only available after certification through June 30th of each year.

[Bears]: Each year without a stabilization fund, the city could face significant challenges in addressing emergencies or capital needs from July 1st until free cash is certified.

[Bears]: Chapter 40, section 5B of the general law stipulates that, quote, cities, towns, and districts may create one or more stabilization funds and appropriate any amount to the funds.

[Bears]: The Division of Local Services, Financial Management Resource Bureau,

[Bears]: Notes in a published article, quote, a city or town's capital assets are a vital part of providing essential services to residents.

[Bears]: Capital assets include public buildings and structures, roadways, parks and fields, large equipment like dump trucks, mowers, fire engines, fire breathing apparatus, police cruisers, radio equipment, as well as land acquisitions.

[Bears]: Major repairs to a capital asset or when it needs to be replaced unexpectedly or reaches its expected useful life early can be a significant shock to the budget.

[Bears]: Additionally, deferred maintenance of capital needs,

[Bears]: Existing capital assets is a major contributor to capital failures, as these necessary upkeep costs are sometimes avoided in the interest of balancing the budget.

[Bears]: One way to better prepare for capital expenditures, both planned and unexpected, is to establish a special purpose capital stabilization fund dedicated to funding regular required capital repairs and maintenance.

[Bears]: In close, please find a draft free cash plan for your review and input.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: And in terms of the free cash plan, we have a free cash and retained earnings update.

[Bears]: Based on the unaudited balance sheet submitted, this is from the Department of Revenue Division of Local Services, notification of free cash approval.

[Bears]: I hereby certify that the amount of available funds for free cash as of July 1 for City of Medford is General Fund $34,241,981, Enterprise Fund Water and Sewer $11,164,741,

[Bears]: This certification is in accordance with the provisions of Chapter 59, Section 23 as amended.

[Bears]: As per requests to the Council dated June 18, 2024, I am requesting the following funds be appropriated from free cash, $6 million General Stabilization Fund, $5 million Capital Stabilization Fund, $3 million Mass School Building Authority Feasibility Study,

[Bears]: for a total of $14 million.

[Bears]: The capital stabilization funding mentioned would be a source for fiscal 2024 and prior year capital improvement needs.

[Bears]: For the remaining funds, I anticipate the following future appropriation requests.

[Bears]: I welcome the Council's input on future appropriation requests before my office and the finance team work to finalize an initial roadmap for the funds.

[Bears]: $1 million additional funding to renovate the Hegner Center.

[Bears]: 2.5 million fire department fleet replacements, 2 million pension liability, 2 million fiscal year 2025 capital improvements, 2 million fiscal year 2026 capital improvements, $9.5 million.

[Bears]: Please note that we do not anticipate future certifications to be as large as the last few years.

[Bears]: There are many factors that contribute to the balance in free cash today, including conservative estimating of revenues in pandemic years, vacancies in personnel positions, health insurance budget turnbacks, and the availability of ARPA funds.

[Bears]: While best practices still dictate that we should be somewhat conservative on revenue estimates, we push the envelope for fiscal 25 with our finance directors out.

[Bears]: We're now able to process personal hires faster than we were able to in the past, and we are not expecting any health insurance turnbacks.

[Bears]: Instead, actuals are showing a deficit for fiscal 24, and the ability to appropriate ARPA funds ends December 31, 2024.

[Bears]: Finally, as the council may know, the Division of Local Services General Stabilization recommended goal is five to 7% of the current operating budget range.

[Bears]: For Medford, five to 7% of the fiscal 25 budget would be 9.47, between 9.47 and 13.26 million.

[Bears]: on funds certified for water sewer enterprise.

[Bears]: As the council knows, $2 million is proposed for a capital stabilization fund specifically for water and sewer, and the city is presently performing a water system analysis capital plan and rate study, which will help further inform the city in its planning efforts to address the aging water infrastructure across the city.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Reinaldo Kernmayer.

[Bears]: So right there, we're talking about $25 million.

[Bears]: sorry, $23.5 million of that $34 million going either to stabilization funds or specific projects.

[Bears]: There was a request for us to review an input on the free cash plan, so at some point we should discuss how we want to do that.

[Bears]: And with that, I will go to Vice President Collins and then Chief of Staff Nazarian.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: On the, I'm just gonna put it out there.

[Bears]: I'm gonna go to the Chief of Staff.

[Bears]: Oh, thank you.

[Bears]: Hi there.

[Bears]: Just wanted to say, sorry, I was late.

[Bears]: And I'm happy to review Committee of the Whole and Administration and Finance at whatever time is helpful.

[Bears]: And just want to thank you, Madam Vice President, for taking on this meeting.

[Bears]: Nope, I can't do it myself.

[Bears]: So thank you all for

[Bears]: Letting me go out of order.

[Bears]: I appreciate it.

[Bears]: The committee of the whole we had three items in there.

[Bears]: We had the tree ordinances, the leaf blower ordinance and the food truck ordinance.

[Bears]: We have met on, I believe on all of them.

[Bears]: This term tree ordinance maybe we haven't quite met on yet.

[Bears]: No, we're still trying to finalize exactly the three different ordinances that will compose that complete package.

[Bears]: The leaf blower ordinance was passed so that is done that is part of the city ordinances.

[Bears]: Food truck ordinance we met on and we had a kind of to go back to basics, given the understanding of law and what our authority is and the fact that our current food truck process really doesn't isn't grounded in any sort of legal authority.

[Bears]: So, we did have a meeting earlier this term and we need to.

[Bears]: come back now that we have that understanding and we did ask KP Law to develop some drafts that would address all of the different components of that.

[Bears]: We also met extensively on this governing agenda in Committee of the Whole and we as well have a few issues that have gone to Committee of the Whole

[Bears]: The next one being a review of a draft free cash plan, which we talked about at last night's meeting.

[Bears]: So that will be exciting.

[Bears]: But yeah, I think I will definitely work with you, Vice President Collins to update this section.

[Bears]: And I do have a motion after I'm done presenting that I think will help us get an updated governing agenda out.

[Bears]: I just also want to say it's been really great to listen to everybody talk about all of the work that's been happening committee this council has been so productive.

[Bears]: So much work has been getting done.

[Bears]: We are a working council with working meetings advancing dozens of important policies and ordinances that are really transformative.

[Bears]: So just really grateful to everybody for that.

[Bears]: In the administration and finance committee, we've made some real progress on some of our big issues.

[Bears]: So we did finalize and finish the budget ordinance as well as held the FY 25 annual budget process under that new ordinance.

[Bears]: Which led to the earliest passage of the budget, certainly that I can remember, as well as a, you know, months long process that really allowed us to get in on the ground floor and understand why the budget was being put together the way it was being put together.

[Bears]: which I'm really excited to continue.

[Bears]: We also had major progress around revenue generation with the three ballot questions approved by the council and with the approval of the mayor that are going on the ballot in November to raise revenue using an overrides and debt exclusions for the first time in the city's history under prop two and a half in the past 44 years.

[Bears]: Those will address structural underfunding in our schools, invest millions in updating our high school schedule, investing in pay and benefits and increased staffing for educators, hire a permanent DPW street and sidewalk crew that can go out multiple times a week.

[Bears]: Build a brand new fire headquarters and on Main Street.

[Bears]: So I'm really excited about those initiatives that really start to address decades of underfunding and the deep needs of our community, both for ongoing operating expenses and our capital needs so

[Bears]: I'm really encouraged by the efforts so far in collaboration that got us to this point and excited to work with everyone in Medford to get this passed in November and make sure that our city and our students and all of us have the resources that we need to invest in Medford's future.

[Bears]: We have not yet received an update on the classification and compensation study.

[Bears]: So there was money in the budget for that.

[Bears]: I noticed in the city budget for fiscal 25.

[Bears]: So I am hoping we can use either the next six months or the second year of the term to really dive deep and make sure that the compensation of our employees and the city reflects the work that they do and also reflects the competitive amounts needed to

[Bears]: bring on the best and make sure that we don't lose talented staff to other communities that are paying more.

[Bears]: In terms of the ordinances, as I noted, we have ordained the budget ordinance, the city's first ever budget ordinance, which is really exciting.

[Bears]: We have also worked on and met on the commercial vacancy tax.

[Bears]: I think from city staff perspective, there was an intent to maybe look at a different approach potentially around commercial vacancies.

[Bears]: We'll continue those discussions.

[Bears]: and look at all the tools that we can to make sure that we don't have vacant properties just sitting vacant for tax benefits or other situations where we see the impact both economically and visually and aesthetically on our community.

[Bears]: Good landlord tax credit we have put that forward to implement that local option.

[Bears]: We need to meet in the next six months, and I think we can keep our goal of December of getting this in place to as part of our comprehensive housing strategy.

[Bears]: including things like rent stabilization and our zoning reforms to address the housing prices here in our community and support those who are doing the right thing and working to keep down rent increases and keep rent prices from skyrocketing.

[Bears]: And then really everything else on here in terms of ordinances is something we're probably looking at in next year.

[Bears]: So looking at community benefits agreements potentially that may need to be part of looking at our planning and permitting, zoning update project as well, the percent for art ordinance, paid family medical leave and extended illness leave bank.

[Bears]: Those are some initiatives we will be looking at in the second year of the term.

[Bears]: And then this fall, really excited to work on, per the budget ordinance, the financial review of the city's financial status and really making sure that we are engaged year-round with our finance department and the city administration to know where we're at.

[Bears]: build out both our understanding of the current fiscal year, but begin deeply the process of long-term financial planning, revenue forecasting, and making that work which is happening in the finance department and the mayor's office more transparent.

[Bears]: and more open to the public.

[Bears]: I think we understand as a council what the city's financial position is, why we need overrides, why we need debt exclusions this time, this year to address budget issues, and working to get the technology and the staffing and the communications in place to

[Bears]: further explained to the public, it may be in a clearer and more concise way.

[Bears]: The city's long-term financial planning needs is definitely a priority of this council and of the administration and finance committee.

[Bears]: So, yep, that committee has definitely done some exciting work and I'm really grateful to all the members of the committee and every member of this council for everything that they have been working on so far this term.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I just wanted to motion to

[Bears]: request that all committee chairs submit an update to the president and vice president on their committee, if there's any changes they'd like to see made to the governing agenda, any items that have been made, and for the president and vice president to also use the newsletters as a guidepost for updating the governing agenda and putting out an updated version of this document, including a short summary of

[Bears]: to date, you know how many meetings we've had and what major accomplishments have been.

[Bears]: Achieved by this council so far this term.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: 14th regular meeting, July 23rd, 2024.

[Bears]: Motions, orders, and resolutions 24441 offered by Councilor Scarpelli, whereas the Mayor and Medford City Council have repeatedly stated their goal to ensure the highest degree of transparency and accountability in all governmental matters, and whereas on June 28, 2024, Medford City Councilor George Scarpelli sent a letter

[Bears]: to the Office of the Attorney General and the Office of the State Auditor.

[Bears]: And whereas the letter of Councilor Scott Polley raised various issues relating to the vote taken on significant municipal financial matters and the actions of the Medford City Council.

[Bears]: And whereas, in light of the long-term absence of an appointed city solicitor in the city of Medford and the fact that the city's private legal counsel is a law firm hired by the mayor, and whereas the director of operations of the office of the state auditor responded to Councilor Scarpelli's letter, that the state auditor would, quote, examine the issues raised in the letter if the examination of these issues had the approval of a majority vote of the city council and the mayor, as required by state statute, and whereas the fairest and most objective fashion to resolve the issues raised in Councilor Scarpelli's letter is to have an outside agency address these issues,

[Bears]: and determine the most appropriate way to address these issues.

[Bears]: Now, therefore, we are resolved that the Medford City Council approve and authorize the Office of the State Auditor to examine the issues set forth in said letter.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: I move that Councilor Scarpelli to approve the resolution, seconded by.

[Bears]: Second, I'll second it.

[Bears]: You can.

[Bears]: Second.

[Bears]: Oh, we have a second.

[Bears]: It is not accurate to say that we did not know that there was money there.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: So that is when we got the official certification.

[Bears]: I would have to look, but it was probably

[Bears]: probably between June 15th and 20th.

[Bears]: No, it was after the budget.

[Bears]: Well, and the financial team communicated to this council at budget meetings and committee of the whole, that there was going to be a free cash balance this year.

[Bears]: similar to the previous few years for three major reasons.

[Bears]: The use of federal funds, ARPA funding from the federal government, one-time funds, in the place where free cash reserves may have otherwise been used.

[Bears]: That was a certification, yes.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: It was a one-time surplus and is not reliably budgetable.

[Bears]: We don't know how much is coming until it's certified.

[Bears]: And the financial experts on our finance team have said that we should not expect to have free cash balances of $9 million going forward.

[Bears]: It would be much more that what they have said in multiple meetings that we've had in this chamber is that we should expect, similar to what was under Mayor McGlynn and Mayor Burke, between $500,000 and $2 million free cash balance surpluses certified at the end of the year.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I think what might be also helpful to bring for August is now that we kind of have, I think we have like a starting point for the corridors.

[Bears]: Sounds like we're going to do Medford Square as a starting point for the square, the squares.

[Bears]: We might want to pick a type of zone as a starting point for the neighborhoods.

[Bears]: And then I think it would be really useful for us to sketch out our remaining, at least that one, you know, we were kind of, we're having the two meetings a month that we had talked about in the past, one meeting being more on these like geographic trends and then the other being kind of on the citywide policies.

[Bears]: I think at this point, it might be good for us in August to at least have like a consideration of,

[Bears]: what we'll be considering for the geographic for the remaining meetings, I think all the way out through next summer so that we can start saying to the public.

[Bears]: We're going to be talking about language for the Salem street corridor.

[Bears]: This is the meeting to come to for that mystic app.

[Bears]: Maybe it's Salem and mystic at the same one Medford square, you know, in October, uh, single family or whatever, we're going to call it the residential district that, that neighborhood district in November, so that people can start to get attuned and we can start messaging to the public.

[Bears]: here's when to show up for your neighborhood, and here's when we're going to have the public meeting on your neighborhood and get your input.

[Bears]: And then I think the other thing that will be helpful, um, is prior to that meeting, um, for each area, being able to have a one page or two explain like, this is what these changes would mean and look like in your neighborhood.

[Bears]: And I think that's just a good way for us to, um, have involved folks who want to be involved in the different geographic areas and the different, um,

[Bears]: you know, changes in their neighborhoods, which I know there are many people who will want to, are interested in that, but also do it in a, like a, like procedurally constructive way that allows us to move forward on these items while also making it clear to residents, like this is when we're going to be talking about your area.

[Bears]: And I don't think we could work.

[Bears]: I don't think we'll get it a hundred percent, right.

[Bears]: You know, that will meet every single meeting will be the one for that we've outlined, but I think we should at least,

[Bears]: Try to do that and at least give like the order in which we're going to hit them.

[Bears]: So maybe some sort of like light early draft of that for August that we could consider I think would be helpful.

[Bears]: And I think that will

[Bears]: make clear to the public for the rest of the process.

[Bears]: Like a, we've heard a lot from a lot of people for a long time about the comp plan and the housing production plan and the climate plan and all these Medford square plans and the neighborhood conversations.

[Bears]: And also the conversations that we just have with neighbors or we have on the campaign trail, like there's been a ton of public input already.

[Bears]: Um, here's the containers for the, uh, where we're going to have that for especially those geographic, uh, neighborhood type questions.

[Bears]: And I think it's more important for the geographic side as well of like,

[Bears]: it might be worth us coming to me and saying, like, here are the core, like, Salem Street Corridor, Mystic Ave Corridor, High Street, Main Street, and Mystic Valley Parkway, maybe those are our five corridor, I don't know if those are, like, maybe we should talk about that.

[Bears]: West Medford Square, South Medford Square, Haines Square, Medford Square, those are our squares.

[Bears]: And then neighborhoods, you know, I think we could say,

[Bears]: if you're currently in an SF one or SF two, we're going to be talking about a new type of district for those.

[Bears]: If you're currently in and people, you know, that might not be as easy for people to know.

[Bears]: Um, maybe we could put the neighborhood, the general neighborhood names of where those districts are as part of it.

[Bears]: Um, but basically get down to like, here's where we think the districts are going to be.

[Bears]: We think there's going to be 12 or so areas slash districts.

[Bears]: Um, and then we can outline like when we're going to be meeting on them.

[Bears]: I think it also applies on the other side of climate action, the housing, etc.

[Bears]: But yeah, I'm not sure people will be as tuned in.

[Bears]: I think that people are gonna be like, oh, you're changing my neighborhood.

[Bears]: I want to be a part of that in some way.

[Bears]: Some people will be.

[Bears]: Um, and I think that's, that's super helpful to understand, um, that like Wellington and maybe Wellington and West Bedford square are later in the process.

[Bears]: I mean, I think that for me, the one thing I want to, I think we need to prioritize, like, I agree that there may be needs for different,

[Bears]: dimensional requirements based on like what neighborhoods look like, but I also think we need to avoid the idea of, you know, just because West Medford has had the zoning that it's had, and you can see it on some of the demographic and census stuff, that it gets to not have to have the setbacks where South Medford is going to have a five foot setback or no setback.

[Bears]: Like, I think we need to,

[Bears]: make sure that the places in the city that have had the most exclusionary zoning are pitching in.

[Bears]: I'm not saying

[Bears]: West Medford, you know, up by Tower Park, suddenly you can have a zero setback six foot office building or anything like that.

[Bears]: But I think distributionally, like, I personally don't think other than maybe some construction stuff like that, we should be treating what is like an SF2 in the Heights and an SF1 in West Medford that differently in future zoning.

[Bears]: And I also think that where the studies may inform like future specialization in the Wellington or West Medford areas that let's say that those studies aren't going to be complete by the time we're targeting completion of this project, that we at least need to bring those up to a comparable baseline with the other squares that we may be doing now and the other quarters that we may be doing now.

[Bears]: and then allow the results of those studies to, in the future, then further adjust and change those areas.

[Bears]: Because I don't think, like, let's say we do Medford Square, and we also are able to do Hayden Square as part of the Salem Street corridor, and maybe even South Medford Square, I think we'll end up down this road again, where people say,

[Bears]: But West Medford Square is not bearing any of the burden of these changes.

[Bears]: And the answer may be, well, that's because the study is not done yet, but I don't think that's what like people are going to experience or feel.

[Bears]: So my inclination would be

[Bears]: that if we end up doing a Haines Square and a Medford Square and maybe South Medford Square, that like we have to bring West Medford up to at least that baseline and then allow the study to adjust that going forward.

[Bears]: So I just wanted to throw those two things out there, but I think in general, everything you said makes sense.

[Bears]: And I think like on the city-wide side of the non-geographic district-based stuff,

[Bears]: I think there's some studies out there, right, like the Nexus thing and some other stuff that will be coming up later.

[Bears]: So maybe those are the later scheduled things on that track of the project.

[Bears]: Yeah, I just want to say that I think they're really awesome, and it's great to have the conversations and look at the maps.

[Bears]: We had some folks in and out.

[Bears]: I know the assessor, Koskin, I think Todd Blake was in and out, so some folks interested who aren't day-to-day part of the project.

[Bears]: Yes, I can give more context on that.

[Bears]: And again, Kit, if I get it wrong, please correct me.

[Bears]: My understanding is that under prior trash contracts, there was kind of selective, some businesses were getting city pickup, some businesses were paying for private pickup.

[Bears]: It was not really clear what the rhyme or reason was, but there was an equal treatment.

[Bears]: some condo buildings were getting city pickup, some were having to pay for private.

[Bears]: This contract straightens that out, A, from a pure fairness perspective, but it also, part of the ordinance that we passed establishes a private hauler program where there's essentially a preferred private hauler, which is the person that the city has, the group that the city has a contract with, and businesses or large residential buildings can

[Bears]: for a contract at a preferred rate with that hauler because they're already in the community doing the public contract.

[Bears]: And the idea is, and this contract just went into effect three, six, five weeks ago, six weeks ago.

[Bears]: And I'm not sure when these provisions exactly start to kick in yet.

[Bears]: I think there's some grace period in there.

[Bears]: But the idea is that in the major squares, instead of having street pickup with city stuff overnight, that there would be potentially areas of public parking lots or areas on private property where you might have all of the businesses for that building using a single dumpster or multiple dumpsters, and then being part of this preferred hauler program to then be able to have the trash in a contained space that is subject to an integrated pest management plan and is rodent proof.

[Bears]: I worked at roses for when I was a kid here and yeah putting out the trash.

[Bears]: I mean I put it out because that's what my boss told me to do but I wasn't happy seeing the street lined and obviously one windstorm that night and we've seen that before in Medford Square and the trash is all over the square.

[Bears]: So that is the intent.

[Bears]: Councilor Collins seems to have more information than me so I will let her answer.

[Bears]: Yeah, one thing we're looking at is the fee and fine schedule.

[Bears]: We've heard from our building commissioner right now that it actually costs more to add a new code enforcement officer because we're only charging certain rates than they're gonna actually bring back in, so it's cost negative.

[Bears]: Is there a way to make that more cost neutral, cost positive?

[Bears]: And you've heard a million times in this room, we don't have enough code enforcement, so I don't need to get into that.

[Bears]: Thank you very much.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I appreciate the comment.

[Bears]: Um, one thing I think when we pass the road and control ordinance, we are limited.

[Bears]: There's a state law around non-criminal disposition that limits the maximum amount of fines and how often you can do them.

[Bears]: And I think that was one of the barriers for us in terms of using fines as a revenue source.

[Bears]: I think we wanted to see, um, it's, I think it's a maximum of $300 per incident, and then there have to have certain time period between incidents.

[Bears]: And it's a barrier that we face because of the state law around, around that.

[Bears]: I don't know,

[Bears]: when the legislature will change it, but that would be helpful.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Yeah, so I can answer partially.

[Bears]: So there is this state law that over overarches what cities and towns are able to do through a non-criminal disposition.

[Bears]: One thing we are trying, my first term, like I think basically the only thing I really was able to get done was we worked on a

[Bears]: the snow removal ordinance and one of the things we were trying to get done was looking into this and when we passed that snow removal ordinance update, there is now a provision where if you have a repeat offender, you can put a lien on the property.

[Bears]: not just for the fine, which is still stuck at that 300 non-criminal disposition, but also we put in the ordinance, the cost of removal of the snow.

[Bears]: So if the city has to send out city employees or contractors to clear the sidewalks, then there could be a lien placed.

[Bears]: I don't think we've actually gotten to that point with any property yet since that ordinance was passed.

[Bears]: So I don't know.

[Bears]: And then I think there is an open question as to

[Bears]: when that comes down the road, and we actually try to do it, and then someone sues and says, no, you can't do this, where are the courts gonna land on it?

[Bears]: We passed it in the solicitor, it went through legal counsel, but we haven't tested it yet.

[Bears]: So we'll see, it's a litigious society out there these days.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Whereas good government is based on the fund, I'm sorry, 24450 offered by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Whereas good government is based on a foundation of openness, clarity, transparency, and accountability.

[Bears]: And whereas the city council, taxpayers, and residents of the city of Medford are intended to be made aware whenever the city resolves claims against the city, the school department, any employee, any department, department head, or employee of the city,

[Bears]: by payment regardless of whether those claims are resolved prior to litigation, after litigation, but before trial, by way of judgment or decision by a court or administrative or quasi-judicial body.

[Bears]: Now, therefore, be it resolved that the mayor provide the council with a list of all such matters resolved during fiscal years 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, or 2025, and further, for each matter so resolved by payment, the mayor report to the council the name of each person, persons, or entity who made such claim and the amount paid to each such person, persons, or entity, if there is a legal reason that any such name should not be disclosed.

[Bears]: such as in the case of a minor, a general description of the claim without identifying the person will suffice.

[Bears]: And further, for each matter so resolved by payment, the mayor reports to the city council the source of the money or funding that was used to pay the claim by specifying which city or school account that money was from, whether it was paid by an insurer of the city or meant for public schools.

[Bears]: Further, that the mayor reports to the council

[Bears]: the names and addresses of any insurers with whom the city or school department maintained a policy of insurance whose coverage was the source of payments used to pay any such claim during fiscal years 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, or 2025, and further, for each policy of insurance listed by the mayor in answering the request set forth in the previous paragraph that the mayor state the annual premiums paid for each insurance policy listed in the applicable deductibles for each year during fiscal years 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024,

[Bears]: or 2025.

[Bears]: And finally, that the mayor provide the city council with a breakdown of all amounts paid to outside council for representing the city of Medford or the Metro Public Schools or any department, department head or employee of the city of Medford for any claims made against the city as a municipality or the Metro Public Schools or any department, department head or employee of the city of Medford during fiscal years 2021

[Bears]: 2021, 2022, 2023, 2024, or 2025.

[Bears]: This request includes payments made for any work performed on such claims to the compliment and page law firm, PB&R law firm, or to any other attorneys.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: Any further comments from members of the council?

[Bears]: I'll just say for one Councilor, the text of the resolution, I don't have a problem with it.

[Bears]: It's answers that already exist and could be compiled into a report, I would guess.

[Bears]: We've seen them in the Warren articles and we've seen them in reports previously, and I'd like to see them all in one place.

[Bears]: And I think we've said so many times here, it'd be nice to see it all.

[Bears]: No problem with the text of the resolution.

[Bears]: but the narrative and the arguments being put forth underlying the resolution to try to tie it into some larger accusation, it's just spurious, it's just not real.

[Bears]: The facts of the matter are this council has never been asked to appropriate additional money for settlements and legal services since I've been on this council, which includes all these fiscal years.

[Bears]: I haven't seen a million dollar end of year transfer to the legal budget because of all these settlements.

[Bears]: That has to happen legally.

[Bears]: There's about six different checks and balances on it from the finance director to the state division of local services and the department of revenue to the mayor to this body.

[Bears]: That if that was happening, they'd have to go through all these, there'd have to be such a massive conspiracy going all the way up to the state level, to the commissioner of revenue for that to be true.

[Bears]: that it's not true.

[Bears]: So I'm perfectly fine asking the questions.

[Bears]: I'm gonna vote yes on it.

[Bears]: But the idea that this fits some sort of larger narrative or example of something that's going on about malfeasance is just false.

[Bears]: The number of people who would have to be involved in it intentionally is not possible.

[Bears]: And I think as everyone knows here, it would involve people who strongly disagree with each other, somehow colluding.

[Bears]: I disagree strongly with Mayor Lungo-Koehn on a number of substantive issues.

[Bears]: I disagree with her on some of the management style in this building.

[Bears]: I am not, you know, it's just not possible.

[Bears]: So I have no problem asking the questions, but when we try to tie it into this larger thing, it's just plainly political.

[Bears]: Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: I think he was asking if there's anything that a public records request wouldn't provide that this would provide.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: 24452 resolution.

[Bears]: This is mine.

[Bears]: Can you take that chair?

[Bears]: President Bears.

[Bears]: Thank you, President Collins.

[Bears]: The resolution is relatively self-explanatory.

[Bears]: There are five statewide questions and three local ballot questions on the ballot for November 5th, 2024.

[Bears]: This is question four, certified by the Secretary of the Commonwealth, which would legalize certain, decriminalize, I should say, certain

[Bears]: psychedelic substances that have been shown in clinical studies to help address mental health issues.

[Bears]: The decriminalization of these has occurred in other places and it has helped, gone a long way to helping a lot of folks.

[Bears]: I personally have spoken to a number of advocates, including veterans who would like to see these options provided to them where current other pharmaceutical practices

[Bears]: items in medicines have not been helpful to address their mental health challenges.

[Bears]: And again, this is a limited decriminalization of certain substances that have been seen in clinical studies and by the FDA to be really helpful in addressing serious mental health challenges.

[Bears]: So I'm hopeful that the voters will approve in November, but also I'm hopeful that the council will endorse this question as well.

[Bears]: Thank you, thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Yeah, and I completely agree.

[Bears]: And I am hopeful that if this question passes, that the legislature may look to make some technical adjustments after passage as they did.

[Bears]: I didn't agree with all of them on the cannabis law and some of the other ballot questions that have passed to address some of your concerns.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Social Services Coordinator.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and City Councilors, I respectfully request and recommend that the City Council approve of the following amendment to the revised ordinances, Chapter 66, entitled Personnel, Article 2, entitled Reserved, the City's Classification and Compensation Plan, formerly included as Article 2, Section 6631 to 6640, by adopting the following language, the language of Capital 11, which shall be amended to replace the title of Community Social Worker with the following title, quote, Social Services Coordinator.

[Bears]: Upon review by the Health Department, Office of Outreach and Prevention, the term social worker is very specific,

[Bears]: It may require the city to hire a licensed social worker, limiting the pool of applicants.

[Bears]: Upon their assessing other municipalities in similar positions, several have social services or human service coordinators for this role and fit within the current cap range in Medford.

[Bears]: The primary responsibility of this role is to connect residents to services.

[Bears]: As the cap would remain the same, there is no change in compensation budget.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: Any questions, comments, or motions?

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: I just want to thank you and the friends for all the work that you do.

[Bears]: You know, whenever we see a CPA application or community fund or whatever it might be, I know we want to support the Chevalier as much as we can.

[Bears]: And supporting the friends is a key part of that as well.

[Bears]: and the organ society and all the other folks who have done so much for the for the building, you know, I'm on the Brooks estate board.

[Bears]: So I kind of understand firsthand a little bit what it feels like sometimes when you're trying to raise money for the city owned property, and then the city is not pitching in services and resources that are needed.

[Bears]: You know, I am an advocate of trying to put more of the city's funds into supporting Chevalier directly, I know that there's a very

[Bears]: very small amount of money that's going to support Chevalier right now from the city budget.

[Bears]: And I think that's really important.

[Bears]: So thank you for coming down.

[Bears]: And I do want to just ask, not just for us, but to share with anyone who may be watching, what's the best way that folks can join as a member?

[Bears]: Is there a website to go to?

[Bears]: And what's the best way to sign up for the annual meeting?

[Bears]: I can't promise everybody, but sure, some of us will attend.

[Bears]: But if the public wants to attend, how can they find out more and sign up?

[Bears]: Approximately.

[Bears]: And is it friends, what's the URL?

[Bears]: friendsofthechevalier.com?

[Bears]: Great, thank you so much, Cindy.

[Bears]: All right, this was public participation.

[Bears]: Do we have any other public participation at this time?

[Bears]: please come forward.

[Bears]: This is the public participation section of the meeting.

[Bears]: If you have any comment you'd like to make not related to a paper on the agenda.

[Bears]: Seeing no one in the chamber, no hands on Zoom, public participation is closed.

[Bears]: 24457, request for amendment to previously approved grant of location.

[Bears]: Do I have a wave of the reading?

[Bears]: I do not want to read this entire letter from... Thank you.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Collins, seconded by Councilor Tseng? President Bears?, the reading in favor of summary.

[Bears]: All those in favor?

[Bears]: Opposed?

[Bears]: Motion passes.

[Bears]: There is a request from National Grid to the City Council.

[Bears]: There's a petition.

[Bears]: There's a grant location application that was previously approved, and this is a request for amendment.

[Bears]: We've received communications from KP Law and City Engineer Wartella.

[Bears]: The folks that want, I could read them, but,

[Bears]: Do we have a synopsis from the engineer?

[Bears]: Sure, great.

[Bears]: Do we have a brief synopsis of the request?

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And if I remember correctly, if I may, just that what we had requested was that if there was a certain amount of pavement that was not going to be restored, that it be

[Bears]: the restore other pavement in lieu of restoring that pavement.

[Bears]: I believe that was the condition so that the square footage of pavement would, that would be the same that was restored or saying no.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: I welcome his hard work.

[Bears]: Okay, Mr. President, if I can.

[Bears]: Sure, I just wanna, go ahead, Councilor Scarpelli, then we'll go to Vice President Collins and Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: I can also read the letter from council to the city.

[Bears]: I could read the letter from Council if that would be helpful.

[Bears]: I just wanted to get that summary out there as well.

[Bears]: Dear Attorney Riley, thank you for your letter made 29th address to the City Engineer.

[Bears]: The City of Medford has asked us to respond as Council.

[Bears]: We have consulted with City Engineer, Director of Public Works and the Mayor in making this response.

[Bears]: then location as you know this matter concerns the proper interpretation of that certain grant of location 23445 issued by the city council on November 14 2023 approving national bridge petition to construct a line of electric underground electric conduits in main street at the location specified

[Bears]: The installation requires cutting and excavating a trench in the Main Street pavement for a length of approximately 370 feet.

[Bears]: Main Street in this location was fully reconstructed less than five years ago and contains a median strip separating opposing lanes.

[Bears]: This median strip is laid on top of the pavement bed, extending as a unbroken hall from the curb on one side of the roadway to the curb on the far side.

[Bears]: As a condition of the grant of location, the City Council required National Grid to provide repaving of another roadway.

[Bears]: equal to the work associated with curb-to-curb roadway restoration within the limits of the Main Street project.

[Bears]: Curb-to-curb is an industry standard term referring to the full width of the roadway, and the restoration condition must be interpreted as such.

[Bears]: The Council is familiar with the roadway in question, and if the Council's intent was to limit restoration limits to curb-to-median curb, it could have so specified.

[Bears]: Please further note that Main Street is not a quote divided road.

[Bears]: That term is used specifically in the industry for highways and state routes with a large median frequently unpaved and northbound southbound designations.

[Bears]: Main Street is not designated that way.

[Bears]: Restoration standard, the city readily acknowledges the authority of the Commonwealth to regulate the placement of utility lines in the city streets and with the application order DTE 98-22.

[Bears]: entitled standards to be employed by public utility operators when restoring any of the streets, lanes, and highways and municipalities as an extension of that authority.

[Bears]: In particular, section nine of the order sets forth the standards for pavement restoration following disturbance by utility.

[Bears]: Section 9.1 provides that quote, all pavement disturbed by the work, unquote, shall be replaced with quote, homogeneous and in-kind pavement to the original strength and condition.

[Bears]: Quote, homogeneous is defined as of uniform structure or composition throughout.

[Bears]: Sections 9.2 through 9.15, 9.15 set forth particular standards relative to pavement restoration without regard to the age of the roadway.

[Bears]: Section 9.16, however, provides that the municipality quote, shall have a jurisdiction to determine the pavement repair method

[Bears]: to be utilized on all pavements which have been installed for less than five years.

[Bears]: Pursuant to the grant location, the City of Medford has determined that the work proposed in Main Street, a street reconstructed within the past five years, requires curb-to-curb restoration within the project limits or its equivalent.

[Bears]: As set forth in Section 9.16, quote, method is simply the procedure for accomplishing the task, and a curb-to-curb restoration is the method the City has reasonably selected.

[Bears]: pursuant to section 9.16 of the order to restore Main Street to its original strength and condition, the structural integrity and life of a paved street as a whole is compromised by partial exclamations and patches, and such compromises can be avoided by curb-to-curb reconstruction to maintain the structural integrity of the street.

[Bears]: The case, Colonial Gloss versus Town of Wilmington, cited by National Register for its interpretation of pavement with restoration requirements does not concern the disturbance of city streets reconstructed within the past five years, and thus does not apply to this matter.

[Bears]: The timing of restoration work, the terms and conditions for work in public streets allowed by a grant of location are determined by the appropriate permanent authority as designated by section 74-141 of the city ordinances.

[Bears]: In this case, the permitting authority for the Main Street project as approved and conditioned by the city council is the engineering division of the Department of Public Works.

[Bears]: As you are aware, National Grid attempted to bypass the permitting process by contacting the DPW commissioner directly after meeting with the city engineer.

[Bears]: Requiring the restoration work prior to commencing the Main Street project is essential to the city to ensure that the required work is satisfactorily completed.

[Bears]: National Grid has repeatedly not completed promised work, one still being from 2019, and therefore the permit authority engineering is conditioning the permit for the Main Street project accordingly.

[Bears]: Thank you for your attention to this matter.

[Bears]: If you have questions, please do not hesitate to contact me, very truly yours, Jonathan D. Eichmann, attorney at KP Law.

[Bears]: So it sounds like fundamentally the dispute is over the roadbed of Main Street and the city engineer and our council have made it clear that the median on Main Street is above the foundation of the roadbed and therefore curb to curb does not mean curb to median curb, but one curb to the other side because the roadbed is continuous under the median.

[Bears]: Is that correct?

[Bears]: Okay, Vice President Collins and Councilor Lazzaro, Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Just a minute.

[Bears]: We'll go to attorney, we'll go to Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: You can tell it's been a month since I've done this.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan and Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: A motion to table is undebatable.

[Bears]: Is it about the motion itself?

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And technically we can't actually table, it's not gonna be a motion to continue the public hearing to a date certain, which is debatable.

[Bears]: It's not a public hearing.

[Bears]: It's an amendment to grant allocation.

[Bears]: Nevermind, so we can table it.

[Bears]: What's your question?

[Bears]: Okay, there's a delay to the work.

[Bears]: Okay, I do have questions myself and haven't had the chance to ask them.

[Bears]: I just think since the rate payers were brought up, do you know what the annual profit was of the Massachusetts Electric Company last year?

[Bears]: It was $104 million.

[Bears]: The year before that it was 120, year before that 122.

[Bears]: Your parent company in the UK?

[Bears]: Annual profits, 7.97 billion.

[Bears]: So I think the assertion of returning this to the rate payers is indicative of the failure of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts to structure our public utility system in a way that is beneficial to the public, and not in a way that pads the profits of very large corporations, which aren't even headquartered in this country, nevermind the state.
