[Bears]: 24047, resolution to request linkage fee updates in the city of Medford.

[Bears]: an act updating the linkage exaction program in the city of Medford.

[Bears]: This is a request by Councilor Leming pursuant to previous motions passed on updating the linkage fee.

[Bears]: We have here two honorable representatives, Christine Barber, Paul Donato, and Sean Garberly, and our honorable Senator Patricia Jalen attached as a home rule petition to update the 1989 act.

[Bears]: that established Medford's linkage program.

[Bears]: Since 1989, this act has provided a critical source of funds for our police, our parks, our roads and traffic, and our water and sewers.

[Bears]: The current act requires a new study every three years to update the exact amount of linkage fees, but in practice, since its institution in 1990, Medford has never performed such a study.

[Bears]: Thus, the exact linkage amounts have not been updated since 34 years ago and have been drastically undervalued by the effects of inflation.

[Bears]: As the city works to update the linkage fees and add a new source of revenue for affordable housing,

[Bears]: We find that the original requirement for review every three years was likely to cost prohibitive.

[Bears]: We therefore request two updates to the Act.

[Bears]: The first extends the period of review from three years to 10 years.

[Bears]: This mandates a more reasonable period in between studies.

[Bears]: The second allows for automatic updates to linkage fees in between studies based on an inflation index.

[Bears]: This would prevent fees from being undervalued over time from inflation and uses the same language that is as that established for the City of Watertown in 2022 Act of the Legislature, Chapter 302 of the Acts of 2022.

[Bears]: We've enclosed the proposed language of the Act.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: An act updating the linkage exaction program in the City of Medford, Chapter 488 of the Acts of 1989, an act establishing a linkage exaction program in the City of Medford is hereby updated as follows.

[Bears]: Section 2, Part 5 shall now read, the level of any exaction shall be reviewed at least every 10 years and reset as required based on the recommendation of the Office of Community Development and the Mayor of said City.

[Bears]: In between reviews, updates to any exaction may be adjusted over time or retroactively based on changes in the consumer price index for all urban consumers compiled by the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics.

[Bears]: Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: I'm going to approve the homework petition and send it to the mayor, seconded by Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Any questions or discussion?

[Bears]: Councilor Kalia.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: I can.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: And the authorizing legislation also enabled an affordable housing, but that was never established.

[Bears]: And I would just note that this change would just provide the authority to the city to update the linkage fees and to have an escalator for inflation costs.

[Bears]: The city still needs to conduct a nexus study to actually update the rates.

[Bears]: But I think we can all agree that what we assessed as the impact of police and fire roads or parks or streets and roads 34 years ago isn't what it's costing the city today.

[Bears]: It also addresses the Supreme Court decision around, I believe, the rationale for the nexus studies, that if you're assessing impact fees, it has to be based on a rational basis test for having a study.

[Bears]: And that's part of this as well.

[Bears]: That's a recent court case.

[Bears]: Council Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: I'll second the motion to approve by Councilor Leming, seconded by Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng? President Bears?.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Collins to approve first reading, seconded by Councilor Lazzaro, any further discussion?

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: really from this council and in partnership with the city administration worked hard to put together a comprehensive approach to trying to keep this rodent problem out of our community and try to improve our waste practices and I think you've been essential to that and I really want to thank you for that.

[Bears]: Obviously, we have more work to do, and we're doing that with an incredibly limited set of resources and funds, which is really difficult, but trying to maximize what we can do given the limited staffing and limited funding is really impressive.

[Bears]: We have here, dear President Bears and members of the city council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the following loan order.

[Bears]: City of Medford loan order water bonds, be it ordered that in order to reduce interest costs, the treasurer with the approval of the mayor is authorized to provide for the sale and issuance of refunding bonds pursuant to chapter 44, section 21A of the general laws or pursuant to any other enabling authority at one time or from time to time to refund any or all portions of the city's general obligation bonds outstanding

[Bears]: as of the date of adoption of this order, and that the proceeds of the refunding bonds issued pursuant to this order shall be used to pay the principal redemption premium and interest on the bonds of the city to be refunded, and cost of issuance of the refunding bonds, and that the treasurer is authorized to execute such documents as may be necessary or desirable to carry out this transaction, including one or more refunding trust agreements with a bank or trust company, and further order that the treasurer is authorized to file an application

[Bears]: with the appropriate officials of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the Commonwealth to qualify under Chapter 44A of the general laws, any and all bonds of the city authorized to be borrowed pursuant to this loan order, and to provide such information and execute such documents as such officials of the Commonwealth may require in connection therewith, Finance Director Auditor Bob Dickinson will be prepared, present to answer questions on this matter.

[Bears]: We also have

[Bears]: In opinion, the loan order in which an authorization is sought to refund any or all portion of the city's outstanding general obligation bonds as of the date of the loan order

[Bears]: including the payment of the principal redemption premium and interest on the bonds of the city to be refunded and the cost of issuance of refunding bonds is in proper form and further such refunding bonds are authorized pursuant to section 21a of chapter 44 of the general laws as amended the loan order properly grants the treasurer with the approval of the mayor the authority to issue such refunding bonds of the city and duly authorizes the city to qualify said refunding bonds pursuant to chapter 44a of the general laws as amended

[Bears]: It is also understood the city's bond council prepared and reviewed the loan order.

[Bears]: But yeah, I'm an IPD fan because that's about that's the price bucket for state and local government relative constant GDP.

[Bears]: And I think that's actually what we should be using, because it's the stuff that cities buy versus what people buy, which is a little different, but we can avoid that.

[Bears]: Yeah, here's what he has.

[Bears]: I have a motion of council member to adjourn seconded by Councilor Keohane.

[Bears]: All those in favor?

[Bears]: Aye.

[Bears]: Opposed?

[Bears]: The motion passes, the meeting is adjourned.

[Bears]: Go ahead.

[Bears]: Thank you, vice president Collins.

[Bears]: I just think, um, in this case, we should, I think, try to keep it simple.

[Bears]: We're not, uh, Seattle, you know, we're not a city of that scale.

[Bears]: And I just think we should reflect the capacity of our staff and also the, you know, sometimes we're not working with,

[Bears]: giant, I don't think we, I don't even want to implement a policy that is too much for some of the smaller folks who might want to be developing something here.

[Bears]: So, um, I think we should err on the size of user friendliness while also maintaining, uh, green priorities, but I could see how we could go down a rabbit hole pretty quick.

[Bears]: Something that I've talked about is, you know, instead of having it be a score between zero and one, let's do between zero and a hundred.

[Bears]: I think people really understand that scale.

[Bears]: All you have to do is multiply everything by 100 anyway, so it doesn't really change the substance of it, but just trying to make it a little more comprehensible to the average person, I think, is something we should consider here as well.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I just think that that was something I wanted to bring up too.

[Bears]: I think how this interfaces with the stormwater work and also the potential tree ordinance, you know, those are gonna be two questions.

[Bears]: I think there was a discussion where some of the green scores leave the stormwater element out of it, since stormwater regulations are handling that separately.

[Bears]: And that might be the road we want to go down here.

[Bears]: Just given what we've discussed, I think site plan review makes a lot of sense, and I think we should move in that direction as a threshold.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I think this is a great start.

[Bears]: I think there's, I kind of like the Portland model versus another point space model.

[Bears]: Although if we did a point space model maybe for this and for TDM and for green score and we could use the same scale for all of them that might be a way to also use a point space model and have the simplicity.

[Bears]: I just think we don't want to overload this I think, you know, to me.

[Bears]: .

[Bears]: I think we are talking about

[Bears]: you know, district squares and corridors only at this point.

[Bears]: So, I mean, I'd be open to thinking about it in other ways.

[Bears]: Maybe the overlays and the infill are ways to go into the neighborhoods and not have this incentive zoning model be the same application.

[Bears]: but to me, right, if we're talking Salem street, the quarter we've been discussing, you know, we're talking about four by right.

[Bears]: And then the incentive would only go up to six with a step back.

[Bears]: So, you know, really all you could say is if you do a certain amount of affordable housing, you get two, or maybe if you do additional ground for commercial and investment in improving the transportation infrastructure, you get one story, something like that.

[Bears]: Um, I think, uh, mystic ab is a little more open.

[Bears]: Um, I think we're talking like maybe a,

[Bears]: by right eight up to 12 or 14.

[Bears]: So there's a little bit more room there, but I still think you could get there pretty simply if you left your incentive categories relatively simple, and then also did it by floor.

[Bears]: And then we could treat like green score and TDM as separate things since most of these are, we're talking all of these, everything I've just talked about would trigger site plan review.

[Bears]: So that might be the way to kind of,

[Bears]: to be able to.

[Bears]: Avoid this Byzantine bureaucracy and still do, uh, all three of these things at once.

[Bears]: I just, I want to throw out the idea too.

[Bears]: I think that the, um, let's say that these are kind of, and I like what Paula just said about in the neighborhood, like we have the square and corridor districts, then we're going to have the neighborhood districts.

[Bears]: I think something like what was just mentioned, like in the neighborhood districts would make sense for,

[Bears]: It's more about the units and the affordable housing.

[Bears]: And it's a little bit simpler.

[Bears]: Like if it's three, maybe you could get four.

[Bears]: If the fourth is affordable.

[Bears]: I mean, that's probably not going to work.

[Bears]: We saw in Somerville, they tried to do, you could do triple-decker, but one of them has to be affordable.

[Bears]: Nobody built anything.

[Bears]: So they went citywide triple-decker.

[Bears]: So I think at that scale, but the four to eight with two affordable or one affordable, you know, you're still talking about a 12, 12% affordable, even if one of those units is affordable deed restricted, which is,

[Bears]: I think higher than we're requesting right now in a 10-unit building, if I'm remembering the inclusionary right.

[Bears]: So something like that might work.

[Bears]: I just think another thing that would be helpful, um, let's say we went with ground floor commercial, uh, investments in improving transit infrastructure and affordable housing as three things for the incentive zoning.

[Bears]: Um, and then we can have green score and TDM also as out there as well.

[Bears]: I think it would be useful for like the community development board to make an recommendation on a regular basis about, um,

[Bears]: minimum thresholds, like if we were to do ground floor commercial, would it be 20% of the ground floor, a certain amount of square footage relative to the size of the building?

[Bears]: Affordable housing as well, I think is a little simpler.

[Bears]: Transportation funding just to factor in.

[Bears]: exactly that situation that I was just mentioning out of Somerville where they said, Oh, we'll do triple deckers everywhere, but one has to be affordable.

[Bears]: It wasn't an effective policy because it didn't build any new housing units.

[Bears]: Um, so I think we want to make sure if we were to say a hundred percent of the first, if you get extra floor, it's 15 foot step back.

[Bears]: So it's only 60% of the square foot of the first floor and the whole first floor has to be commercial.

[Bears]: that's not going to get us anything.

[Bears]: We're actually reducing, you know, it's a countervailing force.

[Bears]: So I think some element of the zoning where the CD board is, who's reviewing these in site plan review is kind of making a recommendation every so often based on their experience as to what these thresholds should be for different incentives, I think would be helpful too.

[Bears]: And some of that's from William's email.

[Bears]: And the other part of it,

[Bears]: that I think is harder is adjusting to market conditions.

[Bears]: I, you know, I have a harder time saying, well, if the interest rate's 7%, then we should only ask for half as much affordable housing or half, you know, that's, I think, a much harder argument to make.

[Bears]: But I think at least getting it right and getting those recommendations based on the CD board's experience and site plan review of how these incentives are playing out will be really useful.

[Bears]: One, actually, just we should make sure that none of this conflicts with the changes we made about the definition of family and people living in a household.

[Bears]: We removed a lot of language around

[Bears]: blood relations and things that courts have said we can't actually legislate.

[Bears]: And we don't want to add anything back, obviously.

[Bears]: Kind of what Councilor Callahan was saying, similar.

[Bears]: The petitioner is seeking to extend the hours of operation of the restaurant in a commercial C1 zoning district at 4091 Riverside Avenue, parcel ID Q1511.

[Bears]: The petition seeks a special permit for hours, Monday through Sunday, and actually, there's an amendment, so I'm going to read the revised request now.

[Bears]: Panda Express, revised request, we request an extended hour special permit to operate until 12 a.m., Monday through Thursday, and 1 a.m.

[Bears]: on Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.

[Bears]: This is in line with extended hour special permits recently granted to Great American Beer Hall, Snappy Patty's, and Pinky's Pizza.

[Bears]: We believe the disruption to the neighborhood from these extended hours will be minimal, because we are mostly surrounded by businesses and do not have a drive-through,

[Bears]: but a set of ample parking for visitors and food delivery drivers to park and come inside.

[Bears]: We look forward to working with the council to develop a plan that works for the neighborhood.

[Bears]: 24-467 offered by mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Capital Stabilization Fund appropriation requests.

[Bears]: September 12 2024 regarding Capital Stabilization Fund appropriation request dear President Bears and members of the city council I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approves the following two appropriations from the Capital Stabilization Fund Spring Street at Central Avenue traffic signal safety improvement project

[Bears]: any amount of $283,535 and matching funds for the MAS, Department of Environmental Protection, VW and refuse truck electric grant program to purchase one electric refuse truck in the amount of $178,000.

[Bears]: As your honorable body knows, the capital stabilization fund presently has a balance of $5 million.

[Bears]: Further, any appropriation from stabilization account requires a two thirds majority vote of the city council.

[Bears]: Director of Traffic and Transportation, Todd Blake, will be present to answer any questions on the Traffic Safety Improvement Project, and CPA Manager, Teresa DuPont, will be available to present any and

[Bears]: We'll be present to answer any questions on the electric refuse truck project.

[Bears]: Finally, I respectfully request that both, or at least the traffic signal safety project, that your Honorable Body move forward tonight as the city is under some tight timelines for award, and Director Blake will elaborate on those at or before the meeting.

[Bears]: And we did receive, I'm sorry, thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn mayor.

[Bears]: We did receive a communication from Director Blake.

[Bears]: He's also here, but I'll read the communication.

[Bears]: I'm providing the following additional information in anticipation of some possible questions regarding this request.

[Bears]: The city's director of traffic and transportation, as well as the city engineer and former city engineer, current DPW commissioner,

[Bears]: Prioritize this project, that is the Central Ave Spring Street traffic signal.

[Bears]: Prioritize this project when developing and prioritizing the city's capital project list slash needs.

[Bears]: The existing traffic signal is substandard, not meeting national and state guidelines for traffic signals.

[Bears]: Specifically, it lacks the minimum number of signal heads per approach to only having one per approach.

[Bears]: The traffic signal also lacks pedestrian actuation and indications, walk slash don't walk indications, et cetera.

[Bears]: This project is necessary to add these important safety features as well as to provide accessible ramps

[Bears]: so the accommodations are available to all persons of all abilities.

[Bears]: The city hired a consultant to design the project, which includes an overhead mast arm for better visibility and to achieve the two signals per approach standard.

[Bears]: The city secured allocated funding using CityARPA to design and construct the project.

[Bears]: The amount sought through that program accounted for paying the consultant as well as paying for the construction of the project based on the construction cost estimate produced by that design.

[Bears]: During the bidding process, the city received three qualified bids.

[Bears]: However, unfortunately, all three bids are higher than the estimated construction costs, substantially higher.

[Bears]: Therefore, the project requires additional funding to be able to award a contract and proceed with construction.

[Bears]: The city project is seeking $283,535 from the capital stabilization fund.

[Bears]: For context, the total construction cost is $749,535 based on the low bid plus estimated police details.

[Bears]: The construction estimate had been $466,135.

[Bears]: The design fees are $141,900.

[Bears]: We do not anticipate receiving lower bids if rebidding the project, and there do not appear to be cost savings from value engineering.

[Bears]: It is already minimum work required.

[Bears]: There are multiple time constraints involved.

[Bears]: Since it is ARPA funded, the funds need to be allocated by the end of the calendar year.

[Bears]: Also, the contract must be awarded within 45 days of the bid opening.

[Bears]: Because of these time constraints, we also not only ask for the funds, but we request approval be given tonight.

[Bears]: without continuing to subsequent meetings, this will help ensure the award within the proper time constraint.

[Bears]: If we do not move forward or miss our window of opportunity to construct this project, safety will remain compromised at this location, possibly leading to incidents and or claims that could be avoided.

[Bears]: Thank you for your time and consideration on this important matter.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Todd Blake, Director of Traffic and Transportation.

[Bears]: So that's the letter.

[Bears]: Any comments, questions, thoughts by members of the council or questions for Director Blake or Manager DuPont?

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: That was an error.

[Bears]: So that's an error in the letter for the mayor.

[Bears]: It's an appropriation request.

[Bears]: So, yeah.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Kaya and Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: And I want to note that the mayor has reached out to schedule a committee of the whole in October to discuss stabilization fund requests.

[Bears]: Now that ARPA funding is expiring, we're coming back to why free cash exists and exists for these one-time expenditures.

[Bears]: So the mayor, I'm working with the mayor to schedule a committee of the whole on an October Wednesday to discuss

[Bears]: for the capital stabilization fund.

[Bears]: And then we have the needs for departments from the stabilization funds, I think, mainly starting with the capital stabilization fund.

[Bears]: These two items were urgent, and that's why they're before us tonight, and the mayor communicated that to me, in addition to this letter as well, in the note that most of the other stuff will be coming to us through a committee process for review

[Bears]: And I just think Spring Street and Central Ave, that's a rough intersection if anyone's ever been walking through it or driving through it or biking through it.

[Bears]: And hopefully between this project and the speed humps, we'll see some safety improvements there.

[Bears]: Gaston, name and address for the record.

[Bears]: You have three minutes.

[Bears]: I'm going to go to Director DuPont on this in a second.

[Bears]: It sounded like she said, Manager DuPont, I keep promoting you.

[Bears]: But it sounded like you said sourcing would take 60 to 90 days.

[Bears]: That includes a procurement process, if I'm correct.

[Bears]: Part of the chapter, I can't remember the chapter, but the procurement law is 30B.

[Bears]: The chapter procurement laws is that you have to have a defined source of the funds before you can go out to procurement.

[Bears]: So I think that's what the issue is here that they have to have the funds approved, then go to procurement to get the vehicle.

[Bears]: And they're just you're matching the grant amount that was authorized by DEP.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: I think that's the answer there.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: The bidding is after the funding is authorized, and if the bid comes in lower than the authorized funding, then I believe that money would revert back to the source of funding.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: Thank you for that.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Any further discussion by members of the public or members of the council?

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: On the motion of Vice President Collins, seconded by Councilor Leming to approve, Ms.

[Bears]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: We'll go to public participation.

[Bears]: Public participation is open.

[Bears]: If you can raise your hand on Zoom or go to the podium, I do have two letters to read, but I will read those after public participation by people who are either in the room or on Zoom.

[Bears]: Any public participation by anyone in the chamber or on Zoom?

[Bears]: Please raise your hand on Zoom or speak up in the chamber.

[Bears]: Seeing none, I have two letters to read.

[Bears]: These were sent to me by constituents, sent to the president and requested to be read at the council meeting.

[Bears]: These are not reflective of, these are not statements by me.

[Bears]: I am reading letters from the public for public participation.

[Bears]: Dear councilors, I have witnessed the appalling personal attacks against our progressive city councils by people incorrectly calling themselves All Medford.

[Bears]: They have screamed, interrupted, kept people from speaking, and ignored honest answers to their concerns.

[Bears]: Meetings have dragged on to 1 a.m.

[Bears]: Our new city councilors are sincere, thoughtful people trying to make Medford a better place for all, with more affordable housing, an end to discrimination, and enough funding to support our underfunded public schools.

[Bears]: One needn't agree with them on everything, but disrespectful conduct keeps our city from moving forward.

[Bears]: I have lived in Medford for 43 years,

[Bears]: and sadly will be departing soon for senior housing.

[Bears]: I can honestly attest that Medford is a better place now, with better schools, more diversity, a brand new police station, interesting new restaurants, and potentially a new fire station than it was when I first came here.

[Bears]: The effort to overturn the regressive Proposition 2.5, which has resulted in underfunding our schools and roads, is a positive thing.

[Bears]: Of course, in the end, it will be put to the voters.

[Bears]: I do understand that this may pose a small hardship for low-income homeowners, but most cities and towns have already passed overrides.

[Bears]: People can, of course, vote against it, but they should not attack those who, in good faith, want to improve our city with essential funding by putting it on the ballot or misrepresent their views, as was done in heated discussions of the real estate transfer fee.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Susan Gerard, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: That's the first letter, and then I have another letter.

[Bears]: Dear Medford City Council President Zach Bares, I request you read this letter at the next City Council meeting.

[Bears]: This past year, I've attended many City Council meetings, mostly on Zoom, a few in City Hall chambers, largely because of closed captioning, which allows me to hear more of what people in the chambers are saying.

[Bears]: The deficient sound system in City Hall, I understand, is going to be renovated, and that will be good for everyone.

[Bears]: A second reason I have often preferred not to be physically present in the City Council Chambers is because of an unruly mob of residents who come to meetings to register their displeasure on hot-button issues like the budget, real estate transfer fee, or renaming of the Columbus School.

[Bears]: These meetings have been perforated by the group ironically now known as All Medford, the small group of residents regularly indulging, screaming, shouting, and insulting our Revolution Medford-endorsed City Councilors,

[Bears]: After one particularly contentious meeting I attended in City Hall, councillors were individually singled out for repeated personal attacks and subjected to blanket attacks on all of them because they belonged to our revolution, Medford.

[Bears]: I was so disturbed by the vitriol, the lies, the hatred, and the unwillingness to even listen to what Councilors had to say.

[Bears]: I'm so sorry that you, Zach, and the other OR-endorsed Councilors have been subjected to this abuse.

[Bears]: I want to assure you that a majority of residents who voted for you and all our Revolution Medford candidates still support the work you've been doing or attempting to do in Medford.

[Bears]: Know that we are still here.

[Bears]: All Medford is not all Medford.

[Bears]: You were elected on the basis of the People's Platform, and we who voted for you still want to work on that agenda.

[Bears]: the city budget we need to support the schools and city services, the creation of an equitable and welcoming city government, desperately needed affordable housing, community safety, and a climate-resilient community.

[Bears]: As we explore solutions to these and other issues, I support you, as do the many who voted for our Revolution Medford candidates.

[Bears]: Please do not allow the not-all Medford to derail or curtail any of your intentions, goals, or efforts.

[Bears]: We who support you are many.

[Bears]: There are a small group of disgruntled people whose leadership and control has been rejected by the voters.

[Bears]: voters.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Eileen Lerner, Knight-Adams Circle, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: Those are the letters.

[Bears]: I think it is important to note, A, there's kind of two things that are at play here for me.

[Bears]: I think that's like a gut feeling that people are gonna feel.

[Bears]: I think the, and there's plenty of examples across this region of that, where you have fours and fives and sixes intermingled and it doesn't feel like when you're standing next to the six, it's so much bigger than when you're standing next to the four.

[Bears]: less worrying than the setbacks.

[Bears]: what people can build.

[Bears]: I think the step backs could make sense.

[Bears]: I think we also have to factor in density bonuses here, where maybe it's 3 over 1, and then there's density bonuses for specific community benefits.

[Bears]: Maybe those additional floors aren't full floors, but they're stepped back.

[Bears]: I think those would be the ways I'd want to approach it, rather than just saying, this is a four-story corridor, and there's no opportunities here to do something else other than that.

[Bears]: I don't phrase it.

[Bears]: Yeah, pros and cons.

[Bears]: Go ahead.

[Bears]: Okay, and that's more like we're going to have to negotiate with MassDOT to have it be something more active than bushes and grass, but that's a MassDOT question, not a property owner question.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: And are the difference between these two options that one may be more legal than the other to ask of the property owners?

[Bears]: Sorry, what's October 9th is?

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: I have the motion.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: It's six bullet points.

[Bears]: I'll just send it now.

[Bears]: guys.

[Bears]: Um I'll read it.

[Bears]: It is.

[Bears]: Promotion to move forward with drafting based on land East option be with incentive zoning.

[Bears]: Um adjust the discussed parcels on the southwest end of Hicks

[Bears]: So that would be like that inner portion, the kind of L-shaped one, as well as the stuff right behind the Harrow's Chicken Pie and the Dunkin' Donuts.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

[Bears]: Just that, that's, exactly.

[Bears]: Hi there, sorry about that.

[Bears]: I am currently sitting at the intersection of Main Street and South Street.

[Bears]: So subject matter expert at the moment.

[Bears]: I just wanted to note a thank you, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Thank you to the Bike Commission and to Emily O'Brien for your work on this.

[Bears]: And thank you to Todd for being our liaison with MassDOT.

[Bears]: But I also just wanted to note

[Bears]: I think it's essential that we get this right.

[Bears]: Medford wasn't built for the level of car volume that we have now.

[Bears]: And just because we pasted an overpass of Route 16 and the highway through it doesn't mean that the rest of our streets can actually handle

[Bears]: the car volume that we have today.

[Bears]: And that's why it's essential that we move in the direction that we're moving to make Medford more accessible for all, not just people with cars.

[Bears]: I'm one who uses my car all the time, but I would use other modes of transportation if I felt like I could get where I was going in a reasonable amount of time.

[Bears]: The Craddock Bridge is the only crossing of the Mystic River for about a mile or more on either side of the east or west.

[Bears]: And we know that it was deeply impacted by the massive volumes of car traffic that have been throughput through that bridge and through the intersections that we're talking about.

[Bears]: by Interstate 93 and by the overbuilt Route 16 overpass.

[Bears]: And I think it's essential that we get this signalization and rebuild of Main and Mystic right, because what we're talking about in Medford Square and what we're talking about on Mystic Ave is returning to a people-centered era, not a car-centered era.

[Bears]: All of the spots on Mystic Ave just south of the bridge and just south of the 16 overpass used to be a vibrant walkable neighborhood.

[Bears]: Medford Square used to be a vibrant walkable neighborhood.

[Bears]: The car supremacy and the building of the highway destroyed so much of the community that was built there.

[Bears]: And now that we're trying to restore it, this isn't the essential link.

[Bears]: to making it work.

[Bears]: So I appreciate the bike commission's work.

[Bears]: I appreciate everyone's conversation here in this meeting.

[Bears]: I also think putting that layer of what do we want our community to look like and how do we want to make sure that it's safe for everyone to

[Bears]: have community and link together in our squares is an important part of the conversation, too.

[Bears]: I don't think the 25% design hit that mark, but I'm hopeful that upcoming designs will.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam Chair.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: The tax year is always based, the assessments for the tax year are always based on the prior year.

[Bears]: So when we're talking about 2025, they only have complete sales data from 2023.

[Bears]: That's what's used to adjust the assessment.

[Bears]: That's the same every year.

[Bears]: That's always the process.

[Bears]: And it always is.

[Bears]: As we all know, the tax rate setting process happens in December after those valuations are calculated.

[Bears]: I have been in communication with the assessor.

[Bears]: All of the data is data from the assessor's database or from the Division of Local Services of the State Department of Revenue.

[Bears]: So that is what is out there.

[Bears]: The tax rate process will essentially follow its normal course where we will have meetings in November and December regarding the tax rate.

[Bears]: Which calculation?

[Bears]: Well in the assessor.

[Bears]: So the way it works is if you take the

[Bears]: the 7.5 million, and then you put the 2 million at that exclusion, that takes you to 9.5.

[Bears]: You go to the DLS website, which has the override calculator, and that will give you the override amount.

[Bears]: And then that is taken, the information for the address calculator is taken directly from the assessor's database, multiplied by the DLS calculator, and that's how you calculate the amount.

[Bears]: Yeah, I mean, I think we're getting a bit into the

[Bears]: specifics or minutiae of the issue.

[Bears]: That's the data is from the assessor.

[Bears]: I've spoken with the assessor multiple times about the data.

[Bears]: They did not do the multiplication, but the data is from them.

[Bears]: So it's their tax rate.

[Bears]: their assessed values.

[Bears]: If there's an individual case where there's an error in the assessed value in the assessor's database, I could work with you and the assessor to correct that error.

[Bears]: But all of the data is from our tax rates from the State Division of Local Services and from the assessor's database.

[Bears]: But not the update assessments, correct?

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: Well, they're based on the assessments we have now, current year.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: I did speak with the assessor a couple of weeks ago, and he actually expects

[Bears]: that next year's bills will increase.

[Bears]: The normal increase will happen no matter what in assessments, not to be as bad as prior years.

[Bears]: looking forward to those meetings on the tax rate and the assessed values.

[Bears]: Any further questions or comments?

[Bears]: Go to the podium one more time.

[Bears]: No, that includes the interest, the estimated annual.

[Bears]: No, it's a $30 million bond.

[Bears]: I didn't say over a 15 year period.

[Bears]: I didn't say it was over a 15 year period.

[Bears]: It's until the bonds paid off.

[Bears]: The $2 million includes debt service costs, yes.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: It is the estimated debt service for a $30 million bond.

[Bears]: It's probably actually going to be slightly lower because the tax rate's going to go down because the values are going to go up.

[Bears]: It will most likely actually be a little lower, you're correct.

[Bears]: No, that's what's happening.

[Bears]: So you're correct, what happens with how Proposition 2.5 works is

[Bears]: The total levy is increased by the limit amount.

[Bears]: That's the numerator of our equation.

[Bears]: Yep.

[Bears]: The denominator of our equation is the total assessable assess taxable value.

[Bears]: Sorry, total assessed value of taxable property.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: The total that denominator total

[Bears]: that's

[Bears]: in fiscal 25, if no override were to pass.

[Bears]: So the override impact is actually likely to be less than it is on the calculator because of that impact, because the values are going up so much faster, but you're also correct.

[Bears]: That's just the calculation for the whole city.

[Bears]: Then you get the tax rate.

[Bears]: The tax rate is then multiplied by your assessed value.

[Bears]: And so yes, there's disparate impact.

[Bears]: on different properties.

[Bears]: The single family class, for example, has been going up in value much faster than other classes of property.

[Bears]: Proposition two and a half is an incredibly complicated, convoluted law that is not a good way to set tax policy.

[Bears]: It's very difficult for people to understand it.

[Bears]: And it places these artificial limits that make it

[Bears]: really are not grounded in any sort of economic science.

[Bears]: They were just a fun number that people decided to pick in 1980 to get a law passed.

[Bears]: So I completely agree with you.

[Bears]: It's a convoluted, complicated law.

[Bears]: So that's one opinion on well, that's my personal opinion.

[Bears]: I don't know what Well, I think we can both agree that there's complications in the calculation.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: But in your to answer your question specifically

[Bears]: the tax rate in fiscal 25 is likely to be lower than the fiscal 24 rate.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: And that's how it is every year.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: So, yep, it's pretty good estimate.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Any further questions on Zoom?

[Bears]: I'm going to go to Marie Izzo.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: We'll go to the podium, name and address for the record, please.

[Bears]: You have three minutes.

[Bears]: We can invite them.

[Bears]: I don't want to schedule a meeting for them.

[Bears]: I will invite them to attend.

[Bears]: We'll try, oh, hands down.

[Bears]: Any further comment by members in the room?

[Bears]: Seeing none, I'll go back to Mr. Castagnetti.

[Bears]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Bears]: Any further comment seeing none on the motion of councilor Scarpelli second by vice president Collins to refer

[Bears]: This paper as amended to committee of the whole to amend the paper to include inviting residents and parents and to request that the Council on Aging, PTOs and community liaisons conduct outreach and that community liaisons are able to translate the city produced materials regarding the override and debt exclusion questions.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Vice President Cohen.

[Bears]: She said she votes yes.

[Bears]: I think we gotta have a verbal.

[Bears]: So the affirmative, none the negative, the motion passes as amended.

[Bears]: I actually need Councilor Scrupley for you to take the chair for this one too.

[Bears]: Sorry.

[Bears]: It's for my paper on the MCAS.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I'll just, uh, would you like me to, I can do it if you, unless you want to do it.

[Bears]: So thank you.

[Bears]: Um, just, uh, the text is, uh, whereas access to high quality publicly funded education is a guaranteed right.

[Bears]: written into the Massachusetts Constitution, and whereas the goal of public education is to teach students essential foundational skills such as reading, writing, and arithmetic, and to develop critical thinkers, engaged citizens, and lifelong learners.

[Bears]: And whereas the bedrock of the Commonwealth's world-class public education system is strong, statewide standards that are uniform throughout our public schools, and whereas the MCAS is significantly limited in its ability to accurately and effectively measure whether students are meeting the Commonwealth standards and developing the skills they need to thrive after high school, and whereas the most effective measures of whether students are meeting our strong statewide standards in developing the skills they need to succeed in college, the workforce, and beyond,

[Bears]: Our educator-led assessments such as projects, papers, tests, and group activities that are conducted throughout the school year.

[Bears]: And whereas the punitive use of MCAS as a high school graduation requirement has restricted curriculum and shifted the focus of education in our public schools towards meeting a test score instead of fostering an environment of creativity, critical thinking, and real teaching and learning that helps students realize their full potential.

[Bears]: And whereas pediatricians, researchers, and school Councilors have warned of the severe impact of high-stakes testing like the MCAS graduation requirement on students' mental health and well-being.

[Bears]: and whereas standardized test requirements notoriously stack the deck against students of color, ESL students, and students with learning disabilities, and whereas using MCAS testing as a high school graduation requirement has prevented or delayed thousands of students from earning a diploma, thereby interrupting or derailing education or career plans with especially harmful impacts on students of color, low-income students, students with disabilities, and students for whom English is their second language.

[Bears]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we support question two,

[Bears]: replacing the MCAS graduation requirement on the November 5th general election ballot.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I'm sure you being in the schools, being a teacher, you've seen the impact.

[Bears]: I was one of the early classes that had to pass the MCAS to graduate high school.

[Bears]: A lot of these requirements, you know, ours came into place from the Education Reform Act in the early 90s, but this was really blasted nationwide by the education reform movement under No Child Left Behind.

[Bears]: At its peak, 35 states required a high-stakes standardized test to pass and graduate high school.

[Bears]: You had to pass it.

[Bears]: That's down to eight states.

[Bears]: So it used to be 35, we're down to eight.

[Bears]: We're one of the only eight who are left.

[Bears]: And the reason is it doesn't work.

[Bears]: It doesn't actually measure what we're trying to measure.

[Bears]: It doesn't actually help anyone get anywhere.

[Bears]: And it harms, particularly targeted harms at groups of students who maybe they passed all their classes, maybe they did all their projects, maybe they passed all their tests, maybe they have all their grades that they need to have, but they struggle with the test.

[Bears]: They don't get a high school diploma, even though they passed all their classes and their teachers think they should get one.

[Bears]: And I think

[Bears]: You know, at the core, that's who we're trying to protect here.

[Bears]: That's the most focused group that's gonna benefit from this, but I think it benefits everyone in the schools too.

[Bears]: Not to have their classmates worried about anxiety about passing the test, not to have teachers feeling like they have to teach to the test, not to have students worried that even if they do everything right, there might be this one little thing that doesn't go the way they want it to go and they can't get their degree or their diploma.

[Bears]: So, you know, for a lot of people, the MCAS is just some boring days.

[Bears]: For some kids, it's the worst five days of their lives.

[Bears]: I don't think for any teacher, any student, it's a good activity that they feel at the end of it benefited their education.

[Bears]: And that's why I think you shouldn't have the high stakes requirement on it.

[Bears]: If it was up to me, maybe you'd go a different direction altogether.

[Bears]: This question doesn't get rid of the test.

[Bears]: You can, the assessment is still there so that we can punish teachers and districts if kids don't do great on it.

[Bears]: So it doesn't go as far as I'd like it to go, being someone who's been in our schools and been an advocate for our schools and worked with our teachers, not just in Medford, but around the Commonwealth.

[Bears]: So it doesn't go as far as I'd like to go, but it does hit that most difficult part of the MCAS, which is the high stakes requirement that really hurts specific groups of students and creates that anxiety and teach the test mentality.

[Bears]: So I think it's great that it's on the ballot and I really hope it passes and I hope tonight we can endorse it.

[Bears]: And our school committee endorsed it last week.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And I think to at least one of Gaston's points, I just wanted to add in the, I think that the passage of this, a yes vote on this, which I'm hoping we'll see on November 5th, will really encourage the state legislature to take more seriously the MCEIA or IEA, I can't remember, it's the mass commission on alternative, it's basically the alternative educational assessment, innovative educational assessment, I think it is MCEIA.

[Bears]: Yeah, they're looking at that portfolio requirement, bringing that back so that we can have a statewide requirement that's not a high stakes standardized test.

[Bears]: And I really hope that that innovation will go in there.

[Bears]: And I also just want to direct some folks, similar to Councilor Scarpelli's experience, there's a Boston Globe article yesterday, I think,

[Bears]: about Deb McCarthy.

[Bears]: Deb is someone I count as a close friend.

[Bears]: We organized together for many years.

[Bears]: She was a teacher in Hall forever, and she started off early on in MCAS, and you can read this in the story.

[Bears]: She was the MCAS data czar for her school.

[Bears]: She thought it was going to be doing these great things, helping get that data out, helping to provide more knowledge to

[Bears]: to teachers to help them teach better.

[Bears]: She did that for a few years, then she started to see the impacts to the point where a few years ago she became what she called, and some other teachers in the district, conscientious objectors.

[Bears]: They refused to proctor the MCAS exam.

[Bears]: And they were sitting with the kids who had been opted out of the MCAS exam as well and working with them on those days.

[Bears]: She's now vice president of the MTA statewide, a huge leader on this issue.

[Bears]: But that profile, I think, is really a great example of a teacher who was teaching before MCAS started, knows what it was like, thought MCAS was going to be this good thing, really gave it a chance, saw the negative impacts, and then has been organizing to try to bring us to a different standard for a really long time.

[Bears]: And I think that is just exactly the story people need to hear to get behind this question, the experience of this in our schools, what our teachers have seen.

[Bears]: what the students have been impacted.

[Bears]: So I refer people to take a look at that Deb McCarthy profile in the Boston Globe sometime in the last couple of days.

[Bears]: Now I know I don't want to let it go though.

[Bears]: It's just you give that to Dina.

[Bears]: You're done for Georgia.

[Bears]: You get that to Dina.

[Bears]: All right, public participation.

[Bears]: replacement of light poles in city parking lots in the amount of $105,000.

[Bears]: Repairs at Brooks Estate, use of funds must comply with city procurement policies and procedures and state procurement law in the amount of 55,000.

[Bears]: on September 17th, 2024.

[Bears]: If all of the above are approved, the capital stabilization fund would have $3,923,737 that remains.

[Bears]: I just wanted to make sure while we, while we have you and, and again, appreciate you being here.

[Bears]: Cause you know, I think there's one, one piece, you know, if it's the Patty project, which I know has been a long ongoing effort, that's one thing.

[Bears]: If it's partially bus network redesign, you know, there may be more questions and engagement with the public that we need to make around the removal of stops.

[Bears]: I don't think we'll have as much problem with the improvements on these specific locations.

[Bears]: Obviously improvements are great.

[Bears]: It's the removals where there may need to be a little bit more public engagement, especially given that kind of we were on our, you know, and again I appreciate the acknowledgement but we were kind of out on our own a little bit last fall and it was hard for us without having you here to give a presentation and then have members of the public be here for it and then maybe even ask us questions or.

[Bears]: or provide some comment that we could then question, provide, ask questions on, you know, that was just a little bit of a breakdown where we have a lot of people who still have kind of outstanding concerns and questions.

[Bears]: And I think moving forward with removal of stops at this time, if they're part of the network redesign, may just need a little bit more care in terms of the process.

[Bears]: So I just wanted to ask that clarifying question before we got into the details, which I'm also very excited.

[Bears]: OK, great.

[Bears]: Yeah, and it's just because I see these here that make sense.

[Bears]: Then we have, A, I'll say there's two of these stops around Winchester that you're asking for removal, so we can't help you.

[Bears]: City way.

[Bears]: Madam President, could we read Councilor Scarpelli's paper and join it with this one?

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I could go through everything, but then I would leave nothing for my fellow councillors.

[Bears]: But there was a litany of procedural errors and issues with the administration of this election, many of which I personally believe would not have occurred had the department been fully funded as this council requested and had the department not had staff turnover as this council also requested.

[Bears]: There's a listing here, the ones that I really want to bring to light right now that I'm sure my fellow councillors will talk about other issues.

[Bears]: Last election, November 2022, the state election, the city also released incomplete, unofficial results that did not include, to my knowledge, early in mail voting.

[Bears]: I don't know if that's what happened last Tuesday, but incomplete, unofficial results were once again released to the public.

[Bears]: We had been told, as we asked for an update on the previous election, that this would be fixed.

[Bears]: It was clearly not fixed.

[Bears]: folks were here for up to at least four hours after polls had closed, maybe even longer than that, trying to fix an issue that shouldn't have been an issue.

[Bears]: I just want to put that out there that left a lot of folks in the community concerned about how ballots are being counted, etc., having a complete tally and accurate unofficial results.

[Bears]: I also just want to put out there that

[Bears]: Again, incorrect information was given to voters both by mail and at polling locations.

[Bears]: Incorrect information as to the date that mail ballots should be returned and a sheet went out that was for the previous year's election.

[Bears]: That should not have happened.

[Bears]: And folks were being told that they could not bring materials into the booths to assist them or provide guidance to them while they were voting.

[Bears]: And that's against the state voter bill of rights.

[Bears]: So again, that's just a couple of the things that I want to bring to bear.

[Bears]: I know other folks have other things they want to bring to bear.

[Bears]: I just think it is a serious issue when we need.

[Bears]: I don't believe that any of these issues resulted in an outcome.

[Bears]: that is different from what the outcome should have been.

[Bears]: However, we need to have beyond reproach trust in the process.

[Bears]: You can't have mistakes like this.

[Bears]: You certainly can't have series of mistakes and errors like this because perception is reality to a lot of folks.

[Bears]: And there's going to be people who won't believe anything that I'm saying forever about this.

[Bears]: And that's a shame.

[Bears]: We need to have full trust of as many people as possible in this community and the absolute

[Bears]: and unimpeachable integrity of the electoral process and errors like these hurt that mission.

[Bears]: So I hope that we will get

[Bears]: very quick guidance and explanation as to why things happen the way they happen, and quite frankly, very quick action from the mayor to make sure that they don't happen again.

[Bears]: And I think that action needs to come, not just in reporting to us what went wrong and how they're gonna do better next time, because that's what they did last time.

[Bears]: We got a report about how we're gonna do better, and then a lot of the same things happened again.

[Bears]: So it's an office that needs to be funded and needs to be staffed appropriately so that you don't have errors like this occurring.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I'll be briefer, because you basically just made my point.

[Bears]: We voted in the spring of 2022 to adopt a piece of state law that modernized the system and moved us from the clerk and registrar voters to a formal elections commission.

[Bears]: The intent of this body was that we would have an elections department with a director that would be at least as well staffed as it was previously.

[Bears]: Under the clerk-registrar-voter system, you had the full-time clerk, three full-time staff in the elections office, as well as the full-time elections coordinator for much of the year.

[Bears]: Then you also had the volunteer board of registrars.

[Bears]: That was an oversight body.

[Bears]: We moved to the Elections Commission and the budget came back.

[Bears]: We went from five, essentially five full-time staff, to two and a half.

[Bears]: Right?

[Bears]: We went, we now have two full-time staff, one 20 hour a week, halftime person.

[Bears]: That position is not even filled because nobody wants it.

[Bears]: It doesn't make sense to have a 20 hour a week position.

[Bears]: You had a ton of work of this election then fall on election commissioners who are not supposed to be running the election.

[Bears]: They're supposed to be certifying results, overseeing it.

[Bears]: They're not supposed to be in the nitty gritty.

[Bears]: I mean, the last people in the office were the elections manager and the elections commissioners and LHS, which is the service the state uses.

[Bears]: Why are the elections commissioners cleaning up this mess at the 11th hour?

[Bears]: That should be what the staff is.

[Bears]: Staff, you should have me fully staffed, so you're never in that position.

[Bears]: The commission is an oversight authority.

[Bears]: They're not meant to be working.

[Bears]: And I just want to be working staff.

[Bears]: And basically, I just want to be really clear here.

[Bears]: When you basically cut the staff in half and then you try to backfill with volunteers or poll workers or temporary workers, it's not gonna work out.

[Bears]: And we were very clear about that from the get-go.

[Bears]: There's an election in 14 weeks.

[Bears]: There's an election in March.

[Bears]: There are four elections between the one we just had, including the one we just had in next November.

[Bears]: As the president just said, elections are more complicated than ever.

[Bears]: They're more frequent than ever.

[Bears]: They require more resources.

[Bears]: And instead, it seems that the choice was made that this was a place where we could find cuts and save money.

[Bears]: Now, I think we all know my position that the city budget is massively underfunded.

[Bears]: I don't think the place you start finding money is in the elections department.

[Bears]: When the council explicitly voted to modernize and fund the department because elections are getting more complicated,

[Bears]: and requiring more staff time and requiring more attention, not less.

[Bears]: So even if we get accountability, even if there's changes of whatever kind, even if we get a report that says, here's all the things that we did wrong and we're gonna do them better next time, it's not gonna get fixed unless the department is fully funded, staffed and staffed competently.

[Bears]: And that needs to happen.

[Bears]: So this council has been saying that the whole reason we tried to do this process was to get us there.

[Bears]: We did what was within our authority.

[Bears]: to make that happen.

[Bears]: And then, as President Morell said, the follow up wasn't there.

[Bears]: The actually funding and appropriating and implementing this modernization process fell flat.

[Bears]: And we're seeing the results this year, in addition to the November 2022 election, where there were some of the similar mistakes that we saw this year happened as well.

[Bears]: So, you know, all this council can do at this point is

[Bears]: put forward resolutions, and then, as Councilor Scarpelli said earlier, approve the appropriations when they come down, because if they had come down, I'm sure we would have held a special meeting to approve anything to get the additional surge resources in.

[Bears]: The call never came, and we don't have the authority to make appropriations.

[Bears]: So that side of things needs to be addressed as well.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Rick lost an election, she's not running again.

[Bears]: So it's not all of us have a personal financial interest.

[Bears]: Okay, so not all of us, sorry, thank you.

[Bears]: Motion to approve as amended.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Thank you guys for pulling this together.

[Bears]: I know

[Bears]: It has been a bumpy road with the state process, and I can appreciate that.

[Bears]: I just want to kind of put this in the context of the work that we're hopefully going to be talking about hiring someone to work with us very soon, since I think the procurement, the RFPs are due by Thursday, and I'm waiting for the second phase of our zoning work.

[Bears]: It's my understanding that this is what we need to get into compliance with the law by the deadline that the law requires us to be in compliance by.

[Bears]: But as we move through the process of looking at the zoning, we could potentially go more in depth on that area, additional changes, look at this district and potentially make adjustments to this district through that process.

[Bears]: I just wanna make sure that's correct and that's your understanding as well.

[Bears]: Arlington just passed theirs, I think.

[Bears]: Yeah, thank you.

[Bears]: And I just wanted to put that forward just to say that this is not the end all be all here.

[Bears]: And even though that this is what the law requires, that you've been thoughtful about making sure that what we actually want in that area is also still possible.

[Bears]: Madam President, motion to suspend the rules to take paper 23447.

[Bears]: April 23-447, November 9, 2023.

[Bears]: To the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council, Medford City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts, 02155, Carr Park Phase II Grant Resolution, dear President Morell, and members of the City Council, I am excited to share that the City has been awarded a $1 million Land and Water Conservation Fund grant.

[Bears]: You're going to?

[Bears]: For Phase 2 of the carpark renovation, the City has also been awarded $1.5 million in federal earmarked funding through the Department of Energy, with the support of Representative Clark.

[Bears]: Carpark Phase 2 consists of two subportions, deemed Phase 2a and Phase 2b.

[Bears]: The total cost of Phase 2a is $2,015,000 and was proposed to be funded by the LWCF grant and ARPA funding.

[Bears]: The LWCF grant requires that the City Council pass a resolution accepting the grant and acknowledging the dedication of the property as parkland.

[Bears]: The grant also requires that the full funding for projects be appropriated upon acceptance of the grant.

[Bears]: The enclosed drafted resolution addresses these requirements.

[Bears]: The grant will then reimburse a $1 million portion of the appropriation.

[Bears]: Phase 2B of the project has a total cost of $3 million.

[Bears]: The federal earmarked funding requires a one-to-one match of non-federal funding to the award.

[Bears]: Please note that LWCF is a federal grant program administered through the state and therefore cannot be used to match funds.

[Bears]: I respect the request and recommend that Phase 2B be funded with $1,385,000 in ARPA funds.

[Bears]: The City, spearheaded by Planning, Development and Sustainability, is exploring additional funding sources to complete the $115,000 deficit in funding.

[Bears]: There is significant community support for open space and recreation in Medford and the City's commitment to accessibility.

[Bears]: Broad community outreach has been performed to create inclusive, comprehensive vision for Carr Park, and there is a strong community passion and investment in the completion of this project.

[Bears]: In summary, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body adopt the enclosed resolution to accept the grant for phase 2A of the car park renovation and authorize a loan order request of $1 million to the project.

[Bears]: As stated in the resolutions, the LWCF grant will reimburse $1 million on the completion of the project.

[Bears]: In addition, I respectfully request and recommend that the total of $2.4 million in ARPA funding be allocated to phase 2 of the project.

[Bears]: $1,015,000 of which will go towards Phase 2A, and $1,385,000 of which will go towards Phase 2B.

[Bears]: The LWCF grant for Carr Park requires that a copy of a certified boat be sent to them by December 1st.

[Bears]: I hope that these requests have been submitted with sufficient time for the Council to review and meet this important deadline.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: Thank you to everybody who has shared their views on this matter.

[Bears]: Obviously, there's a lot of opinions and passion about it.

[Bears]: I have a few thoughts.

[Bears]: Number one, the biggest complaints seem to be about enforcement, whether that's traffic enforcement or parking enforcement or code enforcement.

[Bears]: we have received communications from parking staff saying that they really are imploring the mayor to increase the parking staff.

[Bears]: We've received, I think, recommendations from a couple of building commissioners and DPW directors in a row asking for more code enforcement staff.

[Bears]: And I'm sure that the police chief would say that he needs more support for traffic enforcement as well.

[Bears]: The City Council has zero authority to require enforcement of anything, zero authority to fund enforcement without the request of the mayor to fund those things, and I really strongly encourage, whether it's just related to this proposal or really anything you see in the city, to contact the mayor about those matters.

[Bears]: There's a couple things that we can do here.

[Bears]: Right now, we have a proposal in front of us for 11 to 1 a.m.

[Bears]: every day.

[Bears]: the petitioner could, after hearing this discussion today, maybe come up to the podium and suggest an alternative that might meet their purposes, but not be all 11 p.m.

[Bears]: to 1 a.m.

[Bears]: every day.

[Bears]: It could be maybe only till midnight, or only certain days of the week.

[Bears]: I'm not gonna define what the petitioner may or may not be willing to propose.

[Bears]: They've put something in front of us as written, and that's what we have to consider, unless they were to come up and say otherwise.

[Bears]: I think there's a reasonable accommodation that can be reached between all parties to address the issues that everybody's raised.

[Bears]: But in general, when we talk about setting a precedent, we already have

[Bears]: significant number of restaurants in this community that have permits to open from 11pm to 1am.

[Bears]: So the precedents already set that that is something that many, many, many restaurants have asked for and have been granted.

[Bears]: And I think for me as a Councilor, what I have to consider is

[Bears]: Is there a compelling reason that if many other restaurants have been given that, and they're not just in Medford Square, they're not just in certain places, they're really some are in places that their neighbors would also say are residential areas.

[Bears]: why can't this one be granted as well?

[Bears]: So that's what I'm gonna be considering tonight.

[Bears]: Certainly there are conditions that we could place on a permit if we were to approve it, like a 90 day review to get a report on noise complaints and code infractions and anything else that we have so that the questions that people have raised saying, well, this may happen if this permit is granted, we could actually collect that data, review it and consider the effects of this after a certain period of time.

[Bears]: That'd be certainly something I'm willing to entertain.

[Bears]: I'm going to pause there.

[Bears]: We could have the petitioner say that there may be an alternative that's not as expansive as this.

[Bears]: it'll go into effect after 45 days.

[Bears]: So it's not the same thing.

[Bears]: I understand that strikes are illegal in Massachusetts.

[Bears]: I'll stand that picket line with you every day.

[Bears]: So, you know, I know that's a really hard ask.

[Bears]: And that's why I but I no one's brought it up yet here before and all these conversations.

[Bears]: Nevermind just the contract issue but a million other things charter amendment path is one path, I'm trying to go down to balance things.

[Bears]: I think we try to advocate with with the mayor's office.

[Bears]: There's nothing in the law that we can stop really anything for any more time than 45 days.

[Bears]: But you guys could stop the whole city, because you're not just the face of it.

[Bears]: You're the feet of the city.

[Bears]: You're the people who actually do all the work every day.

[Bears]: And if suddenly the city came to a screeching halt, it would have a pretty big effect.

[Bears]: So I understand that's a really hard decision.

[Bears]: I'm not a member.

[Bears]: I wouldn't be voting on it.

[Bears]: But if you all voted to do it, I'd be with you.

[Bears]: I'll be quick, because that was probably a better ending than what I'm going to say.

[Bears]: And I'm not sure which one of us is worse, but maybe it's like a Jacqueline Hyde kind of thing.

[Bears]: And you can pick which one.

[Bears]: But two things here really, for me, they're just like really sick.

[Bears]: And again,

[Bears]: It's money and fear, right?

[Bears]: At a certain point, we have to say, how much is it going to cost to give you what you deserve?

[Bears]: If George is right and we're screwed, it doesn't change how much it's going to cost us to give you what you deserve.

[Bears]: It just means that we're not going to have as much money to do it, so we have to figure out how to raise that money.

[Bears]: maybe there is a bunch of money.

[Bears]: Maybe this free cash thing is a real thing.

[Bears]: And maybe, so maybe the money really is there, but there's fear to tell us what the situation is.

[Bears]: And then, and this is the part where I'm counseling Buzzkill, there's fear on the part of the mayor to say, okay, it's going to cost $5 million, right?

[Bears]: Like she's always talking about all these contracts.

[Bears]: We got to give everyone the same thing.

[Bears]: That's what equity looks like, blah, blah, blah, blah, blah.

[Bears]: Well, you're not getting what the teachers are getting, right?

[Bears]: And even in that contract, the lowest paid workers in the school system, the paraprofessionals, they figured out a way to make the job better and give them like a real market adjustment and pay significant, not 2%, like 20%, 25, 30% for the lowest paid workers.

[Bears]: So at the very least, let's use that as a model, right?

[Bears]: Let's say that's the baseline.

[Bears]: And for the lowest paid workers, can we give a real market rate adjustment?

[Bears]: Because I think we all know that 45, 50, 55,000 is not cutting it in Medford anymore.

[Bears]: But then the question is, right, like, okay, we really don't have the money right now.

[Bears]: Do we really think that the people of Medford wouldn't vote to raise money to pay the city workers fairly?

[Bears]: I don't.

[Bears]: And that's the fundamental question at the end of the day.

[Bears]: I hope we don't have to ask, but we have to be willing to ask.

[Bears]: That's just where I come down on it.

[Bears]: I know that maybe isn't the most popular thing to say all the time, but I cannot think of a better thing to fund with an override than giving you guys fair pay and benefits.

[Bears]: I don't think the solution, if we don't want to do that because we're afraid to ask, is to stonewall you and take away your longevity and take away your sick bank and take away whatever else.

[Bears]: you know, never going to get 100% agreement on anything.

[Bears]: But I think we're probably most reasonable people listening to say that the way these negotiations have been going is not fair.

[Bears]: And the answer here is, at the end of the day, it's a money question.

[Bears]: So how much is it going to cost?

[Bears]: And how are we going to pay for it?

[Bears]: And I just think if we could answer those, if the mayor could come up and answer those two questions?

[Bears]: Yeah, maybe it puts it back on the you know, I put it back on you, right?

[Bears]: I'm like, go on strike.

[Bears]: You know, that's really hard.

[Bears]: We can put it back on the voters too and say, hey, this is how much it costs to have fully staffed departments or at least better staffed departments where people get fair pay.

[Bears]: And that's kind of what I would like to see.

[Bears]: So maybe that's something we can squeeze out during this budget season is at least getting an answer, how much is it going to cost?

[Bears]: And then asking, why aren't we going to do the thing we need to do to pay for it?

[Bears]: So I hope we can get something.

[Bears]: But George said it at 6 p.m.

[Bears]: We're dejected.

[Bears]: I'm sure you're a million times more dejected than us, because you're here 40 hours a week and not 10 to 20 hours a week, and it's your family's pay on the line.

[Bears]: But we're dejected too, and it sucks.

[Bears]: So it's the worst kind of solidarity I can present, but I feel you.

[Bears]: and the Celtics are winning, so.

[Bears]: This is the one regarding changes to the charter regarding requiring council confirmation of appointees to the merit of municipal boards, committees, and commissions.

[Bears]: Hi, Paul.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: We did get a letter of official comment from the Charter Study Committee saying they were taking no position on these, and we entered that into the record.

[Bears]: We're actually going through two completely different processes.

[Bears]: This is Chapter 43B, Section 10, which allows targeted amendments that don't affect the scope of terms, terms of office, length of terms of office, number of people on any

[Bears]: you know, school committee or City Council.

[Bears]: This only allows changes to essentially the powers of the various municipal bodies.

[Bears]: This process is again targeted and can occur this year quickly and would go into effect in January 2024.

[Bears]: The Charter Study Committee appointed by the mayor is looking at

[Bears]: making recommendations that would be proposed to the council that would need to be enacted by the legislature through special act, and that would not happen until 2026 or 2028, but any recommendation by the Charter Study Committee could overrule or change these charter amendments.

[Bears]: they could propose to change these after, if they were to pass, they could propose to change them.

[Bears]: So we've been pretty clear in our, this is our fifth public meeting on the matter that these are two completely different processes.

[Bears]: And we were very intent on getting the direct input of the Charter Study Committee so as to avoid any confusion.

[Bears]: I think the point is well taken that there have been a lot of plans for Medford Square over the past 30 years.

[Bears]: I think we all know that the condition of Medford Square is basically a car-prioritized throughway between 93 and 16, makes it dangerous for pedestrians, bicyclists, drivers, and makes it incredibly uninviting for commercial activity.

[Bears]: It's not an inviting place to walk to.

[Bears]: It's not an inviting place to walk around.

[Bears]: And if you don't have that, you're not going to have the kind of

[Bears]: development and the kind of environment that we want to see development.

[Bears]: I think we can all agree that we've had many happy days when Clippership Drive or Riverside Ave is closed down and we can all walk around and have Oktoberfest or another event.

[Bears]: In any case, to me, this doesn't create any new revenue.

[Bears]: It doesn't create anything new.

[Bears]: It is, to me, essentially saying,

[Bears]: If we want new growth in Medford Square, we need to improve the infrastructure in Medford Square.

[Bears]: One of the main ways that we're going to do that is by working on the city-owned parking lots, which we've been looking to develop in a multitude of ways for a long time across multiple mayors and across multiple Medford Square plans.

[Bears]: And this is actually a way that we are going to prioritize setting aside the funding to actually make those investments.

[Bears]: And I think that that's important

[Bears]: investments in the water sewer infrastructure in the right away.

[Bears]: Um, with all due respect on the on the planning side of things, you know, Councilor Caraviello and I and dozens and hundreds and I think a certain thousands of men for residents were involved in the comprehensive planning process, um, to create the city comprehensive plan.

[Bears]: One of the major elements of the city comprehensive plan, which was finalized last year.

[Bears]: is this kind of development in Medford Square.

[Bears]: So, you know, having the questions answered about A, you know, if we find that the DIF is a tool that isn't working, we can dissolve it.

[Bears]: If we find that funds that are put into the DIF, we need to prioritize for general funding so that the council can make those votes.

[Bears]: It really, to me, is why not try?

[Bears]: Why not implement a tool that might actually get us where

[Bears]: many councils and many mayors have failed for many years in terms of actually investing in Medford Square.

[Bears]: So if it doesn't work.

[Bears]: it's been made very clear to me that we can dissolve the diff and we can, if we need, if we're looking at funds being tied up in our very tight and difficult budget seasons, we can move those funds back from the diff to the general fund.

[Bears]: So I think it's good to have a tool in law that actually focuses on making, focuses the city on making Medford Square a vibrant,

[Bears]: community hub that it has been in the past.

[Bears]: It certainly was before the construction of the highway and hopefully we can make it again.

[Bears]: in meetings around the comprehensive plan that included people who had a variety of different ideological and political backgrounds, different viewpoints on what development should look like.
