[Bears]: And then would all of you potentially be, you know, one of the questions here is the city sold land to the previous owner

[Bears]: you know, from what my review was pretty, I think it was about $80,000 for the lot, kind of under, because of the restrictions, understanding that, you know, if that lot were fully developed, well, I know it's difficult land.

[Bears]: I live on Fellsbury West up the street.

[Bears]: I know it's not, you know, flat land, 48,000 square feet or anything like that, but conceivably, especially given the value of,

[Bears]: land and housing today, someone could figure out a way to put quite a few number of units on that lot.

[Bears]: I know that's not what you're asking for here, but it could be conceivable down the road.

[Bears]: The restrictions were put on by the city in 2008 with that owner on the condition that there be one unit on a lot, one single family home.

[Bears]: Would there be a consideration to making the three units deed restricted permanently affordable potentially?

[Bears]: Yeah, I'm not a lawyer.

[Bears]: And I think on balance, the story and the explanation of why this would this request is coming before us certainly makes sense.

[Bears]: I guess just more my question is, and you know, feel free to just keep it as a bug in your ear.

[Bears]: And I'm sure there'll be a lot of other conversations with city departments and officials, but

[Bears]: I hear what you're saying, maybe they don't qualify for the affordability restriction now.

[Bears]: If it were possible to make it conditional that if the property were ever to be sold in the future, I don't know if it's possible to say that, put that condition on, that if there was a future sale that the units would be affordable after that point, something like that.

[Bears]: I think that would be...

[Bears]: hopefully a little more in line with the initial restriction while still fulfilling the purpose that the family would like to see.

[Bears]: So just want to put that in as an idea.

[Bears]: But other than that, I'll leave it as is and wait to hear from other councillors and from city staff.

[Bears]: Well, that, that goes back to my question is, is what, you know, what happens after the fact, uh, maybe attorney Everett, you could, um,

[Bears]: provide some guidance on that question.

[Bears]: Is it possible to amend the restriction so that upon sale of the property, the units would be permanently affordable units?

[Bears]: Is that possible?

[Bears]: Okay, because that's, you know, I think that would be something that I would be interested in, because I think, you know, there's one question of

[Bears]: you know, just adding housing stock generally, I think, you know, in this set of purposes, it makes sense, you know, to allow a change in this deed restriction to allow the three family to be built.

[Bears]: In the future, I think we would want the building to serve similar purposes, which would be to serve people who need that kind of supportive housing, right?

[Bears]: So that's what we're doing here for this family.

[Bears]: I think in the future, we'd want that to continue for a future owner.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Yeah, I mean, to be quite frank, the deed restriction, if we lift the deed restriction now, the deed restriction was put in place to protect the public interest relative to the sale of public land.

[Bears]: We now have a request to amend the deed restriction for a very compelling private interest.

[Bears]: I agree it's a very compelling private interest.

[Bears]: I think what we need to do is balance the public interest and the private interest to

[Bears]: achieve the outcome of the private request of the owner of the property without completely, without a significant reduction in the protection of the public interest that the deed restriction had.

[Bears]: I don't think that we tonight have the information that we need to do that.

[Bears]: I don't, I mean, you know, we're all, we're delaying everything else to talk to lawyers.

[Bears]: Maybe we should delay this one too.

[Bears]: Well, you know.

[Bears]: The deed restriction was put in place to protect the public interest.

[Bears]: The purpose of it was that this land was supposed to be for one single family home, and we're trying to change the deal here, right?

[Bears]: Now, there's a good reason to change the deal, but that was the deal.

[Bears]: And that's also the risk the private owner took when they purchased the property with the deed restriction on it.

[Bears]: So we should discuss that in good faith and in an open and honest way.

[Bears]: And if part of the discussion here is how do we have a good public interest outcome that also achieves the private outcome that the interested party wants, I think that's the best course of action.

[Bears]: I don't think that that is where we're going to end up if we just vote to accept the proposal without further discussion from the experts.

[Bears]: So I personally would ask for, I have a third idea.

[Bears]: There's three motions on the floor.

[Bears]: There's a motion to approve.

[Bears]: There's a motion to have committee of the whole.

[Bears]: the planning department, legal counsel for the city and legal counsel for the petitioner, sit and meet and see if there's an agreement that can be made that satisfies the interests of all parties involved.

[Bears]: And then we can discuss that proposal when it comes back before us.

[Bears]: So that's the motion that I'll put on the floor.

[Bears]: My motion was for council for the city, the planning department and council for the petitioner to meet to discuss the proposal and see if an agreement can be reached that could be presented to the council.

[Bears]: I guess, what's your timeline?

[Bears]: I'd be willing to pick a date certain, but I don't want to pick a date certain that doesn't work for everybody.

[Bears]: I just asked to do a bunch of work.

[Bears]: Could we ask director Hunt and attorney Everett what their timeline?

[Bears]: Sounds like it would work for all parties involved.

[Bears]: OK.

[Bears]: Meet to reach an agreement.

[Bears]: Yes, reach an agreement to present to the council and table to the date certain of October 24th.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I want to thank Councilor Scarpelli for bringing this forward.

[Bears]: Yeah, so basically, we received back comments from the Community Development Board on change A. They did suggest a substantive change, which is to, we had recommended that the, or we had initiated a proposal where the council would be the special permit granting authority for a number of

[Bears]: motor vehicle related uses and miscellaneous commercial uses, specifically in C1, C2 and I districts.

[Bears]: This is designed to prevent the further proliferation of motor vehicle repair shops and car yards in Mystic Ave area and other commercial areas of the city where we're looking at

[Bears]: other more significant uses than storage or repair of vehicles.

[Bears]: So I'll come back to that one, because the CD board recommendation is a significant change.

[Bears]: The second change is B, that's on page three.

[Bears]: The recodification, that language that we passed had an unintended consequence of making a lot of properties nonconforming, where you have a single parcel with multiple principal structures on the lot.

[Bears]: The CD board,

[Bears]: did suggest a language change just to specify the districts where that issue is occurring, SF1, SF2, and GR zoning, but otherwise they accepted the proposed change.

[Bears]: The third change is adding a second associate member to the Board of Appeals and clarifying term length.

[Bears]: We passed a zoning change in early 2022 that did this, but then we actually overruled it with the recodification.

[Bears]: So this is correcting us back to the language that we had passed for members appointments to the Board of Appeals and having a second associate member.

[Bears]: There were a number of unintended referrals for papers to the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: This is now the fourth one, number D.

[Bears]: of lack of clear language.

[Bears]: Basically a lot of these are we've had this new zoning recodification in place for now a little bit over a year, and the bodies that are going through it, the Zoning Board of Appeals and the Community Development Board are saying, here are some of the technical things that we think need to be updated.

[Bears]: But essentially, we're referring papers to the Community Development Board that never needed to go to them.

[Bears]: So there's a small technical change.

[Bears]: The CDB did not change.

[Bears]: Community Development Board recommendations don't change what we had proposed.

[Bears]: The fifth one is number E,

[Bears]: There was conflict between who is the special permit granting authority, and the Community Development Board recommended specific language to accomplish that objective.

[Bears]: Number six, F, the language that we passed in 2022 created an extra requirement for a special permit for inclusionary housing that's not necessary, and the Community Development Board accepted the language changes that we proposed for that.

[Bears]: G, the state agency that oversees housing changed its name this year from the Department of Housing and Community Development to the Executive Office of Housing and Livable Communities.

[Bears]: Our proposed change just updates all of those references in the zoning.

[Bears]: I think the CD board may have found one or two more.

[Bears]: They slightly changed the language, just to make it more clear, but basically the same thing.

[Bears]: And then a number of definitions were deleted from the zoning when we recodified it.

[Bears]: Several pages, I think it's pages 10 through, yeah, the whole rest of it, I think, 10 through 21, and the CD board,

[Bears]: agreed with all the ones that we included, and also found a couple other definitions that had been omitted from the recodification to include.

[Bears]: So essentially, that's the summary.

[Bears]: If we were to sever, I would recommend severing change A from changes B through G, or sorry, B through H.

[Bears]: question about the first change.

[Bears]: the Special Permit Granting Authority for a number of these uses, and the Community Development Board has recommended that they be the Special Permit Granting Authority instead, and I was just wondering if you guys could speak to the Community Development Board's reasoning or rationale behind that recommendation.

[Bears]: I don't know if Elliot wants to come up in a minute,

[Bears]: Just one of the reasons I put this on is that this was something that's been a priority for me since even before I was elected.

[Bears]: Short term rentals, you know, certainly have a

[Bears]: limited place, I think, in the housing world.

[Bears]: But what we're seeing is a proliferation of a lot of our housing stock being taken up by short-term rentals and being turned into profit centers.

[Bears]: And we passed a zoning ordinance last year that put significant restrictions on short-term rentals, required registration, required them to pay a registration fee, and also limited their use, where if there is not an owner-occupant in the unit,

[Bears]: And, you know, if there's an owner occupant renting out rooms, that's one thing, but if there's just a housing unit that's being taken off the long-term rental market and being used for short-term rentals, particularly where you basically have small hotels operating in our neighborhoods, unregulated, we ban that.

[Bears]: However, Airbnb and Vrbo have not stopped listing properties that are doing that.

[Bears]: We have had residents like Mr. Jockelson and others who have been reporting, you've probably seen them on various social media sites.

[Bears]: I think there was someone who had a hot tub in a tent in their backyard that they were putting down as a short term rental.

[Bears]: And that got immediately, you know, code enforcement went out they said that's, you can't do that and it wasn't allowed but

[Bears]: the limited code enforcement resources we have in the city really mean that it's on the residents to report these situations.

[Bears]: And even when they do report them, it takes some time to get some enforcement out there.

[Bears]: I really think that we should

[Bears]: be more proactive, I think we'd find a lot of rental units coming back onto the market that are currently being used as profit centers in this way, and that would help with our housing crisis.

[Bears]: So, the two things I'm asking for are that there be more resources and requirements provided to code enforcement so that they can do their job more effectively, but also I do know that thanks to to to Mr. Jopelson and others that

[Bears]: have informed me that other cities have had created direct liaison relationships with the major short term rental sites, which have allowed the city to report issues directly to them and have listings removed so that they can't be rented.

[Bears]: So I think both of those solutions need to be explored quickly and implemented so that our zoning ordinance is being followed by these folks who are breaking the law right now.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: since we don't regulate it, they're gonna do that.

[Bears]: branch.

[Bears]: And we are the legislative branch.

[Bears]: So it's

[Bears]: Yeah, it's just an incredibly frustrating situation to sit here and be trying to voice and engage and and work with residents to come up with to voice have hear residents voice in their concerns and difficulties and wanting to see the city become a better place.

[Bears]: In addition to, I agree that we do collect the property tax I would say the other thing that we as a city to effectively is this city council for the two terms that I've been on it has passed a lot of good ordinances.

[Bears]: We've done a lot of good legislating we passed the road and control ordinance we passed the zoning ordinance on short term rental, we've tried to pass things giving code enforcement clear authority we've passed are working closely to pass a new waste ordinance right.

[Bears]: And we passed all these ordinances, and the staffing isn't there or the, you know, for whatever reason.

[Bears]: the administration doesn't enforce those ordinances to the letter, and that is where the difficulty comes in, is we can pass the strongest and as many ordinances as we want, but if they don't get enforced by the mayor and her team, or the mayor doesn't come to us and say, I need more resources to enforce this ordinance, then we end up where we are, which is passing good ordinances that then don't get the follow-through that they need.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I'll just be fast.

[Bears]: We've been here so long and talked so long that I'm sure some folks have had to use the bathrooms at City Hall.

[Bears]: And I think that the bathrooms at City Hall are actually one of the best examples of how deeply underfunded the entire city is.

[Bears]: I don't think they've been updated since the building was built in 1937.

[Bears]: You know, it is not it is it is not a good experience for a resident to use the bathroom and city hall for any staff to use it, and I just bring it up because

[Bears]: On every single issue, all of the capital infrastructure that the city owns and manages, we have one of the worst water and sewer systems in the state.

[Bears]: We have roads and sidewalks that are in a state of disrepair, trees, you know, we have public buildings like this building that are needing massive renovation, and that's just the capital side.

[Bears]: You come to the operating side, and it's a massive underfunding of code enforcement, health sanitarians, rodent control and animal control, you know,

[Bears]: people to look at the ADA issues around the city, teachers.

[Bears]: basically everything that the city is doing, with the exception of a couple of things that have been highly prioritized, like public safety and emergency response, have been massively gutted over the last 40 years.

[Bears]: And, you know, if the plan is, hopefully there'll be enough, you know, we're gonna pass the zoning and new projects are coming in and that's great.

[Bears]: If the plan from the administration is fingers crossed in five to 10 years, the council zoning will bring in enough commercial development that maybe we'll start being able to fund things again.

[Bears]: It's just not acceptable.

[Bears]: So, you know, we talked about being a broken record we've I think brought up all the great broken record subjects tonight of all of our different priorities.

[Bears]: I'll bring up mine, which is the city needs more money to do its job the city does not have enough money to effectively staff, basic operations or maintain basic capital infrastructure.

[Bears]: And I don't think that new growth and waiting to do that is the plan, but I also agree with my fellow Councilors that in addition to that understanding, and those are just the numbers of the budget if you look at over the last 40 years, we're in an even worse position, because we're not

[Bears]: even using what we have to the best of its effectiveness.

[Bears]: So it is a double-edged sword.

[Bears]: It is both not having enough resources to do everything we need to do and not prioritizing the limited resources we have to be used to their most effective.

[Bears]: And I think that basically rules the day on almost every topic that comes before this council at every meeting that we have.

[Bears]: I'd like to propose a B paper to ask the clerk to compare the length of the captions to the length of the ordinance.

[Bears]: But I would also, that's a joke.

[Bears]: I'll move to refer to, do you have a preference of subcommittee, Councilor Knight?

[Bears]: Motion to refer to subcommittee on ordinances and rules.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I'll be as brief as I can.

[Bears]: The Tufts RAs went on a one-day strike last week, and I was happy to support them and this council also.

[Bears]: asked Tufts to recognize their union and instead Tufts forced an election, which lengthened the process by months.

[Bears]: And now we have the contract process lengthened by months.

[Bears]: So these folks don't have a fair contract when the new school year started.

[Bears]: But the bigger and more important point I wanna make about this is I spent four years working to bring together students and workers and community members and communities to hold universities accountable to treating everybody fairly.

[Bears]: And really the most important thing about that is

[Bears]: whether it's RAs or students on campus or residents in the neighborhood around Tufts who are not getting fair and equitable treatment by Tufts or Tufts is taking actions that negatively impact the community or the folks on campus, we're all in the same fight.

[Bears]: Tufts is a billion dollar institution, multi-billion dollar institution run by a small group of people who make decisions that a lot of people disagree with.

[Bears]: And we can all fight our fights with Tufts separately if we want, but we're actually stronger together.

[Bears]: So one of the reasons I think it's important for community members and the city council to support the Tufts RAs is because if we build that relationship, we can call on the Tufts RAs to support us in asking for and fighting for a bigger pilot.

[Bears]: And there was an interview today, the Tufts Daily interviewed the new president of Tufts, and

[Bears]: the student reporters were making that point too.

[Bears]: They said, well, what about the impact that Tufts has on the surrounding community?

[Bears]: And the president says, oh, we, you know, new president says that we try really hard.

[Bears]: And to give him fair credit, he seemed to be taking a better tone on it than I've heard in the past.

[Bears]: But he said, you know, we wanted to hear about this.

[Bears]: We want to try really hard to support this.

[Bears]: And the student pushed back.

[Bears]: So we have the narrative that we've been talking about by reaching out to Tufts students, reaching out and working with the workers on campus about the impact of Tufts on the communities and the neighborhoods that it lives in.

[Bears]: That message is breaking through.

[Bears]: And if we can all work together to hold Tufts accountable to do better, we have a much better shot than we do of doing it alone.

[Bears]: So that is the larger message and point of why it's important to build relationships and show solidarity like this, because what goes around comes around.

[Bears]: They're mistreating the RAs today.

[Bears]: that we mistreat in the neighborhood tomorrow and someone else the next day, and it's better off if we work together to fight that than if we do it alone.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Sure.

[Bears]: Just three things.

[Bears]: One, on Tufts, it's not about villain or hero.

[Bears]: their budgets $1.2 billion a year the city's budgets 200 million.

[Bears]: They have 2.4 billion in endowment we have 25 million in reserves, they're rich we're not, it's a problem.

[Bears]: I'll leave it there.

[Bears]: The second thing I'll say just on the union workers, I hear you, I understand the issues with the contracts that workers have here.

[Bears]: I know it's not a position that everyone back here wants to say, because it's technically a position of saying that there's an unjust law that public sector workers can't strike.

[Bears]: I support state-level legislation to let them strike.

[Bears]: And I said to workers that came up here, if you took a strike action, I would walk on the picket line with you.

[Bears]: I don't care if it's illegal or not illegal by state law.

[Bears]: It's a bad law.

[Bears]: And it means that bargaining goes on forever for 700, 800, 900 days with no timeline on it.

[Bears]: And the workers have no leverage, right?

[Bears]: The point of the union is that you have collective power and part of collective power is taking a job action.

[Bears]: I guarantee you if the firefighters in the community, which is an even bigger thing to go public safety, right?

[Bears]: The firefighters in the community went on strike for 12 hours.

[Bears]: Everyone in the city would lose their minds and they'd have a contract the next day.

[Bears]: I'm not saying that's the best policy in the world, but at the very least state law needs to change so that they don't sit for 700 days before a contract goes to arbitration.

[Bears]: So I just wanted to put that point out there that

[Bears]: You know, we support the workers to, there's a lot that needs to change around public sector bargaining.

[Bears]: Madam President, I found the records in order and I move approval on the records and all reports of committees.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I believe this is the sixth public meeting we've now had on these items.

[Bears]: These are three amendments proposed to the city charter that with the approval of the council and the approval of the mayor would be submitted to the voters in November for their approval.

[Bears]: This first amendment would provide the city council with the authority to employ staff for research and legal consulting as needed.

[Bears]: The second one would

[Bears]: create a better budget plan and better budget process for the city of Medford by setting a formal date by which the mayor would be required to submit the annual budget.

[Bears]: The City Council would also have a formal date by which it would have to approve or otherwise act on the mayor's budget proposal, and it would also allow the City Council to have a real role in the budget process by reallocating funds between line items.

[Bears]: Right now, the City Council can only approve a whole budget, reject a whole budget, or cut specific line items.

[Bears]: This would make the City Council a partner in the budget process.

[Bears]: But the city council could not increase the budget above the mayor's proposal.

[Bears]: So those are the three amendments of the third amendment sorry the third amendment would.

[Bears]: make appointees of the mayor to municipal boards, committees, and commissions created by city ordinance or by state law, subject to confirmation of the council.

[Bears]: Right now, the city council does not confirm any nominees to the boards, committees, and commissions that are created by ordinance or state law, unless otherwise required by the ordinance or by state law.

[Bears]: So those are the three.

[Bears]: I won't do the summary on the next two.

[Bears]: Save us some time on that.

[Bears]: Yes, the language reflects the motion from our May 9th meeting to incorporate the specific language changes from legal counsel.

[Bears]: And those were also, those changes are also in our packets this past weekend as a red line copy and were also sent out to Councilors about a month ago when they came in from Attorney Goldberg.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: This would actually create something that exists in several other communities, which is an advisory board to conduct such a study regularly and provide regular updates to make sure that the salaries offered to all municipal employees are competitive.

[Bears]: Just a quick summary this is we've discussed this many times now over the past three years and committee and subcommittee This is a proposal to create an affordable housing trust for the city of Medford.

[Bears]: This would create a trust of the provisions of state law where

[Bears]: City funds private funds etc could be pulled for the benefit of creating more affordable housing in the community.

[Bears]: This has been reported out of committee, just the latest updates.

[Bears]: Motion when this is reported on a committee in November was to request comments from Greater Boston Building Trades.

[Bears]: They have submitted a letter of comment through the Greater Boston Labor Council, which was included in our packets last week.

[Bears]: I also have distributed a short, there's two minor technical amendments that need to be made here.

[Bears]: I just caught a couple of typos when I was reading through the, well, caught a couple of typos and a couple of typos were brought to my attention looking through the ordinance on the agenda.

[Bears]: I'm happy to present them, but there's one in section 49-52, which the

[Bears]: Number four should be replaced with the remaining members.

[Bears]: It says the board shall be composed of seven members, but then it says one shall be the mayor.

[Bears]: One may be a member of the Community Preservation Committee.

[Bears]: And then it says four, that would only add up to six or maybe even five if the may of the Community Preservation Committee members considered.

[Bears]: So I just proposed a technical amendment to strike the number four and replace it with the words, the remaining members.

[Bears]: And then in section 49-54, subsection 11, just clarifying language here.

[Bears]: that we had put into the ordinance, just to explain that borrowed by the trust shall pledge any borrowing that pledges more than 70% of the cash assets of the trust for Park City Council approvals.

[Bears]: It was just a little bit confusing there.

[Bears]: And I talked that over with planning development and sustainability.

[Bears]: So I would move to amend

[Bears]: the ordinance to reflect those two technical amendments, which all Councilors should have and the clerk should have.

[Bears]: And I would also move to attach the letter of comment received from the Greater Boston Labor Council and require the trustees to incorporate the language provided by the Greater Boston Labor Council into the rules and regulations of the Affordable Housing Trust.

[Bears]: And so that would be the language that we received back regarding project labor agreements.

[Bears]: It clearly reads any borrowing by the trust that pledges, any borrowing by the trust pledging more than 75, 70% of the assets of the trust requires city council approval.

[Bears]: The change would be any borrowing by the trust that pledges more than 70% of the cash assets of the trust requires city council approval.

[Bears]: And I would propose those amendments and to approve the ordinance for first reading.

[Bears]: It may not be a full response.

[Bears]: It may say, this is the process you need to go through to get us to do this, or we don't do this, or whatever else it may be.

[Bears]: But I just wanted to put some timelines and a shock box on the whole thing, because I agree we need the right answer, but I also agree that we should try to move as fast as we can.

[Bears]: Does that make sense to everybody, the three folks who proposed motions?

[Bears]: Any members of the Council wish to speak, I'm happy to hear from them first.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: I respect my colleagues positions on this.

[Bears]: I think

[Bears]: There's been a number of issues.

[Bears]: I think that maybe the chain of events and the opinions are getting a little bit conflated, but I, again, I respect my fellow councilors positions.

[Bears]: To me, the way that this is presented tonight, it's very clear that a new position in the city does not exist until it is approved in the cap.

[Bears]: This is presented as a new position to be added to the cap, which did not exist prior to any action that we take on this.

[Bears]: We did receive legal advice from KP Law, a memorandum from KP Law around these issues, clearly delineating the requirements of Chapter 44, Section 33A.

[Bears]: And when it comes to creating a new position,

[Bears]: that requires four votes.

[Bears]: If it's something else, there's other requirements.

[Bears]: But this is, I think, to me, very similar to the senior planner position that was created by this council and amended to the CAF in late last year.

[Bears]: And I also think, and I'm just gonna say what I said at that meeting,

[Bears]: The work that we do here is a balancing of interests and a balancing of what's best for the city.

[Bears]: this person that the creation of a traffic and transportation director, and making sure that a person who fills that role has the multiple years of experience with the city that the person who would, you know, likely be taking the role has is essential, and we know that there are

[Bears]: not enough experts to fill too many open jobs.

[Bears]: I believe, I can't remember which one of us did it last time, but it was me.

[Bears]: You know, I think you made really great points.

[Bears]: Something that we did two years ago is we were able to look at assessor data at the City of Medford.

[Bears]: And if Tufts, just Tufts for example, was taxed at the same rate as

[Bears]: was taxed at all for property taxes.

[Bears]: They would pay $8 million a year in property taxes.

[Bears]: Now, this law would only require up to 25% of what they would nominally pay, so it would be about $2 million a year.

[Bears]: But I just want to say since we've had the discussions here tonight.

[Bears]: That's $2 million for sidewalk crew to support our firefighters to support all the emergency calls that go out to tops to support street and sidewalk infrastructure repairs in their area to support affordable housing in the area around the top neighborhood, and I'm just putting that out there to say.

[Bears]: I can understand why a nonprofit education or healthcare institution maybe shouldn't be treated the same as a for profit business, but I don't think the answer is that they should be treated, it should be 100% for one and 0% for the other.

[Bears]: And I also want to put out there to this isn't just about tops.

[Bears]: This is about all of the large nonprofit institutions, and whether or not they play pay pilot payments to the city tops for example while this legislation would allow basically up to $2 million.

[Bears]: If they paid normal private tax to be $8 million tops right now pays $450,000 to the city.

[Bears]: But other pilot agreements such as right across the street from this building, Harvard Vanguard used to pay a trace health whatever it is now.

[Bears]: They used to pay a pilot agreement and they pulled out of their power agreement unilaterally without any city engagement they no longer provide any.

[Bears]: pilot payment to the city.

[Bears]: Something I'm exploring actually is that Atrius Health was just bought up and is now a for-profit institution, so maybe they'll have to start paying.

[Bears]: But my point is to say that right now, the way that the current state law reads,

[Bears]: it's up to the discretion of the institution.

[Bears]: And that means that even if you have an agreement, the institution could pull out at any time and leave the city holding the bag.

[Bears]: And we're already holding the bag for all the services and needs in the areas around these large institutions that they're not paying their fair share for.

[Bears]: So I really hope

[Bears]: that the State House can do something to create a fair system where we're still understanding that these are nonprofit health and education institutions that should have some benefit, but that benefit shouldn't be all or nothing the way it is now.

[Bears]: And furthermore, just to drive home the point, this is for large property owners, the threshold, your property has to be worth, I believe, over $15 million to even be qualified under this suggested amendment.

[Bears]: Technically the city can, there is a process, the only process the state allows for a city to accept a private way as a public way is if the public way meets the standards of the state for a public way.

[Bears]: But the residents would have to collectively pool and pay to upgrade the private way to meet those standards.

[Bears]: before the city can legally accept the road as a public way.

[Bears]: So that's kind of the catch-22.

[Bears]: In terms of the public safety issue, we had the discussion on it.

[Bears]: The city, because there is public access to the private way, the city voluntarily provides certain public safety service, but it is voluntary.

[Bears]: The state of the city is technically under no legal obligation to provide them.

[Bears]: The police department has also had a number of meetings that are recorded about parking issues on private ways.

[Bears]: residents on private ways, as long as they have the agreement of all the butters and that's probably why he recommended looking at the real estate thing to see exactly who has the legal rights to the private way.

[Bears]: If everyone agrees you can put up speed bumps stop signs whatever you want, and the city can't say yes or no to that because it's a private way, but a lot of our private ways don't have sewerage systems drainage systems.

[Bears]: things of that nature, which are basic requirements under state law for acceptance of a private way as a public way.

[Bears]: You know, I'm not going to justify the response that you got.

[Bears]: I don't think it's right.

[Bears]: I'm not going to say that it's a fair thing that the way that private ways are treated relative to public ways.

[Bears]: but it goes beyond the city of Medford.

[Bears]: One of the reasons we have a lot of folks on public ways waiting 2, 3, 5, 10 years on sidewalk lists as well, it's because we have $100 million backlog and we have a report that says we need to spend $10 million a year, we spend $1 million a year, and there's not $9 million to cut somewhere else to fund roads and sidewalks.

[Bears]: I think if we had a large community conversation around private ways and we're willing to raise $50 million, $100 million to turn every private way up to code to bring it into a public way,

[Bears]: That would be a path forward but there's no path forward that doesn't cost either the butters a significant amount of money or the community is significant amount of money.

[Bears]: And that's the catch 22 or and so I do feel for you I think obviously if there's public safety issues the city should come out and try to address them but but state law says that the city doesn't actually have to and it's the responsibility of the private butters to handle.

[Bears]: Just really quickly, like again, I think

[Bears]: We all agree that this is a situation that the city doesn't benefit from it anyway, but I think the scale and scope is a little out of, you know, if we had if all the private ways in the city was became public ways, the state would send us like $400,000 more a year.

[Bears]: We'd be able to plant like three trees fix for sidewalk panels I mean it's, it's, it's, that's the issue, you know state hasn't doubled hasn't hasn't increased chapter 90 in years, the city's not putting really any money, you know when we talk about paying for services quite frankly city property tax money mostly doesn't go to roads and sidewalks.

[Bears]: mostly goes to everything else.

[Bears]: The only thing that's really going to road and sidewalks is chapter 90, which comes from the state, which is tax money to state tax money, but is 10 times less than the amount that we should be spending on roads and sidewalk repairs.

[Bears]: And I'm guessing now that I think about it more, that the road and sidewalk analysis is probably only for public ways.

[Bears]: So the number there that's 130 million may well be 200 million if you add the 30% of the city that's private ways.

[Bears]: You know, I think we brought up in that meeting with the DPW Commissioner, you know, look at our existing ordinance, what can it do?

[Bears]: It pretty much goes to the extent of state law and says the city, you know, we, the City Council absolutely authorizes the city administration to, to fund the programs that Councilor Caraviello was talking about.

[Bears]: We could strengthen that ordinance even more if the mayor doesn't appropriate money to that.

[Bears]: doesn't, you know, we don't even have legal authority to move money around to make or fund that, which is another fight that we're fighting.

[Bears]: And we're fighting about a capital needs assessment, so that we know the amount of needs so that we can say, okay, it is $200 million.

[Bears]: If we did this amount each year, it would take us 12 years to get to a state of good repair for everybody.

[Bears]: Or if it is 100 million to convert every private way to public ways, if we spent

[Bears]: you know, 8 million a year, we'll get there in 15 years.

[Bears]: And you know, those those are, that's what we need to do.

[Bears]: But those are the answers that we don't even have, like, not only we know the problem, we know, we'd like to fix it.

[Bears]: But the will to actually find the answer to the question, how much does it cost?

[Bears]: And how much do we need to invest over what period of time to achieve our goal to fix the problem?

[Bears]: We don't have that answer.

[Bears]: And that's the answer we need.

[Bears]: Then we can go to everybody in the city and say hey, we have this private ways problem, it'll cost $8 million a year, do we all think we should spend $8 million a year to fund that and we can actually have that kind of community conversation, but that's the real issue you know this council could pass the best ordinance in the world next week on this question, and it won't force any single hand to appropriate a single dime.

[Bears]: to match private money to fix private ways.

[Bears]: So until there's the willingness to like actually from the city administration side say okay, we fully acknowledge that we have this massive amount of capital need and operating need to effectively fund the city.

[Bears]: three years people have been able to stay on the program without re enrolling and meeting all those requirements so they may be at risk after this expires of losing their health insurance and not really being aware of it given that there hasn't been the ongoing education and programming needed on that.

[Bears]: This is the first of three.

[Bears]: proposals tonight on the council agenda relative to specific charter amendments to the city charter.

[Bears]: We first discussed this over a month ago and regular session and we had a committee of the whole meeting this month on the matter, and I really appreciated the thoughtful comments of all my colleagues

[Bears]: on this issue.

[Bears]: I think echoing what that Councilor Caraviello said our committee of the whole is that this really focuses on the city council around a purpose which is making sure that we have the authority that we need to conduct oversight and and also to make sure that we are having real voice and input and bringing the people's voice and input to the city budget.

[Bears]: I think I won't rehash everything that we've discussed in the past two times.

[Bears]: We've discussed this, but the city charter of the city of Medford, as acknowledged by many, many elected officials, including the mayor, is one of the strongest planning charters in the Commonwealth, which means that the mayor's office is incredibly strong and the council's powers are not so strong.

[Bears]: And this is one way that we can take action very quickly through some common sense measures to rectify that and make sure that the city council

[Bears]: not just should be a partner but must be a partner at the table.

[Bears]: When it comes to things like the city budget and appointments of members of boards and commissions and making sure that we have the legal advice that we need, which kind of came up tonight once again and it comes up pretty much every meeting that we have the legal advice and support that we need to make the best decisions possible.

[Bears]: on this and the other two proposals.

[Bears]: I'm going to motion that we schedule a public meeting of the ordinances and rules subcommittee and committee of the whole, um, per discretion of the council president to discuss these matters, and then that we also schedule a public hearing that is required by Chapter 43 B section 10 at our May 23rd regular meeting, and that will give enough time as notice is required for the city clerk to do the required notices for that.

[Bears]: So that's my proposal.

[Bears]: two more meetings on this where we can collect more public feedback and then a public hearing on May 23rd.

[Bears]: Then pursuant to the discussion, if there are any amendments to these proposed amendments, any changes to these proposed amendments, that can happen in that public hearing.

[Bears]: And then the Council and my fellow Councilors are at the discretion to vote on this, the process after that.

[Bears]: And I'll just go over this again, not to belabor the point,

[Bears]: it would require a two thirds vote of the City Council, the assent of the mayor, submission to the state attorney general for review, and then it would be voted on by the voters in our November election.

[Bears]: So, again, this is not just something that we can do on our own.

[Bears]: There's a lot of pieces of the process, the ideas, and with my hope to have everybody on board so that we can move forward and make sure that this council and the people that elect these councilors have the powers that we need to do our jobs effectively.

[Bears]: So thank you.

[Bears]: I was just going to say that, yes, there'd be a public hearing, but then it would need to be approved by the mayor, reviewed by the state attorney general, and then voted on by the voters on the ballot as a ballot question.

[Bears]: So it wouldn't just be the city council saying, this is what it is.

[Bears]: That certainly is not how the law works.

[Bears]: It would be the voters of the city approving a change.

[Bears]: And I just want to also add that this is not charter review.

[Bears]: These are specific amendments to address specific problems that we've seen.

[Bears]: There are portions of charters that exist in many other communities.

[Bears]: Charter review, which would look at everything, would look at ward representation, would look at

[Bears]: you know, a bunch of other things that would potentially write a completely new charter compared to the charter that we have now.

[Bears]: That's a separate process.

[Bears]: That's the thing you can get signatures to collect for.

[Bears]: That's where you can have a home rule petition at the State House to do a comprehensive review.

[Bears]: Most of the things that people talk about when they talk about charter review, you can't even do through this amendment process, which is very specific to the balance of powers.

[Bears]: You can't change mode of election, terms of election,

[Bears]: or the districts that people are elected from.

[Bears]: So this is much more targeted than a comprehensive charter review.

[Bears]: This is saying very specifically, we have seen what a disempowered council looks like, and that the council by charter does not have the powers that it needs to assert its authority as an independent branch of

[Bears]: the city government as to address the separation of powers, and this is specifically targeted at that.

[Bears]: These amendments wouldn't even give the city council unilateral discretion on any of this anyway.

[Bears]: It would just give us an equal share of voice in these questions.

[Bears]: So thank you for the comments, and I appreciate it.

[Bears]: I hope folks will come to public meetings and voice that, and we can do the education work, and we can also consider what voters are saying and residents are saying about these amendments over the next few weeks.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President, for reading that out loud.

[Bears]: our existing charter regarding appointments by the mayor to require city council approval of municipal boards, committees, and commissions.

[Bears]: Well, first, I just wanted to say to what Councilor Caraviellol was speaking earlier about free cash.

[Bears]: My understanding, at least from the revenue discussion that we had in the committee of the whole recently, is that the administration has been underestimating local receipts portion of revenue and over and

[Bears]: estimating at least highly the amount of expenses such that having done that there is now a significant surplus free cash, of course, is a horrible term for what it actually is, which is the reserves of the city is built up by surplus collection of tax revenue.

[Bears]: I believe Councilor Collins made an incredible point recently about a month ago talking about how.

[Bears]: that surplus and that balance of that surplus means that there are things whether that be collective bargaining agreements, or sidewalk repairs or the school funding or any of the many other things that we think need to be happening and should be happening urgently, that were not funded instead for that money to sit in the non interest bearing reserve account.

[Bears]: So we have that money.

[Bears]: It's more than any bond agency says we need to have in reserves.

[Bears]: So when I talk about a scarcity mindset, and what we're talking about with the schools, right, they were talking about needing about 74 million and they suggested appropriations gonna come as about 71.8 million, so that's $2.2 million.

[Bears]: That could come from this pool of money, which is essentially money that could have been in the budget, instead was not in the budget, went to a surplus fund.

[Bears]: You know, and may have also played into last year's discussions around structural deficits as well that maybe we're actually smaller than we thought because there's this surplus tax revenue.

[Bears]: We have answers to those questions and answers to the process and fixes to the process and staffing and resources in that department.

[Bears]: And number two, when mistakes happen, which in any human endeavor is inevitable that there will be things that go wrong.

[Bears]: the public is made aware and the candidates are made aware right away.

[Bears]: I think that's really the most important thing.

[Bears]: We want you to know

[Bears]: how we tried to address it, or who we brought in to help address it.

[Bears]: And that has to be how our elections offices operate, right?

[Bears]: If there is an issue, you get the word out right away.

[Bears]: The operating procedure can't be that if there's an issue, you try to fix it without anyone noticing, because that just does not bring trust.

[Bears]: you know, 20%, which is good.

[Bears]: Thank you Madam President, yeah I mean I think at the end of the day we're talking about redesigning roads that were designed before the modern science of road design that we have today and we know that tighter turns closer to 90 degrees and narrower lanes inherently slow and calm traffic and I understand hey I drive everywhere I'm not Justin I'm not taking the bus I'm not walking everywhere I drive everywhere, and I park everywhere.

[Bears]: I'm going to drive a little slower, you know, I don't like to walk very far, you know, people can make whatever jokes they want to make about the whole thing.

[Bears]: I'm, I'm tied to my car.

[Bears]: So don't, don't take me as the one who's, you know, not car dependent or wants to be car-free.

[Bears]: I like my car.

[Bears]: I enjoy driving it and I will likely be driving a car for a very long time.

[Bears]: And I know there are people are going to be mad at me for saying that, but it's how I live my life.

[Bears]: That being said, if I have to drive a little bit slower because it's safer, you know,

[Bears]: for everyone else in the street and for me and my vehicle.

[Bears]: I think people know that the issue of car safety is important to me.

[Bears]: I had a close friend who was killed because she was walking her bike on a street that didn't have proper infrastructure, didn't have curbing, didn't have lights and wasn't painted correctly.

[Bears]: And if that infrastructure had been there, I'd have my best friend.

[Bears]: That's how I think about this issue.

[Bears]: That's how I think about these issues.

[Bears]: I get it.

[Bears]: Sometimes it's frustrating to be driving a little slower.

[Bears]: Sometimes I'm frustrated sitting in a no turn on red sign that I used to take a turn on red.

[Bears]: But at the end of the day, I, as a driver, am not going to live the rest of my life

[Bears]: knowing that I had been in a, you know, situation.

[Bears]: If I'm going 25 and someone lives versus I'm going 35 and someone dies because I didn't see them or whatever reason, I don't have to live with that.

[Bears]: The family of the person doesn't have to live with not having somebody.

[Bears]: And we all don't have to live with the fear of that happening to us on either end of it.

[Bears]: And that's how I think about these issues.

[Bears]: I'd like it to be permanent curbing.

[Bears]: I'd like it to look a lot nicer.

[Bears]: I agree with that.

[Bears]: I think everyone knows my position on what public utilities should be paying these companies that are taking billions of dollars of profits from the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and sending it to the Netherlands every year, instead of investing it in curb cuts and beautification of our communities.

[Bears]: it wasn't in the scope.

[Bears]: I actually may have misspoke.

[Bears]: I actually don't know if that mitigation agreement was under Mayor Burke or Mayor McGlynn, so I just want to put that out there.

[Bears]: I may have not had my facts straight on that one.

[Bears]: Clearly, doing this the way that we would like to do it wasn't in there.

[Bears]: And I think if you look at, I think it was Director Blake's communication about the complete streets, this was like number 19 on the list.

[Bears]: I think we've only gotten through four of the dozens of intersections that need these kind of treatments.

[Bears]: have paint, we have the temporary barriers, we're going to be able to use them as a pilot program to test what the geometry of this intersection should look like.

[Bears]: And then, not to be the broken record again, we need to find the funding to do these kinds of projects.

[Bears]: We need to have funding, not just for the repairing and bringing streets and sidewalks in their existing condition to a state of good repair, but also

[Bears]: funding complete streets projects and safer intersections and intersections that are accessible to people with disabilities and that are multimodal.

[Bears]: And that sadly will mean that I get to drive five miles an hour less than I usually do and take two minutes longer to get to where I want to go.

[Bears]: But at the end of the day, I don't think the issue, at least for me, it seems the issue for most people is not with the substance, with the concept, it's with the execution.

[Bears]: As much of that as we want to push on Eversource or ask about that being about the engineer or the traffic and transportation director, I do really think the other piece of that equation is the money.

[Bears]: And we know that Haines Square and Tufts Square cost in the hundreds of thousands of dollars nearing millions of dollars to do similar things.

[Bears]: So if we want to do these kind of more permanent treatments, we're going to have to pay for them.

[Bears]: Madam President, would you like me to suspend for, I can summarize?

[Bears]: Aye.

[Bears]: So something that council leadership, President Morell and I have been looking at

[Bears]: with the city clerk over the past few months, going back to last fall is the meeting and agenda management software right now.

[Bears]: We had the system from IQM2 that was installed in 207 and 201.

[Bears]: That system is not really being used, obviously, since the pandemic.

[Bears]: We were still signed up for a contract up until last fall that was costing some funds.

[Bears]: And given the hybrid meetings that are now in our rules, given the setup of this chamber, given that Medford Community Media and the city administration have said that both 201 and 207 should also, at least at some point, be made

[Bears]: available for those hybrid meetings.

[Bears]: That software really was deprecated.

[Bears]: It was not useful software.

[Bears]: The camera technology is not compatible with the hybrid meetings that we use now, et cetera.

[Bears]: In addition, it just is not great agenda software in terms of accessing information.

[Bears]: So given that we weren't using it, hadn't used it for multiple years, we moved away from that system.

[Bears]: The clerk and myself and the president have been looking at

[Bears]: other potential meeting and agenda management systems.

[Bears]: And we ended up finding that the company, the vendor that provides MuniCode also provides a system called Civic Clerk.

[Bears]: which will allow for agenda and meeting management software to be significantly improved, to have all packet materials and agendas provided through the system, you can track resolutions through the system, as well as it, you can even use it during the meetings itself to put up information on the on the screen and directly connect your agenda and documents into your meeting.

[Bears]: that's actually going to cost less than half of what the prior software was costing.

[Bears]: So really, just implementing this is going to streamline a bunch of different work that the clerk's office does right now, you know, in spreadsheets or on Word documents or in agenda postings on the city website into one software service.

[Bears]: And part of what we've looked at also includes the training necessary so that all people involved will have the training they need to get up to speed on the software.

[Bears]: So it is a

[Bears]: will be a real improvement, I believe, for the clerk's office, although I wouldn't ask the clerk to speak to it, but in our conversations, he's been really excited and thinking that it will really improve the workflow on this meeting and agenda work in his office.

[Bears]: And he's nodding yes for those who can't see.

[Bears]: And it's less than what we're spending now, and it's already in the budget because it was a software, it's replacing a software that we were using in the past that we haven't used since 2020.

[Bears]: So that's my general summary and happy to

[Bears]: answer any questions having been in the process.

[Bears]: just two other quick things that I forgot.

[Bears]: This is also going to integrate directly with Muni code.

[Bears]: So meeting records and documentation will seamlessly move forward instead of having to go through an upload process and all of that burden.

[Bears]: And there's the least as far as I know, and we'll see through the implementation process, it may be possible for other boards and commissions to use the software as well.

[Bears]: So you'd be able to access other public meeting information and agendas through this as well.

[Bears]: But that's

[Bears]: We're focusing on the council first, but hopefully if possible, and it's just already built in, then maybe we can make it available to boards and commissions as well.

[Bears]: I mean, potentially, I don't know.

[Bears]: we're gonna try to get the software implemented for the council and see what kind of availability is there, but also I think it would be up to them and to any board and commission if they wanna stick with what they're using now or the process that they have now versus using this software or not.

[Bears]: And it is coming out of, is it technically coming out of the clerk's budget or the council budget?

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: And these were the pesticides that killed that bald eagle.

[Bears]: And I know a lot of folks were obviously distraught about that specific case, but it's not, you know, this is a statewide issue.

[Bears]: That's why there's a statewide bill.

[Bears]: It's also a state law

[Bears]: regulates this.

[Bears]: So it's not like Medford can say, we won't let you use this type of pesticide here.

[Bears]: It really has to happen through the state.

[Bears]: One person who I communicated with a little bit about this was our animal control officer, Pat Hogan, who was especially distraught at this happening and losing such an amazing animal to something like this.

[Bears]: Basically what happened is a rat ate some rodenticide and it

[Bears]: The eagle ate the rat and the eagle died.

[Bears]: And there are alternatives that are not this kind of anti-coagulant as far as I understand, no expert, but alternatives to this option that are not going to cause such detrimental impacts up the food chain when we're talking about rat control and rodent control.

[Bears]: So he was one person I talked to, I said, hey, I'll put a resolution on it.

[Bears]: And he said, thanks, because he had put out a call asking people to call their lawmakers about this bill.

[Bears]: And there's several other folks from many communities who've had incidents like the one that we had, who are also hoping that this law will change and that this will not be something that our animal control and other folks have to deal with on a regular basis anymore.

[Bears]: Yeah, I mean, it flows right from the last conversation.

[Bears]: Really what I intend with this proposal is that we've seen how the process is broken.

[Bears]: We've seen this question of feeling respected, feeling included within the process.

[Bears]: And we've seen over the past couple of years what it's taken for us to force the conversations that we need to have.

[Bears]: I don't think any of us were

[Bears]: know, just barely four of us were comfortable with what happened in the last budget meeting last June, right?

[Bears]: And I respect my colleagues who didn't want to go down that path, because that's not how government should operate, right?

[Bears]: It should never have gotten to that point.

[Bears]: It should never have been 1.30 in the morning.

[Bears]: It should never have been

[Bears]: we have to say this is gonna be a cut or we won't approve or put us into a period of uncertainty because we didn't have the information that we needed, residents didn't have the information that we needed, and we didn't have the good faith collaborative process that quite frankly, the city deserves.

[Bears]: And this is really calling the question, I mean, my thoughts here are, you know, I have thoughts I want to meet in committee of the whole to really outline what this would look like.

[Bears]: But there's these are the big three things for me that really I think will hit on a lot of the complaints and frustrations that we have voiced right here in this meeting and that we've voiced pretty much every meeting because I think we all share them.

[Bears]: a budget process where the council actually has real authority.

[Bears]: Right now, we are the final vote, quote unquote, but all we can do is approve, reject or cut.

[Bears]: We can't adjust, we can't amend, we can't say, you know, we really think that this priority is essential and it needs to be funded.

[Bears]: And instead we were in the situation we were in where it was cutting some sort of deal.

[Bears]: That's not how it should be.

[Bears]: We should be able to say, hey, we need 50,000 for zoning.

[Bears]: We're amending the budget to put 50,000 for zoning.

[Bears]: We need legal counsel.

[Bears]: Well, maybe we'll put that in the budget directly, you know, and quite frankly, other cities have this, other cities have implemented it recently.

[Bears]: you know, it's not like we're, you know, the city council's going and moving around 10 2030% of the budget, it's still on the margins, it's still, you know, a few hundred thousand dollars and like less than 5%, or even less than 1% of a budget.

[Bears]: But those priorities and really being heard.

[Bears]: If we want to, if we want to have that respect, we need that power.

[Bears]: And that, you know, means going through the discussion of what that what that would look like.

[Bears]: The two other things that I put in here are two other things directly related to that one is

[Bears]: this question about boards and commissions.

[Bears]: As we all know, we only approve a certain small number of boards and commissions.

[Bears]: We've been trying to put into the ordinances more recently, adding, you know, confirmation.

[Bears]: But I really think that moving towards a real collaborative process where

[Bears]: There really is a public process for who gets appointed to what boards and commissions and this council is consulted is another valuable change in power that needs to happen.

[Bears]: And finally, this third question around the direct hiring of staff to support the city council.

[Bears]: And to me, that could mean a lot of things.

[Bears]: I think having the authority to make that decision on our own is important, but specifically I'm thinking legal counsel, you know, sometimes I don't like to say it, but sometimes I, you know, Adam Knight was right.

[Bears]: And here we are in... It's in the record.

[Bears]: But seriously, I'm as frustrated, I think, as you are, that we're sitting here on March 21st of this year, after June 28th of last year, and there's no one working in the city solicitor's office.

[Bears]: Now, there's a million potential explanations for why that is, but I'd like to give us, maybe people would wanna work for us.

[Bears]: maybe that's a difference of opinion.

[Bears]: And we don't know that, maybe I'm wrong, but I'd like to at least try it.

[Bears]: A lot of other communities have multiple clerks working for councils, have a separate legal council working for city councils.

[Bears]: These are not crazy ideas, they are just things that we would need to change.

[Bears]: The process for us doing that, again, I think we should really look at it and have this committee of the whole, that's why I'm proposing this, but the process for that, and I think focusing on a small number of things makes the most sense here,

[Bears]: is we have the authority under state law to put forward discrete amendments to the city charter.

[Bears]: Not a full charter review, not addressing representation or ward representation or who serves on the council, but specific targeted amendments to the charter to make sure that the balance of power is really fair in this community and that this council has the teeth to demand respect.

[Bears]: and to demand a part in the process because it's in the charter and not just because, you know, we have one vote that we can hold up or something else.

[Bears]: I don't disagree that there are other strategies that we need to do in the interim, but to me, how this would look is let's all sit down.

[Bears]: If we can all agree, or at least most of us, you know, five, six or seven of us can agree on some language, we can suggest that.

[Bears]: We can recommend it to be put forward to the voters to decide if they think that this balance of power would work.

[Bears]: That can go forward if the mayor says it goes forward she can be a part of that I mean obviously she can block it if she wants but if, again, all seven of us agree on that.

[Bears]: I'd like the voters to make that choice.

[Bears]: I'd like the people to make that choice.

[Bears]: And the other fallback position, I have thought this out a little bit.

[Bears]: We as a council have unilateral authority to put non-binding ballot questions on the ballot.

[Bears]: So if the mayor chooses that she doesn't want to put forward these amendments to the voters, if we agree on something that we would all like to put forward to the voters, we could put it on as a non-binding question in November, see what the people think, and then go back to the mayor after that and say, hey, 70% of the city thinks this is a good idea.

[Bears]: You really want to stand in the way?

[Bears]: in any case, or to whomever is the mayor in January.

[Bears]: But I just think these are common sense ways where not just today, not just last year, this year, next year, but for a long time, we can make sure that the Medford City Council, while still maintaining the form of government we have, has those tools that we don't have right now under the charter to do our job and do what residents want us to do.

[Bears]: So that's my thought here.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President, I just want to I want to speak to what all my colleagues have a specific accounts to Scarpelli's points earlier I mean, you know, I do think we all share the frustration we may all express it differently and that's that is what it is but but I do think we share it.

[Bears]: And I think to Councilor Caraviello's point.

[Bears]: shouldn't have to put this in the charter.

[Bears]: To me it's it's it's bad politics to not just do this.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: I mean it hasn't worked out that way, apparently, but you know, keep some money aside, so that council priorities can be considered in the budget process, give the council some time to consider the process give enough time to have a good process, say to the council are there staff and supports that you need that will provide and you don't have to leverage to get it.

[Bears]: Give the council

[Bears]: you know, time and consideration and an actual packet of information when you're appointing someone to a board and commission so we can review it and approve it.

[Bears]: I mean, it's not just Somerville, it's like every other city in the Commonwealth that does this this way.

[Bears]: And I think, again, just on a pure politics, it's like, while you're not doing it, you're just taking an L for no reason.

[Bears]: And that I don't get at all.

[Bears]: So, you know, if suddenly there's a policy to just start doing all of this without changing the charter,

[Bears]: I'm all for it.

[Bears]: That's a lot easier.

[Bears]: It's a lot less time that I'm going to go around all fall hopefully saying to everyone I talked to is voting, hey, this is a reasonable thing that this council needs to be a fair partner in government, please vote for it because it's just like basic governance and due diligence for a community.

[Bears]: You know, what I rather spend my time actually doing the process and doing the thing.

[Bears]: Absolutely.

[Bears]: But again, I think really it would comes down to the only reason to not do this as you maintain power to control power to withhold power to stall power to hide, and that's where Councilors got placed point comes in, you know, when we don't have the information that we want.

[Bears]: And I can hear you that an answer to you feels like we just shouldn't do these things because we're giving them what they want and we're not getting what we want.

[Bears]: And I hear that, you know, on principle, I probably agree with that.

[Bears]: It's just, then I go and I hear, well, we're gonna lose this person and this person and this person, or, you know, I hear directly from Tim or Chief Friedman, like, these are essential needs that we have now.

[Bears]: It's gonna take three years to get a fire truck, you know, from the producer.

[Bears]: And it's like, so can we hold off and wait on that?

[Bears]: I don't wanna be the person saying no.

[Bears]: And I think that's really the key thing.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: It's what are the expectations of the people.

[Bears]: who are purchasing properties.

[Bears]: I mean, obviously you have people who live on the properties as Councilor Caraviello said for a very long time.

[Bears]: And that's one thing, but as properties turn over, I think it's important for residents or future residents who are purchasing those properties to understand that you're not getting the same level of service that you're getting on a public way.

[Bears]: And I understand the argument, everyone pays the same taxes, everyone should get the same thing.

[Bears]: I live on a state road, right?

[Bears]: There's a lot of state roads in the city where we don't get the same level of service or comparable services as people on city roads.

[Bears]: I actually have a specific gripe about big sweep that I'm going to come to you with later, which is.

[Bears]: My zone and the DCR zone keep getting scheduled at the same time in the fall, so there's nowhere to park anywhere.

[Bears]: And it's not just for me, but for the whole neighborhood, because I know the main idea of it is we don't do the main roads, we're doing the side roads, so people can move to the main roads and then move back.

[Bears]: But I think that's just a great example of there are disparate levels of service because of who has jurisdiction over certain ways.

[Bears]: And there's basically three levels of jurisdiction.

[Bears]: There's a lot of city-controlled public ways.

[Bears]: There are state-controlled public ways.

[Bears]: And then there are private ways, which are, as our attorneys have noted, controlled by the abutters of those ways, the people who live on those ways.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President.

[Bears]: Just in terms of the cost, I just, you know, since we talked about this last October, I want to just bring it up.

[Bears]: I think we're talking at least a couple miles of private ways in terms of length, but I think the number that we talked about was if not tens of millions, hundreds of millions of dollars would be needed to bring all the private ways up to the state necessary to be accepted by the public.

[Bears]: You know, I think, too, in terms of things that could maybe go and I don't want to overload now this website that, you know, will eventually be created this page on the website.

[Bears]: But I think also some sort of link to this is how you can organize your neighbors to try to bring your

[Bears]: street up to the level, you know, if they want to spend the money so that they don't have to be responsible for it in the future, it seems like that may be the direction that maybe some folks are going.

[Bears]: I don't know if you'd ever get everybody on the street to agree, but it does seem like, given all of the discussion around this, that it could be possible for residents to organize themselves and pitch in the money to

[Bears]: bring streets up to the standard to be accepted.

[Bears]: And then once we accepted them, then they would be public ways and then they would be streets that would be invested in by with public money.

[Bears]: But I think that that kind of.

[Bears]: resource, just making sure that resource is available would be good.

[Bears]: But even just those three bullet points that you just said, right?

[Bears]: If you want to do this, you're going to need to organize your neighbors.

[Bears]: You're going to probably need an attorney.

[Bears]: You're going to need to raise funds.

[Bears]: I think just making it clear what the process is, if folks ever want to go down that road.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: And speaking of that, I think I have a question for Attorneys Everett and Stein, which is just how does the subdivision control law, or I don't know the exact term,

[Bears]: play into what the city can do?

[Bears]: Because it seems to me that there, you know, in certain neighborhoods, there were a lot of subdivisions and that's why a lot of our private ways were created.

[Bears]: And I was just wondering if that plays any specific legal role differently than the parts of mass general law that we've already talked about.

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: On that front, does the city have the ability to require that private ways built through the subdivision process be built to the standard that they could be accepted as public ways?

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: That makes sense.

[Bears]: I mean, it, there's not much land left to be subdivided.

[Bears]: So I don't think it's going to be a huge problem, but it does.

[Bears]: And it sounds to me, Tim, like you're saying that the subdivision rules and regulations meet the standards for acceptance for the public way.

[Bears]: Right, but we're not allowing people to subdivide and build substandard private ways at this point.

[Bears]: Okay, great.

[Bears]: Because I just think, you know, obviously the last thing we want to be doing is compounding the mistakes that have, you know, not that it's the mistakes of any of us, it's mostly mistakes made by people who made choices 100 or 50 years ago.

[Bears]: We certainly don't want to keep doing it.

[Bears]: the contracts and we can't, by all the times that we've tried and all the ways that we've tried, have had no impact on the negotiations.

[Bears]: And when the decision or the question is before us to tell people they're not going to get raises because other people didn't get raises, or effectively shut down the city because people didn't get raises, I have to weigh the harm of that too.

[Bears]: And when I know that those decisions are going to be incredibly harmful, and we're not going to get anything anyway, because we're just going to get waited out,

[Bears]: I have to try to find something that's gonna improve the process in the future because better or worse, it seems that this is how it's been going for four years and the voters could make the same choice again.

[Bears]: And so it's an incredibly difficult position.

[Bears]: I work in labor every day.

[Bears]: I work in an organization where I've worked for years.

[Bears]: I've been a union member.

[Bears]: I have never seen a negotiation go this long.

[Bears]: I've advocated for changes to state law to basically put a shot clock on public sector negotiations because they shouldn't be allowed to drag out this long.

[Bears]: And I'm a supporter of the public employee right to strike because I think that's a way to force people to the table when you don't feel like they're negotiating in good faith.

[Bears]: All I know here is that when we say no to stuff about, because it's about the labor relations piece of things, it doesn't impact the negotiations.

[Bears]: And so that's how I think about these things.

[Bears]: so that voters are informed and educated about what the budget looks like.

[Bears]: So I'm taking a different strategy.

[Bears]: repeat an ineffective strategy because it may make us feel better that we said no and stood up to something, but if we still get nothing at the end and somebody else gets hurt, it's just not, that's not fair either.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President, through extensive discussions between the mayor and council leadership, I believe we were able to reach an agreement that makes progress on our goal for a better budget process and enables us to move forward and create a plan to fix the city's biggest challenges.

[Bears]: Thanks to that agreement, I'm able to move ahead and support the fiscal 24 budget as amended to include increases to the schools library and zoning reform.

[Bears]: We received commitments to create a financial task force with city council members, school committee members and city staff to make a plan to fund the city's major challenges to establish a better budget process based on clear principles of having budget meetings starting in January and February.

[Bears]: A process for the council to submit recommendations to the mayor and receive responses from the mayor prior to the budget being submitted by the mayor, as well as to conduct comprehensive assessments of our operating and capital budget needs.

[Bears]: We also agreed to explore the use of one time funds for budget planning for assessing our staffing needs and our capital needs.

[Bears]: And we also agreed to continue discussions to advance the charter amendments approved by this council in some form.

[Bears]: I think this agreement leaves much work to do, and I plan to work in good faith to implement it, because I truly believe that if we can get this done, we can build a better future that everyone in our city deserves.

[Bears]: That's all I'm going to say.
