[Bears]: Could one of you just say that the numbers that for actual expenditures in ClearGov, they are not updated regularly and not correct the correct numbers in ClearGov for the actual expenditures for several of the recent fiscal years?

[Bears]: Again, on all of this, like, I think this goes back to what we were talking about at the beginning of this process and what we've talked about with your office, which is like your staffs running around you.

[Bears]: So one of the reasons we wanted that money for budget planning and it's one reason I'm glad we're going to explore it, and what we've discussed because it seems to me there just wasn't enough time to get the right figures into clear gov about actual expenditures.

[Bears]: And that that seems to be the issue or that this clear gov system didn't make it easy enough to do it and it wasn't a priority.

[Bears]: And I think that's created an information gap here where people think one thing and it's not the real numbers because numbers were put out that are not the correct numbers for whatever reason, either capacity or the technology itself.

[Bears]: And I think you know something for me, it would be really good to make sure that

[Bears]: We update the clear gov budgets to have the correct actuals that we have up to date for prior fiscal years for the end of fiscal 23, and then we go into fiscal 24 there's a clear note on there somewhere that says, FY 24 actuals are not complete because the year is not complete yet and we will update them after June 30, because there's this information that went out.

[Bears]: that was not complete and not accurate.

[Bears]: And it's created a disagreement here about what the actual numbers are.

[Bears]: Now, I've gotten other versions of actuals from you guys in different documents.

[Bears]: So I know that's how I knew what was in ClearGov was not the actual actuals.

[Bears]: It's not the actuals from the ACFR.

[Bears]: It's not the actuals from the actual spreadsheets that you've sent over.

[Bears]: So I know ClearGov is not a reliable source for those pieces of information.

[Bears]: So, again, I just think that's something going forward that we wouldn't have had just 3540 minutes of confusion and debate about what the city has actually spent over the last three fiscal years if numbers hadn't been released that were not the correct numbers, and so I just wanted to say that, for the record, on the rest of this I've already made my motion, which is I think we've discussed this, if there are further questions, you know, clearly there was not enough of a supermajority to support the motion and debate but I'm voting on voting.

[Bears]: my concerns about the future are very real.

[Bears]: I want to talk a little bit about why we're here.

[Bears]: We're here because we see the impact of chronic underfunding around all of us, all around us every day.

[Bears]: Kids without the resources they need to thrive.

[Bears]: Schools in desperate need of maintenance.

[Bears]: Teachers and paras who aren't paid enough.

[Bears]: Not enough teachers and paras and staff in the first place.

[Bears]: Streets and sidewalks in such bad shape that people are getting hurt and everyone's cars constantly need repairs.

[Bears]: A 60-year-old fire headquarters without the proper living quarters and gear storage to keep our firefighters safe.

[Bears]: Not only do we see it, the numbers lay it out.

[Bears]: We're the fifth lowest in per capita spending of the 97 cities and towns with more than 20,000 people in Massachusetts.

[Bears]: 92nd out of 97.

[Bears]: Fourth lowest residential property tax rate of that same group, 93rd out of 97.

[Bears]: And we're one of only 20 cities out of all 351 cities and towns in Massachusetts that has never even tried to put an override or a debt exclusion on the ballot.

[Bears]: Even the people who passed Proposition 2.5 in 1980 thought that these votes would be happening regularly.

[Bears]: It wasn't that we should starve government, it was just that people should know what their money's going towards.

[Bears]: And we have those items on the ballot today.

[Bears]: We're here because it's time to turn the ship around and invest in Medford.

[Bears]: Medford residents have been clamoring for the chance to vote to invest in our city, and elected officials have finally delivered by putting questions six, seven, and eight on the ballot on Tuesday, November 5th.

[Bears]: We need to spend the next two months pounding the pavement, raising money, and talking to our neighbors about why we need to vote yes to invest in our schools, our streets, and our fire department.

[Bears]: Now, this campaign is not going to be easy.

[Bears]: Some people may have seen the latest attack line.

[Bears]: Stop the scam.

[Bears]: And I'm sure all of, many of us are around to talk and answer questions.

[Bears]: So with that, I will turn things over to Jenny to introduce herself and then Paul, and then we'll go from there.

[Bears]: Thank you, Paul and Jenny.

[Bears]: So just, we've had a few more people come in, and as I noted before, we're gonna be taking questions right after our presentations and our introductions.

[Bears]: There's an app called Slido.

[Bears]: I think I just sent an invitation to everybody.

[Bears]: You can ask questions using this app and upvote questions, and we will take them as they go.

[Bears]: If we see the same question multiple times, we're probably only gonna answer it once, but really encourage folks to start

[Bears]: putting forward their questions using the tool so that we can start to answer them.

[Bears]: So feel free to start doing that now, and hopefully we'll have a good lineup of questions to be answered.

[Bears]: But before that, I just wanna talk a little bit more about how we got here.

[Bears]: So as Jenny noted, many of us in the city and many of us who run for office

[Bears]: have seen the impact of underfunding and austerity budgets and cost growing up faster than revenues going up and the impact that's had on our city.

[Bears]: We see that our streets are not in the condition we want them to be in.

[Bears]: We know we have firefighters at the headquarters that is still appetited and far past the end of its useful life.

[Bears]: And of course, as Jenny and Paul have noted, we have a school system that really has faced a lot of challenges when it comes to budgets, hiring staff,

[Bears]: maintaining programs, maintaining buildings, things that we see every day.

[Bears]: And two years ago in 2022, we had the fiscal 23 budget.

[Bears]: I'm sure if folks were paying attention at the time, they noted that it was a very contentious budget season.

[Bears]: And one of the things that came out of that was really a clear picture for the first time in a long time of the structural deficit in the city budget.

[Bears]: the use of one-time funds to pay for ongoing expenses, the soon-to-be-expiring federal funds that even two years ago were on our radar as expiring that we were using to pay to keep our schools and our city moving.

[Bears]: And where we are after that budget season, the city council, Councilor Collins and I tried to work with the mayor to see if we could get towards looking at

[Bears]: an override to address that structural deficit.

[Bears]: We weren't able to reach an agreement, but the following budget season, after a lot of negotiation, we were able to work with the mayor to form, to reach an agreement, to pass a budget ordinance and to form a financial task force.

[Bears]: The school committee through its budget process and the council through this budget ordinance have really moved to a more transparent process that's more engaging of the public when we talk about creating the budget and understanding the challenges that we have.

[Bears]: And the piece I want to focus on just for a minute is the financial task force.

[Bears]: So the task force was announced in June of 2023, and consisting of the mayor, who is also the chair of the school committee, the council president, the council vice president, the school committee vice chair, and the chief of staff, also being supported by the staff in both our city departments

[Bears]: finance, et cetera, assessing, and our school finance and operations team.

[Bears]: So that task force was announced in June 2023.

[Bears]: We started to meet, we put out an initial press release and public statement in September of 2023, talking about how we were going to continue to meet with the goal of coming back to folks before the end of the fiscal year with a proposal that addressed the major financial challenges facing the community.

[Bears]: In March of 2023, sorry, 2024, we kind of put out, we announced a framework for that approach.

[Bears]: And then in June, we released the detail of that plan, which are the three ballot questions that are now on the ballot for November 5th for the consideration of the voters of the city of Medford.

[Bears]: Those ballot questions are question six, what should be a debt exclusion to fund the construction of a new fire headquarters?

[Bears]: Question seven,

[Bears]: which addresses the school system structural deficit and also the fact that right now we don't have anyone in our DPW who is dedicated to fixing our streets and sidewalks.

[Bears]: We would bring back a dedicated street and sidewalk repair crew for the first time in many years.

[Bears]: And question eight is about the future of our schools and then really investing and expanding our schools.

[Bears]: So the $4 million override to invest

[Bears]: significantly into our schools, into our educators, into programming, into making our schools what we want to be, and addressing what Jenny and Paul noted, all of the things that people want to see our schools do.

[Bears]: Now, will we be able to do every single one of them with $4 million?

[Bears]: No, but it's the first time we're going to be able to have a serious conversation about what transformational investment would look like in our schools.

[Bears]: So the total of those items, the debt exclusion pays for a $30 million bond,

[Bears]: The estimated cost of that is about $2 million per year.

[Bears]: That's question six.

[Bears]: Question seven is $3.5 million per year.

[Bears]: And question eight is $4 million per year.

[Bears]: Those amounts would be part of the property tax levy.

[Bears]: They would be paid by residents and businesses, and it would essentially affect the tax rate.

[Bears]: The tax rate would be about 60 cents per, 60 cents higher.

[Bears]: So it would go up from about 8.5

[Bears]: dollars per $1,000 in assessed value to about $9.1 per $1,000 in assessed value.

[Bears]: And the average impact on the average single family home is about $37 per month.

[Bears]: So that is the summary of what we're talking about and how we got here.

[Bears]: And, you know, the financial task force really does believe

[Bears]: that and has stated very clearly that this is a path forward that really does bring us to some financial stability and also the ability to make significant investments in our public schools.

[Bears]: So with that, I will end my comments and we can move into the question and answer period.

[Bears]: I see we do have a few questions here and I really do hope folks will submit some questions in the Q and A so that we can

[Bears]: answer any concerns and provide information to the community about the questions they see around the override.

[Bears]: And I'm just putting out an invite once again for folks to submit their questions.

[Bears]: The first question is, can you speak to cuts that will likely be made in our schools should the overrides not pass?

[Bears]: That's from Melanie.

[Bears]: H and we have five likes on that.

[Bears]: I will go to Paul or Jenny to talk about that.

[Bears]: Yeah, I think just to follow up on that, the specifics of the cuts are part of the budget process, but the answer is 35 to 45 full-time equivalent positions, right?

[Bears]: And that's...

[Bears]: then I will clarify to at least 35 to 45 full-time equivalent positions.

[Bears]: But what that looks like, I mean, that's, it's a huge cut, you know, that's, it's incredibly large.

[Bears]: It's certainly would affect every building, every classroom, every program.

[Bears]: Jenny and Paul, I just wanted to follow up on, I just wanted to follow up on one thing, Jenny, first before we go to, there are some,

[Bears]: Good questions here that we want to get to, but what was just there was 1 follow up to this question, which was.

[Bears]: What was actually cut this year and would anything be able to come back if the override did pass.

[Bears]: I think that's a great transition.

[Bears]: And I think we might be able to meet both of your requests, Jenny, for a more hopeful question and talk about some of the things we could be able to do.

[Bears]: The question was, could you provide some examples about funds from question eight?

[Bears]: So that is the investing more in our schools question, what those could be used to improve our schools.

[Bears]: Thank you, guys.

[Bears]: I want to move to some of our other top questions here.

[Bears]: And folks, please feel free to submit some more questions.

[Bears]: We have about 35, 40 minutes before we start to move into some wrapping up.

[Bears]: But the two top questions on deck right now, we'll start with one along these lines.

[Bears]: Is there a long-term plan to fill these budget gaps, or will we continue to need budget overrides?

[Bears]: The answer is there is a long-term plan to increase revenue for the city.

[Bears]: The city council has been working on that in partnership with our planning department for several years now.

[Bears]: Two years ago, we passed the first recodification of the city zoning in 60 years.

[Bears]: And what that does is if we allow new development and new growth, that is the only way outside of an override or a debt exclusion.

[Bears]: that the property tax levy can increase above the 2.5%.

[Bears]: So the last two years have actually been the best two years for new growth values in the city of Medford in the last 25 years.

[Bears]: No matter what other people may say about that, that's just the fact you can go to the State Department of Revenue Division of Local Services website to see that information.

[Bears]: And that has helped in the past two years, it hasn't been

[Bears]: astronomical Cambridge, Somerville, Boston level, or even Worcester level growth, but it has been an improvement.

[Bears]: It has staved off even more cuts.

[Bears]: It made possible this year some of what Jenny and Paul were talking about around not having to make the cuts that we had to make.

[Bears]: And part of that is also the one-time revenue, the one-time funding from the federal government, of course.

[Bears]: But the city council,

[Bears]: In partnership with the planning department.

[Bears]: We now have a city comprehensive plan for the first time ever.

[Bears]: We have a city housing production plan we also have our climate plan and our open space plan.

[Bears]: And those are going, all of those are being looped into a zoning update project that the council has been working on with the planning department and our zoning consultant in associates.

[Bears]: 11 times on that year in city council in our planning and permitting committee.

[Bears]: We have some really, we made some initial adjustments and we have some really, I think, transformative proposals coming up around our Mystic Avenue corridor, our Salem Street corridor, our Medford Square corridor, in terms of the transforming those neighborhoods and allowing significant new growth to see

[Bears]: modern walkable mixed use corridors with commercial space and residential space that once the zoning is completed and then once property owners and developers come in to start working on these projects would be transformative for our community in terms of raising revenue.

[Bears]: So that is the long-term vision for how we raise revenue beyond going down the other model.

[Bears]: I think this is maybe going into the next question a little bit, but the other model is the Winchester, Weston, Arlington, and other place model, which if folks don't know, those are places that do overrides and debt exclusions all the time.

[Bears]: Something that may be a surprise to folks is that when Proposition 2 12 passed in 1980, the proponents of Proposition 2 12 actually said,

[Bears]: that they expected communities to do overrides and debt exclusions regularly, and that the reason for the law was just so that it would be transparent and decided on by the voters.

[Bears]: Now, many, 315, I think, of the 351 cities and towns in Massachusetts have since proposed an overrider or debt exclusion.

[Bears]: Many of those communities have passed an overrider or debt exclusion.

[Bears]: Medford is one of the few that has never even put one on the table.

[Bears]: So we think that with our location close to Boston, the value of our community, the transformative opportunities and corridors that have not seen the economic development focus that they've needed to see.

[Bears]: And quite frankly, if we had seen 10, 20, 30 years ago, we might be having a different conversation today.

[Bears]: We might be having a conversation more like a Somerville or a Cambridge or even an Everett.

[Bears]: That's a way for us to

[Bears]: transform the community in a positive way, bring new amenities and benefits to the people who live here and increase the city's tax base significantly in the long run.

[Bears]: I think in the medium to short term, you know, the financial task force believes that these overrides and the debt exclusion for the fire station provide significant fiscal space in the next few years for the city to not be in a budget crunch.

[Bears]: and maybe even be a bridge entirely to that development and revenue from those new developments.

[Bears]: I can't say that with any certainty.

[Bears]: Certainly if there's another period, you know, if the tariff that have been proposed by a presidential candidate go into place and we see inflation at 10 or 20% again in the next couple of years, we're gonna be in really big trouble right away.

[Bears]: If we see 2% inflation for the next 10 years, it's a different story.

[Bears]: But, you know,

[Bears]: That's really the thinking here.

[Bears]: The one project that I think would fall outside of that is, of course, the new Medford High School.

[Bears]: There is no way, and you haven't really seen any community, even Somerville with Assembly Row had to do a debt exclusion for its new high school.

[Bears]: That is the one project that I think there would be a further request of the voters to fund.

[Bears]: But right now, that is the only thing on the horizon that the current leadership team between the mayor, council, and school committee foresees asking the voters to do.

[Bears]: the conditions remain reasonable and we don't have 20% tariffs on everything we import.

[Bears]: I don't know if Jenny or Paul you want to add on that long term court plan around the budget gaps at all.

[Bears]: I think there's a follow-up on that, Jenny.

[Bears]: There's a question, why do we have to wait so long for the high school debt exclusion?

[Bears]: And I may have misspoke.

[Bears]: That would be sooner than 5 to 10 years.

[Bears]: The MSBA process, the stage we're in now, we would probably find out.

[Bears]: Jenny, could you go into that a little bit more?

[Bears]: For the new high school for the new high school.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: All right, Paul, I cut you off and then I will go to Matt.

[Bears]: Another panel, Matt.

[Bears]: I'm just missing those.

[Bears]: That's really a really important point.

[Bears]: Sometimes I take for granted that people don't know that we don't have such basic things that I forget to mention that we're establishing things for the first time here in Medford that many communities have had for decades, if not longer.

[Bears]: Jack, could I speak to the admin is heavy question?

[Bears]: Sure, yeah, we'll jump back to that and then we can talk about a couple other questions.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: I want to go to the next question that we have a bunch of votes on.

[Bears]: which is, do we know what other towns have done to get overrides to pass given that Medford is a laggard compared to similar towns?

[Bears]: I will defer to my colleagues in just a moment, but I wish there was a magic formula, because I'd be less stressed out about whether or not this question or these questions are going to pass.

[Bears]: I think, to be honest, the first step is the city government needs to have the courage to ask.

[Bears]: This is the first time the city government has had the courage to ask the voters.

[Bears]: I don't think anyone thinks, oh, let's raise our taxes is a popular thing for anyone to ask anyone else.

[Bears]: And I understand like deeply and completely that it's a difficult decision for a lot of people.

[Bears]: I think we all understand that.

[Bears]: I think we also know that there's a lot of difficult decisions that have been had to be made or continue to be making when it comes to

[Bears]: layoffs?

[Bears]: And do we pay our staff enough?

[Bears]: And do we have this department exist anymore?

[Bears]: Things that are really fundamental to the functioning of city government.

[Bears]: And, you know, do we have our firefighters have a building where they feel like they're not going to get sick in that building, right?

[Bears]: Like, these are really human deep questions, just as much as am I able to afford the tax increase is a really human deep question for a lot of people.

[Bears]: And I think for a long time, city government

[Bears]: felt like we could keep asking the community to not invest in city government, to do more with less, and found creative or uncreative or short-term, not long-term ways to make that work.

[Bears]: And the last five years, especially with the pandemic and with the cost growth, we hit the wall, right?

[Bears]: And so now we don't have another choice but to ask.

[Bears]: And I think we've been clear that if we ask and we

[Bears]: And the answer is no.

[Bears]: And there's a lot of very, very hard choices that come after that.

[Bears]: And so that's the first step I think to getting an override to pass is that an override is on the ballot.

[Bears]: From what other towns have done what we need to do I think Matt really spoke to it and Paul spoke to it and Jenny spoke to it as well right like

[Bears]: How do one of the big things that we're talking about the financial task force is how do we make sure that we address the scope of problems that is significant enough that people can see the investment that we're asking them to make.

[Bears]: Because if we don't do a big enough thing and we ask people to do this and they don't actually see a change.

[Bears]: we're not engendering any more trust than we've been engendering with the lack of progress that the city has been making for a long time.

[Bears]: Um, so I'm really encouraged.

[Bears]: I think we've done a lot of public education, quite frankly, over the last two to four years around the difficulties and issues that we see in our schools and on our streets and in our city departments, where a lot of people are saying, Hey, you know, maybe I don't want to pay more taxes.

[Bears]: Maybe it will be a challenge for me to figure out how to afford to pay more taxes, but also I care about this community.

[Bears]: And I know that we need to do these things because.

[Bears]: And we can just see it, right?

[Bears]: Like it's literally the environment that we live in and the buildings that our kids are in and the teachers who are overworked and the city employees who are overworked, right?

[Bears]: Like we see and feel the reality and I think people are ready to make this investment.

[Bears]: So I've been really encouraged talking to my neighbors, been really encouraged talking to lots of folks across the city that these things are going to pass.

[Bears]: And I think the good thing that if we move forward on these is it sets a foundation for us to show progress, to show improvement, to maybe get the financial systems and softwares in place where we can point to a dashboard instead of a spreadsheet, point to, you know, pull data in a day instead of a week to answer questions more quickly.

[Bears]: And my hope is to see that virtuous cycle of investment beginning more investment and

[Bears]: city government having the resources that it needs to do its job, meaning that the public trust the city can do its job.

[Bears]: So that is my real hope.

[Bears]: I feel good right now.

[Bears]: I'm going to be working very hard over the next 27 days, talking to people, getting people, raising money to send out the mailers, doing all the different things that we need to do to make sure that we get a yes vote on November 5th.

[Bears]: But that's my kind of

[Bears]: pitch and spiel around what do we need to do to get an override to pass and why we went this direction.

[Bears]: Paul, I see that you're next.

[Bears]: I don't know if anyone can tell that Paul is the secretary of the school committee, because one of the jobs that Paul has to do is sign every bill.

[Bears]: So he's pretty familiar with that side of things.

[Bears]: I think Jenny raised the same exact point, though, around our class sizes, right?

[Bears]: When you ask teachers and paras to have more kids in the room, it gets harder to educate the kids.

[Bears]: And if you can have four less kids in a room, that may be the difference between someone staying or someone going somewhere else where the class sizes are smaller.

[Bears]: To be honest, there's burnout and turnover in the school.

[Bears]: Sure, I'm on the city council and I spend a lot more time on the city side of things.

[Bears]: We have a lot of turnover and burnout on the city side too.

[Bears]: A lot of great folks come in, build some relationships.

[Bears]: They're here for a year, they're here for two years, and then they get offered a job that isn't as many hours, is at a higher pay rate in another city or in the private sector, and they move on.

[Bears]: I mean, I think the greatest example of this is our issue hiring a city solicitor.

[Bears]: We've raised the pay like two or three times now.

[Bears]: hoping that this latest one, which was just a month ago, might actually, or two months ago, might actually lock us in and hopefully we can hire someone.

[Bears]: But yeah, people come in, they work hard, they realize that they don't have the, they're working more or doing more jobs that they would have to do.

[Bears]: And then, you know, doing two jobs here where they might be able to do one job in another community, they move on.

[Bears]: And I think we see that across the board, city and schools.

[Bears]: I wanna go to the next question.

[Bears]: We'll just want to add in quickly that there was a clarification on the heavy administrator talking about the curriculum and department heads, not more superintendents.

[Bears]: So just wanted to note that.

[Bears]: Thanks for putting that clarification.

[Bears]: On the questions here that are left and we're coming up, you know, we got to probably about 10 or so minutes left if folks want to throw another question into the chat.

[Bears]: The next one is, has there been discussions about an owner-occupied property tax exemption like Cambridge and Somerville have, and is that something the city council could pass?

[Bears]: So every year we use, we set the tax rate.

[Bears]: I won't go into the, take me more than 10 minutes to go into the complexities of exactly how Proposition 2 12 works, but we set the tax rate every year.

[Bears]: And one of the options that is, you know, we technically vote to consider is,

[Bears]: could we do an owner-occupied property tax exemption?

[Bears]: What that means is that the city would set a certain percentage of the average residential bill.

[Bears]: And if you were an owner-occupied unit, you would get that, essentially, your tax bill would go down by that amount.

[Bears]: Let's use some round numbers here.

[Bears]: Let's say it's $3,000.

[Bears]: that would be like a 30% exemption.

[Bears]: Let's say it's $3,000.

[Bears]: Now, I don't know off the top of my head, it's actually probably pretty close.

[Bears]: How that would work is everybody who pays a residential tax bill from, if your owner occupied, regardless of your value, you'd get $3,000 off your bill.

[Bears]: So if your house, essentially it creates a breakeven point where,

[Bears]: And it's a little more complicated than this, but basically everyone who's owner-occupied would get that cut off.

[Bears]: But that money doesn't just go away.

[Bears]: The city can't afford to actually have the taxes go down.

[Bears]: So that amount that owner-occupants get, that reduction, gets shifted onto people who don't get the owner-occupant exemption.

[Bears]: So essentially, you'd be shifting the city, the cost of the property tax on residential properties,

[Bears]: off of owner-occupants onto non-owner-occupants.

[Bears]: But the other side of that is that that actually changes the tax rate.

[Bears]: It essentially means instead of a flat residential tax rate on residential tax bills, you end up with a progressive rate.

[Bears]: I don't actually think that's a bad thing, but one of the reasons that previous councils prior to 2022

[Bears]: didn't pass it is it actually would raise taxes on owner occupants in high value homes.

[Bears]: So if your home is worth more than the breakeven point, even though you get the exemption, the tax rates going up more than the exemptions, you actually pay more.

[Bears]: The point being that it's a complicated conversation.

[Bears]: Essentially, if you are in a condo or a small single family and you're

[Bears]: living in that, you're an owner occupant, your taxes will probably go down.

[Bears]: If you're in an expensive single family or a multifamily, your taxes are probably going up.

[Bears]: If you're a certainly large apartment buildings, those there'd be significant increase because the rate would go up.

[Bears]: So it's not just this, you know, everyone who gets an if we implemented it tomorrow, that everyone would get this benefit in the same way.

[Bears]: It's a complicated conversation.

[Bears]: One of the reasons we haven't implemented it is because both the previous city assessor and the current city assessor say it would take them about a year to do the calculations and get everything in order.

[Bears]: And they'd probably need one to two more staff people in the assessing office just to process the applications for the owner occupancy exemption.

[Bears]: So it's a significant undertaking.

[Bears]: A lot of places like Everett's and Somerville's and Cambridge's did this a long time ago when the conversation was a little bit different because of the property values that we see today.

[Bears]: But yeah, so we've talked about it a lot.

[Bears]: I think I actually know too much about it because I don't know that I explained it particularly well right now.

[Bears]: But we've talked about it every year that we've set the tax rate since I've been on the council and I know on prior councils before that.

[Bears]: It would be a complicated undertaking, and it isn't the silver bullet that it's presented to be a lot of the time.

[Bears]: But do I think it's a bad idea?

[Bears]: No, and I'd be willing to move forward on it if folks felt we could make the time and effort and make it a priority personally.

[Bears]: Next question is on

[Bears]: The when would we expect to see changes to the high school vocational schedule, if we were able to move forward and if the negotiations were able to be concluded.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I think, yeah, I think everybody who's everyone I've talked to talks about it gets that it's a heavy lift, but also that getting prepared to make that lift everyone's on that page.

[Bears]: All right, we got two more questions left.

[Bears]: We're about on time.

[Bears]: Well, two and a half, there's a dueling questions for anyone who's seen it at the end and we'll take that one last, but just Rebecca's question is money from the override only required to go to the directed budget for the first year and after that could go anywhere else in the city budget.

[Bears]: There's two answers to this question.

[Bears]: Proposition two and a half date law requires that in the first year, it goes towards the specific purposes outlined in the question.

[Bears]: Those appropriations would be made

[Bears]: people would be hired, things would be purchased, contracts would be signed based on those things.

[Bears]: In the second year, could the mayor and the school committee and the council then fire everybody that they just hired and go completely in another direction?

[Bears]: And I mean, is it legally allowed?

[Bears]: Yes, is it something that would be

[Bears]: in the realm of possibility?

[Bears]: Absolutely not.

[Bears]: I think we've all been very, very clear that what the purpose of these overrides are for.

[Bears]: And I don't think anyone here, I think we've already been very clear that we don't like the fact that there are layoffs and position cuts and things happening now.

[Bears]: I certainly don't think that some massive bait and switch, I don't even know what we would put it into, to be honest.

[Bears]: These are the things that we want to do with the money.

[Bears]: These are the things that we think are the priority of the city.

[Bears]: And yeah, there's a little bit of trust that comes from that, and I acknowledge that, but we've been very clear about what these priorities are.

[Bears]: And a lot of it, especially on the school side, is also subject to negotiation, collective bargaining agreements, other laws, and that's what it is.

[Bears]: We've been very clear that if these overrides are to pass,

[Bears]: they would fund our schools, they would fund our educators, they would fund the people who work in our schools, they would hire a DPW street crew.

[Bears]: And what I can say is that if the debt exclusion passes question six, that just have to go to the fire station.

[Bears]: That's the law.

[Bears]: They can only pay for the bond for the fire station, period.

[Bears]: So that's the answer to that question.

[Bears]: And can I just add to that?

[Bears]: Thanks, Jenny.

[Bears]: I want to move to wrap up on

[Bears]: incorporate the, you know, incorporation and the general provisions as part of that I think that might be, I'm just trying to think of like the scope of work, you know, those seem to be a little bit quicker to get through like I'm sure we'll just kind of take what the Charter Study Committee said for section one is like,

[Bears]: you know, we are the city of Medford and this is our mission statement, that kind of thing.

[Bears]: It's not as nitty gritty as the details of like, what are the districts maybe going to be for different bodies?

[Bears]: Or do we want that to be uniform?

[Bears]: We already have elections every two years, stuff like that.

[Bears]: So I think those are,

[Bears]: kind of the bigger buckets of work.

[Bears]: So maybe there's five buckets of work, but maybe it's four meetings, maybe we could do a couple in one meeting.

[Bears]: And the one that just sticks out to me is what we might want to schedule separately as a school committee, just so that I just don't think we should lump that in with legislative executive branch I think it's a little bit different.

[Bears]: And then I think if we're having those four meetings of this committee.

[Bears]: My other question would be, do we want to have a meeting before those four meetings where we.

[Bears]: receive the mayor's thoughts and the study committee's thoughts before we go into specifically those four meetings on the actual topics.

[Bears]: And that might give Councilors, you know, time to review that report.

[Bears]: If we want to send any questions back to the mayor or to KP or Tina to legal counsel or to the study committee, um,

[Bears]: we could do that and then we could go step by step and say like, here are the four meetings and Councilors could bring their proposals to those four meetings on the different kind of areas of the charter.

[Bears]: And that would probably be maybe that first meeting where we just start reviewing and asking questions about the study committee proposals and recommendations and the mayor's report, you know, recommendations and proposals.

[Bears]: Maybe that's next month.

[Bears]: And then maybe we could do, try to do one or two meetings a month over the next

[Bears]: you know, December, January, February, and then hopefully we're getting something out by March.

[Bears]: Um, and maybe we could even be putting that on the ballot for November, 2025, um, to go into effect in 2027, something like that would just be my thinking.

[Bears]: Um, instead of having, I think if we go longer than that, we're probably waiting until 2026 or 2027 and not having anything going to effect for another five years, which I think we all want to avoid.

[Bears]: Yeah, and to Councilor Collins, Vice President Collins' point, maybe that's the approach.

[Bears]: Maybe that meeting in a month from now or so is

[Bears]: if we took down the four or five buckets that I kind of outlined, have Councilors bring their ideas, what they've seen, what they think works for Medford, bring that to the meeting.

[Bears]: We could then also have Collins Center or study committee or an example from another community.

[Bears]: And that would be a way for us to have that discussion without it being inherently like, I think what we want to avoid here is, um,

[Bears]: Pitting different groups that have been moving through this against one another.

[Bears]: And like the ideas, I think like there's just going to be different ideas.

[Bears]: And now that this process that we are starting our process, which is the formal process and, you know, it can't move forward without a vote of the council can't move forward without the mayor being able to say,

[Bears]: All right, councilors think this, council maybe has been able to reach some consensus here.

[Bears]: How does that compare to what the mayor's thinking is?

[Bears]: How does that compare to what the charter study committee's ideas are?

[Bears]: How does that compare to what some other communities do?

[Bears]: That would be a good way for us to factor in those different perspectives in a way that is productive and based on like a discussion format rather than it being like competing proposals.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: I would move to have the chair through the clerk, send that out to members of the committee for members of the committee to come back with their ideas and comments on each of the different articles and sections.

[Bears]: And maybe when you send that out chair, you could lump them into those different groupings.

[Bears]: Each of it's basically I think two or three articles, a group.

[Bears]: And then when we come back in a month, hopefully we'll have a good discussion on that substance.

[Bears]: And then, so I'd move to do that and move to adjourn.

[Bears]: All one motion.

[Bears]: 24475 offered by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: be it resolved that the Medford City Council hold a question and answer session to discuss the definitions and terminology regarding the proposed Proposition 2.5 overrides and the proposed debt exclusion measure.

[Bears]: To that resolution, the following amendments were added.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli asked that the administration and Council on Aging do outreach to seniors about this meeting.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan requested outreach to parents of school-aged children, not just teachers, and specifically requested outreach to the PTOs.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng requested general outreach and specifically requested that the community liaisons translate into other languages the information that is on the city website about the overrides and the debt exclusion.

[Bears]: To ensure that the council is able to answer questions in a timely manner and that decorum is maintained, the council president, myself, will be enforcing the following rules.

[Bears]: One, members of the public will have one minute to ask one question.

[Bears]: Members of the public will not be able to ask a second question until all who seek to ask a question have had the chance to ask their first question.

[Bears]: The president will verbally request that residents not ask duplicative or largely similar questions to questions that have already been answered.

[Bears]: and may move to the next question if a duplicative or similar question is asked.

[Bears]: Each Councilor will have up to two minutes to answer per question.

[Bears]: The president will verbally request the Councilors not answer if a duplicative or largely similar answer has been given by another Councilor and may move to the next question if a duplicative or similar answer is given.

[Bears]: After members of the public have had the chance to ask their first question, the president will open the floor to either a second question or a short public comment by members of the public in attendance.

[Bears]: There were five members of the financial task force, the council president, the council vice president, the chair of the school committee, who's the mayor, the vice chair of the school committee, and the chief of staff for the mayor, who administratively runs city hall.

[Bears]: The $3 million number comes from the school finance director from the fiscal 25 budget process.

[Bears]: $500,000 number for the DPW street and sidewalk group comes from the DPW commissioner.

[Bears]: The $4 million number for the question eight, that comes also from the fiscal 25 and 24 school budget process from the finance director, from many of the administrators in the Medford public schools talking about, this is what we need to do the things that people are asking us to do.

[Bears]: And the $30 million bond number for the fire headquarters came from the mayor, the chief of staff, and the fire chief based on the design process for the new headquarters.

[Bears]: That's where it came from.

[Bears]: two and a half, three years, dozens of recordings of this body and the school committee talking about these needs.

[Bears]: Just to Councilor Leming's point, there was the $34 million certified balance at the end of June.

[Bears]: $6 million went to a stabilization fund.

[Bears]: $5 million went to a capital stabilization fund.

[Bears]: $1 million of that has already been spent on emergency capital repairs.

[Bears]: $3 million went to the MSBA feasibility study.

[Bears]: The mayor also outlined an additional $9.5 million, $2.5 million for fire department fleet replacements, $2 million for the pension liability, which we have to fund by 2034.

[Bears]: $2 million per year for fiscal year 25 capital improvements, $2 million for fiscal year 26 capital improvements, $1 million to match federal and state money to renovate the Hegner Center.

[Bears]: We also have the estimated $15 million that we heard the other week from Assistant Superintendent Cushing to fix the HVAC at the Andrews Middle School and McGlynn K-8 school.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan has noted the $67 million in road debt, $35 million in sidewalk debt,

[Bears]: People have noted the school water issue.

[Bears]: As Mr. Belson said, we made money on those schools, but apparently we did it because we didn't put the right stuff in for water.

[Bears]: So I just spent all 35 million right there on things that are urgent, right there.

[Bears]: We're still gonna have to prioritize these urgent capital needs with that free cash and stabilization fund money.

[Bears]: Yeah, that's plus there's the money in the stabilization funds.

[Bears]: Yeah, I just went beyond that though.

[Bears]: It's not a scare tactic.

[Bears]: It's just math.

[Bears]: It's just math.

[Bears]: That is the need of the community.

[Bears]: I could not name you a community in the state.

[Bears]: Is that the math that the task force has?

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I don't interrupt you.

[Bears]: So when we talk about sufficiency of the override, in the public documents that have been repeatedly asserted don't exist, but are of course public and on the website, the financial task force has said that we believe that this override and debt exclusion is sufficient.

[Bears]: along with whatever needs to be done for the high school, which we all knew always was going to be an independent question to allow the city's planning and development work based on the comprehensive plan and the zoning recodification and ongoing zoning work to take effect to begin to raise the funds.

[Bears]: So yes, right now in the public documents that have been released, I think both the March document and the June document talk about that question.

[Bears]: We believe that not only is this the best path forward for the city's financial health,

[Bears]: but that the amounts are sufficient that we would not be coming back in the next five to 10 years outside of a Medford High School question to address the city's financial health and challenges.

[Bears]: When it comes to the Financial Task Force question, Financial Task Force was not a public body, did not include, for example, members of the public, appointed citizens, etc.

[Bears]: It was an internal body to City Hall.

[Bears]: similar to project meetings in different departments, interdepartmental groups designed for different projects.

[Bears]: So that is why it was held internally and not in publicly posted meetings and public meetings.

[Bears]: All right, in terms of where the money goes, $3 million from Question 7 goes to Medford Public Schools to replace $1.7 million in one-time funds that were used for Fiscal 25 to cover positions to address the inclusion of federally funded

[Bears]: pandemic aid positions and to address maintenance costs, $500,000 would go to DDPW to hire staff to have a permanent in-house road and sidewalk repair crew, and $4 million would go to the school to address a number of issues, mainly collectively bargained issues around pay for

[Bears]: teachers, paraprofessionals, staff, addressing the issue of the school day, and potentially also addressing issues such as coaches, stipends, and transportation, depending on what is prioritized during the next budget process.

[Bears]: Thank you for the question.

[Bears]: I can go to other folks, but I do have the answer, I think.

[Bears]: So in terms of the temporary versus permanent, question six is a debt exclusion.

[Bears]: So it's temporary in the sense that there's the $30 million amount for the bond.

[Bears]: The $2 billion that you cited is an estimate for the annual debt service cost.

[Bears]: That estimate was created to try to give folks an understanding of what that might look like on an annual basis on their tax impact.

[Bears]: So that's a temporary until the bond is paid off.

[Bears]: For question seven and eight, those would be permanent.

[Bears]: Those are overrides intended to be permanent increases to the levy limit to fund ongoing operations.

[Bears]: In terms of the line items, I believe there is a page on the city website right now that does outline the specifics that I just said in terms of the

[Bears]: 3 million for the MPS and 500,000 for the DPW in question seven and the 4 million in question eight.

[Bears]: I can look at seeing if the city might be able to also add a graphic there, but I believe if you go to medfordma.org, there's a button right on the front page that says override information, and it does outline the line items for each specific question to the greatest extent possible.

[Bears]: So we do, it would be 3.5 million for question seven and 4 million for question eight.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And that's the max, it can't go higher than that.

[Bears]: And those are not funding any sort of bonds or debt exclusions.

[Bears]: Those are for the override.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: That's not the format here.

[Bears]: We'll take public comment at the end.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Just on the point about question six, Department of Revenue guidelines, it can be for the bonded amount.

[Bears]: It's not written into the question.

[Bears]: That's because of how the Proposition 2.5 law is written.

[Bears]: but it is for the $30 million plus minor project changes.

[Bears]: It is not a blank check.

[Bears]: It is not just an open thing.

[Bears]: Department of Revenue has extent, the State Department of Revenue has extensive guidelines on this.

[Bears]: So if there are minor project changes or construction related inflation adjustments, those could be included, but they have to be minor.

[Bears]: If there's a significant increase to the budget, it would have to either be going out for another bond funded by another revenue source or funded by an additional debt exclusion vote of the people.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I'm going to go to Zoom.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: On this specific question, when we were looking at the financial state of the city, we said, what is the biggest capital obligation that the city is going to have over the next five to 10 years, other than a high school, which we've excluded from everyone acknowledges is such a big project needs to be handled on its own.

[Bears]: It was a new fire headquarters.

[Bears]: We can get into the back and forth dispute over should there have been a combined headquarters?

[Bears]: Should this have been 10, 10 years ago?

[Bears]: Those, quite frankly, were decisions that were made before I was even thinking about running for office.

[Bears]: When we looked at that, we said, that's the biggest expense.

[Bears]: If we ask the voters to do that as a debt exclusion, it means that bond capacity is available for many of the other things that we've talked about.

[Bears]: Now we looked at that.

[Bears]: There has been an owner's project manager hired by the mayor.

[Bears]: The mayor has controlled the design process, has included, my understanding, chiefs, has not included the union or firefighters to the level that they've wanted to be included, and has never included this council in the design process.

[Bears]: We're not part of the design process for the fire station.

[Bears]: We made a decision based on the financial health of the community, based on the estimates provided by the designer, the mayor, and the fire chief, that a $30 million fire station is what they think will need to be built.

[Bears]: The design is not finalized.

[Bears]: My understanding is that changes can and are being made.

[Bears]: But to us, it was a separate question.

[Bears]: The design process is not something that this council has been involved in.

[Bears]: But the financial health of the community is obviously something that we work on during the budget process.

[Bears]: And so identifying this project as what should be funded by a debt exclusion was how we made that decision.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan?

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng?

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: Just to be brief, you know, we have had for the last three years, the best three years of new growth in the city in the last 25 years.

[Bears]: Those are just, again, the facts.

[Bears]: They're on the DLS webpage.

[Bears]: We can't disagree with data and mathematics.

[Bears]: Data and mathematics are not fear tactics.

[Bears]: They are just the facts.

[Bears]: Alternatives, there was no way in the short to medium term to raise reliable, recurring, sustainable revenue to fund operating budget expenses, except for asking the voters to fund those expenses through an override.

[Bears]: The property tax levy is the vast majority of the money that the city brings in.

[Bears]: The state is not providing the city with significant new aid.

[Bears]: The city departments go above and beyond finding federal and state grants.

[Bears]: They are looking far and wide for them.

[Bears]: Just because we don't receive them doesn't mean we didn't apply for them.

[Bears]: And to be honest, a lot of the formulas and ways that those things are decided are not favoring places like Medford.

[Bears]: because the state school formula looks at our city and they say, Oh, they should pay more in property taxes.

[Bears]: We're not going to send them more state aid.

[Bears]: That's literally how the formula is written.

[Bears]: It's based on capacity for a city to do so.

[Bears]: So when we are 93rd out of 97 for property tax revenue, when we are 94th out of 97 for per capita spending, we are where we are.

[Bears]: The state's judges us based on that reality and says, we're not giving them more money.

[Bears]: So,

[Bears]: Again, we came together over dozens of public meetings over three budget cycles addressing needs of the city and the school department and said, this is the best way to raise sustainable recurring revenue to fund city operating budget expenses.

[Bears]: We believe this is the best path forward in the short to medium term.

[Bears]: And we are going to ask the voters to make that decision.

[Bears]: The voters are, the voters are going to vote.

[Bears]: We'll see what happens.

[Bears]: I certainly hope they vote one way.

[Bears]: Other Councilors may hope that they vote another way, but I don't envy anyone in any, I don't think any of us are going to be excited to do the budget if these funds are not available.

[Bears]: They were installing geothermal energy.

[Bears]: It's just completely incomparable to the project that we're talking about in Medford Square, which is a knockdown.

[Bears]: Again, the cost overruns were mainly due to historic preservation issues.

[Bears]: and projects that they were trying to add in there that are not things that we're trying to add to our station.

[Bears]: Um, we were able, uh, this year to keep most of those people by using the one-time funds that we're talking about, um, that the city had staved up, but in the long run, um, it's really difficult, uh, for us to keep that promise if we don't have the money to keep paying people.

[Bears]: So, um, question seven, as Anna noted, um, would allow us to make sure that we can keep everybody on, um,

[Bears]: who's there now, we don't have to look at asking people to leave, firing people, laying people off.

[Bears]: And question eight means that the city and the schools have a lot more opportunity to give our teachers and the people in your school the pay that they deserve to have more staff in the schools to help out in the classroom.

[Bears]: And if we don't,

[Bears]: see a yes vote on those two questions, it's going to be a lot harder for the city to do those things.

[Bears]: So, um, we're, we're going to do our best no matter what happens.

[Bears]: And one hard thing about democracy that you might be learning pretty young is sometimes people don't agree with you.

[Bears]: And sometimes people make a decision that you don't want them to make.

[Bears]: And if that happens, we're going to do our very best to try to make sure that everything stays okay.

[Bears]: Um, but if people do say yes, it'll be easier for us to do that.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: So that 30 million bond could really be 32 to 35.

[Bears]: If the changes can be made within that,

[Bears]: then this debt exclusion continues to pay for the fire station headquarters.

[Bears]: If it's more than that, you've said a number 40, 45 million, you think, potentially, I'm 100% in to say we need to look at the bond capacity or we need to ask again.

[Bears]: for more.

[Bears]: I don't think that voting no on this debt exclusion will get us to eventually a yes.

[Bears]: That's my position on it.

[Bears]: I think voting yes to the financing.

[Bears]: And I didn't mean to put words in your mouth that you're advocating for that.

[Bears]: My personal position is voting yes funds most of this project, the way that I think it can best be funded, the fastest way it can be funded.

[Bears]: I didn't have all this information when we released the plan.

[Bears]: Do I wish that people had acted differently so it would be easier to talk to the residents and get them to support things like this?

[Bears]: As you're aware, as other folks here are aware, there are things that are not within

[Bears]: this council's control within my control.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: I personally agree that the communication needs to be better.

[Bears]: It needs to be more of a seat at the table.

[Bears]: I'm still going to vote the way I'm going to vote, because I think it gets us a lot of the way there on the financing question, even if I personally have a lot of problems and issues with the design and the design process as it stands.

[Bears]: So that's just where I'm at.

[Bears]: And I appreciate you coming down.

[Bears]: And yeah, I think the other thing we've talked about a lot tonight is that the state is not doing us right in a lot of ways.

[Bears]: That includes MassDOT and DCR on our streets and roads in general.

[Bears]: And you know,

[Bears]: they get to say, well, we're not going to spend the 6 million to redesign your intersection if you don't do it our way.

[Bears]: And we don't really have a lot of recourse, even though I wish we did.

[Bears]: So it's a tough situation.

[Bears]: So if you've got a ramp that's 60,

[Bears]: It sounds like a lot of heads need to get together before a final design happens.

[Bears]: Anything else on this question?

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: I think we are.

[Bears]: Thank you, Chief.

[Bears]: We have someone who hasn't asked a question yet, and then we have a hand that has and someone in line that has.

[Bears]: So we'll go to the floor, name and address for the record, one minute to answer one question or ask one question.

[Bears]: It's on, you're good.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: And you shouldn't need to touch it.

[Bears]: I can answer.

[Bears]: Does anyone else want to go first on this question?

[Bears]: I know Councilor Scarpelli and I have been in five tax setting meetings together.

[Bears]: I don't know if you want to

[Bears]: All right, residential exemption.

[Bears]: It's not the panacea, it seems to be A. There is a breakeven point in the home valuations, where if you implement a residential exemption, if your value is above that, you actually start paying more.

[Bears]: So if we implemented a residential exemption, I believe two years ago, that breakeven was almost exactly the average, around 768,000.

[Bears]: If you're above that value, you actually start paying more.

[Bears]: than you did without the exemption.

[Bears]: If you're under that value, you pay less.

[Bears]: Now, the reason this happens is essentially to do this, A, the council would set it, but it would be in partnership with the assessor's office.

[Bears]: The assessor's office has said they probably need to hire two more full-time staff in that office just to process the applications every year.

[Bears]: But essentially, you take what is the flat tax rate,

[Bears]: across all residential, your 8.51 per thousand, I think is our FY 24 rate.

[Bears]: And you create a 30% exemption on the tax of the average home.

[Bears]: So 30% of the tax bill for a $768,000 home, that becomes your exemption.

[Bears]: That's a fixed dollar amount.

[Bears]: Let's say for just for

[Bears]: efficiency sake, let's say that's $3,000.

[Bears]: So if your tax bill is, uh, you know, $6,000, you get $3,000 off.

[Bears]: Um, but that has to be shifted, right?

[Bears]: So the city's actual tax doesn't come down.

[Bears]: The city still needs to raise all the revenue it's raising every year.

[Bears]: So that, that fixed dollar about

[Bears]: actually also means that you increase the tax rate.

[Bears]: So instead of having an 8.51% rate, you might have a 12.5% rate, but then you get the $3,000 off if you're owner occupied.

[Bears]: So if you're getting a 30% rate increase,

[Bears]: and you're getting a 30% exemption, if you're in a lower value home, you save money.

[Bears]: If you're in a condo, you probably save money.

[Bears]: If you're in an under low value single family, you save money.

[Bears]: If you're in a multifamily, a high value single family, certainly if you're in a large apartment building, you're actually paying more because the tax rate's going up significantly.

[Bears]: to cover for that shift.

[Bears]: So essentially, it benefits some people in the community, it benefits people who generally condo owners, people in single families below the breakeven point.

[Bears]: And it actually would result in increased taxes for people who have very high valued single family homes.

[Bears]: Most multifamily homes are over 750,000 valuation apartment buildings are so we could implement it.

[Bears]: We would need six months to a year to do so before a tax rate hearing, which happens in December.

[Bears]: So we'd probably need to make a decision by April or May of the prior year.

[Bears]: The assessor's office was ready to be budgeted to hire more staff to process the applications.

[Bears]: And at the end of the day, it doesn't, it's not a panacea for everyone.

[Bears]: I tend to support it anyway.

[Bears]: I think it turns a flat rate wealth tax into a progressive rate wealth tax, where the rate is actually lower on lower wealth properties and higher on higher wealth properties.

[Bears]: But it doesn't help everyone.

[Bears]: It doesn't mean, if you're a senior and you're above the break even, you might pay more.

[Bears]: So it's not, it doesn't help everyone.

[Bears]: It certainly is.

[Bears]: We consider it and discuss it every December.

[Bears]: We basically have the conversation I just tried to summarize at our tax rate setting hearings.

[Bears]: And I know there's been different perspectives on it.

[Bears]: I've been a supporter because I generally tend to think that having that progressive rate system is a better approach than the flat rate.

[Bears]: But similarly, I've heard arguments from my colleagues, Councilor Caraviello, Councilor Knight, who are not on the council, but they were,

[Bears]: concerned about what if you're in a home value above the breakeven point and that's about basically about half of people who are owning properties.

[Bears]: So I think it goes either way.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Any other stuff on the residential exemption?

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: Can you wait?

[Bears]: Can you wait?

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: We are now, I think no one, has anyone who has, hold on one second, Andy.

[Bears]: I'll make a brief though.

[Bears]: Just one second.

[Bears]: Has anyone not asked a question who wants to ask a question?

[Bears]: Seeing none, we'll go to public comment.

[Bears]: I'll take Andy, then I'll take Gaston for a second question, then we have Micah on Zoom.

[Bears]: Mr. Castagnetti.

[Bears]: Thank you, Andy.

[Bears]: Gaston, either a question or a comment, and I'm gonna go up to two minutes for everybody for this last little section.

[Bears]: Thank you, Gaston.

[Bears]: Anyone else on that comment?

[Bears]: I just wanna note myself, and this is just me being an economics nerd, and I'm really sorry to do this at 10 p.m.

[Bears]: I like to use the PCE price deflator for state and local government.

[Bears]: It's line 24 on the BEA table of the GDP price deflators.

[Bears]: And if you look at that, it tells a little bit of a different story.

[Bears]: Even when PCE for like the average person was 4%, for example, in 2021, for state and local government, it was 6.7.

[Bears]: In 2021, it was,

[Bears]: 7.1, 2022 for PCE, generally it's 8.0 for state and local.

[Bears]: State and local price inflators tend to be higher than the PCE.

[Bears]: It's PCE, but it's just PCE broken down for state and local.

[Bears]: It tends to be higher.

[Bears]: I appreciate your comment.

[Bears]: I agree that the new growth element is a factor here, right?

[Bears]: And I think Matt was saying over the last, since 1980, I can't remember the fact, it's not 2.5% that we've averaged, it's 3.1 or something like that because of the new growth.

[Bears]: In the last couple of years, the new growth is significantly higher.

[Bears]: So I think we're at like four, but we're also talking about 4% when we're looking at a cost increase of eight, right?

[Bears]: So it's still running behind.

[Bears]: Someone put out a great chart where it was showing the real,

[Bears]: a nominal dollar increase and then it also had a graph of the inflation adjusted real dollar increase.

[Bears]: And I think personally we're catching up for 2020 to 2023 here with this override.

[Bears]: And to me, now we're going back and forth, and this is just because I- We're already gutting up.

[Bears]: I enjoy this.

[Bears]: I mean, I think this override catches us up to where we need to be, where the new growth, it fits to me what I'm seeing as this is the one time we're going to have to ask for this outside of the high school, because the new growth will get us there in five to 10 years.

[Bears]: And this catches us up from the inflation adjustments that we need over the past few years.

[Bears]: So, thanks.

[Bears]: I like arguing about PC with people.

[Bears]: We'll go to Zoom, and then we'll go to the podium.

[Bears]: Zoom, I have Mike name and address.

[Bears]: Second question, you have two minutes if you want to ask a question and make a comment.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Any further comments on that comment or question from members of the council?

[Bears]: Seeing none, we'll go to the podium.

[Bears]: Our esteemed election commissioner and former school committee member.

[Bears]: 24482, offered under suspension by the entire Medford City Council, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we hold a moment of silence in honor of our beloved City Messenger, Lawrence Lepore, who passed away last night from cancer, an Army veteran,

[Bears]: Larry loved, lived, and breathed Medford.

[Bears]: He loved City Hall.

[Bears]: He loved his job as city messenger, and he loved working with this council and his colleagues in the clerk's office.

[Bears]: He was a calming and steady presence at council meetings, and he provided wise counsel to anyone who sought his advice.

[Bears]: We offer our deepest and most sincere condolences to Larry's family, to his friends, and to all who loved him, be it further resolved that the Medford City Council dedicate tonight's meeting in Larry's memory.

[Bears]: who's an incredible steward of the city council and the chambers and was so dedicated to his role.

[Bears]: He'll be truly missed both as an individual and for all he brought to this body.

[Bears]: And I get the difficult task of going last, but Larry once said to me, so long as you're not throwing chairs at each other, it's a good night.

[Bears]: Because I think he saw someone almost throw a chair at someone.

[Bears]: maybe this side to this side.

[Bears]: I think anyone who's only sat on this side has missed out sitting over here and seeing Larry's face and being able to make that eye contact with him.

[Bears]: And sitting up here too, it's been interesting the first few months of this term, but I didn't get to know Larry as well as I wanted.

[Bears]: I've known him for five years.

[Bears]: The first few years were the pandemic.

[Bears]: We were on Zoom.

[Bears]: Larry's still coming to my house every day, every Friday, bringing the papers and whatnot, but didn't get

[Bears]: uh, really to get to know him until we were back here and we were able to talk more before and after meetings during expected and unexpected recesses.

[Bears]: Um, but I always like to think of it kind of how Councilor Scarpelli did.

[Bears]: If you were hearing words of encouragement from Larry, he didn't have a great day, but he, he presented it in a nice way.

[Bears]: If you're having words of respect from Larry, you had a decent day.

[Bears]: He did.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: And if you had words of pride from Larry, you had a really good day.

[Bears]: And I was lucky enough to experience all three.

[Bears]: I probably have a warped sense in my mind that may be more pride than encouragement, but it was really just helpful to be able to talk to Larry about just have all that knowledge, decades of knowledge of this body and these meetings, to talk to someone with a different perspective on a lot of issues, but then find a lot of common ground.

[Bears]: And I know that he will be missed by this body, by the former members, by a lot of people in City Hall and certainly by his family.

[Bears]: He was just a really wonderful, kind, caring person who I really enjoyed spending time with in the limited ways that I was able to.

[Bears]: And I know there are a lot of people who got to enjoy a lot more time with Larry who aren't going to be able to share that time with him anymore.

[Bears]: So I'm thinking of them because if I feel this way, I can only imagine how they feel.

[Bears]: Zoom link posted no later than Friday, petitioned by Boston Gas DBA National Grid for installing a new gas main in Hale Avenue, plan marked W01530950 Hale Avenue, Medford MA, date of July 20th, 2023,

[Bears]: The purpose of this position is to install approximately 160 feet of new gas main in Hill Street in accordance with plan DPL MED 080248-1043 filed in the office of the city clerk.

[Bears]: This has been approved by the chief engineer, city engineer with the following conditions.

[Bears]: The engineering division recommends this grant application be approved with the following conditions.

[Bears]: Granted location is limited to the approximately 160 feet of four inch gas main depicted on the plan.

[Bears]: Before starting work, the contractor shall notify DigSafe and obtain all applicable permits from engineering division.

[Bears]: Project must obtain a trench permit pertinent to section 74-141 of the city ordinances prior to commencing work.

[Bears]: No other utility structures, conduits, duct banks, or other appurtenances are adversely impacted.

[Bears]: National Grid shall insure all sewer, water, and drain lines are marked prior to excavation.

[Bears]: Project site must be swept daily after installation or daily, shall be kept free of debris for the duration of installation, at least 72 hours prior to the start of the project.

[Bears]: National Grid must coordinate and better communications with the Director of Communications and submit any required information that may be requested to effectively inform the public.
