[Bears]: So two years ago, a little past that.

[Bears]: We had a little bit of a disagreement, I would say, the mayor and I, over the budget.

[Bears]: And, you know, and I think it's important to sort of like, just be straight up, right?

[Bears]: Council had some serious questions about the budget.

[Bears]: We wanted to talk about an improved budget process.

[Bears]: We wanted to talk about the underfunding issue.

[Bears]: Council Vice President Collins and I were, had identified the need, the significant underfunding and the excuse of what type of funds to fund operating expenses.

[Bears]: And that budget went to the last, I think, 2 a.m.

[Bears]: meeting, the Mayor came out, and at the end of it, we made some improvements to the budget, and we talked about what we'd do the following year, and that budget actually passed, I think, unanimously, or at least the Councilor and I next to me voted for it at the end of the night.

[Bears]: The next year we came back and we took a bit of a different approach, really focusing on what would a better budget process for the city look like.

[Bears]: And what ended up happening, the council collectively again unanimously put forward a set of budget requests, budget demands in a sense.

[Bears]: President Morell at the time, Nicole Morell and I went and met with the mayor and we sat down and we said, here's what the council wants.

[Bears]: We want a better budget process, we want more funding for our schools, we want more funding for our library.

[Bears]: And what we were able to negotiate on behalf of the council as council leadership with the mayor was three things.

[Bears]: The formation of a financial task force,

[Bears]: consisting of the leadership of the school committee, the city council, and the mayor, the commitment to establish a new budget process through a budget ordinance, which we passed this year and used in this year's budget, starting the process earlier than ever in the most transparent way possible, and the commitment to really address this issue of underfunding.

[Bears]: And that's what the financial task force did.

[Bears]: We've released, again, multiple press releases.

[Bears]: We announced it at the budget time last year.

[Bears]: We announced the formation of the task force, and then we announced

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And I think the Mayor can speak to it too, right?

[Bears]: Just to get to this budget, we basically didn't do $3 million worth of looking at the Mayor for it, because she did approximately $3 million worth of stuff that we wanted to start doing this year about that on the city side.

[Bears]: So, when you talk about having enough people to make sure that city government is performing its basic services,

[Bears]: just another impact if it doesn't happen.

[Bears]: You know, we're talking, I think you guys mentioned it before, right?

[Bears]: Not only would we likely have to cut many of the things that are funded by one-time funds, but there certainly would not be an opportunity for the city to add a staff member in a key office.

[Bears]: That's where it's currently needed.

[Bears]: The other thing I just want to say, going quickly back to the grant side of things, grants are 99% of the time one-time or short-term funds.

[Bears]: Whether it's one year, two years, or three years, eventually the

[Bears]: It's not a sustainable way to fund a permanent operating budget.

[Bears]: The reason we're talking about an override and talking about property taxes is because it is a permanent revenue source to fund ongoing expenses.

[Bears]: And the great sad impact of Proposition 2.5 was that sustainable revenue went away.

[Bears]: You know, DPW 40 years ago had twice as many people working here.

[Bears]: Now we're talking about just having people to work there to fill potholes, because we don't even have that anymore.

[Bears]: And I think that's a legacy both of the Proposition 2.5 law and 45 years of not being willing to say to the voters, yeah, this is hard, but we need to ask us to come together and fund these things.

[Bears]: Otherwise, they're not going to get done.

[Bears]: And as Dana mentioned, then it just snowballs and gets worse and worse and worse.

[Bears]: Thanks, and I just want to make kind of two points.

[Bears]: I think what the mayor said about there are things that are not set in stone and need to be tweaked, I think that's important.

[Bears]: I think we've heard from some folks that there are tweaks that they would like to see made.

[Bears]: I think this question of the clean zones and the phasing for folks, firefighters coming back from a firefighter, from a fire.

[Bears]: Some questions around showers and bunk space.

[Bears]: But there's two things here.

[Bears]: Voting yes on question six is about voting yes on a five and six mechanism, not a final design.

[Bears]: The State Department of Revenue has very clear guidelines that say minor project changes, inflationary adjustments due to construction and timing can adjust the size of the bond slightly.

[Bears]: It's not gonna jump from a $30 million bond to a $40 million bond.

[Bears]: It's not gonna happen, but it might be from 30 to 31 or 32 if there are minor project changes that need to happen.

[Bears]: So my hope is, as the mayor noted, there's a concept design.

[Bears]: It's not a final design.

[Bears]: There's been statements at the Council Q&A last week from firefighters around things that they would like to see different, and I think we can vote yes on the financing mechanism, and my hope would be that as the design moves from a concept design to a final design, those project changes can happen.

[Bears]: The mayor mentioned earlier the exemptions available through the assessor's office.

[Bears]: They are the maximum exemptions allowed by state law.

[Bears]: Only state representatives and state senators can increase them.

[Bears]: The council and the mayor's office have been really intentional about maximizing, making sure that we're doing the most that the state allows us to do, and then tying our own exemptions to the state law so that if it ever goes up, Medford's go up automatically.

[Bears]: There's been some talk that seniors could be exempted.

[Bears]: There's nothing in the Proposition 2 12 law that allows that.

[Bears]: It just doesn't exist.

[Bears]: It's not true.

[Bears]: So it's a difficult situation.

[Bears]: We are doing, as a city, the most that the state law allows us to do to try to protect all the people that the state law allows us to protect through exemptions.

[Bears]: We have the deferral program.

[Bears]: Yes, there's 5% interest on the deferral program, but again,

[Bears]: that is what the state law allows.

[Bears]: I think we maybe could reduce that to as low as 2%, something we could look at 4%, so we're at 5 and you go down to 4, thank you.

[Bears]: We could look at that, but we'd still have to talk to assessing, you know, and what would the impact of that be?

[Bears]: There's the work-off program, but again, I think Anna's point

[Bears]: is incredibly restrictive about what it allows municipalities to do.

[Bears]: I wish we had a very different local tax system that could much more target and direct the impact and who's paying what taxes, but we have a flat property tax with limited exemptions, and that's what the state wants.

[Bears]: Yeah, I think just to add to what Jenny said, you can also just not make decisions, right?

[Bears]: And I think that's the other thing.

[Bears]: Camps have been kicked out of the road for decades.

[Bears]: Some good things have happened.

[Bears]: There have been projects that have founded the norm.

[Bears]: I think the new schools project is one of them.

[Bears]: But most basic maintenance, basic staffing, fixing 100

[Bears]: Having enough staff to do the basic job of what a city needs to do has basically just not happened, and now that has created a massive debt that is coming due.

[Bears]: It is a difficult inflection point, and it sounds like the library is closing soon.

[Bears]: But there's another thing right there.

[Bears]: Our library is not open on Sundays.

[Bears]: Most libraries are.

[Bears]: Our library closes early on Saturdays.

[Bears]: You can find every department, every single thing that the city does.

[Bears]: It's generally a little less than most other places because we don't have the funds to do it.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam President, Madam Chair.

[Bears]: Again, I think we need to talk about what the process actually was in the RFP, which discussed us having specific public meetings around specific proposals for specific neighborhoods.

[Bears]: This is a public meeting on the Mystic App proposal.

[Bears]: We can talk about the process that got us here.

[Bears]: Again, robust, extensive, comprehensive planning over two years.

[Bears]: feedback from thousands of residents, et cetera.

[Bears]: When you read the RFP, when you read the contract that was awarded, we talked about holding public process and public meetings throughout on specific proposals for specific areas.

[Bears]: We've had multiple meetings to generate this.

[Bears]: We're now having a meeting on the final draft proposal coming out of committee.

[Bears]: It goes to council for automatic referral to Community Development Board, where there'll be another public hearing on this proposal.

[Bears]: a community meeting, whatever we want to call it.

[Bears]: There's public meetings ahead on this proposal specific to Mystic Avenue.

[Bears]: And that's the process.

[Bears]: So we are having the public meetings and engaging the residents.

[Bears]: on these proposals based on the two plus years of public engagement and community engagement that's already happened to develop the city comprehensive plan.

[Bears]: We're now executing on literally years of community process and engagement around this issue.

[Bears]: We've heard from residents around Mystic Avenue multiple times on proposals and on the ideas of what was in the comprehensive plan.

[Bears]: And now we have a draft.

[Bears]: This public meeting is occurring.

[Bears]: There will be the meeting

[Bears]: about how we communicate this process, and I mean this for all stakeholders here and those who have been part of this so far.

[Bears]: the public to be able to access the different pieces of the project as we move along.

[Bears]: 20th regular meeting Medford City Council October 2024 Mr. Clerk, please call the roll Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: announcements, accolades, remembrances, reports, and records.

[Bears]: 24480, offered by President Bears, resolution to thank two DPW staff members for an act of kindness and their dedicated service to Medford.

[Bears]: Whereas on Saturday, October 5th, quick thinking by DPW employees, Jeff Gangy and Anthony Pompeo helped return a lost wallet to Robert Bohannon, an 82 year old disabled veteran.

[Bears]: And whereas Mr. Bohannon was deeply thankful to have the wallet returned, both because it was designed by his late brother and because the cards and information would have taken months to replace, describing the act, quote, as quote, as close to a miracle as we have experienced and,

[Bears]: Whereas Mr. Bohannon and his wife wanted to express their gratitude and, quote, do something for these really thoughtful employees while noting that, quote, they wouldn't take anything and including his letter with the words, quote, we love Medford.

[Bears]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford City Council that we thank Jeff Genge and Anthony Pompeo from our DPW for their dedicated service to the city of Medford and honor their active service and kindness that was described as Mr. Bohannon as, quote, the best of many great moments I've experienced in Medford.

[Bears]: For me, we just got a really, really kind email and I felt like it was worth saying thanks.

[Bears]: reports of committees 24475 offered by council President Bears committee of the whole October 15 2024.

[Bears]: This was the question and answer session that we held October 15 regarding the proposed override and debt exclusion ballot questions that are on the ballot on November 5.

[Bears]: And just a point of note, as regards to the voting Councilor Scarpelli raised to me the point of

[Bears]: the letting people know if you're coming in, we're seeing a lot of early voting, a lot of mail voting.

[Bears]: And just a reminder to everyone, when you early vote or you mail vote, your ballot is put into a sealed envelope and that envelope is opened on election day and counted on election day.

[Bears]: So if you're expecting it to run through the machine on the early voter, the mail vote, that's not how the state law around elections work.

[Bears]: So those envelopes will be opened by the elections department staff on election day and then will be run through the machines on election day, along with all the ballots of everyone who votes on election day.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: We do have a petition from Marian Tomaszczuk.

[Bears]: We have here October 23rd, 2024 petition to the Honorable City Council, Councilors, the undersigned respectfully pray for discussion of the well-used parking lot adjacent to the Medford Senior Center.

[Bears]: So recognize Marian and we will go from there.

[Bears]: No.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: and then we'll go to, I'm gonna read the response, we'll go to councilors, then we'll go to the public.

[Bears]: I have here to Council President Bears and honorable members of the council regarding the public participation petition respectfully submitted for your honorable body's consideration as additional information about activities concerning the municipally owned parking lot at 75 Riverside Avenue.

[Bears]: Clippership pop-up as of October 9th, the corner of the parking lot has been repurposed to create

[Bears]: Oh, sorry, repurpose to create the clipper ship pop up park, the pop up is utilized by the city, particularly the recreation department for periodic programming and is otherwise open for passive recreation to the public.

[Bears]: To create the pop-up park, no parking spaces were lost.

[Bears]: The pop-up area was created from what was a previously redundant drive aisle and six parking spots.

[Bears]: To prevent any loss of parking, eight new parking spots were re-striped in the parking lot, resulting in a net positive for parking spaces overall.

[Bears]: Please see photos below demonstrating locations of eight new parking spaces.

[Bears]: Request for proposals Medford Square, the city published an RFP request for proposal for three underutilized parcels behind City Hall on September 30th, 2024.

[Bears]: The city wants to garner interest from developers to explore what redevelopment options there would be for these three combined parcels, including mixed use buildings, affordable housing and parking structures.

[Bears]: The city will enter a long-term ground lease for up to 99 years with a qualified developer for these parcels.

[Bears]: The due date for responses is December 20th, 2024 at 1 p.m.

[Bears]: Community outreach for this project was conducted through focus groups and community meetings through the Transforming the Square project in partnership with Metropolitan Area Planning Council in 2023.

[Bears]: MAPC conducted research using previous plans and site visits of the square.

[Bears]: Please note that parking for our seniors is a top priority for the city.

[Bears]: The mayor explicitly mentioned this in her greeting to developers before the walkthrough last week.

[Bears]: Construction employee parking.

[Bears]: Due to the large-scale construction project at 121 Riverside Avenue, the adjacent Clippership lot has seen an influx of commercial and personal vehicle parking to accommodate workers and staff.

[Bears]: As a result of this temporary parking situation, the mayor contacted Medford Housing Authority Director Jeffrey Driscoll to get a more complete breakdown of what vehicles are occupying spaces during the day, how long this disruption is anticipated and how a compromise can be reached to alleviate community concerns and allow accessibility to the worksite.

[Bears]: The mayor concluded that there were up to an additional 40 cars due to the lot construction.

[Bears]: Director Driscoll has been receptive and helpful.

[Bears]: He reached out to the contractor for support

[Bears]: Jim Silva, Special Project Coordinator, also visited the lot earlier last week and requested that the workers use the lower City Hall lot instead so that seniors had spots when visiting the Senior Center.

[Bears]: It is a work in progress to get the construction workers to relocate, but we are doing everything possible as parking for our seniors is our priority.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: And I'll recognize Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Any further comments?

[Bears]: Council Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: We'll go to Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: So there would be further public meetings regarding the proposal, and it would require a vote of the council to authorize the city to lease the land.

[Bears]: Go to Councilor Callahan, then we'll go back to the microphone for public participation.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I do want to just make a point.

[Bears]: I don't disagree with what you said and engaging people is really important, but I just want to be clear that going to the RFP was not the first thing as part of this process.

[Bears]: This process references the 2017 Medford Square plan under Mayor Burke.

[Bears]: There was a 2019 evaluation of development potential under Mayor Burke.

[Bears]: the 2022 housing plan and the 2022 draft comprehensive plan.

[Bears]: And there were multiple community meetings last year before the drafting of this RFP, including two at the senior center.

[Bears]: So, you know, that work has happened.

[Bears]: Maybe not everyone went to every meeting, but when we talk about what happened, I just think that should be noted.

[Bears]: There was two public meetings at the senior center talking about this project and the transforming the square initiative.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And I certainly don't disagree with that.

[Bears]: I do know that the office worked with the senior center to get the word out.

[Bears]: And I am hopeful, again, we heard from Dan Kennedy recently online about a city newspaper.

[Bears]: We need that level of information and resource, but there have been meetings and we do do as much outreach as we can.

[Bears]: And that doesn't always reach everyone, even when we try to reach everyone.

[Bears]: We'll go to Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I'll go to the podium, name and address for the record, and you'll have three minutes.

[Bears]: In terms of the Colleen's behind there, that's not part of the scope of the request for proposal.

[Bears]: Name and address the record, you have three minutes.

[Bears]: Yeah, so we don't have the proposals yet, but the request for proposals document says that parking is a priority and that the senior center parking needs to be replaced in full no matter what develops.

[Bears]: But the specific proposals such as height, et cetera, hasn't come out yet.

[Bears]: And that won't be out until after December 20th, which is the deadline for the proposals.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Any further discussion on this subject Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Yeah, I would just note.

[Bears]: 24484, resolution to adopt local options of HERO Act, whereas Governor Healey recently signed into law an act honoring, empowering, and recognizing our service members and veterans, also known as the HERO Act, Chapter 178 of the Acts of 2024, to increase benefits, modernize services, and promote inclusivity for veterans in Massachusetts, and whereas the HERO Act allows local option in which cities may tie property tax exemptions and veteran-specific exemptions to the Consumer Price Index

[Bears]: allowing for automatic year-to-year increases in these exemptions.

[Bears]: Now therefore be it resolved by the Medford City Council that the City of Medford accept General Law, Chapter 59, Section 5, Clause 22i, which authorizes an annual increase in the amount of the exemption granted under General Law, Chapter 59, Section 5, Clause 22, 22a, 22b, 22c, 22e, and 22f,

[Bears]: by the percentage increase in the U.S.

[Bears]: Department of Labor Bureau of Labor Statistics Consumer Price Index for the previous year as determined by the Department of Revenue to be effective for the applicable exemptions granted for any fiscal year beginning on or after July 1, 2025, and be it further resolved that the City of Medford accept the General Laws Chapter 59, Section 5, Clause 22J, which authorizes an annual increase in the amount of the exemption granted under General Laws Chapter 59, Section 5, Clauses 22,

[Bears]: 22A, 22B, 22C, 22E, and 22F by up to 100% of the personal exemption amount subject to the conditions in Clause 22J to be effective for applicable exemptions granted for any fiscal year beginning on or after July 1st, 2025.

[Bears]: 21st regular meeting Medford City Council November 12 2024 is called to order Mr. please call the roll Council Callahan, Vice President Collins Council is our Council Leming, Councilor Scarpelli, Councilor Tseng, President, President Bears present seven present none absent the meeting is called to order please rise to salute the flag.

[Bears]: Announcements accolades remembrances reports and records records the records of the meeting of October 29 2024 pastor Councilor Callahan Councilor Callahan how did you find those records.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Callahan to approve seconded by seconded by Councilor Collins Mr. Clerk please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes, 70 affirmative negative the motion passes.

[Bears]: Refer to committee for further discussion just a reminder that the intent of this section is for us to refer items to committee for further discussion, no final action will be taken on these items during this meeting.

[Bears]: 24491 resolution to discuss compensation ordinance for elected officials.

[Bears]: It looks like there's an amended version resolution to discuss ordinance to disallow the city council from passing any salary changes that affect sitting elected officials by councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Whereas only the city council can change the salaries of Medford elected officials, mayor, city council and school committee.

[Bears]: And whereas there's no way for elected officials to adjust elected official salaries for inflation or general cost of living increases without the city council voting to change elected official salaries.

[Bears]: And whereas there is a personal incentive for city Councilors to increase their own salaries, whereas the city council increasing salaries that are increasing salaries of others is viewed as in form of impropriety and be it resolved that this governance committee take up an ordinance to disallow the city council from passing any salary changes that affect sitting elected officials and to encourage city council to consider Cola adjustments for elected officials in the next cycle.

[Bears]: I would just note before turning this over for a brief, I hope, discussion or introduction by the proponent before the motion to refer to committee that I don't think an ordinance would affect this at all we already have three charter and state laws that affect this so as a plan a charter chapter 4317 a.

[Bears]: already applies to the city.

[Bears]: Chapter 71, section 52 governs how school committees are compensated.

[Bears]: And then the acts of 2002 chapter 447 is a Medford specific law that would supersede any ordinance passed by the city.

[Bears]: So the way to go at this is with charter amendment, not with an ordinance.

[Bears]: But with that, I will go to Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: We're on the motion of Councilor Callahan to refer to governance committee seconded by Councilor Collins, excuse me, please wait.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Any further discussion by members of the council.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Well, what I can say is that state law controls here no matter what, but I will go to councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: You've amended your resolution.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I would just note again,

[Bears]: The existing law for the school committee is Chapter 71 Section 52, which means we have to do that.

[Bears]: And the existing law for the city is the Mass General Law Acts of 2002 Chapter 447, which I think was an attempt to in 2003 to try to get this to be more of a something that happens as

[Bears]: part of the course of other folks, specifically that says that the mayor and the council salaries would increase the same amount as the director of budgets, finance director, director of community development, city clerk, city treasurer, city solicitor, chief assessor, the average percentage for those offices.

[Bears]: So those are the current laws that apply.

[Bears]: Any further discussion from members of the council before I go back to Councilor Callahan?

[Bears]: Seeing none, I'll go to Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: So first of all, that has been removed and that's like... I think the problem is that we didn't need to have this discussion right now.

[Bears]: That's the issue.

[Bears]: I mean, I just think this is a waste of everyone's time to be completely honest.

[Bears]: There's a law in place.

[Bears]: And in fact, the city council and the mayor, like what the law is, is that when other people's salaries go up, the senior management of the city, the council and the mayor salary would also go up by that same average percentage.

[Bears]: That's the current law on the books.

[Bears]: That's what happened in June.

[Bears]: So I think there's misrepresentation on all sides of what happened.

[Bears]: And I think that's just my perspective.

[Bears]: And I apologize for

[Bears]: just giving my opinion from the chair without recognizing anybody else, but I just didn't like, really don't think this is a productive conversation on any front, because everybody seems pretty confused and frustrated on all sides.

[Bears]: There was a motion to refer it to committee.

[Bears]: It was seconded, Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Give me one second.

[Bears]: Go ahead.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: I'm gonna go to Councilor Leming, then Councilor Scarpelli, Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: I'm just gonna let him finish and you can go.

[Bears]: Well, I think we just did a very good thing for our community, but...

[Bears]: Let's not get back and forth, guys.

[Bears]: I hear you, but let's not go for it.

[Bears]: The salaries may be increased at the recommendation of the Mayor and the approval of the City Council if the salaries of each of the following officers of the City of Medford are increased.

[Bears]: Director of Budgets and Personnel, Finance Director Auditor, Director of Community Development, City Clerk, City Treasurer,

[Bears]: collector city solicitor and the chief assessor appraiser.

[Bears]: Any salary increase for the office of mayor and the members of the city council should not increase exceed the average percentage by which the salaries for the aforesaid officers is increased.

[Bears]: There's no one in the chamber, no.

[Bears]: Present.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: Thank you to my colleagues.

[Bears]: I won't reiterate the points and discussions that have already been made, but I do want to focus in on

[Bears]: specifics around the legality here.

[Bears]: I agree that it's shameful that corporations have managed to get the government to pass legislation and write regulations that gives them so much authority and takes authority away from local governments that are really responsible for these decisions at the end of the day.

[Bears]: But I do want to propose a B paper, and I'll get to the text of it in a second, that focuses on the legal matters here.

[Bears]: There were two

[Bears]: orders issued by the FCC in 2018.

[Bears]: An August 2018 moratoria order and a September 2018 small cell order that essentially is the reason that we're in this position.

[Bears]: Completely limits the ability of local governments to address the issue.

[Bears]: Those orders have been litigated.

[Bears]: Communities have challenged those orders and all the way up to the Ninth District Court, the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals, and the litigation has been denied.

[Bears]: Courts have said that the FCC order is a blanket, that that is, you know, that that's the law.

[Bears]: So I agree that with what Councilor Knight said especially, this is not, you know, something that we should be voting on.

[Bears]: But at the end of the day, unless we have a change in federal law and unless state laws are changed, if there's litigation, it'll be moved up to the chain, you know, moving up the chain of courts and eventually Verizon will force its way through anyway.

[Bears]: and it will also cost the city money according to the FCC order.

[Bears]: So I'd like to propose a B paper specifically focused on the legal question, which is that the city council request that the Biden administration, the FCC, and our federal delegation amend the FCC's August 2018 moratoria order and September 2018 small cell order to remove restrictions on local government authority to regulate the design

[Bears]: replacement and installation of 5G small cell transmitters.

[Bears]: And that we receive a reply within 30 days.

[Bears]: And Mr. Clerk, I'm going to send that to you right now.

[Bears]: And I appreciate the comments of my colleagues.

[Bears]: I just wanted to focus specifically on that legal question.

[Bears]: Because, you know, we may find ourselves right back in the same position after years of lawsuits.

[Bears]: I think we lost the council chambers.

[Bears]: Mr. President, could we hear from attorney wall before we go into questions?

[Bears]: OK.

[Bears]: We can't hear if people aren't speaking into the microphone.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: I want to thank you for your presentation.

[Bears]: Thank the CD board and the Conservation Commission members for what seemed to be some significant improvements since the start of the project.

[Bears]: I think my questions may be better suited for Patrick from BJ's.

[Bears]: Hi, Patrick.

[Bears]: My first question is, how long do you expect this station to be operational?

[Bears]: You know, 10 years, 20 years?

[Bears]: Um, and do you have an expectation of the annual revenue that you're going to be gaining from this facility?

[Bears]: Um, I think that would be helpful for us to understand as well.

[Bears]: Cause you know, I appreciate what you're saying about your customers, but I think you as a, as a business also have a vested interest.

[Bears]: You wouldn't be putting this forward if it wasn't going to, to make you money.

[Bears]: Um, the third piece of this that I want to ask about is, you know,

[Bears]: If this project doesn't finally get final approval, would you commit to making some of the improvements around safety and environmental protection that are included in this plan?

[Bears]: Or some of it.

[Bears]: I mean, it seems like currently we have runoff going into a stream, et cetera.

[Bears]: No, I'm just wondering.

[Bears]: I mean, it just, you know, it kind of goes to, I appreciate the comments from my fellow Councilors, Scarpelli and Falco, you know, about stewardship and, you know, being a member of the community, it seems like there are some ongoing issues.

[Bears]: And then finally, you know,

[Bears]: If, I guess, say there's a 15 year lifespan, what would the process be for removing the facility if it eventually closes?

[Bears]: Got it, I appreciate that.

[Bears]: To me, this seems like a little bit of a short-term plan

[Bears]: Um, and not necessarily where we're going in the long term to be installing a gas station at this late stage in, in our energy transition.

[Bears]: Now that the community process is underway, and now that it's clear that the developer and the Historical Commission and the Historic District Commission are near to a good faith compromise, I think we should approve the district, ensuring that the community process can continue without the threat of demolition hanging over the discussions and the goal of compromise.

[Bears]: I think 16 Foster Court clearly deserves the historic designation, regardless of the compromise.

[Bears]: I'm hopeful that it will keep the facade of the building and that we can really celebrate the shipbuilding history of the city of Medford.

[Bears]: I think you've had an incredibly difficult job over these past several months, keeping people alive, keeping people safe and healthy.

[Bears]: We all want things to go back to normal.

[Bears]: We all want things to be the way they were before, but we are where we are.

[Bears]: You know, we have positive tests at some point in the Medford Public Schools.

[Bears]: So that's the intent of this resolution.

[Bears]: And I think just if I may for a moment, you know, one piece of this is conversations and dialogue.

[Bears]: And I think that's important.

[Bears]: It's important for bringing people together.

[Bears]: It's important for changing hearts and minds.

[Bears]: And it's important for meeting across differences.

[Bears]: And I think there's a lot of value there.

[Bears]: And I do want to know what the administration is doing on that front.

[Bears]: The other piece of this is policy and change.

[Bears]: What are we doing to review city policies to make sure that they don't have disparate impact?

[Bears]: What are we doing to review city ordinances and our city budget to see that we're funding, our funding priorities are meeting the stated verbal priorities that we're putting out there.

[Bears]: What are we doing when it comes to zoning and housing production and environmental justice and climate change to address racial inequities that cross all of those intersections?

[Bears]: So, you know, a piece of this is dialogue and conversation that I think is very, very important.

[Bears]: And I think the other piece is the work of government.

[Bears]: What are our policies?

[Bears]: How are they being reviewed?

[Bears]: And I think some of it as well, we've had some meetings as a council in subcommittee.

[Bears]: We've had discussions in full council.

[Bears]: The mayor's administration facilitated some conversations last year, and that was a good starting point, I think.

[Bears]: But again, it was volunteers.

[Bears]: It was people scrambling to get people to facilitate breakout rooms.

[Bears]: It wasn't like,

[Bears]: we were putting together a full plan and saying, here's how we're going to fund it.

[Bears]: This is the purpose that it's going to seek.

[Bears]: So, you know, I think concreteness is important.

[Bears]: I think understanding the outcomes we're trying to achieve is important.

[Bears]: And I especially think that paired with good conversation and dialogue must be the real work of looking into, you know, and I think we all know this as well on many fronts, we have many old policies and old forms and old ways that we do things.

[Bears]: Maybe we need to take a look at some of those I'm not going to lay out any specifics, I want to hear what what's happening I want the administration to report back on what they've been doing.

[Bears]: And I just hope that the answer isn't insufficient.

[Bears]: Maybe it will be maybe it won't be.

[Bears]: We need to know what the administration is doing on policy.

[Bears]: And then I also hope that we as a council will continue to raise these efforts.

[Bears]: And to be honest, I think we have brought this up when it comes to zoning recodification, we've had some good discussions.

[Bears]: When it comes to the marijuana zoning ordinance, we had some good discussions and put some strong equity provisions in there.

[Bears]: We have made some declarations as well.

[Bears]: Is it enough?

[Bears]: I think maybe we need to do more, but you know,

[Bears]: We've taken some steps.

[Bears]: I want to hear what the administration steps are.

[Bears]: And I'm very hopeful that in the next round of budget discussions, we will have that more clearly outlined in, in both staffing and programming.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Mr. President.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: The king of Paris Street.

[Bears]: Mr. President, point of personal privilege, if I may.

[Bears]: I'm sorry to do this to everyone at the end of the meeting, but I'm a little sorry.

[Bears]: I just want to make a quick statement, if you'll indulge me.

[Bears]: This is just on reference to something I said last week.

[Bears]: You know, the word totalitarianism was brought up to describe our form of government.

[Bears]: And I made a comment that this is democracy.

[Bears]: And I just would like to clarify, because there's been some commentary and speculation about what I was saying, that I was talking about the election.

[Bears]: I was talking about who I'm supporting in the local election.

[Bears]: And I just want to make a quick point.

[Bears]: It actually relates exactly to what General Elasky and Judy Murray have been doing for several decades in this community, which is

[Bears]: about democracy and the fact that we're blessed in our country and in our city to have a government of, for, and by the people.

[Bears]: that we elect our leaders by majority vote.

[Bears]: And if we like them, we can keep them.

[Bears]: And if we don't, we can elect somebody else.

[Bears]: You know, we've seen a lot of people on television and online making statements and lying to undermine our democratic process.

[Bears]: And, you know, occasionally people bring those lies into this room.

[Bears]: They throw around words like totalitarianism to describe our democratic process.

[Bears]: And it more than frustrates me.

[Bears]: I don't know what that beeping is, but

[Bears]: Well, I'm gonna wait, or if you take it out of the room, thank you.

[Bears]: I won't start over.

[Bears]: But I'll just continue to say that it more than frustrates me when people come in here and throw around words like that when we have a democratic system of government.

[Bears]: Everyone behind this rail, our school committee, and the mayor was elected democratically by the people.

[Bears]: None of us are perfect.

[Bears]: We're all going to make mistakes.

[Bears]: And I think I know better than most that I'm not always going to get my way.

[Bears]: Nobody's always going to get their way.

[Bears]: And that's what democracy is about.

[Bears]: It's a blessing and a gift handed down to us by the people who came before us that many people have fought for died for on battlefields and in streets across this country.

[Bears]: It's our job to preserve that to improve that.

[Bears]: and not to decry and undermine that.

[Bears]: So when I said last week that this is not totalitarianism and it's an election season, I wasn't speaking in a small and parochial way.

[Bears]: I was speaking in a way that's bigger than every one of us and any one of us.

[Bears]: We are blessed that every two years at every level of government, we get a peaceful revolution.

[Bears]: We get to decide our future and we get to preserve, protect and improve democracy.

[Bears]: That's what we all are here to do.

[Bears]: That's what I will continue to do as long as the people of Medford allow me to do it.

[Bears]: And I just wanted to make that clear to folks online who thought I was making a snide comment when I was actually talking about something much more important than that.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Aye.

[Bears]: There is the one on Mystic Valley Parkway.

[Bears]: There's also one on the Fells way and now combined properties has issued.

[Bears]: At least started the process around Mystic Avenue.

[Bears]: These are I mean I think those add up to almost a thousand new units.

[Bears]: It might even be more than that.

[Bears]: I'll have to double check my math.

[Bears]: But obviously that's significant new development.

[Bears]: And it's happening under state statute that limits some of our ability to control development.

[Bears]: I think as I've said many times to people that all of this development should be community driven.

[Bears]: We need to have community driven processes to make sure that development is happening.

[Bears]: The way that we wanted to happen, not the way that developers wanted to happen, but as I said, anything that's coming through 40 B puts us in a much more difficult position to get that done.

[Bears]: We will need strong community and administrative pushback, or at least, you know, really a strong movement around these projects to see what we can do.

[Bears]: To make them fit into the community and in a reasonable way if possible.

[Bears]: And I think it just speaks a couple things specifically on 40 B that I want to get out there.

[Bears]: It really speaks to the need to get to safe harbor around this so that we can make sure that developers are negotiating with the city and with the community.

[Bears]: And also just speaks to the fact that on any of these in any of these developments all of the affordable you know the defined affordable units need to be in perpetuity.

[Bears]: We need to make sure that those units are permanent to the best extent possible.

[Bears]: And I want to turn it over to Councilor Morell, who I believe spoke to the administration and has some updates as well.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: Just a point of information, which is that even if we were to do a moratorium because of how Chapter 40B is written, these projects could move forward anyway.

[Bears]: So that's kind of the crux of the issue here, is we need to

[Bears]: That that if we did a moratorium then and then we could still get 40 B applications in that move through the process outside of our zoning and height and design restrictions and whatnot.

[Bears]: So so that's part of the point is I think we need to get to that safe harbor point where 40 B is not the threat that it is right now.

[Bears]: I don't know if that's, yeah.

[Bears]: Somerville was at their 10% safe harbor threshold, so they couldn't get 40B the way that we can, being under that percentage.

[Bears]: Thank you Mr. President.

[Bears]: So I think there's two issues here.

[Bears]: One is let me preface this.

[Bears]: So the issue here is that the council should have the ability to have its own legal services for a variety of reasons.

[Bears]: I think in just permanently I think it's important for the council to have that resource so that we can get legal opinions and have legal services independent of the executive branch of the city administration.

[Bears]: I think that will be always permanent but also

[Bears]: I think the current circumstances facing the city bring us to.

[Bears]: I won't say a unique point but kind of we're coming to a head with the amount of ordinances and other work that we're going to need to do especially as a council.

[Bears]: And also we know the city solicitors currently enacting city solicitors so there is a process to hire a permanent city solicitor.

[Bears]: So I think there's both good reasons at all times why the council should have legal services and also very important reasons at this moment as to why the council should have legal services and

[Bears]: My motion on the issue would be that we make sure to add it to the future agenda of our committee of the whole meeting with the mayor, which I believe is forthcoming.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Six regular meeting February 2022 is now called the order, Mr. Clerk, please call the role.

[Bears]: Hearings 22-037, City of Medford, notice of a public hearing.

[Bears]: The Medford City Council will hold a continued public hearing in the Howard F. Alden Chambers at Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, and via Zoom on Tuesday, February 8th, 2022 at 7 p.m.

[Bears]: on a petition from Orville Anabazi of OBE's Auto Service to operate an automotive repair and auto body shop class four license at 38 Harvard Avenue, Medford MA 02155 in a commercial one zoning district.

[Bears]: A Zoom link for this meeting will be posted no later than February 4th, 2022.

[Bears]: Petition and plan may be seen in the office of the City Clerk, Medford City Hall, Medford, Massachusetts.

[Bears]: Call 781-393-2425 for any accommodations and aids.

[Bears]: TDD 781-393-2516.

[Bears]: The City of Medford is an equal opportunity employer.

[Bears]: By order of the Medford City Council, Adam Hurtubise, City Clerk.

[Bears]: Do I see Mr. Abbasi?

[Bears]: Is it here in person?

[Bears]: Wonderful.

[Bears]: I believe where we left this off was there was a question as to whether this was an allowed use under the special permit.

[Bears]: And I believe Councilor Knight has had some communications with city staff regarding that.

[Bears]: Councilor Knight.

[Bears]: I think you believe wrong.

[Bears]: I believe wrong.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: Well, in that case, Chair of Licensing, do you have a recommendation?

[Bears]: Yeah, yes 70 affirmative zero and the negative.

[Bears]: We've taken paper 22-073 which I'll now read 22-073 February 4 2022 by electronic delivery to the Honorable President and members of the Medford City Council City Hall Medford Massachusetts 02155.

[Bears]: Regarding Home Rule Petition Charter Commission, dear President Morell and members of the City Council, I respectfully request and recommend that your Honorable Body approve the following Home Rule Petition and transmit to the General Court for their consideration.

[Bears]: Thank you for your kind attention to this matter.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: The Home Rule Petition is the following, an act authorizing the election of a Charter Commission in the City of Medford.

[Bears]: being enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives and general court assembled and by the authority of the same as follows.

[Bears]: Section one, notwithstanding the provisions of chapter 43B of the general laws or any provisions of any general law, special law or regulation to the contrary, the city of Medford City Council shall at the first regular city election or earlier occurring special election held on or after the 60th day following the effective date of this act by order provided for the election of a nine member charter commission.

[Bears]: Section two, the charter commission shall be composed of one commissioner elected from each of the eight wards of the city and one elected at large.

[Bears]: In the event a charter commissioner elected to represent a particular ward should move within the city during their term of office, they may continue to serve as the representative from the ward from which they were elected.

[Bears]: The vacancy created by any commissioner who moves from the city during their term of office or who resigns may be filled by a majority vote of the entire commission.

[Bears]: other than section three other than as set forth here in the provisions of chapter 43b of the general law shall be applicable to the nomination and election of the charter commissioners and to the duties and responsibilities of the city and the charter commission elected here under section four this act shall take effect upon its passage and just to be clear the section two regarding eight

[Bears]: one commissioner elected from each of the eight words and one elected at largest for the Charter Commission, not that would not be for anything else just for the Charter Commission, that would be allowed by this whole petition.

[Bears]: Any Councilors?

[Bears]: Councilor Caraviello.

[Bears]: That's an amendment from Councilor Caraviello, so that any vacancy on the charter commission would be filled by the person who received the next most votes in the election to that commission.

[Bears]: Seconded by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Any further comments from members of the council?

[Bears]: That's the motion, please.

[Bears]: So motion by Councilor Scarpelli to refer this to committee of the whole seconded by seconded by Councilor Knight, further discussion, President Morell, and then Councilor Knight and then Councilor Collins and Councilor Kelly.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: These bills are all on a similar topic which is the accountability of large tax exempt institutions to municipalities here in the Commonwealth.

[Bears]: The first bill is H3080 and S1874 are regarding allowing local municipalities to set up a regulatory framework and require that large tax exempt institutions with values over $15 million excluding religious institutions can be required to pay up to 25% of what they would otherwise pay in property taxes.

[Bears]: The second bill H 3803 would have, I believe the Department of Revenue, study and examine, or maybe the Division of Local Services, examine how much municipal tax revenue is lost every year to large tax exempt institutions.

[Bears]: And the third bill is something this council has already voted through as a home roll petition, but still has not passed due to the objection of ACUM and the private college and university lobby, which is requiring an institutional master plan from Tufts University.

[Bears]: So these three bills, again, I believe all three of them survive joint roll 10 day and have extensions in their committees.

[Bears]: So it would be great if,

[Bears]: the state would allow us to over the objections of these, you know, very high paid lobbyists for these large private institutions allow cities and towns to adequately plan for and regulate and cooperate and collaborate with large tax exempt institutions, like large universities and hospital systems.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: This William you know I hadn't actually thought about this way before but the way that this is structured it would be a maximum 25% on what they would otherwise pay in property taxes.

[Bears]: Now, looking at the city's, you know, tax classification that's probably less than what the display is between land and buildings, but it is kind of similarly.

[Bears]: If they let us do our job, I wouldn't be filing these resolutions.

[Bears]: I remember probably like my third meeting.

[Bears]: I tried to vote present on something.

[Bears]: I got, I got told I couldn't.

[Bears]: 22-071 offered by Councilor Collins, whereas the Governor's fiscal year 2023 state budget proposal includes a 2.7% increase in unrestricted general government aid, and whereas this modest increase in local aid is disproportionate to the dramatic forecasted increase in 2023 state tax collections, 22% increase from

[Bears]: original FY22 base and 7.3% increase from calculation of base used to create the FY22 budget.

[Bears]: And whereas municipalities such as ours rely on state revenue sharing to balance local budgets and fund essential services, and as we contend with the ongoing pandemic recovery in the midst of economic inflation, these resources are needed as acutely as ever.

[Bears]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council express its support for a higher level of unrestricted general government aid in the fiscal year 2023 state budget.

[Bears]: Be it further resolved that the city clerk forward a copy of this resolution

[Bears]: to the Medford legislative delegation as well as Senate President Spoka and House Speaker Mariano, Councilor Collins.

[Bears]: 22-072 offered by councilor Collins.

[Bears]: Whereas in February, 2020, the Medford city council, Medford school committee and mayor pledged to make our city hunger free by 2028.

[Bears]: And whereas the pandemic conditions of the past two years has exacerbated hunger and food insecurity in Medford as in surrounding communities.

[Bears]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council reaffirm the pledge to make our city hunger-free by 2028.

[Bears]: Be it further resolved that the Medford City Council express support for expanding the city's capacity to address food insecurity, development of convenient and affordable food sources throughout Medford, and targeting our pandemic recovery resources towards ensuring that our community's basic needs are met.

[Bears]: State general law.

[Bears]: Which chapter, section?

[Bears]: All right, we're gonna take a minute to look at this.

[Bears]: Well, they were passed for first reading, so.

[Bears]: We don't have a specific chapter or section.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: My ruling is that it's an order with four votes, so unless there's a motion to count, my ruling is to chair.

[Bears]: I'm happy to review this before we do that, though, if folks would indulge me.

[Bears]: Yeah, I'm just going to, you know, considering that I don't have the specific citation and I don't want to delay the proceedings, the ruling of the chair is that the vote- Would we not want to err on the side of caution, considering we've taken an oath?

[Bears]: worked in good faith to delay for a week and now have a motion under suspension.

[Bears]: I just want to add that I fully support this.

[Bears]: I'm a neighbor down the street on Fellsway West, and we need safer crossings on Elm Street.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: I bring this resolution before the council today at the request of hundreds of residents who've asked that we hang a Black Lives Matter banner on Medford City Hall.

[Bears]: This moment of uprising and reckoning with our history of white supremacy and racism demands it.

[Bears]: As my fellow councilors and the public know, many communities have placed similar banners on schools, town halls, and other city buildings to show solidarity, respect, and support

[Bears]: for the movement to address the ongoing structural racism that has been tearing families and communities apart in this country for centuries.

[Bears]: We've seen protests and demonstrations for Black lives in our community, thousands of people standing up in person, online, through lawn signs and conversations to say no more, to say that we will not sweep this under the rug or treat this as a side issue when we know we can't move forward as a nation, as a community, or as a human family without permanent transformative change on the issues of structural racism and economic inequity.

[Bears]: I expect we will have a robust discussion tonight.

[Bears]: I hope it does not include any conspiracy theories that have been being forwarded around about this being some sort of fundraising front for the Democratic Party.

[Bears]: And I also expect to hear the need to take action and not just say more words.

[Bears]: And the assertion that this is about symbolism and not about substance.

[Bears]: I would agree that it's about time that we dive deeply into charter review, rethinking how we elect elected officials in an all at large way.

[Bears]: that diminishes racial representation and has been struck down by courts in other Massachusetts communities.

[Bears]: I would agree that it's about time that we transform our city zoning and really root out the history of racial bias and zoning that permeated the zoning process when zoning was last reviewed in the city decades ago.

[Bears]: Action is necessary.

[Bears]: These are urgent projects on the path of transformation and they will take time, but words matter.

[Bears]: Words matter.

[Bears]: What we say matters.

[Bears]: How we convey our support to the community matters.

[Bears]: And I hope that by saying these words, we spur ourselves to take on the bigger things that we have to do as well.

[Bears]: We know, and we've heard from Black parents and children and grandparents and brothers and sisters and neighbors and friends, from our neighbors and friends and residents of color, that this community has caused harm, that many have felt exclusion and disillusion and persecution in this community.

[Bears]: I can never understand that.

[Bears]: But when I try to even imagine the thousand stabs and paper cuts that our coworkers, neighbors, and friends of color experience on a daily basis, I can't begin to describe the horror that I feel.

[Bears]: And I want every black parent, every child of color, every person in this community to know and to see when they walk by our city hall, the seat of power in this community, that we stand with them, that we hear them, that we will listen to them, talk to them,

[Bears]: and empower them to lead this fight and fight alongside them, undaunted and undeterred.

[Bears]: If my best friend experiences racist treatment, which I've seen over and over when we've been together, and then drives by our city hall, I want him to look up and see that we know that his life matters and that we are working to make that truly alive and real for everyone who calls Medford home.

[Bears]: I wanna look up and know that.

[Bears]: Mr. President, that's why I put forward this resolution

[Bears]: why I and many others think this is a necessary and overdue step, and why I ask for my colleague's support.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: Yeah, I was actually going to make a similar point that there have been a variety of banners with co-logoed with the city and private organizations.

[Bears]: So I'm not sure what the policy is.

[Bears]: I'm certainly interested to see what the policy is, just specifically on the First Amendment argument and the idea that the city hall could become a billboard.

[Bears]: The First Amendment is designed to protect

[Bears]: citizens of the United States, and it's incorporated to the Commonwealth of Massachusetts through the 14th Amendment, from the government interfering with the private right to communicate.

[Bears]: The government has not offered City Hall as a billboard to anyone.

[Bears]: It's not that any citizen could just come and apply to put whatever banner up that they want, as far as I know.

[Bears]: So if such a process were to be initiated, then there may be First Amendment concerns.

[Bears]: But if the city itself is deciding what messages to put out on city property,

[Bears]: and not an open input for, you know, it's not a bulletin board, right?

[Bears]: That's the difference in the First Amendment.

[Bears]: The city has a complete right to put messages up on city property.

[Bears]: It doesn't have the right to infringe on private property and, well, it doesn't have the right to infringe on the residents' use of their free speech or freedom of expression.

[Bears]: Yeah, just a couple of things.

[Bears]: I hear you, I'm sure there are thousands of spurious lawsuits filed all the time, judicial watches,

[Bears]: well known as an organization of files, though.

[Bears]: I understand, though, that lawsuits can be filed.

[Bears]: I would just say, I don't think there should be a permitting process for putting banners up on City Hall.

[Bears]: I think that would create the problems that are being brought up here.

[Bears]: I don't think this is a slippery slope.

[Bears]: There have been banners hung on the building for years.

[Bears]: And I would just add that if the council doesn't want to be the banner approval authority, then it's on the councilors not to introduce a lot of resolutions about banners.

[Bears]: So that's all I'll say.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Bears.

[Bears]: I don't disagree that we should have a policy.

[Bears]: I'm just saying that if we created an open permit, then we get into these First Amendment questions, which we're currently not facing.

[Bears]: However, the mayor would like to approach this, I'm happy with.

[Bears]: And personally, I would be fine if we hung a Black Lives Matter banner on every municipal building in the city.

[Bears]: It would be that we suggest or ask the mayor.

[Bears]: I believe that given the fact that, as we've already been told and said,

[Bears]: The mayor has control over the building that functionally the language as existing serves as a suggestion to the mayor.

[Bears]: I'm saying that we will do this, and then it would be, you know, the mayor is the one who makes that choice.

[Bears]: Thank you for the clarification.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Just a short message.

[Bears]: I just want to read from the letter from the Birmingham jail by Dr. King, which is,

[Bears]: I have almost reached the regrettable conclusion that the Negro's great stumbling block in his stride towards freedom is not the white citizen's Councilor or the Ku Klux Klan-er, but the white moderate, who is more devoted to order than to justice, who prefers a negative peace, which is the absence of tension, to a positive peace, which is the presence of justice, and who constantly says, I agree with you and the goal you seek, but I cannot agree with your methods.

[Bears]: So let's not talk about Dr. King in such a way.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: Very quickly, this is not in any way an attempt to divide the city.

[Bears]: I think what's dividing the city is decades, if not centuries of unaddressed discrimination.

[Bears]: This is an attempt to heal.

[Bears]: I can't say it any better than Grace about how important this is to so many people that we do this.

[Bears]: So let's do it.

[Bears]: This is the action we can take.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. President.

[Bears]: Motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Bears]: 24499 offered by Vice President Collins and President Bears.

[Bears]: This is the aforementioned amendment to the zoning ordinance for the Green Score for referral to the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: The purpose of the Green Score is to provide flexibility in meeting environmental performance standards, promote attractive environmentally functional landscapes, strengthen climate adaptive goals established in the Climate Action and Adaptation Plan released in 2022 by improving flood resilience, heat mitigation, storm infiltration, and water, air, and soil quality,

[Bears]: And to offer a many free ecosystem services, including mitigation of pollution shade and energy savings recreational opportunities and enhance property values and quality of life.

[Bears]: As this was discussed in planning and permitting committee right now, this will only apply if approved to the Mystic Avenue Corridor District, which is currently under consideration by the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: And as further zoning amendments move through, the green score would be added.

[Bears]: But also right now applies to, I'm sorry,

[Bears]: construction of new principal buildings or major renovations in FEMA flood hazard layer zones or projects that require site plan review.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Tseng to refer to community development board seconded by councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: Seeing none, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes, 70 affirmative.

[Bears]: None of the negative.

[Bears]: The motion passes and the zoning amendment is referred to the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: Communications from the mayor 24494 submitted by Mayor Brianna Lugo Kern Riverside Plaza P. A. R. C. Grant loan order and C. P. C. Appropriation approval request.

[Bears]: for the Parkland Acquisitions and Renovations for Communities Park Grant for the Riverside Plaza Improvements Project.

[Bears]: The City's Community Preservation Committee is also recommending an appropriation of CPA funds in the amount of $144,250 for a total project cost of $343,103.

[Bears]: The park grant requires that the City Council pass a resolution accepting the grant and acknowledging the restrictions to this space slash project for providing recreation purposes.

[Bears]: The grant also requires that full funding for the projects be appropriated upon acceptance of the grant.

[Bears]: The enclosed resolution addresses these requirements.

[Bears]: 24497 submitted my bear brain on go current ballot question seven and eight override supplemental appropriations for the fiscal year 2025 Medford public schools operating budget and the Department of Public Works.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the city council in accordance with the vote of the city of Medford approving question seven and eight on November 5 2024 state election ballot.

[Bears]: I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approves the following additional appropriations to the fiscal year 2025 men for public schools operating budget, and the Department of Public Works.

[Bears]: and further rescind the city council's June 11th, 2024 vote to appropriate a one-time fund advance of ARPA funds that was provided to avoid severe budget cuts in the fiscal 25 MPS operating budget in the event that the override questions did not pass.

[Bears]: These ARPA funds will now instead be used for items outlined in the city's capital improvement plan, such as, but not limited to, the purchase of a fire engine for the fire department and two hybrid police cruisers for the police department.

[Bears]: for supplemental appropriation to below DPW and close as a comprehensive budget breakdown as with any budget is subject to adjustments.

[Bears]: The city will provide a breakdown of funds spent on the DPW and through my role as chair of the school committee, I will work with my school committee colleagues and the MPS administration to ensure detailed reporting for all override funds expended by the Medford public schools as well.

[Bears]: Supplemental Appropriation One, Medford Public Schools.

[Bears]: It is hereby ordered that the city of Medford raise by taxation and appropriate the additional sum of $3 million to supplement the fiscal year 2025 Medford Public Schools operating budget for the purposes stated in question seven on the November 5th, 2024 state election ballot.

[Bears]: Cost of teachers, literacy coaches, behavior specialists, administrative assistants and nurses positions and regular facilities maintenance.

[Bears]: department Medford public schools fiscal 25 appropriation 3 million and further rescind the city council's june 11 2024 vote appropriating the sum of 1.75 million in american rescue plan act funds as a one-time advance for the fiscal 25 mps budget sorry there just a second

[Bears]: Supplemental appropriation to Department of Public Works is hereby ordered that the city of Medford raised by taxation and appropriate additional sum of 500,000 for the Department of Public Works consistent with the vote under question seven on the November 5 2024 state election ballot for additional staff for road and sidewalk infrastructure repair related insurance expenses and related capital expenses.

[Bears]: All is set forth in the chart below.

[Bears]: Department DPW highway salaries FY 25 appropriations $270,192.64.

[Bears]: DPW highway expenses fiscal 25 $67,195.36.

[Bears]: Related insurance expenses fiscal 25 $102,612.

[Bears]: Related capital expenses including for example trucks to be used by additional staff $60,000 total $500,000.

[Bears]: Supplemental appropriation three, Medford Public Schools.

[Bears]: And to effectuate and further the will of the voters of the city of Medford as evidenced by their approval of question eight, the school committee per its procedures and prior to expenditure of the funds appropriated here under shall determine in detail the specific anticipated operational costs and expenses to provide the reference programming.

[Bears]: Communications from city officers and employees 24495 submitted by director of traffic and transportation Todd Blake authorization of future blue bikes contract exceeding three years to Medford City Council from Todd Blake director of traffic and transportation.

[Bears]: Sorry, authorization of future blue bikes contract exceeding three years

[Bears]: This memorandum summarizes the request to authorize a future contract as required by section 12 of chapter 30 be the general laws, the city's contract with lift the operator blue blue bikes will expire in fall 2025.

[Bears]: The Metropolitan Area Planning Council intends to issue a request for proposals on behalf of all the municipalities that are part of the Blue Bike system to select a new operator in 2025.

[Bears]: MAPC will select one operator to manage the entire system to ensure that it continues to operate regionally.

[Bears]: Each municipality will then have the opportunity to contract with the selected operator separately or enter into a joint contract.

[Bears]: It is the intention of Blue Bikes municipalities to enter into a five-year contract with two two-year options to renew with the future operator.

[Bears]: entering into a longer-term contract will encourage the future operator to provide a higher level of service to users and help secure more funding through the system's title sponsorship, which will then allow the service to continue growing throughout the region.

[Bears]: And I'm not gonna read the rest if folks don't mind me reading the legalese on chapter 30B.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: I do want to go to Scott and then maybe to Tim.

[Bears]: But my general understanding is the tree warden generally isn't involved in the private sector regulatory realm and

[Bears]: zoning enforcement is subject of the building department and code enforcement.

[Bears]: So my suggestion is it might be worth sitting down outside of a public meeting with the building department, maybe making a decision not to include tree warden and DPW, and maybe that's a step forward.

[Bears]: You can come up with something there, but I do want to give Scott a chance to talk before we move forward on anything.

[Bears]: If you have anything to say.

[Bears]: Thank you, commissioner.

[Bears]: I appreciate it.

[Bears]: I'm sorry for not recognizing you as commissioner.

[Bears]: I'm going to just open it up to discussion.

[Bears]: Members of the council about path forward here.

[Bears]: Any thoughts?

[Bears]: Councilor

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: I'm gonna go to Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: I think it would make sense to involve the planning office and the NS Associates team

[Bears]: who is working on the zoning update in a meeting between, I guess, you or you and Councilor Collins, Commissioner Vandewalle, and some folks from PDS and NS to kind of work through this.

[Bears]: I know Attorney Silverstein could provide some guidance around the law without necessarily having to come up with a draft, send it to KP, get KP comments back.

[Bears]: but I think, yeah, I would suggest that that happened as kind of just a city meeting, a mini meeting of city staff.

[Bears]: And then when you guys have been able to iron something out that can come back to us and maybe it's part of the zoning process, or maybe it's, you know, we keep, we probably want to keep considering these three papers together, but I'm not sure how it'll interface with the work that we're doing for the zoning.

[Bears]: There's a pretty ambitious timeline and calendar there.

[Bears]: So,

[Bears]: That would be my suggestion.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: Councilor Kelly?

[Bears]: Go ahead.

[Bears]: By staff, you mean the building commissioner and the planning department?

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Callahan, seconded by.

[Bears]: Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Any further discussion by members of the Council?

[Bears]: Any further discussion by members of the public?

[Bears]: I'm just going to add in, come to the podium, yes.

[Bears]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Bears]: The first motion was for the public and the tree committee.

[Bears]: Any further discussion?

[Bears]: I have Kim on Zoom.

[Bears]: Kim, I will recognize you.

[Bears]: Name and address for the record, please.

[Bears]: Thank you, yeah, I appreciate that comment.

[Bears]: And I'm seeing a nod from Councilor Callahan, maybe that you could work with Councilor Collins and the other folks to entries meant for to invite someone.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Awesome.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Callahan, seconded by Councilor Leming, all those in favor?

[Bears]: Opposed?

[Bears]: Motion passes.

[Bears]: Any further discussion on this topic at this time?

[Bears]: All right, I just wanna thank everybody for getting us re-centered with staff changes and everything else and council changes.

[Bears]: I think we're in a good place now to move ahead.

[Bears]: We have good next steps on each of the ordinances and hopefully we can come back in January for public trees and then we'll wait to hear back on the private tree from the group that's gonna be working on it on a timeline there, making sure it fits in with the zoning project.

[Bears]: on the motion to adjourn by Councilor Callahan, seconded by Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Medford City Council special meeting November 26 2024 is called to order.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Present.

[Bears]: Seven present, none absent, please rise to salute the flag.

[Bears]: Hearings 24-501 submitted by the Board of Assessors.

[Bears]: Allocation of the fiscal 2025 property tax.

[Bears]: Let me read the legal notice real quick.

[Bears]: Legal notice, notice of a public hearing, City of Medford, the Medford City Council will hold a public hearing in the Howard F. Alton Chambers at Medford City Hall, 85 George P. Hassett Drive, Medford, Massachusetts, and via Zoom on Tuesday, November 26, 2024, at 7 p.m.

[Bears]: A link to this hearing will be posted no later than Friday, November 22, 2024.

[Bears]: The purpose of this hearing is to hear the Board of Assessors on the following items for the purpose of allocation of the FY 2025 property tax.

[Bears]: One, to determine the residential factor for FY25.

[Bears]: Two, selecting an open space discount.

[Bears]: Three, selecting a residential exemption.

[Bears]: Four, selecting a small commercial exemption.

[Bears]: Call 781-393-2501 for any aids and accommodations.

[Bears]: Order of the Redford City Council, Adam Hurtubise, City Clerk.

[Bears]: And I will turn it over to our assessor, Mr. Costigan.

[Bears]: But the recommendation would be to not- To not vote.

[Bears]: OK, yeah.

[Bears]: I think last time we talked it was in the high 700s, low 800s.

[Bears]: Is that just a major change in valuations or what happened there?

[Bears]: Got it.

[Bears]: It would have been higher.

[Bears]: Exactly.

[Bears]: And the issue being if we pass this tax rate,

[Bears]: Essentially, let's say 10,000 people apply for 35% exemptions if that's what we pass.

[Bears]: We would need to have tens of millions of dollars in the overlay account to pay back those exemptions.

[Bears]: But we wouldn't have raised that because the tax rate would be set based on not having that exemption, essentially.

[Bears]: They don't allow us to estimate.

[Bears]: So if you would open up applications in June, we receive 9,000, you could say we expect this, that would, and then, or?

[Bears]: This would not be the vote to establish the exemption?

[Bears]: And just to add on to the context of your point,

[Bears]: The issue is also that you're making an assumption of like how many people are going to take it.

[Bears]: And the point is the break even point has to be set based on that assumption to keep the levy even.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: So you're setting a new tax rate to raise the same amount of money, but you're basing that on the assumption of how what percentage of residential classes will not change.

[Bears]: And under this system, you may, let's say you have a, and this is just, I wanna clarify this too, like say you're in a three-family unit, one of the units is owner-occupied, the other two are not, would that whole structure qualify for an owner occupancy?

[Bears]: So you basically would have people, even if they, let's say that three-family is worth 1.2 million, it's over the break-even point, they would have to apply for the owner-occupied exemption

[Bears]: their taxes are still gonna go up even though they'll qualify for the exemption essentially, right?

[Bears]: But it'll just go up less than if they didn't get the exemption at all.

[Bears]: And I'm not saying that to make, I mean, it's a specific case.

[Bears]: Adam has it, yeah.

[Bears]: Okay, thank you.

[Bears]: Are you mostly just assuming single family and condo?
