[Bears]: Motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Bears]: 24-503 offered by Councilor Lazzaro, President Bears, and Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Let me get the full language here.

[Bears]: Whereas speed is one of the most important factors in traffic safety and crashes that occur at lower speeds cause less injury.

[Bears]: And whereas a pedestrian hit by a car traveling 40 miles per hour has a one in 10 chance of surviving a crash, while a pedestrian hit by a car traveling at 20 miles per hour has a nine in 10 chance of surviving.

[Bears]: And whereas Medford has set a citywide speed limit of 25 miles per hour on city controlled streets.

[Bears]: and whereas Medford has a high proportion of state-controlled roads, including Mystic Valley and Alewife Brook Parkways, Route 16, Route 28, Route 38, and High Street, Route 60, which are Medford's busiest thoroughfares, connecting Medford, the surrounding towns, and I-93, and passing through residential and commercial areas, impacting the safety of people walking, cycling, taking transit, and driving to school, work, parks, grocery stores, natural spaces, and city squares.

[Bears]: excuse me, and whereas Massachusetts general law chapter 90 section 18 allows city councils to petition state agencies to modify the speed limit on a state highway within their geographic boundaries.

[Bears]: Now, therefore, be it resolved by the Medford city council that we respect the request and recommend that the Massachusetts department of conservation and recreation, DCR and Massachusetts department of transportation, MassDOT set the speed limit on route 16, route 28, route 38 and route 60 in Medford at 25 miles per hour.

[Bears]: Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I will go to Councilor Callahan and then Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: But just before I do that, it might be worth the amendment being, saying Route 16, Route 28, Route 38, Route 60, and any other streets or highways controlled by state agencies, something like that as an amendment, just to be a catch-all.

[Bears]: Yeah, because I off the top of my head I'm thinking of South Border Road, Elm Street, Highland Avenue.

[Bears]: And there's a couple of other state, there's a Valley Parkway that's not part of Route 16 by the lakes.

[Bears]: I mean,

[Bears]: Someone said that I think Medford has the second highest proportion of state-controlled roads after Boston, which is pretty wild, but we do have a lot.

[Bears]: And 38 is partially city, partially state.

[Bears]: I think 60 is the only one that's all under city control.

[Bears]: So I think a catch-all amendment might be worth.

[Bears]: Yep.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: I'll go to Councilor Callahan and then Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Kelly, and I'll go to Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Yeah, as someone who grew up on a state road, Fells Bay West, but has spent many years

[Bears]: looking out my driver's side mirror or looking left and right across the street, worried that someone's going to come whipping down Fells Bay West in the one-way section at 45 miles an hour.

[Bears]: And they have taken out two of our cars and a tree in that time.

[Bears]: And luckily, no people, but that's probably only because there's no crosswalks.

[Bears]: And the only thing

[Bears]: To our West is 93.

[Bears]: There's other parts that are even much more dangerous.

[Bears]: I'm a huge supporter of this resolution.

[Bears]: I'm also directly experienced what it's like to lose someone in another community, not in Medford to traffic violence so

[Bears]: Yeah, it's just important to me.

[Bears]: And I have here a suggested amendment in the last sentence, set the speed limit on any street, highway, or portion of a street or highway controlled by a state agency, including but not limited to Route 16, Route 28, Route 38, Route 60, South Border Road, Elm Street, and Highland Ave in Medford at 25 miles per hour.

[Bears]: Sound good?

[Bears]: You'll make that amendment?

[Bears]: I wrote it down.

[Bears]: That's a complicated question.

[Bears]: Actually, there are state routes like Route 60 that are city controlled.

[Bears]: Most of High Street and Salem Street is city controlled.

[Bears]: So I believe Medford does repairs on those the state controlled portions of state road state routes or non state routes, the agency.

[Bears]: that controls them is responsible.

[Bears]: So, for example, I lived on Fells Way West.

[Bears]: Our snow shoveling and snow removal, that's DCR region, I can't remember the region number, but it's the region that's up at Spot Pond, the headquarters there.

[Bears]: So Medford snow shoveling and street sweeping rules don't apply to that section of Fells Way West, nor does maintenance or redesign.

[Bears]: It's actually also one of the reasons that

[Bears]: Main Street and Mystic Ave and Medford Square, that intersection design is so complicated, a portion of the streets are city controlled, a portion of the streets are DCR, and a portion of the streets are MassDOT.

[Bears]: So you had to get all three of those groups together to approve design.

[Bears]: And probably when it's done, you'll have different agencies maintaining different parts of that intersection.

[Bears]: That's my general understanding of how it works.

[Bears]: It's probably even more specific stuff but for example, if you're going up fells way west towards stone them, or you can turn right onto Elm Street.

[Bears]: They put a paint bump out to change the angle of the curve because it was really steep and people were just whipping right up Elm.

[Bears]: but it was just paint.

[Bears]: I remember talking with director Blake about putting bollards out to further try to make people actually follow the new curve.

[Bears]: And DCR said that they wouldn't do it.

[Bears]: They didn't have the staff to maintain the bollards and Todd and DPW offered to do it ourselves.

[Bears]: And they said, we won't let you do that.

[Bears]: So there's jurisdictional questions that create some

[Bears]: really frustrating issues.

[Bears]: Yeah, cyclists on that street too.

[Bears]: I mean, I would have a really, I mean, it seems like a great place to go on a bike ride and then you're there.

[Bears]: There's a couple larger conversations DCR at the state level.

[Bears]: It used to be even more ridiculous how many agencies controlled different parkways and roadways, and they were regionalized.

[Bears]: And you had the old MDC and different regional district commissions.

[Bears]: And I won't go into it, but that all got merged into DCR.

[Bears]: But it still doesn't make a ton of sense to have DCR maintaining all of these roads.

[Bears]: MassDOT should probably be doing it.

[Bears]: It should be centralized.

[Bears]: DCR is deeply underfunded.

[Bears]: I think, yeah, I could go into that forever.

[Bears]: But that's another piece of the problem with the enforcement on,

[Bears]: You know, fells by going up towards stone or south border road.

[Bears]: Snow shoveling, I mean it was ridiculous you know they won't even put up bollards to because they're like what if someone we don't have the staff capacity to put them back up if they get knocked down, so that was their justification so that that funding issue with DC ours and there's a problem to that needs to get solved.

[Bears]: But I appreciate the comment.

[Bears]: And the one other thing is that the Chapter 90 money that we get, which is basically the only money most cities use for street maintenance, is based on just the proportion of the public ways that are in the city control.

[Bears]: So the state-controlled roads are out of it.

[Bears]: The private ways are out of it.

[Bears]: And that formula is also deeply underfunded, but we get an even shorter end of the stick because we have such a smaller proportion of the mileage in the city is actually controlled by the city.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Thank you very much.

[Bears]: You got it.

[Bears]: I think what we're looking at is an enhancement to the area to make it what we want it to be, which is more walkable, bring commercial in, and just make it a place for the neighborhood instead of just the cut through that many people experience it as now.

[Bears]: I just really want to note

[Bears]: the comment about the sprinkling of gas stations.

[Bears]: You know, not only is that from like a design perspective and an experience perspective, not great, but we've had a lot of problems with those stations over the years as a community being not great neighbors.

[Bears]: So that's something to note.

[Bears]: And we're also going to see this become high frequency transit corridor with the T96 coming soon every 15 minutes.

[Bears]: And this is going to, I think,

[Bears]: really respond to that and make this a really improve some of the outstanding issues with the existing zoning.

[Bears]: I want to thank Innes Associates for noting the residential blocks remaining residential, keeping historic buildings, as well as noting like the serious loopholes in the existing zoning that would allow like a 12-story hotel right now, which I think

[Bears]: None of us, nobody wants that here.

[Bears]: So correcting this to match more of the community character and identity while also enhancing it in exactly the ways that we want it to was the goal of the comprehensive plan.

[Bears]: And that seems to be the content of this draft.

[Bears]: So assuming that the committee votes to refer out a proposal tonight, that would appear on the regular agenda for our next regular meeting.

[Bears]: And I just want you guys to correct me if I'm wrong at any point.

[Bears]: That would be referred to the Community Development Board, and the Community Development Board would hold a public hearing where further public comment could be taken.

[Bears]: And then that would come back to the city council for a public hearing after a recommendations are made by the community development board, at which point it would require a further vote of the council to amend the zoning ordinance.

[Bears]: Is that correct?

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: So there's two more public hearings after tonight.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thanks, Madam Chair.

[Bears]: And I just wanted to build off a couple of things.

[Bears]: I think too, there was the granular analysis that was done, but also, you know, we're not going, when you look at the apartment one in the commercial districts, the parcel boundaries actually aren't that out of bounds.

[Bears]: It's just like the dimensional and the use requirements are kind of nuts.

[Bears]: So it seems to me that by and large, that existing

[Bears]: delineation was also used partly to outline some of the how far back things go.

[Bears]: Of course, with some differences when you have that large apartment building on Paris Street, I think that, you know, was not in that zone.

[Bears]: But in any case, I think the bigger question and the thought actually brings us all the way back to the beginning of the meeting.

[Bears]: When we talk about walkability and accessibility and placemaking and streetscape.

[Bears]: this is one piece of the implementation of the comprehensive plan.

[Bears]: We're implementing land use and zoning policy.

[Bears]: Emily and others have spoken to how incentive zoning and other elements here, and I'm also going to hopefully say in the future that site plan review processes and other things when things actually, you know, when this zoning actually turns into proposals and turns into construction of new buildings.

[Bears]: That is where the rubber will meet the road to a large extent of actually improving the streetscape, getting a large new, say someone does want to put a few parcels together and build something big, not saying that that's what we want all over the place here, but they may need to give more back to the community to improve a stretch of the street.

[Bears]: And so in addition to the traffic commission and all the other things that we want to do, a piece of this through the incentive zoning and through site plan review and through just the general transformation and goal that we want to see here over a long period of time, that is what will help us to make this a safer, more accessible, more walkable street.

[Bears]: So when we see the implementation of the comprehensive plan recommendations,

[Bears]: happening piecemeal because it has to happen piecemeal because we're just focused on the zoning piece right now it doesn't mean it's not that it's not factoring in these other questions around what it means to improve the street and actually

[Bears]: this being an emanation or an iteration or an implementation of the comprehensive plan is an important thing to remind ourselves of because we can go back to the comprehensive plan and say, okay, one piece of creating these walkable vibrant neighborhoods is zoning.

[Bears]: Another piece is something we may need to be talking about in our traffic commission or be talking about in another sense here in the community.

[Bears]: So I just think that's important to note too.

[Bears]: There's a great implementation table at the back of that comprehensive plan that is kind of its own.

[Bears]: I mean, I can't even think of the word to describe it, but it's intense and this is a piece of that implementation.

[Bears]: So I hope we can keep having the discussions and especially have the discussions when we have specific projects that want to be built coming after the establishing of the new zoning ordinance.

[Bears]: I think there is that comprehensive holistic approach, and it just doesn't always get implemented all at the same time.

[Bears]: And we're implementing different pieces of the comprehensive plan through different processes, and this is just one of them.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: Seconded by Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes, I'm in the affirmative, none the negative.

[Bears]: The motion passes and this meeting is adjourned.

[Bears]: We'll reconvene at 7pm for our regular meeting.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, give me a heads up when we're ready to go.

[Bears]: Great, and we're good on the Medford Community Media side as well?

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Fantastic.

[Bears]: All right, then.

[Bears]: Yeah, I think they probably don't need the booth for the Zoom meeting, I think, if I remember correctly.

[Bears]: So we should be all right.

[Bears]: All right, well, last meeting of the year.

[Bears]: Hi, everybody.

[Bears]: Thank you for being here.

[Bears]: We'll get going right now.

[Bears]: Medford City Council, Committee of the Whole, December 18th, 2024.

[Bears]: It's a call to order.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: present, five present, two absent, the meeting is called to order.

[Bears]: There'll be a meeting of the Medford City Council Committee of the Whole at 6 p.m.

[Bears]: on December 18th, 2024 via Zoom only.

[Bears]: The action and discussion item for this meeting is paper 24-006, which is a review of the 2024-2025 Council Governing Agenda.

[Bears]: So we'll take that up.

[Bears]: At our first regular meeting, January 9th, 2024,

[Bears]: We resolved that Councilors would submit items to create a governing agenda document based on a draft template.

[Bears]: We then met on January 24th, 2024 to review the governing agenda and refer it out to each of the committees.

[Bears]: And we also made a motion to have reviews in June and December and to review the governing agenda regularly.

[Bears]: And pursuant to those motions, we held the committee of the whole, I believe in June, and now we're having one in December to review progress to date, to suggest updates to the document, and to send a link to resident services and public engagement committee to be included in the January newsletter, the updated document.

[Bears]: I wanna thank Vice President Collins for working on the updated document with me.

[Bears]: Folks can find it

[Bears]: at a link that I'll post in the chat.

[Bears]: It's also available on the city website, but it is also on the council portal.

[Bears]: And this is as of Monday when the agenda went out.

[Bears]: So again, thank you, Vice President Collins for your work on this with me.

[Bears]: And I think we can either start with any comments or questions from councillors, and then we can

[Bears]: quickly go through and review highlights from each committee so far this year and what's coming up for the next year.

[Bears]: With that, I'm happy to go to Vice President Collins if there's anything you'd like to add.

[Bears]: Thank you, Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: I'll recognize Councilor Callahan in just a moment.

[Bears]: And just wanted to note, you know, throughout this project, this meeting, if folks have amendments that they'd like to make or edits, or if they want to submit edits subsequent to the meeting, we can update the document a little further before it goes out with the newsletter in January.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: I wasn't going to take credit, and I really do feel like it's a team effort, but, you know, working with my colleagues over the past few years and seeing what I thought and then working with everyone in this council to implement some changes around

[Bears]: this document, creating a committee structure that really focused on being functional and effective and aligning with how the city works was a major priority at the beginning of the term.

[Bears]: And I think it's gone well.

[Bears]: I am going to note some unexpected things that we've learned so far and just ways to think about this going forward.

[Bears]: But overall, I'm really just proud of this council and the work that we've done.

[Bears]: putting it out there.

[Bears]: I totally agree with you, Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Having this document and being able to point to a single document, yeah, it's a little long and sometimes a little wordy and maybe a little wonky, but to say here's what we're doing and it's actually comprehensive is groundbreaking in my opinion.

[Bears]: All right, well, we can start I just want to, I'll do a quick screen share and if folks, you know, want me to do that when they're talking about their committees or any other point I'm happy to do it but just wanted to let people see kind of the form of this document.

[Bears]: So, this is the front cover page with all our lovely names on it.

[Bears]: City Seal, but there's this great table of contents and luckily our new portal even makes it linkable.

[Bears]: You can click into each different section, starting with a helpful document section, and then it's broken down by each of our committees.

[Bears]: Our Committee of the Whole, Administration and Finance Committee, our Education and Culture Committee,

[Bears]: the Governance Committee, Planning and Permitting Committee, which has been particularly prolific, and as well as our Public Health and Community Safety Committee, Public Works and Facilities Committee, and the Resident Services and Public Engagement Committee.

[Bears]: And within each of those sections, there is a

[Bears]: kind of broken down in three ways, some major projects that the committee is working on, some ordinances that the committee is working on, and then some of the oversight and engagement work that committees do as part of their task.

[Bears]: So I'll start with our helpful documents.

[Bears]: This is just a great place to find just a few quick links to some of the major plans and things that we reference regularly in our meetings.

[Bears]: are not just our committees and their members, but the city's ordinance, the code, as well as the major plan governing a lot of what we're doing around the city comprehensive plan, talking about zoning and built environment and what the vision for the community is over the next 30 years.

[Bears]: Housing production plan, how we're trying to produce more housing so that people who live here can stay here and people who want to live here can move here.

[Bears]: A climate action and adaptation plan to address the climate crisis,

[Bears]: and our open space and recreation plan.

[Bears]: And I'm hoping we can get some more documents linked in here in the future as well as they are developed.

[Bears]: Our committee of the whole, which I chair, but as a committee of all seven councilors has had a lot of meetings, but mostly those are meetings to review papers from the mayor or to review things that have been reported out of another committee.

[Bears]: order review kind of ad hoc resolutions that are coming up during the year.

[Bears]: But we did have two projects in committee of the whole term started the tree preservation protection and replacement ordinances and our food truck ordinance.

[Bears]: We have held meetings on those this year.

[Bears]: Food truck ordinance we are hoping to incorporate some significant legal feedback.

[Bears]: We definitely learned a lot about the laws around food trucks and our meeting on that this year.

[Bears]: And the tree ordinance we met on in November and the tree ordinances, the public tree ordinance and the tree committee ordinance are awaiting some review by city staff as well as some Councilors before coming back to the council committee of the whole.

[Bears]: And then the private tree ordinance is going to be reviewed by city staff and incorporated also into our

[Bears]: or at least reviewed by our zoning consultant because that is mainly a zoning ordinance.

[Bears]: So that is being, we're taking advantage of the resources that we have around zoning to review the private tree ordinance.

[Bears]: And the goal is really to get this done early in 2025 so that we can get these ordinances on the books and update our public tree ordinance and get a workable private tree ordinance in place so that we can stop losing trees and hopefully start growing our tree canopy again.

[Bears]: So that's Committee of the Whole, happy to, it's an easy one, happy to pause there and if anyone has any comments or anything they want to add on the Committee of the Whole before moving to the next committee.

[Bears]: Seeing none, I will also take on the next committee, which is our Administration and Finance Committee.

[Bears]: This hasn't met as much as

[Bears]: I had initially thought and it's kind of one of those lessons learned.

[Bears]: I think a lot of what this committee nominally is responsible for is our things that we've been doing in committee of the whole.

[Bears]: There have certainly been a few meetings on more on the ordinance level.

[Bears]: But, you know, we have our annual budget process every year that happens mostly in committee of the whole meetings.

[Bears]: And we are now going to be in our second year of an annual budget process guided by our first ever budget ordinance, which is really exciting.

[Bears]: As folks noted, there were some dates in the meeting schedules for the upcoming six months around the budget, including getting some of our budget recommendations in early March per the budget ordinance.

[Bears]: And we did work on a major project around the Proposition 2.5 overrides.

[Bears]: We had our first ever override process this year, and since Proposition 2.5 went into effect nearly 50 years ago, and the passage of Questions 7 and 8 is really significant for our public schools and our DPW.

[Bears]: So that's going to be a part of our budget process for the first time this year.

[Bears]: working, you know, we have we did appropriate the funds for the DPW sidewalk and street repair crew to bring that back in house.

[Bears]: Certainly won't fix every street and sidewalk, but it's good to have a team in the DPW dedicated to this and the staffing restored for this function, which is really a basic essential function.

[Bears]: And we have the

[Bears]: certainly that we will hear from our Medford public schools, the school committee will be working on implementing their supplemental budget this year and then working on their budget process for fiscal 26.

[Bears]: And, you know, our role in that is just to approve the allocation and they approve the expenses.

[Bears]: But I know that it's going to be a really impactful year in our public schools because of the funds that are going to be available for them.

[Bears]: So that's exciting around the budget.

[Bears]: I talked again a lot about the revenue generation project and proposition two and a half.

[Bears]: We were able to complete, you know, at least a piece of that project this year around the overrides.

[Bears]: And, you know, I think revenue generation outside of proposition two and a half is always a focus of the council, especially when it comes to economic development, as well as just updating our

[Bears]: city's ordinances.

[Bears]: I really want to thank Councilor Leming for leading on linkage fees, hopeful that we'll be able to meet on updating the fee schedule for the city early this year.

[Bears]: That was a big call as well from the council earlier this year, just so that we're not 30 years out of date on inflation, which we have been on way too many things in the city for a long time.

[Bears]: I'll just move quickly through the rest.

[Bears]: Another project that we talked about was the classification and compensation study implementation.

[Bears]: We were hoping to get started on this many months ago, but we have not received any sort of document or really even any sort of update from the city administration on when we can expect to be updating the city's personnel ordinance and looking at this.

[Bears]: So I'm going to be checking back in with the administration in the new year on that.

[Bears]: And I will go to Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Yeah, our role is really to we have to update the personal ordinance.

[Bears]: That's how the so that element of it around compensation and changes to the different classifications.

[Bears]: in that ordinance, that would all have to come to us.

[Bears]: So I think the next step is we need to see what those recommendations were and then discuss those changes.

[Bears]: And I think it's a big project.

[Bears]: I think we should take due diligence and time with it.

[Bears]: But really, the next step is that we need to have the administration

[Bears]: let us know if that study is completed, if there's a document, some sort of implementation recommendation from the Collins Center, and then look at that from there.

[Bears]: So, we'll see.

[Bears]: Yeah, absolutely, yeah.

[Bears]: I'll get in touch with them and let them know it's something we want to work on this year, this upcoming year.

[Bears]: mentioned the linkage fee project.

[Bears]: We have a home rule petition in at the State House to update the linkage fee ordinance and allow for regular updates to our linkage fees.

[Bears]: And I believe also then we would look at an updated linkage fee ordinance.

[Bears]: I don't know if Councilor Leming, you want to talk any more about that?

[Bears]: You were really leading that project.

[Bears]: Great, thank you, Councilor Leming for that update.

[Bears]: And the Home Rule petition did end up getting submitted

[Bears]: Uh, this session so and I actually did have a little correspondence.

[Bears]: I'm slightly hopeful it might end up in an end of year omnibus bill or a local, uh, home rule petitions package.

[Bears]: Um, so Maybe we'll we'll have some good news on that before January 1st.

[Bears]: We'll see Great Um

[Bears]: We also worked on maximizing tax exemptions that are allowed by the state to maximize those.

[Bears]: I really want to thank Councilor Leming on both the MGL Chapter 59, Section 5, Clause 22G, as well as adopting provisions of the HERO Act.

[Bears]: That is something we are always looking for to make sure that our residents have the most opportunities under state law for exemptions from the property tax.

[Bears]: We have also completed an establishment of a General Stabilization Fund and a Capital Stabilization Fund and Water Sewer Stabilization Fund, which has already been making a difference this year, having access to reserve funds for emergencies and capital needs.

[Bears]: Ordinances-wise, we passed our budget ordinance.

[Bears]: So excited about that and excited to see it used again this year.

[Bears]: We did discuss the commercial vacancy tax, and that is still in committee.

[Bears]: So this has really evolved and maybe we should update this, uh, going forward.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Seeing a nod, yes.

[Bears]: Next item is the good landlord tax credit.

[Bears]: We actually have reviewed this and found that the way that the state law was structured makes this a really actually unappealing credit to implement.

[Bears]: So it's probably not something we're going to move forward with, at least the discussions that we have with the assessor, or that this would be of great benefit to essentially only the very, very large commercial property, well,

[Bears]: residential property owners, but the companies that own large multi-unit buildings and would not really be of benefit for our two-family, three-family landlords.

[Bears]: We also, in the future, would like to look at a Community Benefits Agreement ordinance around having a Community Benefits Committee that negotiates with very large real estate projects and nonprofits around what the needs assessment for our neighborhoods is and figuring out how that would work in alignment with our zoning process and also with the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: We have a look at a percent for art ordinance that was proposed many years ago, which would create a requirement that 1% of costs would be earmarked for public art projects for large developments.

[Bears]: So that's something we could look at.

[Bears]: We could also look at that probably in the context of our zoning project.

[Bears]: 24th regular meeting Medford City Council December 17 2024.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: The meeting is called to order.

[Bears]: Please rise to salute the flag.

[Bears]: Before we start, this is our last meeting of the year.

[Bears]: And I do ask my colleagues for limited indulgence and welcome the crowd for being here as well.

[Bears]: I just wanna thank my colleagues for an incredible 2024.

[Bears]: It's been a busy year of nearly a hundred meetings of this body and committee and in regular session.

[Bears]: And I don't think anyone can say that this council has not been outspoken and spoken its mind on a variety of topics.

[Bears]: In January, I spoke about three leadership principles, collaboration, planning, and trust.

[Bears]: This council has worked together collaboratively within our committees with the city administration, city staff, community organizations, businesses, educational institutions, and thousands of residents to implement and discuss a clear and transparent governing agenda created and published in February.

[Bears]: Tomorrow night we're going to conduct our one year review of that plan and suggest updates for the year ahead and I encourage everyone in our city to join us.

[Bears]: I firmly believe that this open and direct approach to governance is foundational to good governance and to trust, and I'm going to continue to lead with these principles in 2025.

[Bears]: There's always disagreement, and we've had some tough meetings.

[Bears]: I'm always open to meet with anyone, whether that's Councilors, residents, employees of the city and others to hear from them.

[Bears]: And of course, this council will always hear from anyone who speaks at this podium under our rules.

[Bears]: I'm excited for 2025.

[Bears]: Earlier this week, released our January to June schedule.

[Bears]: There are 60 meetings scheduled on topics including the budget, a new city charter, zoning and much more.

[Bears]: And I really just want to implore and invite the community to join us in the process of building a better Medford together.

[Bears]: So thank you for your indulgence.

[Bears]: And with that, we'll move to the agenda.

[Bears]: Announcements, accolades, remembrances, reports, and records.

[Bears]: 24-512 offered by Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Be it resolved that the Medford City Council commend and congratulate Barbara Kerr for her 40 years of tireless and selfless service at the Medford Public Library.

[Bears]: We thank her for her work with our residents and for providing a welcoming hub for our community.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Collins, and I just want to note certainly to thank Barbara, and I think Barbara would also want us to thank her staff, the trustees, the Library Foundation, which has been so instrumental in the construction of and outfitting of the new library, the friends of the Medford Public Library, and all of the folks who walk through those doors or use the online resources or take out a book

[Bears]: or other material at the library has really become so much more than just a place to go and get a book, but it really provides essential community services to so many people in our community, especially our kids and our teens.

[Bears]: So just thank you to Barbara and the whole library team.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by Councilor Tseng, and we will invite Director Kerr for a citation in the new year.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Seven in the affirmative, none in the negative.

[Bears]: The motion passes.

[Bears]: The records of the special meeting of November 26, 2024 were passed to Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Councilor Leming, how did you find those records?

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Leming to approve the records of the special meeting of November 26, 2024, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, when you're ready, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Seven in the affirmative, none in the negative.

[Bears]: The motion passes.

[Bears]: The records of the meeting of December 3rd, 2024 were passed to Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli, how did you find the records?

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Scarpelli to approve the records of the meeting of December 3rd, 2024, seconded by.

[Bears]: Seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: When you're ready, Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: Having the affirmative, none of the negative, the motion passes.

[Bears]: Reports of committees.

[Bears]: Council Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: One moment.

[Bears]: That is ordained for third reading. 24510.

[Bears]: presented by Mayor Breanna Lungo-Koehn.

[Bears]: Loan order, school HVAC infrastructure and roof bonds.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears and members of the city council, I respectfully request and recommend that your honorable body approve the below loan order.

[Bears]: By way of some background, the Andrews and McGlynn Middle Schools are in need of extensive HVAC work, as well as at least repairs to the McGlynn School roof.

[Bears]: The city has hired an owner's project manager and designer with the goal of conducting the majority of the construction work during the summer months to further the project and keep the timetable for construction

[Bears]: In January, the city needs to pre-order equipment, continue to design with the designer and OPM and the pre-construction services of the construction manager to accomplish this, a fundering authorization of about $5 million is needed.

[Bears]: In the future, after further designing cost estimates have been finalized, we will likely return for the rest of the cost to complete construction, which is expected to be about an additional $20 million.

[Bears]: City of Medford loan order, school HVAC infrastructure and roof bonds, be it ordered that $5 million is appropriated for the purpose of replacing boilers and cooling systems with new condensing boilers and heat pumps, including associated automatic controls, structural and architectural work, electrical work and weatherization at the McGlynn School and Andrew School, and the acquisition and installation of solar panels for a new roof and a new roof or roof repairs at the McGlynn School, including the cost of planning, design, architectural and engineering services and all other costs incidental and related thereto.

[Bears]: And that this appropriation to meet this appropriation the treasurer, with the approval of the mayor is authorized to borrow the set amount pursuant to chapter 44 section seven subsection one of the Massachusetts general laws or pursuant to any other enabling authority, and to issue the bonds or notes of the city therefore.

[Bears]: and further ordered that the treasurer is authorized to file an application with the appropriate officials of the Commonwealth of Massachusetts, the Commonwealth to qualify under chapter 44A of the general laws, any and all bonds of the city authorized to be borrowed pursuant to this loan order and to provide such information and execute such documents as officials of the Commonwealth may require in connection therewith.

[Bears]: Respectfully submitted, Breanna Lungo-Koehn, Mayor.

[Bears]: We have Director Hunt and Assistant Superintendent Cushing with us tonight to further discuss the project.

[Bears]: do you have a presentation before we move to questions from the council?

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And just to confirm the school committee did discuss this last night and there was a vote of the school committee.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: With that, I will go to the council for questions and further discussion.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Before I recognize Councilor Collins and Councilor Callahan, I do just want to note on the ARPA funding that has to be encumbered by December 31st.

[Bears]: And we did receive a communication from the mayor at a large chunk of that 800,000 plus dollars that we were able to buy a fire engine from the city of Lynn.

[Bears]: So there's a new fire engine coming through that money.

[Bears]: So a large chunk of that money has been appropriated.

[Bears]: It does have to be encumbered by the end of the year.

[Bears]: I'll go to Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, Tom.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: I'll go to Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: 2-4-518, offered by Councilor Scarpelli, be it resolved that the City Administration report back to the Council on the following information.

[Bears]: costs associated with terminating the superintendent's contract, any communications, correspondences, meeting minutes, records, and reports regarding the separation, anticipated costs of the superintendent search committee, and interim appointment, be it so resolved that the finance director appear before the council to articulate a plan to restore our dropping bond rating, be it so resolved that the city administration cease and desist the use of private investigators to follow and harass employees, utilizing contractually afforded leave benefits,

[Bears]: Be it further resolved in the city administration report back to the council with the identified line in the budget where we are paying private investigators and a complete financial report from the start of this practice to the present and be it resolved at the city administration report to the council, the cost associated for the drug testing of questionable drug testing of our DPW staff and a report outlining the reasons for these tests.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: I have two documents from the administration that I'll read, and then I'll go to members of the council, and then we can go to public participation.

[Bears]: First, I was on the bond rating we received a message from the mayor.

[Bears]: Hello President Bears and city council members after a great deal of preparation and bond rating call last week.

[Bears]: I'm pleased to report that our a three bond rating was reaffirmed by Moody's financial services company upon receiving updated documentation related to our fiscal year 23 audit.

[Bears]: As you're likely aware the AA3 rating is regarded as a quote high grade rating and per Moody's analysis the city is in line for an elevated credit rating in the future.

[Bears]: You can read about Moody's outlook on the city's financial health and borrowing strength in a press release on the city website.

[Bears]: While this is welcome news it comes with opportunities for us to shore up our financial reporting operations and strive to increase our rating in the future.

[Bears]: If you have any questions please feel free to contact my office.

[Bears]: We then also received a message regarding Council Resolution 24518, which is what we're currently considering.

[Bears]: The mayor said, hello, President Bears, I wanted to provide some insight on Council Resolution 24518.

[Bears]: Quote, my responsibility as mayor is to the residents and taxpayers of the city of Medford.

[Bears]: When I receive allegations from multiple parties alleging various employee matters, including potential misconduct, fraud, et cetera, I believe our community expects that I investigate these allegations to the fullest extent possible.

[Bears]: Additionally, depending on the specific nature of the allegations at issue, our human resources department does not have the bandwidth to undertake investigations that are broad in scope or are too cumbersome that such efforts would impede daily office duties and responsibilities.

[Bears]: Also, as it relates to school items, please refer all school matters to the school department.

[Bears]: With respect to the portion of the proposed resolution pertaining to drug testing, this is a confidential personnel matter and due to individual privacy considerations, we cannot comment.

[Bears]: If you have any questions, feel free to contact me.

[Bears]: Is there a motion to sever the paper into at least elements regarding finances and non-finances?

[Bears]: Or does the Councilor want to pull back rule 21?

[Bears]: On a motion to question the ruling of the chair by Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Ms.

[Bears]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: I'm not sure what the motion is.

[Bears]: It's just a...

[Bears]: I have said that I believe that there are financial elements to this paper.

[Bears]: My ruling that there are finance elements to the paper that rule 21 would apply here.

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Sounds like there's two options in front of us.

[Bears]: One is I have ruled that there are financial elements to this paper.

[Bears]: Um, we could move forward with questioning that, that any of this counts as a finance paper, um, or we could consider the motion to sever prior to that.

[Bears]: Uh, that's up to, um, councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Councilor Callahan did indicate their decision wanting a motion to sever.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: um then uh there's but it was after the second there was already a motion to question the ruling of the chair the motion to sever was was that we would do it after discussion you didn't make a motion to sever you said it was a recommended course of action there was no second there's a second emotion to overrule the ruling of the chair that there are financial elements in this paper that qualify under rule 21

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: If they want to reach out to me now, I would be happy to hear their interpretation.

[Bears]: Is there further discussion on the motion of question really in the chair?

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I would just note that I am actually operating under

[Bears]: legal opinions that I received that rule 21 stems from the charter right.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli invoked the charter right in June, and I had to go to legal counsel to discuss that charter right, and legal counsel informed me that the charter right under this rule applies to any motion, order, or resolution under consideration by the council.

[Bears]: So it's kind of a catch-22 situation.

[Bears]: I don't like it.

[Bears]: It's one of the reasons I think we need to have a charter change.

[Bears]: And I believe I misinterpreted it last time by being too restrictive.

[Bears]: And that's why I'm not being restrictive now, based on advice of counsel.

[Bears]: So, we are where we are because this has been invoked multiple times by multiple Councilors, and given the council opinion that I received in July.

[Bears]: I believe that under mass general law is the charter that's been adopted by the city.

[Bears]: The interpretation that I received from the city's legal counsel was that literally any paper could be postponed by any Councilor until the next meeting for any reason.

[Bears]: So, um, huh?

[Bears]: Yeah, it wasn't from the mayor.

[Bears]: It was from the council at KP law.

[Bears]: So, um,

[Bears]: We could take a motion on the ruling of the chair, but again, that's the council advice that advice I received from council.

[Bears]: I've been on both sides of this.

[Bears]: I was too restrictive last time when I ruled something one way, and now I'm trying to go the other way because of the advice I received.

[Bears]: He said that he wanted more information.

[Bears]: He wanted more time to receive more information.

[Bears]: I don't know if he can speak to it,

[Bears]: If we want to go on the motion overall, the ruling of the chair by Councilor Scarpelli, seconded by Councilor Callahan, that's the motion that's on the floor.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: No.

[Bears]: representing private property owners and they are allowed to.

[Bears]: petition the city within the zoning ordinance and the Massachusetts general laws for whatever they need to do on their private property.

[Bears]: So, so we don't have any.

[Bears]: Only the private property landowner has the right.

[Bears]: They have their unlimited right to choose who they want to represent them when making petitions to the city regarding permits, licenses, et cetera.

[Bears]: We don't have any control over that.

[Bears]: That's, that's, um, pretty, pretty foundational, um, under the current way that the state and federal laws work for private property.

[Bears]: No, so that would be if the city owned land and was then trying to build a project in these areas, then we would have to go through this process, the bidding process procurement.

[Bears]: Zoning affects private property owners.

[Bears]: I mean, it affects public property nominally, but most of the property in the city is owned by private entities, individuals, corporations, groups.

[Bears]: So when we change the zoning, that changes the laws about what we allow private property owners to do.

[Bears]: um private property owners can pick any construction company any lawyer or any designer any architect that they want to make a proposal make a design um and the city just has the process of outlined here like a site plan review process or special permitting process

[Bears]: where the city has some limited, in some cases limited, in some cases significant discretionary choice as to what to allow, but we do not control who owns private property and we do not control who private property owners choose to hire to design projects, to construct projects, to make proposals to the city.

[Bears]: So, and I don't think there's any law that would allow us to change that.

[Bears]: I know that between the performance standards and the other things that are set in the zoning ordinance, the different boards, community development board especially, and other site plan review and special permit granting authorities will use the power allowed to us by the state zoning law to

[Bears]: Any further discussion by members of the Council?

[Bears]: I'm just going to say very quickly that on this and the next ordinance, a very dangerous federal administration with a very particular and specific agenda is going to be coming into place in about a month.

[Bears]: And

[Bears]: As a council, I think it is responsible and essential of us to act by passing a law that lets the people in this community know that the police of this city are not going to enact an agenda that weaponizes people's identities, people's documentation status, people's very livelihoods.

[Bears]: And that is essential.

[Bears]: Yeah, there might be consequences.

[Bears]: We may not get the FBI grant for, I don't know, whatever, more, we might not get the weapons that come for a discounted rate or something, right?

[Bears]: These certain things that the Department of Justice and other agencies send to municipalities.

[Bears]: To me, that is a very small cost to standing up for what's right, standing up for our values and letting, again, the people of this community know that they will be safe

[Bears]: If they want to report an incident to a Medford police officer, that they don't have to be afraid for their livelihoods and their ability to stay in this country.

[Bears]: If they want to be a witness in another case, if they just want to be a good citizen, right?

[Bears]: And there's a lot of other reasons too.

[Bears]: Folks who are pulled over, folks who are questioned or whatever those might be.

[Bears]: They shouldn't also have to have that added fear that they may well not be going home to their kids, because what we've heard over and over again in the last administration, and quite frankly, this administration seems dangerously more competent to implement this horrific agenda, is that kids went home after school and their parents were gone.

[Bears]: And that's not something that we should have in this city.

[Bears]: Thank you, Vice President Collins, for your presentation.

[Bears]: I think it really speaks to

[Bears]: all of the issues, or at least some of the issues around 401 Boston Avenue.

[Bears]: I do know we have a number of residents still on Zoom who wanted to speak to this.

[Bears]: I just want to note that tomorrow night is the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: The Community Development Board is the authority that is reviewing this application.

[Bears]: And I just wanted to also note a couple of things here.

[Bears]: To me,

[Bears]: I am grateful that Tufts is taking on this responsibility to add housing on its campus.

[Bears]: That is something that this community has wanted Tufts to do for a long time.

[Bears]: But every project that Tufts does falls under a greater scope of the balance of power between municipalities and large educational nonprofits.

[Bears]: That is way out of whack when it comes to our state laws.

[Bears]: When it comes to our state laws around

[Bears]: site plan, Dover amendment, and what these institutions have to do to collaborate with municipalities and their neighbors.

[Bears]: When it comes to the pilot legislation, payments in lieu of taxes and the, you know, five years ago we analyzed the Tufts on its non-taxable property would be paying $8 million.

[Bears]: and it is paying $500,000.

[Bears]: It's a huge loss for us when it comes to the city services that we need to provide, and the city services that institutions like that consume, both on campus and off campus.

[Bears]: So this really does fit into this larger question, which is why a big piece of this resolution is about the state legislation that this body has supported.

[Bears]: both the home rule petitions around institutional master plans that we have submitted along with our neighbors in Somerville to ask Tufts and require Tufts to provide a master plan for their growth and development so that we can be aware of that and inform our community about that, as well as the pilot legislation to require a 25% pilot versus the completely voluntary system we have now.

[Bears]: One reason I bring up the institutional master plan is that around this Tufts proposal, you know, couple of years ago we had Tufts initially doing the storm proposal at around seven stories and 400 beds.

[Bears]: It's now 10 stories and 700 beds and I am actually a fan of more beds I think Tufts taking on more responsibility for on campus housing is a good thing.

[Bears]: But I can understand how residents feel that the maybe the scope of the site plan and the height of the building and the shadows are a major issue, or even residents who just feel that the process itself, where it was seven stories now it's 10 stories, how do we get there.

[Bears]: And what what's the city's role in trying to mitigate and mediate and collaborate and negotiate in that process.

[Bears]: City doesn't really seem to have much leverage.

[Bears]: So I really just respect the residents in the area who have advocated for changes to this project.

[Bears]: I want to put ourselves on record as supporting those efforts.

[Bears]: I also did speak to the mayor earlier today about this issue.

[Bears]: She

[Bears]: and noted that she had sent a letter and that she supports our efforts and advocacy around this issue, but also that she has had some good conversations with Tufts and is hopeful for an outcome that has more mitigation, more community benefits than the initial Tufts proposal of three or four months ago.

[Bears]: That process is ongoing in the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: I also spoke with Rocco DiRico from Tufts, and I do have want to just read an email that he sent over.

[Bears]: This is to the Honorable President, Zach Bears, Medford City Council regarding Resolution 24-513 to request changes to the proposed Tufts Dormitory project.

[Bears]: Dear President Bears, I ask that the following statement be read at tonight's City Council meeting.

[Bears]: Tufts University is proposing a new residence hall to be operated by Capstone Management on Boston Avenue.

[Bears]: The proposed project is part of an ongoing effort that meets many of the city's and the university's shared goals.

[Bears]: More on campus housing, mixed use development, density near public transit, and an energy efficient building design that meets the city's specialized stretch energy code.

[Bears]: The university has spent the last four months meeting with neighbors, government officials, the Community Development Board,

[Bears]: and other stakeholders.

[Bears]: As a result of those meetings, we have added several community benefits to the project.

[Bears]: Those improvements include new sidewalks on both sides of Boston Avenue, new crosswalks, new trees, new retail options, and a blue bike station.

[Bears]: All these improvements will make Boston Avenue greener, more walkable, and more accessible.

[Bears]: Tufts University has hosted three community meetings on this project.

[Bears]: At these meetings, we listened to our neighbors, acknowledged their concerns, and acted upon feedback.

[Bears]: The university has also agreed to a $500,000 one-time payment to create a neighborhood improvement fund

[Bears]: for the neighborhood impacted by the project.

[Bears]: We look forward to working with the neighbors and the city to determine the best way to utilize these funds.

[Bears]: Thank you for the city's partnership with Tufts University on this project and many other initiatives.

[Bears]: The university remains committed to building more housing, revitalizing Boston Avenue, and improving accessibility.

[Bears]: This project will have a positive impact on the city and the university.

[Bears]: Sincerely, Rocco DiRico, Executive Director of Government and Community Relations, Tufts University.

[Bears]: So I wanted to read that to note.

[Bears]: That is the position of Tufts University.

[Bears]: And Rocco and I have disagreed on many issues over the years, and we are able to have amicable discussions based on the positions that we both hold.

[Bears]: And I just say that because, again, commenting on civil discourse, I think, and what that means and how the truth plays a part in it.

[Bears]: And I also just want to say I have some honest disagreements.

[Bears]: with Rocco, especially when it comes to

[Bears]: what is the responsibility of these large educational nonprofit institutions to the municipalities, the cities, and the towns that they call home.

[Bears]: And I don't think state law reflects what the best arrangement of that should look like.

[Bears]: And I think until we have changes there and until Tufts and cities like Benford are able to work together as partners to rebalance that relationship, it's going to poison processes, community processes around construction, around pilot, around expansion, around

[Bears]: what these institutions mean to the communities that they call home.

[Bears]: And I think that's what's happened here.

[Bears]: I think there's a lot of good that can come out of this project.

[Bears]: I think there's some things that could change, and I would hope would change, and there's some things that maybe just can't change, and that's going to be really difficult to deal with.

[Bears]: I know that a lot of folks don't feel heard in the process, even, even with everything that Rocco said, people don't feel heard and people feel like Tufts just has so much power that it feels like a bully institution.

[Bears]: And that's really difficult.

[Bears]: And I don't think Tufts wants to be seen as that I don't think they want to act like that.

[Bears]: And I think because, sadly, everyone in our society seems married to the idea that we just have to do whatever the law requires and nothing more, because the law is so imbalanced in Tufts' favor, they may not even realize how they're appearing and presenting to the community.

[Bears]: So I really hope we can see some systemic change here.

[Bears]: I think this project is sitting in that larger context.

[Bears]: But I do hope that our Community Development Board can work

[Bears]: to get to a project approval that also reflects as much mitigation as possible.

[Bears]: And that in some ways, this resolution enhances the negotiating position of the city to secure additional community benefits.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: You know, it's funny, the name bears derives from Pierce, and this picks it up as Pierce, which is so interesting.

[Bears]: We should talk about that for 15 minutes, I think.

[Bears]: All right, last item on the agenda, legally required referral.

[Bears]: This is our proposed amendments to the Benford Zoning Ordinance, Salem Street Corridor District for referral to the Community Development Board.

[Bears]: Is there a motion to first we need a motion to waive the reading for a brief summary.

[Bears]: So moved on that motion by Councilor Collins seconded by Councilor let me Mr. Clerk please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: I have a negative motion passes.

[Bears]: So this is the proposed Salem Street Corridor Zoning District.

[Bears]: This is the product of several meetings of the Planning and Permitting Committee.

[Bears]: The memorandum contains the draft text for the following proposed zoning changes.

[Bears]: to amend 94 dash 2.1 division into districts to amend 94 dash 3.2 table of use regulations and dimensional standards to end table.

[Bears]: of dimensional requirements to amend the definitions and to insert the section 94-9X Salem Street Corridor District.

[Bears]: And so that is the summary of this.

[Bears]: There's obviously much more detail here in this document of proposed zoning changes.

[Bears]: But what I'm going to do for now is I'm just going to outline the process here.

[Bears]: So, um, two years ago, uh, the city released a comprehensive plan that comprehensive plan includes a number of recommendations around updates to the city zoning.

[Bears]: Uh, last year, the city council received funding and issued an RFP for proposals for zoning consultant.

[Bears]: We were able to choose the proposal of Innes Associates, which is a group that has a lot of done a lot of great work.

[Bears]: They are, um,

[Bears]: the proponent primary writers of the regulations for the MBTA Communities Act and also we're our consultant on the comprehensive plan.

[Bears]: So they have intimate knowledge of the city's comprehensive plan and its zoning requirements.

[Bears]: Since then, the planning and permitting committee has held 16 or 17 meetings this year with Innes Associates regarding a zoning updates project.

[Bears]: It's reported out a number of items including this, the Salem Street Corridor District.

[Bears]: At this point, this is a vote to refer to the Community Development Board this initial proposal.

[Bears]: From this point forward, there will be two public hearings.

[Bears]: Community Development Board will open a public hearing, followed by the City Council opening a public hearing, which people can be heard.

[Bears]: Community Development Board will review this and make recommendations to the City Council, and the City Council will then consider this, consider those recommendations, consider any other amendments, and then take a final vote on whether to amend the city's zoning ordinance.

[Bears]: Similarly, earlier tonight if folks are paying attention or were attending this meeting earlier.

[Bears]: We approved the Mystic Avenue corridor district, which followed the same process, and this amendment and other amendments will also have

[Bears]: several public meetings, generally at least two of the council before the public hearings, followed by at least two public hearings, and sometimes those public hearings occur over multiple meetings as well.

[Bears]: So this proposal will go to the Community Development Board for a public hearing in the new year.

[Bears]: Recognizing Councilor Collins and then Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: On the motion of Councilor Collins to refer to the Community Development Board, seconded by Councilor Tseng, I will recognize Councilor Skarpuk.

[Bears]: Thank you Chair Tseng. I appreciate the work that you've put into outlining a timeline for the council to consider the proposed draft from the mayor based on the recommendations of the Charter Study Committee.

[Bears]: I think that this timeline makes sense.

[Bears]: My biggest

[Bears]: concern is around inviting the participation of the school committee and the other boards and commissions.

[Bears]: So I think having that as our final meeting gives them time to provide feedback.

[Bears]: I have heard from some members of the school committee and some chairs of boards and commissions that they would like to provide some feedback on the proposed draft.

[Bears]: So giving them as much time as possible to do that, I believe makes a lot of sense.

[Bears]: Of course, the mayor has already reviewed this document and made, I believe, changes from the initial recommendations of the study committee to what we see here today.

[Bears]: So having that be the second meeting also makes sense to me and discussing all of that, but I just wanted to note that she had a swing at this already.

[Bears]: Um, and then I think, you know, our first meeting being discussing the council also makes a lot of sense, uh, because we haven't had a look at this yet.

[Bears]: Um, this is our first look and we are likely, I think, to make some changes and amendments similar to what the mayor has done.

[Bears]: So, um, I think this is a good timeline.

[Bears]: I do have a few motions that I want to make towards the end of the meeting after we hear more discussion around just have some questions, some thoughts around procedures and how we'll get more information and of course solicit that input from the school committee and the boards and commissions.

[Bears]: But I'm also really interested to hear what my fellow Councilors think about the draft that we see so far.

[Bears]: what articles may need the most attention versus what articles may not need as much.

[Bears]: And then I also think, and it's technical, I think we may, there's also a question about article 10, which I just don't think we listed.

[Bears]: That's okay.

[Bears]: It's just transitional provisions.

[Bears]: So I think it's really not actually it basically just says everything continues as this moves forward.

[Bears]: But we may want to talk about that towards the end as well.

[Bears]: But I think I don't really that seems to be really technical and more just about.

[Bears]: the form of how adopting this new charter impacts the existing charter.

[Bears]: So I don't think that would be of significant discussion.

[Bears]: At least I don't think so.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Yeah, and I just wanted to note to Councilor Collins point the composition questions.

[Bears]: I think some of the main concerns are going to be the composition and term length of the different bodies that we would discuss the council as our part of it's part of Article two, the mayor is part of Article three, and then the school committee is part of Article four.

[Bears]: So those would be happening across the three separate meetings.

[Bears]: It's probably, I think, actually good considering that those are certainly major suggested changes being proposed.

[Bears]: Also, compensation is across those three.

[Bears]: So that's just another thing we're going to have to take a look at, maybe put to bed forever, which I think everyone would appreciate.

[Bears]: And I do have some thoughts on feedback.

[Bears]: My first thought is that councilors, and it's obviously not necessarily, you know, folks are going to have ideas and questions in the moment, and it's not to preclude that, but to request if folks do have suggested changes or questions in advance, I would move that we request that councilors submit those in writing to the clerk.

[Bears]: by the Thursday before the upcoming meeting so that those can be added into the packet for all of us to see and take a look at.

[Bears]: and also to request that Councilors submit questions for the call-in center to Chair Tseng by the one week before the meeting, just so we can give them some time to prepare.

[Bears]: That doesn't mean we won't have questions in the moment or that answers to our questions may spawn new questions, which I think we've seen, but I just think getting some of that in writing

[Bears]: earlier will help the call-in center come prepared, help us come prepared.

[Bears]: So that would be my motion to request councilors submit in writing points of discussion or specific amendments on the Thursday prior to each meeting on the topics for each meeting and to submit questions for the call-in center to Chair Tsang one week prior to each meeting so that Chair Tsang can submit those to the call-in center.

[Bears]: you chair saying yeah I have I can just go through my the rest of what I have I'd also make a motion to request that feedback from the school committee and any boards and commissions be received by Wednesday February 12th for consideration for the meeting on February 19th and of course this can be submitted earlier than that if there are topics that

[Bears]: boards and commissions or the school committee want to discuss in those first two meetings, but I think a lot of that, I think there's a bunch of stuff about multi-member bodies in the section in Article 9, the school committee in Article 4.

[Bears]: So that last meeting seems to be where most of that discussion would happen, so that's

[Bears]: where I'm suggesting that motion.

[Bears]: Okay, great.

[Bears]: I have a decent idea of that, but I'm not 100% sure.

[Bears]: Motion passes to 5006 resolution to support families of youth with disabilities offered by Councilor Leming and Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: Whereas youth with disabilities need support during their developmental years, whereas parents of youth with disabilities are under supported and often have often have to go outside municipalities to find programs for their kids.

[Bears]: And whereas after school programs are rare in Medford and those support that support youth with disabilities are non existent.

[Bears]: Be it resolved that the Bedford City Council strongly encourage the administration to prioritize these members of our community by finding a way to quickly set up programs that meet their specific needs.

[Bears]: Be it further resolved that the City Council listen to the comments of parents of youth with disabilities on their own experiences in finding support.

[Bears]: Sorry, one second, Gaston, sorry.

[Bears]: All I can say is I agree with the spirit of your question of what is the point of this.

[Bears]: State law requires that we advertise in a print newspaper

[Bears]: these ordinances.

[Bears]: You can find about five copies at 7-Eleven.

[Bears]: I used to be a subscriber when it covered Medford up until about 2022.

[Bears]: And then Gannett Company essentially gutted all of the local newspapers that they owned, merged some together, reassigned reporters to different beats.

[Bears]: And we no longer had a Medford beat reporter, which is the situation we've been in for

[Bears]: two and a half years if folks can correct me on the timeline a little bit.

[Bears]: But this was advertised in the print version of the Medford transcript in Somerville Journal.

[Bears]: The clerk can can provide the receipts.

[Bears]: And to be honest, I think this

[Bears]: There's a state law around advertising that harkens back to the time when most everybody got a local newspaper and actually read through the advertisements to see what was going on in the city.

[Bears]: So we advertise public hearings in the paper, we advertise second readings of ordinances in the paper.

[Bears]: We also, of course, put up the agendas and write everything on our website and the portal that we have.

[Bears]: But the state requires us to post in

[Bears]: print paper of record.

[Bears]: And they might have a new.

[Bears]: I don't know if they publish everything from the print newspaper online.

[Bears]: I don't think they do.

[Bears]: So yeah, that's.

[Bears]: Yeah, I have seen

[Bears]: I was reading through the end of session bills to see if something that we had put forward had gone through at the legislature they just had their end of session, December 31, I think 2024 lasted maybe a little longer at the state house and everywhere else.

[Bears]: I'm just kind of saying that I saw a title of a community that had filed a home rule petition to request that they could post these things on a bulletin board on their city website instead of in a paper.

[Bears]: I think we would have to ask the state to allow us an exemption from the state law to do so.

[Bears]: No, I appreciate it.

[Bears]: It's a procedural quirk that deserves some explanation.

[Bears]: So thank you.

[Bears]: We'll do 24.351, a resolution to allow the director of veteran services to offer housing incentives to veteran renters, whereas veterans in the city of Menford need a place to live and are often discriminated against when searching for housing.

[Bears]: be it therefore resolved that the veteran services director shall have the authority to offer available funds to entities that choose to rent to qualified veterans.

[Bears]: Be it further resolved that this be discussed with the veteran service director and the city's legal representation and committee.

[Bears]: It looks like this has been done and we have a report out from the

[Bears]: um resident services and public engagement committee uh here to amend uh the revised ordinances chapter two administration article four officers and employees division seven director of veteran services there are some minor amendments to um

[Bears]: add pronouns, all the pronouns in this ordinance were just he and this adds she on her.

[Bears]: And then also under section, creates a new section, section 2-765 called housing incentives.

[Bears]: which says the directive of veteran services may in coordination and in the sole discretion with an in the sole discretion authorization of the mayor and subject to the available appropriation and compliance with applicable legal considerations including and not limited to general law chapter 30 b

[Bears]: which is our procurement law partner with a non-profit organization which may offer cash incentives up to $750 annually to landlords who offer rental housing to qualified veterans.

[Bears]: And then it amends the reserve section number to reflect the addition of the new section.

[Bears]: Again, the council doesn't make these determinations.

[Bears]: I understand.

[Bears]: But I want to just clarify for my own understanding.

[Bears]: Right now, a call would go out through dispatch.

[Bears]: The building commissioner or the former commissioner, if the building commissioner is not available, would answer.

[Bears]: And they would make a determination about what their staff would do.

[Bears]: And the prior policy was that the staff themselves would make a decision about who would go out to this, if they would go out to the site or not.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: OK.

[Bears]: And so you would, I guess, in the past practice, you would call the individual cell phone number of one of the inspectors.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: And I'm just saying, it sounds like what the administration is trying to change to say,

[Bears]: that the call goes to the building commissioner and then if the building commissioner makes a determination, that's the chain of command to the people who work for the building department.

[Bears]: But my point being that the building inspector is just changing who's making the determination.

[Bears]: I'm just saying.

[Bears]: To be honest, we're coming to this body that has no authority to do anything about this.

[Bears]: And the administration is basically, it seems to me the administration has said, we would like a different, we want the building commissioner to determine instead of the individual building inspector to determine when to go out.

[Bears]: And it sounds like there's, that has been a change that has caused some issues that some people are saying has caused some issues that need to be worked out.

[Bears]: to be frank, it's the prerogative of the mayor if the mayor wants to say this is the person who makes that decision.

[Bears]: Now, it doesn't mean that that doesn't mean that the process is working perfectly.

[Bears]: And like, I just want to say like, it sounds like some communication needs to happen or like things need to be adjusted.

[Bears]: But just to say that there are two options, and the option is that only the building inspector can decide to go out whenever they want, or

[Bears]: the mayor's way is working perfectly.

[Bears]: I don't think either of those things are absolutes.

[Bears]: So I'm not comfortable myself right now saying we must go back to the old system.

[Bears]: It sounds like there's some sort of disagreement internally or lack of communication internally that's going on within the executive branch and the people who work for the city that I agree like we would like to get more information on and understand how it's worked out.

[Bears]: But I just don't think this is as easy as to say,

[Bears]: There are only two ways to do this.
