[Bears]: Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yeah, it's 60 from the one that even though she passes me and he's adjourned.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam Chair.

[Bears]: I just want to thank you for getting us off to the start of this meeting.

[Bears]: And I want to note just that the comprehensive plan and the zoning that we've been implementing based on the comprehensive plan for the city

[Bears]: which was developed over two years with input from thousands of residents, is based on a model of neighborhoods, squares, and corridors.

[Bears]: We have been looking at corridors so far, and we'll be looking at squares going forward, and this

[Bears]: tonight we're talking about neighborhoods and neighborhood residential and I really appreciate that this meeting you know we're taking a second meeting in two weeks to look at a proposal and starting tonight just looking at general ideas and the research that has been done on the neighborhood residential and having looked at the presentation that was sent over by email I

[Bears]: I'm really looking forward to the presentation, but also, you know, do have some thoughts and some suggestions that I'm going to make after this meeting and look forward to seeing those hopefully incorporated into the draft that we see in two weeks.

[Bears]: And with that, I just want to thank again, the chair and the team that's working on this as well as fellow members of the committee.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: We can see the screen share on Zoom.

[Bears]: I think it might require maybe with the Zoom update a change in the booth to click the screen share instead of the video.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And thank you, Chair Collins and Councilor Scarpelli for your comments.

[Bears]: And thank you Paula and Emily and the team for this presentation.

[Bears]: I do have a concern about the level of incremental step up that we see here.

[Bears]: And I'm not necessarily saying

[Bears]: I'm going to make a motion, and I'm not saying that it has to go exactly by the lines in this proposal as exists now.

[Bears]: But I think for neighborhood residential, it really should just be NR1, NR2, and NR3.

[Bears]: And perhaps we could consider something like NR4 as an urban residential one and an urban residential two.

[Bears]: And I think that would be a more

[Bears]: incremental change to allow for more of what we see actually existing in a lot of these places compared to the zoning that was passed in many cases decades after homes were constructed.

[Bears]: That limited what could be built beyond what's actually there and created all the nonconformities that we have.

[Bears]: So I would recommend, and I'm gonna make a motion and I will email it to the clerk.

[Bears]: And I do have a second motion, but I would move to adjust the proposed neighborhood residential districts by one, removing the NR4 district type and considering that as part of the urban residential topic as a potential urban residential one district.

[Bears]: Classifying all the areas currently on this proposal listed with some adjustments based on the work that you guys are going to do to go down to the parcel level.

[Bears]: Currently on the proposal listed as NR1 and NR2 as NR1.

[Bears]: Classify the areas currently in the proposal listed as NR3, as NR2.

[Bears]: and classify all the areas currently listed on the proposal as NR4, as NR3, and to adjust the NR3 type to remove the one unit by right, which I think will meet some of the changes.

[Bears]: And then I would also just note that any parcel where the current district is general residential should be at least NR2.

[Bears]: and that any district where the current zoning is an apartment district should be NR3.

[Bears]: Yes, I'll do that.

[Bears]: And I have a further motion, but I know folks want to discuss that one first.

[Bears]: It's a significant change.

[Bears]: I think, yes, that's fair.

[Bears]: And I'm emailing it now.

[Bears]: Thank you, Madam Chair.

[Bears]: I just wanted to make my other motion, which is to request that the chair work with the administration to increase accessible materials, notices, and communications about upcoming meetings and distribute them to the community.

[Bears]: and I've sent the language for both of these over.

[Bears]: I have to step out in a few minutes, five minutes, but I'm happy to answer any questions on my motion now and potentially consider them if possible.

[Bears]: But if not, I hope my colleagues will consider them and approve them.

[Bears]: It would be the second one.

[Bears]: It's essentially downstepping each of the shades.

[Bears]: So the very light yellow would stay the same, the medium yellow would go down to the light yellow, the lighter orange would go down to the medium yellow, and the dark orange would go down to the lighter orange.

[Bears]: Yes, that's the intent.

[Bears]: Test 1, 2.

[Bears]: You basically answered the question I was going to ask which, but just to kind of clarify and drive the point home.

[Bears]: It's much we're using the capital funding much more efficiently

[Bears]: this way than we are when we're doing spot repairs with contractors.

[Bears]: And this is both for sidewalks and for street repair.

[Bears]: The crew is going to be doing spot repairs where we previously were hiring contractors to do spot repairs like patching and crack sealing and spot panels of sidewalk.

[Bears]: Yeah, so essentially on both of these fronts we're talking about moving from triaging emergency spot repairs with outside contractors to being able to do all of that work in-house plus maybe even a little bit of

[Bears]: production worker, you know, maybe some people might call it, you know.

[Bears]: a new project.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: And then just on the front of the money going towards our roads and sidewalks, and you know, correct me if I'm getting my six-month-old back of the napkin calculations wrong, but

[Bears]: We were talking about needing to move into the $5.5 to $6.5 million a year range of spending, and we were somewhere in the $3.5 to $4 million range.

[Bears]: So this gets us another $500,000 closer to that $5.5 to $6.5 million range, essentially, because we're going to still be doing.

[Bears]: And does the efficiency impact that at all as well?

[Bears]: Because we're using the money more efficiently, does it give us an even further added benefit than just adding 500,000 towards that annual repair budget?

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: some other grant money we're using this year and say, well, that all adds up to four and a half million.

[Bears]: Yeah, I mean I think it's pretty.

[Bears]: The standard test is, do you or any immediate family members or associates stand to benefit financially from your vote?

[Bears]: And I don't, I mean, that's your call.

[Bears]: I don't know.

[Bears]: But unless you are going to be hired by the UU Church to do door restoration or someone in your family, which I don't think

[Bears]: either of you are.

[Bears]: I've attended a couple of services myself.

[Bears]: I plan to vote on this.

[Bears]: So that's generally the test.

[Bears]: If you don't feel comfortable with it, I think we have the quorum and the votes to move forward without you.

[Bears]: But yeah, you're not receiving a personal benefit from this project.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: Councilor Lazzaro, and you could check with the Ethics Commission.

[Bears]: If you wanted to ask them, you could ask them.

[Bears]: You have to ask prior to a vote.

[Bears]: So if you abstain tonight, you could ask them in advance of the vote at the regular meeting.

[Bears]: You could review their regulations online or review the conflict of interest and ethics trainings that we all have to take every year.

[Bears]: But generally, I think you're in the clear on this one.

[Bears]: Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Right, yeah.

[Bears]: I mean, unless you were being hired to do the work itself.

[Bears]: That's really the only way I could see this being an issue.

[Bears]: An example I can give you, in 2020, I and my family, my parents and I had invested in Medford Brewing Company.

[Bears]: Prior to that, we had to, I called the ethics commission, we had to divest and sell our investments in order to, for me to vote on the brewpub ordinance because it would have benefited the, because we were investors.

[Bears]: But this, I know it's a church, it's a nonprofit organization.

[Bears]: You're not shareholders.

[Bears]: you're not paid by the organization, nor will you be paid for the work.

[Bears]: So that's my general interpretation.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: Thank you chair saying, um, I want to, uh, thank my colleagues.

[Bears]: Thank you for putting together these meetings.

[Bears]: Thank the members of the charter study committee, the mayor and the Collins center for their work up to this point.

[Bears]: Um, and especially for those who are here tonight, as well as member of the public members of the public who are interested in this topic.

[Bears]: Um, we are,

[Bears]: And I think I've said this a few times now, we're working on all three of the big three that Councilor Knight once told me the city council is responsible for this term.

[Bears]: We've passed a budget ordinance and a budget, and we have another budget coming up.

[Bears]: Obviously we are in, I think meeting 18 or 19 of the term of the planning and permitting committee regarding zoning updates.

[Bears]: And we are here tonight on the charter.

[Bears]: which is the foundational document for our community.

[Bears]: And we are looking at the first update in nearly 40 years and bringing us into, I would say, the modern age of city charters based on what we're looking at here and before us with the proposal from the Charter Study Committee revised by the mayor.

[Bears]: And by and large, I think this proposal is a really great proposal, a charter that the people can understand and something that I wholeheartedly support as a whole.

[Bears]: Last week I submitted to the council and shared with the public very openly a series of amendments that I would like to propose for discussion tonight by this committee.

[Bears]: And I am hopeful for the consideration and moving forward on them.

[Bears]: But I also just want to note that part of the reason that I went about this the way that I did is that there have been fantastic discussions

[Bears]: from multiple people all over the Internet talking about what they would like to see, what they wouldn't like to see, bringing forward new ideas that have added to my knowledge base and that I am going to bring to the discussions that we have tonight.

[Bears]: As regards to the first article and the sections within it,

[Bears]: I want to thank the study committee for putting together a thoughtful preamble.

[Bears]: I really think it represents what our community is, as well as its rich history, as it says right in here, our city's rich history and where we want to go and what the purpose of a charter is.

[Bears]: As regards to the rest of the article one and sections, I did have a couple of minor proposals around the definitions, but they do relate to

[Bears]: the proposal around the composition of the city council.

[Bears]: So I will not make any motions or discuss them at this time, but we'll discuss them when that topic comes up for the chair.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I just wanted to also, I was remiss to not thank the Collins Center.

[Bears]: They worked up a great comparison document that we received the other, I think yesterday or the day before, comparing what's in the current charter to the proposal.

[Bears]: So I just wanted to thank the team at the Collins Center for putting that together.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I see President Bears.

[Bears]: You can go to Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Oh, OK.

[Bears]: George, give me a second.

[Bears]: Yeah, no problem.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: see you president bears thank you Councilor Tseng um just a note uh we're going to come back to 2-1 and 2-4 okay um i just yeah and i appreciated the question i just want to make sure we stay on course have the discussion on those um i have as regards to section 2 or article 2

[Bears]: I have thoughts on 2-5, 2-7, 2-9, 2-10, and then I also have a thought on 9-6 and moving into section two.

[Bears]: So.

[Bears]: I think the question is though, not in the case of an investigation or inquiry,

[Bears]: I regularly communicate with the city assessor to set up a meeting with the resident to talk about their assessment.

[Bears]: This would seem to prohibit me from doing that.

[Bears]: Is that true?

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I think, um, obviously subject if you want to take a look at it and come back, but it would seem to me that if the intent is to make clear that the council cannot order a city employee to do anything, um, maybe just eliminating everything between the comma after section two, six and the word neither.

[Bears]: So eliminating the city council shall contact the officers and employees serving under the mayor solely through the mayor and

[Bears]: because then it would just read, except for the purpose of inquiries and investigations pursuant to section two, six, neither the city council nor any member of the city council shall give orders or directions to any officer or employee, either publicly or privately.

[Bears]: I don't know if that makes sense to folks.

[Bears]: I'll make a motion to

[Bears]: make that amendment pending further discussion and information from the representatives from the Collins Center.

[Bears]: Or yeah, I can work on emailing it.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: Yeah, sorry.

[Bears]: It would remove the sentence, the city council shall contact the officers and employees serving under the mayor solely through the mayor and

[Bears]: but maintains the intent that we could not give orders or directions.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: I just had one one item here under section two five subsection one that the regular meetings of the city council be held at a time and place fixed by ordinance.

[Bears]: I would change that to the city council rules.

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: Is that a motion?

[Bears]: That that would be a motion, yeah.

[Bears]: And the clerk already has that language in the document I sent over.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Through the chair.

[Bears]: Yeah, the city council can change the rules of the city council by majority vote.

[Bears]: But it doesn't require multiple readings.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng, um, regarding this section, um,

[Bears]: Thank you Chair Tsang.

[Bears]: This is the second of the three charter amendments passed in 2020.

[Bears]: three, I believe.

[Bears]: And this regards the Council confirming the appointments of the mayor.

[Bears]: The initial amendment that we had put forward that wasn't advanced to the legislature at the time by the mayor

[Bears]: would have had us affirmatively approving all appointments unless otherwise noted by mass general law by majority vote.

[Bears]: This has us having to take a specific motion to reject an appointment by a two thirds vote.

[Bears]: I do know that there were some concerns by the mayor about having to send all of the appointments to the council and get affirmative.

[Bears]: votes, I did read through the study committee report and found that that was relatively common.

[Bears]: But in the spirit of compromise, I can understand that concern.

[Bears]: And I would just propose changing the threshold from a two-thirds vote to a majority vote, which also seems to be very common across most communities.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: So I think my opinions, I don't disagree if I make sure I don't disagree with you.

[Bears]: So this, the way it's written without my amendment is the council would need two thirds to reject.

[Bears]: So we wouldn't see everybody.

[Bears]: that we would only appointments would be made and then we would have 30 days to say we don't want that appointment and then it will require two thirds to reject that appointment.

[Bears]: So it's not saying they would come before us.

[Bears]: I actually agree.

[Bears]: I support.

[Bears]: Yeah, I would support if someone else wanted to move in that direction more.

[Bears]: affirmative process where all of the appointments come before us.

[Bears]: But in the absence of that, I don't think it should require two-thirds for rejection.

[Bears]: I think it should require just a simple majority to reject an appointment.

[Bears]: I apologize.

[Bears]: I misunderstood.

[Bears]: Yeah, I just wanted to... I completely agree with your sentiment on that.

[Bears]: I want us to be able to have more authority as regards appointments.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Some of them would pertain if there was a change in the proposed composition.

[Bears]: So I'll hold those, but we did receive a communication and I noted as well from the chair of the elections commission that the references to the city clerk in here should be references to the elections commission.

[Bears]: notes on that.

[Bears]: Okay, great.

[Bears]: President Barras, to that point in your research, have you found there to be a significant difference in incumbency bias between someone who has the label candidate for re-election and someone who doesn't, even if they were serving?

[Bears]: Right, which I think this charter gets rid of.

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: I'm just wondering how much, if you had any knowledge on how much that benefit to incumbents

[Bears]: being a selection being made by the rest of the council is probably the most representative of the will of the people in that situation, because the people elected the other Councilors.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: And I appreciate you including this in this meeting.

[Bears]: as I was going through a section 9-6 in the existing charter's periodic review of ordinances.

[Bears]: This is a suggestion to amend

[Bears]: This motion would move section 9-6 to article 2, make it section 2-11.

[Bears]: It would then change the words by ordinance to by vote of the City Council, both in the second sentence and the fourth sentence.

[Bears]: Can I make a motion actually regarding section 2-4 first?

[Bears]: Okay.

[Bears]: I would just move that we move section 2-4 to a future meeting and to discuss sections 2-4, 3-1 and 4-4 as a single conversation at a future meeting.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Thank you, Chair Tsang, and just given the length of the meeting so far to get through the smaller stuff, I figured this is gonna take a while, I think.

[Bears]: And also I think it seems to be the main point of discussion around the proposals that I put forward was around the composition of the council.

[Bears]: So just to set the frame here, the charter study committee recommended to the mayor and then through that to the council, city council composed of 11 members, eight representing each individual ward of the city and three elected at large.

[Bears]: And something that I discussed in my conversations with the Charter Study Committee and something that I've had a lot of conversations with the past few years has been what the composition of the council should look like.

[Bears]: And part of the proposal that I put forward tonight, which is to amend that proposal to have

[Bears]: to follow what the Charter Study Committee proposed for the school committee, which would be a city council of seven members, three elected at large, and four from districts, which would be composed of two boards each, stems from three factors.

[Bears]: One are my principles, two are the data, and three are my experience serving on the council and serving in the leadership of the council for the past three years.

[Bears]: I think we've had a lot of conversation in the state and in the country about how should we elect elected officials.

[Bears]: And we're one of only actually I think three countries on a federal level that elects our legislatures by first past the post single district voting.

[Bears]: And I think one of the great advantages of the system that we have now, and I'm not advocating that we maintain an all at large system, is that everybody

[Bears]: faces a competitive election.

[Bears]: There's one district.

[Bears]: Everybody's running against each other.

[Bears]: There's no sailing through.

[Bears]: And there was a great New York Times piece talking about proportional representation.

[Bears]: That's a model that the Cambridge Planning Charter uses.

[Bears]: And you see, through that model, the election of people of differing ideologies representing different bases of voters.

[Bears]: Another conversation that's been discussed is a multi member districts.

[Bears]: We also had the statewide ballot question on rank choice voting.

[Bears]: And all of those are different ways to try to elect people that is not a first pass the posting.

[Bears]: And the reason for that is that a first pass the post single district system tends to have

[Bears]: less than ideal outcomes.

[Bears]: And I think what is being proposed or was proposed with having a single district first past the post war districts might lead that direction here in the city as well.

[Bears]: I have always been a strong supporter of more localized representation.

[Bears]: I just think that there are different ways to have ward representation, different ways to have district representation than just saying our only options are all at large or all ward or a hybrid where you have only at large and only ward systems.

[Bears]: So I think the charter study committee's proposal for the school committee and the reason that I went in that direction

[Bears]: with my proposal is that it was already in the draft.

[Bears]: I'd love to have a bigger conversation about more unique and interesting opportunities and options like proportional representation or ranked choice voting or multi-member districts, but those weren't surveyed, those weren't discussed, those weren't put forward as options.

[Bears]: I went into the product, the work product of the charter study committee itself and found something that I think met the goal of having more localized representation while also maintaining some of the benefits of the at-large system and while avoiding some of the downsides of having so many of the council seats filled by first past the post single member districts.

[Bears]: And that's why I proposed what I proposed.

[Bears]: I mentioned a few different items here in my initial memorandum representation.

[Bears]: This does bring us to local representation very much so compared to the existing approach of all at large council.

[Bears]: accessibility-wise, it would be, I think, easier for voters to understand having a district Councilor, a district school committee member, and then the at-large members.

[Bears]: They'd have less voters to, you know, less officials to keep track of, in some senses, or not exactly knowing which side of which street they lived on means that this is their Councilor versus that Councilor.

[Bears]: Certainly from an efficiency perspective,

[Bears]: there wouldn't be a need for more Councilors, chamber renovations, the meetings being longer because more Councilors are talking.

[Bears]: I'm less married to those arguments, although I think they are just facts.

[Bears]: And that is to say that I'm not opposed to a larger council.

[Bears]: I just don't think that a larger council should be made up of first-past-the-post single-member districts.

[Bears]: And some of the great discussion that has happened since I put these out and discussions that I had with lots of folks over the past two, three years, I want to note as well, from a representation perspective,

[Bears]: you would have under the ward system of having eight wards versus four districts, significantly different weighting of individuals votes.

[Bears]: If you're a voter in ward two or ward three, where you have very, very high turnout, your vote would be much less valuable to the selection of a Councilor than a vote in ward one.

[Bears]: And I think that's an issue.

[Bears]: I think the district moving to the district model mediates that somewhat.

[Bears]: You'd also, from a representation perspective, if you look at, for example, racial demographics, there's essentially no difference in racial demographics between the Ward 6 seat and Ward 8 seats being separate and them being combined.

[Bears]: There's somewhat of a difference in the Ward 7 seat versus combining the Wards 1 and 7 seats, but it's, I think, less than five points or maybe less than 10 points of a difference.

[Bears]: And then I have talked to councillors as Councilor Scarpelli did in neighboring communities and other communities around the state that have a hybrid ward council representation.

[Bears]: And there is a concern about competitiveness of running.

[Bears]: You have a lot of uncontested elections for ward seats and

[Bears]: I think again, that's one of the main concerns in general with first past the post single member districts is essentially you have two people running against each other.

[Bears]: And, um, sometimes no one will run for that seat at all.

[Bears]: And you'll have an uncontested race right now in Medford.

[Bears]: I can't even remember the last time there was an uncontested race for city council, because I'm pretty sure all the elections in the past 20 years, there's been more than seven people running.

[Bears]: Um,

[Bears]: I've also heard some concerns about similar to what Councilor Scarpelli raised earlier that I think he, you know, he said those were his concerns before and he feels more alleviated by them from his discussions, but around prioritizing what's happening in one eighth of the city versus the whole city.

[Bears]: And I've heard that as well as a concern from people who serve on bodies that have this type of representation.

[Bears]: So I believe that this proposal that I put forward moves us significantly towards local representation of neighborhoods of the city without going down to such a small district and maintaining more of a balance between at large

[Bears]: and local representation.

[Bears]: So that's why I put this forward.

[Bears]: I'm really interested to hear the thoughts of my colleagues.

[Bears]: Certainly I'm happy to entertain amendments.

[Bears]: And I would say that the, you know, the piece of this that I'm least concerned about is a bigger council.

[Bears]: I'm not against a bigger council.

[Bears]: I just am against a bigger council being formed exactly in this manner.

[Bears]: So I hope that we can have a discussion

[Bears]: of a model that fits the goals that all of us are seeking and fits, quite frankly, the way that most legislative bodies are elected in most of the world and most of the country, which is not through most of them being elected in first-past-the-post single-member districts.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, and I appreciate that information as well.

[Bears]: It's good to see, and two of the examples I saw in there were Revere and Weymouth, and you had a much more balanced distribution of at-large and district Councilors.

[Bears]: Weymouth, I saw in there six, I believe six district five at-large, or maybe it was six at-large, five district, but again, right.

[Bears]: And again, district, not ward.

[Bears]: I want to make a point that this is local representation, the proposal that I put forward.

[Bears]: We had a survey that went out that asked about one way that that could look, and people said we'd like a hybrid between local representation and an at-large.

[Bears]: We didn't ask about a number of other ways that that could have been formulated, and we don't know what the survey would have said.

[Bears]: other than to say that the survey said they want a hybrid of more local representation and at large representation.

[Bears]: People did not want to stay at all at large, by and large, although I think some percentage did.

[Bears]: People did not want all local representation.

[Bears]: They wanted some form in the middle.

[Bears]: And this proposal maintains that.

[Bears]: I think it, I've seen a bunch of people who are very anti our revolution, Medford, who say we should stay at all at large.

[Bears]: You know, I've seen a number of people who feel differently about that from different political persuasions.

[Bears]: I don't think this is about politics in the most base sense.

[Bears]: I think people have a lot of different opinions about how this should look.

[Bears]: But again, my principle that I have said since I started running, a principle of the Our Revolution Mentored Platform was more local representation and not just having at large representation.

[Bears]: And I stand fully with that.

[Bears]: And again, another one was about more diversity.

[Bears]: The demographics difference between the ward, going to all eight and doing four districts was not really statistically significant demographic difference in that makeup.

[Bears]: The idea of a five at large four district,

[Bears]: fine with that, too, if making the priority being a larger council, which I know the Charter Study Committee noted, and Chair McDonald has noted online, that having a larger council would make more sense in terms of our comparable communities in Massachusetts.

[Bears]: I'm not against that.

[Bears]: I just proposed what was proposed for the school committee in the Charter Study Committee's recommendation.

[Bears]: And my main concern remains having more of a balance than three to eight of essentially a giant multi-member district for three councilors, which is a more fair way of electing people, and eight single district first past the post elections, which may in fact countervail our priorities for more diversity and more representation if we end up with

[Bears]: people incumbents winning those elections and sitting in those seats for 20 years unchallenged because that happens a lot in communities that have a lot of small districts.

[Bears]: And again, I just want to note the other point that I made earlier.

[Bears]: If we have a bunch of small districts, given the traditional turnout in this community, we're devaluing certain votes and highly more valuing other votes in the city.

[Bears]: And I think the district model proposed, whether it's three at large and four district or five at large and four district, it's a better balance between the two.

[Bears]: It avoids some of the pitfalls of having votes weighted so differently against each other.

[Bears]: And I just think it would serve the community better.

[Bears]: That's why I propose this.

[Bears]: It's my basic principle of why I propose literally everything I ever do here.

[Bears]: So to anyone who may question that for whatever purpose, you're wrong.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: I just want to be very clear.

[Bears]: I'm not worried about the politics or the elections of any of these models.

[Bears]: And I'm quite frankly, really sick of the politicization and the putting words in people's mouth that happens on this council by my colleague.

[Bears]: I mean, we're having a discussion about what is a model that would work best for the community?

[Bears]: What do we think gets us the best long-term outcomes in terms of good governance for this community?

[Bears]: It's not about winning an election.

[Bears]: Who's gonna win this election?

[Bears]: Who's gonna win that election?

[Bears]: It's not about saying that Matt thinks some words don't matter when he never said that.

[Bears]: It's not about, you know, you're quoting a platform I helped to write.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: And you're not quoting it in good faith.

[Bears]: It says, I understand what's under you.

[Bears]: I've read it.

[Bears]: I wrote it.

[Bears]: I helped to write it.

[Bears]: And thank you.

[Bears]: And it said, this is a version of word representation.

[Bears]: It's a version of word representation that will be the school committee will have.

[Bears]: That's what I'm proposing.

[Bears]: And I laugh when I laugh because the absurdity of completely misreading and misstating what I've said and what other Councilors have said and what has been written down is just beyond the pale of having a respectful dialogue in this body.

[Bears]: I support a new charter.

[Bears]: If this discussion goes the way it seems like it's going, I support a new charter, but the way that it had to get here and the fact that

[Bears]: the things that had to be brought up to try to spin it and tweak it and turn it in that way is just so beyond disappointing and beyond frustrating.

[Bears]: Because again, the data, who cares, right?

[Bears]: We said, who cares about data?

[Bears]: I care about data.

[Bears]: and the data shows that we would be on the very small end, not just of Massachusetts, but of the country in terms of if we go to word-based representation, Councilors per population.

[Bears]: I think that's an important data point.

[Bears]: I think the data point that's been raised about the fact that it, whether it's district or ward, doesn't affect the racial demographics of the districts, but does affect the fact that you might end up with

[Bears]: uh, you know, long term incumbencies in very small districts or some people winning award seat with 2500 votes and some people winning award seat with 750 votes and then saying, so does that mean that some voters matter less than some voters matter more?

[Bears]: That's just a data point.

[Bears]: I'm very confident in the ability of everyone here to win elections because we've done it many times.

[Bears]: I think we could have

[Bears]: and all at large model and win elections and all ward model and win elections.

[Bears]: But I just can't stand when the words are being put in our mouth.

[Bears]: So it's just really frustrating.

[Bears]: Another thing that we talked about was, do we want to fix what's been wrong or do we want to make things better?

[Bears]: I don't want to make things worse.

[Bears]: And the reason that I put this forward is that I in good faith think that there's a way that the way that this is written out makes things worse.

[Bears]: I would support a 15-person city council with seven at-large and eight wards.

[Bears]: That's ward representation and an even number of at-large seats.

[Bears]: My biggest concern is having a ward-based representation of all eight wards as individual wards with only three at-large city councilors brings in some of the worst practices of elected government in this country and in the state and ruins and takes out some of the best.

[Bears]: That's my issue.

[Bears]: I think more balance between those two things is a good thing.

[Bears]: I don't think at this point that this is going to be well considered, but I'd be willing to do another survey with a few more models and see what people actually support.

[Bears]: Cause I don't think we really know.

[Bears]: And I don't think we've had a conversation about all of the costs and benefits of making these choices.

[Bears]: That's why I put forward what I put forward for no other reason.

[Bears]: And I really, really resent

[Bears]: the implication to the contrary.

[Bears]: And I think quite frankly, that bringing all of the politics into this is what poisoned it and will poison it in either direction.

[Bears]: So I really hope that that's something we can get away from on this council as it continues under this form or any other form, because

[Bears]: This is a good faith conversation based on data and principles.

[Bears]: And when we bring in all this other stuff that nobody brought up except to malign their colleagues, it just leaves a horrible taste in my mouth.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

[Bears]: No one is asking my colleague to apologize for what he believes or for his position on this.

[Bears]: Specific things were said that were then mischaracterized to make a point.

[Bears]: and I don't take your words and then say, oh, you actually said this other thing that you didn't say.

[Bears]: That's the only thing that frustrates me here.

[Bears]: That's why, I mean, I didn't say that.

[Bears]: It's not about anything like that.

[Bears]: I don't think you should believe what you should believe or be able to say, Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: But I do think that saying that another member of this council said that some words don't matter when he didn't say that is just beyond the pale.

[Bears]: I also want to say that we have a statutory role in this process as members of the city council.

[Bears]: There were many times I can think of many votes and I appreciate that councilor Scarpelli's mind has changed on this matter.

[Bears]: where a lot of people came up to this podium and said, we think this is what's best for the community to have a charter change.

[Bears]: We need a charter review process.

[Bears]: We need this council to pass a home rule petition so that we can elect a charter commission and do a charter change.

[Bears]: And all of those voices didn't change that mind of that council or other Councilors who voted against it for multiple terms.

[Bears]: I also want to say that

[Bears]: You've heard of multiple differing opinions from the six people who supposedly all believe the same thing tonight.

[Bears]: We don't obviously believe the same thing.

[Bears]: We've all said, we believe in different pieces of this.

[Bears]: So that's what I'm talking about.

[Bears]: I'm not talking about, I'm sorry for bringing politics into politics.

[Bears]: Of course this is politics.

[Bears]: I'm talking about misrepresenting the information and the facts on the matter and the things that people say to score political points, to try to make something seem like what it isn't.

[Bears]: because that may serve some sort of purpose, or it may advantage your position, or maybe you'll end up getting the result that you want.

[Bears]: It's not something that I do.

[Bears]: We can go back and look at the tape.

[Bears]: I'm very, very, very consistent in saying that I do, I say what I think should happen, and I try to represent those values and those principles based on the facts and the information that I have at hand.

[Bears]: I did want to ask the Collins Center a question about what

[Bears]: it looks like in terms of the competitiveness of elections in districts where you have, in cities or other communities in Massachusetts where you have systems like this.

[Bears]: Do you see that having, or do you have any data to talk about what it looks like, how many races go uncontested in ward seats versus an all-at-large model?

[Bears]: how long incumbent terms are in models like this versus models where there's more competitive elections.

[Bears]: Do you have that data available to you?

[Bears]: And also, if members of the Charter Study Committee would like to talk about discussions that may have happened in the Charter Study Committee around what this model would mean for competitive elections, incumbency, et cetera.

[Bears]: Sorry.

[Bears]: So competitiveness of the different models wasn't considered as part of the discussion.

[Bears]: I'd be happy to hear personal experience.

[Bears]: So about half the time.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: And again, I talked to my colleagues in Somerville.

[Bears]: I talked to my colleagues in Malden.

[Bears]: I talked to my colleagues in Everett.

[Bears]: And were you in a ward-based seat?

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: A lot of ward-based seats go uncontested.

[Bears]: Under the current model of the city council, no one ever goes uncontested.

[Bears]: Those are the facts.

[Bears]: And I'm not saying let's stay at all at large.

[Bears]: The people don't want that.

[Bears]: But I'm hearing that we don't have data on competitiveness.

[Bears]: We didn't discuss competitiveness.

[Bears]: And I think having competitive elections where the people in office are challenged to maintain their seats.

[Bears]: is essential and that we should have a form and a structure of democracy that encourages that.

[Bears]: And I think that if we're going to move in a direction where there's going to be potentially more uncompetitive elections, that we need a balance there.

[Bears]: And I think saying that we're going to have a model where eight of the seats may often be uncontested or at least uncontested half the time, and only three of the seats would be contested more regularly is not a good balance for the competitiveness of elections.

[Bears]: And those are the questions that I would like to see

[Bears]: looked at more or for us to have a discussion here about looking at a model that has a little more balance considering that we didn't consider those questions and we don't have the answers in front of us.

[Bears]: I wanna be challenged, run against me.

[Bears]: I don't think this is a model that encourages that.

[Bears]: That's why I put this forward.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: First, I just wanted to state that some of the concerns that

[Bears]: former member Van der Kloot raised are exactly the reasons that I have concerns about the model.

[Bears]: But I have just two questions for you, Chair McDonald, if I may.

[Bears]: In your research from past elections, did you find any council election that went uncontested?

[Bears]: Thanks.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: And, you know, just given the discussion that we've had tonight and given the discussions that I've been having, would you or leadership of the Charter Study Committee or in partnership with us and the mayor

[Bears]: be willing to survey specific options for hybrid representation at this point so that we could determine more specifically what the intent of the people who was surveyed with about the different options that have been proposed?

[Bears]: If we were to move in that direction, would you be open to being consulted in the process?

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: I just think we actually mostly agree on this.

[Bears]: We all agree on a hybrid model of some at large and some local representation, and I think we've spent

[Bears]: 90 minutes plus, two hours, and maybe even longer than that, arguing about the specifics of it.

[Bears]: And we don't actually have a lot of data beyond the fact that people want a hybrid form of government.

[Bears]: And it might behoove us to try to do a scientific poll to actually askgive people specific options about what that could look like.

[Bears]: Not proportional, not rank choice, none of that.

[Bears]: Like the district versus board.

[Bears]: I want to consult on what we would specifically ask.

[Bears]: But it just seems to me that we basically all agree that there should be

[Bears]: a hybrid model where there's some level of local representation and some level of at-large representation, but that beyond that specific question, the residents weren't asked about different models that that could look like.

[Bears]: And to be frank, and I understand that some people disagree with this, the Charter Study Committee chose two different options for the two different legislative bodies of the city.

[Bears]: And so

[Bears]: I understand why you felt, why this committee's recommendations felt that they could be considered differently.

[Bears]: I just think that the reason that I put forward what I proposed is because I saw what you guys wrote for that school committee.

[Bears]: I mean, there's a bunch of different configurations across a bunch of different cities.

[Bears]: Right.

[Bears]: I'm not suggesting it's unheard of.

[Bears]: I'm just suggesting thatI'll leave it at that.

[Bears]: I think we could get more information about the specifics and ask the voters, because I

[Bears]: I just think there are some pitfalls that have been for the school committee correctly identified in the formation of the composition of the school committee that I'm very concerned would be very similar for the council if composed differently.

[Bears]: And I think it's worth trying to have a deeper answer to that question.

[Bears]: So I might propose that.

[Bears]: path forward, but.

[Bears]: Absolutely.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Just to follow up on that, would you consider if we were to adopt the three at large for district or five at large for district for the council for that to be unusual for the legislature to see?

[Bears]: Oh yeah, multi-member district or proportional representation.

[Bears]: Yeah, I don't think we're considering that at this point.

[Bears]: Did that amendment also then go to a referendum?

[Bears]: To that end, I'd like to further amend my motion, which has been amended by Councilor Collins, to refer these recommendations to a final committee of the whole meeting to consider all of the proposed recommendations of this committee after the three meetings of the Governance Committee.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: So, do we have a second on?

[Bears]: I'm just amending my initial motion.

[Bears]: I don't know if there's a second on my initial motion but my initial motion was to make this proposed change and then Councilor Collins amended that to be five at large and four from districts instead of the original proposal and then my final is that this this along with everything else that this committee recommends go to committee the whole for final consideration.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: I got you.

[Bears]: To further clarify that we hold a committee of the whole to consider all of the recommendations voted on in this committee.

[Bears]: So we voted on some recommendations, amendments earlier in the meeting, the smaller ones to the different sections.

[Bears]: essentially that we, once we've gone through these three meetings where we split it up, we have a meeting where we review the amended red line draft based on the votes of this committee.

[Bears]: So, basically what I'm just saying is that I think at least as I was understood in this process, up until this point, the recommendations of this committee would have gone directly to the regular meeting.

[Bears]: I think it makes sense to have a committee of the whole prior to a final vote of the regular meeting so that we can hear from our two colleagues not on the committee in a committee meeting dedicated solely to this topic.

[Bears]: And then the regular meeting vote would be based on something that the whole council had reported out of committee.

[Bears]: Yes, in that committee of the whole that we take all of the motions from this committee and create a red line draft and then we can consider that in committee of the whole before it goes to a regular meeting.

[Bears]: just to outline the schedule we're scheduled again to meet on February 4th and then February 19th this would have essentially the only difference here would be considering this on February 25th or March 11th at our regular meeting

[Bears]: we would need to consider it on the 11th if we tried to schedule a committee of the whole in advance.

[Bears]: So it would be a two weeks of additional consideration.

[Bears]: And that does assume that we get through everything in the three governance committee meetings and we don't have to move to the governance committee scheduled for March 4th, which would have put us at March 11th anyway, which is ahead of our goal of getting this done by the end of March.

[Bears]: I guess just to the call-in center representatives in terms of moving this through legislatively, is there a material difference of us reporting this to the mayor and the mayor submitting this to the council in early March versus late March in terms of the legislature getting this done in time for us to?

[Bears]: Yes.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: So we need to try to get this to them in early March then as we originally planned.

[Bears]: Great.

[Bears]: Whereas we have received multiple phone calls and emails with the misunderstanding and confusion and fear of tax increases in their recent tax bill.

[Bears]: we do have reports and there have been communications that we've received and that are available to the public from the parking task force that reviewed the parking policies and established the G zone pilot, which then the parking department, I believe moved from pilot to permanent.

[Bears]: And that, you know, there were fees in the city that haven't been updated in 45, 50 years.

[Bears]: And I think to me, it is important for the city to maintain with the times

[Bears]: fees.

[Bears]: Also, on the flip side, we haven't done linkage fees in 40 years, right?

[Bears]: So it's really a symptom of a larger problem where the city was not keeping track of its different user fees, different programs for a very long time.

[Bears]: And now, yes, we see an increase that's coming in.

[Bears]: But that's because the task force said, hey, we haven't done this in 50 years.

[Bears]: And we're out of scope with comparable communities in a lot of these things.

[Bears]: I'm not saying they got everything right.

[Bears]: I'm not saying there's not stuff that's open for discussion, but that's just something that I think is valuable.

[Bears]: And I know that we, I'm hoping we will finally receive the report from all the other departments about their fees that haven't been updated in a long time and how we're going to address that.

[Bears]: I just wanted to note also that while we can have

[Bears]: the parking director and talk about this with the parking department, the traffic commission makes these choices.

[Bears]: We can make recommendations to the traffic commission, but we cannot overrule the traffic commission.

[Bears]: The traffic commission is established by a 1957 special act of the state legislature and is the final decision maker.

[Bears]: I don't know what the policies of our current parking director are.

[Bears]: I know the past parking director said that they do not serve on the traffic commission and they did not want to because they did not feel that they should be making the rules that they enforce.

[Bears]: I don't know if that's a different

[Bears]: viewpoint.

[Bears]: I know that parking traffic and parking directors and other communities do serve on their traffic commissions.

[Bears]: Also, I believe in Somerville a Councilor serves on that commission.

[Bears]: So,

[Bears]: just throwing it out there.

[Bears]: If anyone wants to look up that special act, um, that's what is that almost 70 years since we've updated the structure of the traffic commission.

[Bears]: And I have heard from, you know, members of the public that maybe that's worth taking a look at as well.

[Bears]: Um, so just wanted to put those, that information out there.

[Bears]: I'll go to councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: 25015 resolution to make city council meetings more business friendly, whereas businesses come before the council to request approval for storefronts, and whereas small business storefronts and our quarter squares and business districts foster a sense of community that residents desire.

[Bears]: I'm a little loud here.

[Bears]: allow our residents to shop small and local and bring needed revenue to the city and whereas we want business owners to understand believe Medford is friendly to small businesses be resolved that the city council's regular meeting agendas here the petitions from businesses prior to resolutions made by members of the council be it further resolved that rule 19 be amended as follows.

[Bears]: The following a petition shall be reserved for only matters requiring council action for law including not limited to special permits grants location sign variances and common picture licenses.

[Bears]: only petitions filed meeting this criteria shall be assigned a council paper number such hearings and petitions shall be heard immediately after the reading of council reports and before orders and resolutions and motions sponsored by council members i will entertain this but i want to remind councillors that there isn't the order of business currently does this and the only reason that that isn't happening is because we vote on motions to suspend the order of business and that even if we update the rules a majority vote of this body

[Bears]: can suspend the regular order of business and move us beyond this.

[Bears]: So I don't personally believe that a rule change is necessary.

[Bears]: With that, I don't believe this is out of order, but I just don't believe that any rule change would change the practice and that that is on us as individuals acting collectively to change the practice and just make sure that we do not suspend the rules before taking these.

[Bears]: I will go to Councilor Lazzaro and then Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Sorry.

[Bears]: Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: One second.

[Bears]: There you go.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Just a note, Rule 12 is the order of business.

[Bears]: It's the roll call, salute the flag, and then there is announcements, accolades, remembrances, reports and records, and this is intended to serve as a consent agenda analog.

[Bears]: Refer to committee for further discussion is in there.

[Bears]: because we shouldn't talk about it when it's in that section.

[Bears]: So if people do submit something for that section, it's about sending that to the committee for the discussion.

[Bears]: So if folks want to discuss it in the regular meeting, they should be clear that should go in motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Bears]: And then we can still refer it out, but the intent of that was to clarify when we're having a debate on something significant versus when we are trying to say, we just want to introduce a topic because we can't talk in committee.

[Bears]: if a paper is not first introduced in the council, but we want to reserve that discussion for committee.

[Bears]: So again, it is more about councilor intent and behavior than it is about the order of business.

[Bears]: And then following that consent agenda, we have hearings, presentations of petitions and similar papers, then motions, orders and resolutions, then communications and reports from the mayor, city officers and employees.

[Bears]: Um, so if we, uh, you know, if we were to just follow that, um, and the intent behind the agenda and the rules, we would, we would avoid these situations.

[Bears]: Councilor Scarpelli.

[Bears]: Thank you.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: And I think, you know, the intent here is I'm interpreting it and I'll let everybody who wants to speak interpret it as well as.

[Bears]: let's get the things we know we're all gonna agree on out of the way before we start talking about the things we're not gonna agree on.

[Bears]: And that was the intent of forming the consent agenda in the first place in 2022.

[Bears]: We don't call it that, but it's that first section announcements, accolades, remembrances, reports, and records.

[Bears]: Those would be mixed in with motions, orders, and resolutions.

[Bears]: You'd have reports and records at the end of the meeting rather than at the beginning of the meeting.

[Bears]: So you have these things that were non,

[Bears]: essentially non-controversial that were pro forma, just actions that the council needs to take.

[Bears]: I mean, we added to that in January of last year, this refer to committee for further discussion, because we had some questions about, are we taking a final action on something?

[Bears]: And no, the answer is we're just trying to start the process, the legislative process.

[Bears]: So I think I'm interested to hear what you have, Councilor Scarpelli, as the Subcommittee on Licensing, Permitting, and Signs Chair.

[Bears]: And I know that in Somerville and some other communities they will have, and I think we're moving in this direction on some things where they do a lot of work in the committee, and then it comes to the regular meeting and it is just kind of signed off on by the larger group and.

[Bears]: And then the petitioner doesn't have to be here necessarily.

[Bears]: They've been heard, questions have been asked by that subcommittee or committee.

[Bears]: And we also could potentially look at, I think, a revision to the order of business to look at moving petitions that have come out of that subcommittee to the more consent agenda could be something that we look at too, even though they are pretty early on.

[Bears]: I appreciate the intent of my fellow Councilors and Councilor Scarpelli on this matter and Councilor Leming and Lazzaro and I will go to Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Sounds like we might have a rule amendment.

[Bears]: So that would be the governance committee.

[Bears]: I'll go to Councilor Callahan, and then Councilor Lazzaro.

[Bears]: I will say I am urging that.

[Bears]: I do personally feel that's probably more the role of the chair than the rules, but that's just my opinion.

[Bears]: Councilor Lazzaro and then Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Lazzaro, Councilor Leming.

[Bears]: The motion to refer this paper to the governance committee, seconded by Councilor Callahan.

[Bears]: We'll go to public participation.

[Bears]: We'll start at the podium, name and address for the record.

[Bears]: And you have three minutes.

[Bears]: Thank you for your comment.

[Bears]: We'll go to Zoom, back to Paige Lieberman.

[Bears]: Name and address for the record.

[Bears]: You have three minutes.

[Bears]: Thank you for your comment.

[Bears]: On the motion to refer to Governance Committee by Councilor Leming seconded by Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: All those in favor?

[Bears]: Opposed?

[Bears]: The motion passes.

[Bears]: 2 5017 review of a meeting law complaint of a meeting law complaint.

[Bears]: Acknowledged receipt of open meeting law complaint from Laura Ortiz against the City Council.

[Bears]: Did it January 11th

[Bears]: 2025 acknowledge and review complaint and discuss response.

[Bears]: Votes may be taken.

[Bears]: We do have the open meeting law complaint form here.

[Bears]: This is from Laura Ortiz of Lowell, Massachusetts, who has made an open meeting law complaint that is in very, very small text, and I will not be reading the whole thing, but it is essentially an argument that the council has violated the open meeting law by independently councilor signing onto a letter.

[Bears]: There is

[Bears]: I've been working with council and there is a response drafted.

[Bears]: This is to the Open Meeting Division at the Office of the Attorney General.

[Bears]: It says, just because it's long, I will sit down to make sure I can read the whole thing on my computer.

[Bears]: This firm represents the this is from Janelle Austin KP law.

[Bears]: It says this firm represents the city of Medford the city council, and the receipt of an open law complaint filed by Miss Laura Ortiz dated January 11 2025 which was received by the council that same day.

[Bears]: The complaint alleges that the council violated open meeting while when five members of the council individually signed a digitally circulated letter.

[Bears]: concerning recent changes to Massachusetts law.

[Bears]: This is essentially the summary on January 20, 2025.

[Bears]: That's this meeting, the city council met at a properly posted meeting and open session, which we're doing right now to discuss the complaint.

[Bears]: The council has carefully reviewed the allegations contained in the complaint following such discussion has authorized this response on its behalf in accordance with general law chapter 30 a section 23.

[Bears]: and 940 of the Massachusetts regulations subsection 29.05 subsection five, which is based on the information provided.

[Bears]: The complaint alleges that a quorum deliberated outside of a properly posted meeting as set forth.

[Bears]: However, the council respectfully submits that no openly meeting law violation has occurred.

[Bears]: specifically while five individual members of the council did voluntarily and separately sign on to the letter in question individually.

[Bears]: No deliberation occurred among or between the councillors whatsoever regarding this matter.

[Bears]: Specifically, the five individual members of the council who signed on to the letter did so as individuals completely independently from one another in response to a mass circulated correspondence among public officials across the Commonwealth.

[Bears]: There was no discussion, coordination, or communications regarding signing this letter between or among a quorum of the council at any time.

[Bears]: As a result, the council respectfully submits that no open meeting law violation occurred.

[Bears]: All right.

[Bears]: There's more in the letter, but it's just a recitation of further facts and documentation outlining that summary.

[Bears]: Is there any discussion by members of the council on this matter?

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: The vote would be to acknowledge and review the complaint and accept the response as drafted by Council.

[Bears]: On the motion of Vice President Collins, seconded by Councilor Leming, is there any further discussion?

[Bears]: Seeing none, is there anyone in the chamber on Zoom who would like to speak to the matter?

[Bears]: Vice President Collins.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Collins, and I would note that

[Bears]: We did receive communication that the person who filed this as a serial filer of complaints against officials across the Commonwealth.

[Bears]: And it's just does this all the time and most very often they're frivolous and the determination is that no violation was held.

[Bears]: Councilor Tseng.

[Bears]: I'm just impressed that you can read the text that small.

[Bears]: Yeah.

[Bears]: That was my joke.

[Bears]: I was making that joke.

[Bears]: Please let me make my jokes.

[Bears]: Thank you, Councilor Tseng and I appreciate that.

[Bears]: On the motion of Vice President Collins is seconded by Councilor Leming to acknowledge the complaint and to adopt the response as drafted by council.

[Bears]: Mr. Clerk, please call the roll.

[Bears]: Yes, having affirmative, none negative, the motion passes.

[Bears]: Requesting the appropriation of $85,000 to the Department of Public Works Segmentary Division for design phase two of the Oak Grove Cemetery Historic Buildings Restoration Project.

[Bears]: request the appropriation of $250,000 to the Affordable Housing Trust as initial funding to conduct affordable housing tasks and requesting the appropriation of $98,285 from the CPA Open Space Reserve to the Recreation Department to complete the Condon Shell Field Lighting Project.

[Bears]: The project will be tracked in the Community Preservation Fund, the recommendation letters are attached and incorporated, and we have manager DuPont and chairperson Cameron in attendance as needed.

[Bears]: All right, a capital stabilization fund rescission and appropriation request from the mayor dear President Bears members of the council I respect the request and recommend that your honor body rescind the capital stabilization fund appropriation, and the amount of 322,500 for the window restoration in the chambers.

[Bears]: That was approved November 12.

[Bears]: None of the appropriated funds have been spent yet, and a request to appropriate the CPA funds has been submitted, and we just approved it.

[Bears]: And this was, I think, as we discussed last week, the CPA funds were a better use than the stabilization funds because of the restricted purposes of CPA funds versus the general purposes of the stabilization fund.

[Bears]: And that Manager DuPont and Director Riggi indicated there'd be potentially a one week delay in the procurement process.

[Bears]: So it's not super significant in terms of the timeline.

[Bears]: The second request is to appropriate $197,012.95 for facilities which include the following projects.

[Bears]: window dressings in the City Hall chambers, emergency boiler repairs in City Hall, flooring replacement in the Veterans Office and Elections Office, City Hall lock changes, replacement of backflow preventers at Engine 3, Fire Engine 3, new shades and blinds, Fire Station Engine 3, bathroom renovations and adjacent repairs at Engine 4,

[Bears]: window trims at Engine 4 and window trims at Engine 6.

[Bears]: The total is $197,012.95.

[Bears]: With the rescission, any appropriation requires two-thirds majority vote, and with the rescission and the appropriation, the balance of the capital stabilization fund would actually increase from $3,405,000 to $3,530,481.

[Bears]: That is the proposal before us.
